She said she'd never heard of Poindexter, did hear about Oliver North's trial but didn't know the outcome. _Angela Jones, 26, a nursing assistant at Children's Hospital in Washington. She heard that the Poindexter trial was coming up, but didn't know what the former national security adviser was accused of. ``Basically, I flip'' to other channels when the news comes on, she said. _Barbara Myers Destry, 29, a nursing assistant who takes care of the elderly at a nursing home, works eight to 16 hours a day and says she has no time for television. She hadn't heard about Poindexter and when asked about whether she had heard of Oliver North, said, ``Not really.'' High school education. Married nine years. _Hattie Lake, 62, retired, widowed and with two grown children, said she had ``heard a little'' about former President Reagan giving videotaped testimony for Poindexter's trial, but didn't pay much attention because ``it really just didn't concern me.'' _Gloria May Salmon, 45, a bridal consultant at a downtown department store, grew up in Kingston, Jamaica. She has a son who is a Marine. She said she could recall only that Poindexter ``was Mr. North's boss'' but had heard that Reagan had refused to turn over his diaries to Poindexter and that ``a video was offered instead.'' _Marilyn Patricia Bonner, 45, a secretary at postal service headquarters for the past 21 years, said she had heard that North ``got rid of some papers'' and ``was supposed to be doing some community service'' work. Asked about Poindexter, she said she had ``just heard the name.'' _Johnny Sylvester Blakeney Jr., 49, a senior administration specialist with International Business Machines' learning center in Arlington, Va., and a Vietnam veteran. Said he recognized the name of the computer system on which North and Poindexter communicated and which was vital to prosecutors in assembling criminal cases in the affair. Blakeney had served as a juror previously in a drug trial and a murder trial, with guilty verdicts handed down in both cases. _Gladys C. Montgomery, 46, a claims auditor for Blue Cross-Blue Shield, where she started working in 1969. She has four children and her husband works for the postal service. She said she pays little attention to news because ``it's so depressing'' and that she reads romance novels instead. _Leroy Witherspoon, 44, a distribution clerk for the postal service at Dulles Airport outside Washington. Spent five years in the Army and was a paratrooper in Vietnam. He said ``I hope I would'' rule impartially in the Poindexter case and that ``I hope I could'' treat former President Reagan's videotaped deposition the same as anyone else's testimony. He said that if he had heard Poindexter's name he ``didn't pay much attention.'' _William L. Harris, 42, who does accounting work at the University of the District of Columbia, said North ``helped supply arms and ammunition to help the Contras fight the civil war down in'' Central America and that North ``reported directly to'' Poindexter, whose name Harris had heard ``mentioned once or twice.'' _Anna Christine Thomas, 44, is a budget development specialist at the Department of Public Works in Washington. She has two children in high school. Her husband is a warehouseman. She couldn't recognize Poindexter in the courtroom.

DOC.HEAD: Pollution Bill Advancing in Senate, House Committee
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Senate session resumes 9:15 a.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: The Senate is on the verge of approving stricter air pollution controls for the first time in a decade, while a House committee reports progress in crafting its own version. The Senate planned today to move through a remaining string of amendments under an 8 p.m. EDT deadline for a final vote on the pollution control package. The clean air bill has dominated the Senate's agenda since January. It is the product of three weeks of closed-door negotiations with the White House and then lengthy debate and tradeoffs on the Senate floor and in negotiations among senators. Across the Capitol, the House Energy and Commerce Committee was expected to move a step closer toward approving clean air legislation, with a scheduled vote on a newly reached compromise over regulating toxic air pollutants. The panel's chairman, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., said he hoped the bill would be ready for a final vote in the committee later this week before Congress takes its Easter recess. The measure would go to the House floor in May. Both the Senate and House bills represent the first toughening of federal air pollution controls in 13 years. The federal Clean Air Act, enacted in 1970, was last revised in 1977, although environmentalists and many federal pollution control officials for years have acknowledged serious shortcomings in the law. The bills impose new pollution controls on industry, automobiles and electric power plants and have been estimated to cost the economy $21 billion a year. The compromise reached Monday in the Energy and Commerce Committee by Dingell and other key members of both parties involved a provision that covers releases of toxic chemicals, including cancer-causing substances, from industrial sources. As part of the agreement, the legislation would require more than 90 percent of industrial polluters to install ``maximum available technology'' to control toxic chemicals. The bill originally covered only 50 percent of the polluters, exempting many of the smaller sources. But in return, attempts were abandoned to require a second-stage ``health-based'' standard that has been strongly opposed by industry. That so-called ``residual risk'' provision, which some committee members had wanted, would have required industrial plants to meet minimum cancer risk standards based on exposure to nearby residents no matter what technological controls are being used by the polluter. If the standard could not be met a plant would have to be shut down. The decision was ``not to fight about the (residual risk) issue now as long as we are getting the best reductions (of toxic chemicals) up front,'' said Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., who has pushed for strong toxic control provisions in the bill. ``It's the best we can get right now,'' added Rep. Bill Richardson, D-N.M., who had been preparing an amendment for a health-based requirement. ``I'm willing to forgo residual risk in exchange for tighter, stricter standards up front.'' Under the compromise, the Environmental Protection Agency still would be required to assess in the year 2000 whether additional controls are required and could impose additional standards if there is not an ``ample margin of safety'' from cancer-causing pollutants.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Studies Pesticide Use on Imported Fruits, Vegetables
DOC.TEXT: Some foreign fruit and vegetable producers try to conform with U.S. bans on certain pesticides, but others often are unaware of restrictions, according to a report to Congress. The General Accounting Office said Monday it found that each of five countries checked has laws and regulations controlling pesticide availability and use by their own producers. However, those laws and regulations often don't mesh with U.S. standards. Latin American and Caribbean countries supply most of the fruits and vegetables imported by the United States. In 1988, those totaled 5.5 million metric tons, or 77 percent of total imports. The five countries checked by GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, were Chile, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Guatemala and Mexico, which accounted for more than half the 1988 produce imports. Exporters and producers in some of the countries try to use practices that take U.S. pesticide restrictions into consideration, the report said. The GAO found this to be done by ``multinational firms'' in all five countries and by other growers in Chile and Mexico. ``Where U.S. requirements were not specifically considered in selecting pesticides for use on exports _ particularly among the less experienced growers in Costa Rica, the Dominican Republic and Guatemala _ growers had not developed networks for obtaining information on their export markets' pesticide requirements,'' the report said. The GAO was asked to look into efforts being made by foreign governments and private industries to ensure imported fresh produce meets U.S. safety requirements. The report was requested by Reps. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., and Frank Horton, R-N.Y. Efforts are being made in the current Uruguay Round of trade negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to harmonize food safety and sanitary requirements, including pesticide residue standards. The GAO said the five countries, like the United States, have not designed their food safety and quality systems to meet the import requirements of other countries. However, the report said some of the countries limit the legal availability of pesticides that are also not allowed in the United States and ``help to increase the likelihood that exports to the United States will not contain residues'' of those chemicals. ``For example, the five governments had prohibited or not registered from 81 percent to 94 percent of 52 pesticides whose registration (the Environmental Protection Agency) had canceled or suspended as of Oct. 25, 1988, including 26 whose registrations had been voluntarily canceled by manufacturers,'' the report said. GAO also identified 110 pesticides registered for use in one or more of the five countries that do not have EPA tolerances established for food use in the United States. In some cases, EPA may not have evaluated the pesticides or may have denied a U.S. tolerance or registration. ``Registering pesticides that do not have U.S. registrations or EPA tolerances may be appropriate in a country because of its specific pest problems, crops and climate; because the pesticides are suitable for non-food uses; or because exporters need alternative pesticides to be legally available to meet their export markets' differing requirements,'' the GAO said. Even so, a pesticide permitted in a foreign country could result in that country's produce being refused U.S. entry if residues are detected by the Food and Drug Administration, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Buffalo's Transit Problems Symptomatic of Nationwide Ailments
With PM-Buffalo Transit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When the Buffalo, N.Y., transit system came to a halt, the squeal of its brakes was a familiar sound to public transportation officials in Youngstown, Ohio, and Birmingham, Ala. In 1981, those two cities saw their federally subsidized bus systems fail because they were unable to raise local taxes. The two systems did rise and roll again _ Youngstown got an advance on its state funding to tide it over until the levy passed; Birmingham was revived by a beer tax. So reports of the death of the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority in Buffalo may be premature. Yet transit experts predict that the inherent problem _ a shortage of mass transportation funding at the federal, state and local levels _ will recur. Arlee Reno, transportation director of the Urban Institute, a Washington-based think tank, said Monday it is likely that a solution will be found to Buffalo's problems, but fares may go up while ridership declines. ``It might be a situation where everybody has to compromise more than they want,'' Reno said. Buffalo ``is an example ... of a local community that is hard-pressed to come up with the dollars necessary,'' said Charles Bishop, spokesman for the American Public Transit Association. ``And it may indicate thatnow is not the time to be turning to local governments for more.'' Last month, President Bush and Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner announced a federal transportation policy that continues a decade-long effort to shift to state and local governments the burden of paying for mass transit. But deep federal cuts throughout the 1980s have left mass transit in a state of continuous fiscal crisis, particularly in the Northeast, Reno said. ``In a lot of places, we've seen deterioration of the infrastructure and in some places, instead of that happening, we simply run out of operating money,'' he added. ``That appears to have happened in Buffalo.'' Buffalo's system reached a crisis on Monday because Erie County legislators failed to find a source of transit funding as they agreed to more than two years ago. But the city's problems have been exacerbated by economic difficulties in the region, declining population and the general trend of shrinking ridership for large Eastern cities, Reno noted. The Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority faces a $15.6 million budget gap this year. The deficit is monumental compared with those that temporarily shut down mass transit in Youngstown and Birmingham. The Birmingham bus system closed in March 1981 because of rising costs, declining ridership and a projected deficit of $800,000. At the time, the system served 11,000 riders, making about 30,000 trips a day. But the Alabama Legislature refused to pass an emergency funding measure and the buses stopped running. The system remained shut until June 1981, said Jerome C. Beasley, general manager of the Birmingham-Jefferson Transit Authority. But ``the fight is never over,'' Beasley said. ``Every two or three years we go through these problems.'' Beasley said a bill in the Legislature would provide $5 million for mass transit throughout the state. ``At least that's a foot in the door,'' he said. ``Right now, the state gives no money at all.'' Youngstown was left without bus service in November 1981 when voters rejected a proposed tax that would have raised about $1 million. At the time, the Western Reserve Transit Authority faced a $1.5 million deficit. It served 5,000 daily riders, including 2,900 public school students. The Ohio city got a reprieve when the governor stepped in and advanced the authority its 1982 state funding, said Jim Ferraro, agency executive director. That enabled the bus system to reopen in a month and run until a two-mill property tax assessment was passed, he said. But the assessment has to be periodically reauthorized, and it doesn't always pass on the first try, Ferraro said. In addition, he said, the amount of the assessment has dropped as property values plummeted and its value declined as the cost of living rose.

DOC.HEAD: Students Know Little About History, Civics
DOC.TEXT: A new survey suggests only 38 percent of eighth graders know Congress makes laws, more than half don't know the meaning of separation of powers and barely half know the United States is a representative democracy. Ina V.S. Mullis of the Educational Testing Service outlined those and other examples Monday to show the significant gaps in knowledge American students have in history and civics. Ms. Mullis helped conduct the first surveys of achievement in history and civics at grades four, eight and 12 for the National Assessment of Educational Progress, popularly known as the Nation's Report Card. The key result of the 1988 assessments, which coincided with the bicentennial of the writing of the U.S. Constitution, was that American students have basic facts and skills in history and civics but cannot apply what they've learned to draw conclusions and demonstrate understanding. ``The assessment seems to show a Trivial Pursuit sort of familiarity with some of the key figures and dramatic events of our past, but even on this level the gaps are wide,'' said Richard Riley, former governor of South Carolina and a member of the assessment governing board. Mary Frances Berry, a history professor at the University of Pennsylvania and member of the U.S. Civil Rights Commission, said the assessment ``gives us fresh evidence for despair.'' ``If ... the report is accurate, our high school graduates, on the whole, lack the kind of understanding of the nation's heritage that is necessary to be an informed citizen in a democracy,'' she said. Key findings were: _Most fourth graders knew why Thanksgiving and July 4 are celebrated, but only 36 percent knew why Columbus sailed to America. _More than three-fourths of eighth graders could identify the Rev. Martin Luther King's ``I Have a Dream'' speech, but fewer than half knew he advocated nonviolence. _In both 1986 and 1988, 11th graders correctly answered only 55 percent of history questions. Scores improved, however, on questions about exploration and colonization, and the rise of modern America and World War I. _Nearly one-third of eighth graders and almost half the high school seniors didn't recognize the presidential veto, congressional veto override and Supreme Court decisions as examples of the federal system of checks and balances. The ETS evaluated the history achievement of 16,000 students and the civics achievement of 11,000 other students. The tests were graded on a scale of 0 to 500. Ms. Mullis said there was a vast gap between the performance of students attending schools in rich and poor urban neighborhoods. For example, about two-thirds of the eighth graders performed at or above level 250, which reflected knowledge of a variety of historical figures, events and terms. However, although 80 percent of the eighth graders from higher-income neighborhoods attained that level, fewer than half the disadvantaged eighth graders did.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Of Child Abuse Rise
DOC.TEXT: Reports of child abuse and neglect rose 9 percent last year, the largest increase since 1985, says the National Committee for Prevention of Child Abuse. The survey released Monday found that 2.4 million reports of child abuse and neglect were recorded in 1989 by state child welfare agencies, including at least 1,237 child abuse-abuse related deaths. Ann Cohn, executive director of the abuse prevention committee, said the growing problem of drug and alcohol abuse figures prominently the increase, along with social problems such as poverty and homelessness. But she said some of the increase was due to state changes in the definitions of child abuse and in their reporting systems. The 2.4 million reports last year compared with 2.2 million in 1988. Most of the abuse occurs in the home, according to the survey. The group also concluded, based on a nationwide telephone survey, that fewer parents are disciplining their children with insults, swearing or spankings. The telephone poll of 460 randomly selected parents found that the proportion who said they had not used swearing or insults as discipline in the previous year rose from 45 percent in 1988 to 60 percent this year. It also found that those who said they never spanked or hit their children grew from 36 percent in 1988 to 49 percent this year. The proportion who said they often swore or used insults to discipline their children went from 2 percent in 1988 to 3 percent this year, and the group that said they often hit their children went from 4 percent to 5 percent. The survey, conducted by Schumlan, Ronca and Bucuvalas Inc. of New York, has a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 28,759.72, up 757.65 points, or 2.7 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Economy Shows Signs of Recession
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: There are signs President Fernando Collor de Mello's draconian economic measures are throwing the economy into recession, and Brazilians are desperately trying to weather the storm. Industrial production dropped 20 percent from February to March, private economists say, and the automobile and contruction industries are virtually paralyzed. Unions say 200,000 workers have lost their jobs. ``A recession is now inevitable. What we must avoid is a depression,'' said Rep. Jose Serra of the center-left Brazilian Social Democratic Party. Collor de Mello passed the measures by decree on March 16, the day after he took office as the country's first popularly elected president in 29 years. They became law immediately but can be voted down by Congress within 30 days. Legislators were to begin voting on the plan Monday but failed to obtain a quorum. Congressional leaders said they would try again today. The economic measures, designed to halt record 4,000 annual inflation, includes a 30-day price freeze, a new national currency and drastic government spending cuts. The package also contains an 18-month freeze on assets of more than $1,200 in private savings accounts and $600 in money market funds. The freeze withdrew about $115 billion from circulation, or 80 percent of bank deposits, and led to a brutal drop in consumer spending. Restaurants, movie theaters and shops have seen a radical drop in business. ``I haven't gone out to eat or to a bar since the plan was announced. I've cut out all expenses that aren't absolutely necessary,'' said Saulo de Oliveira, a 36-year-old businessmen. Even Rio's illegal but widely tolerated numbers racket known as the ``Animal Game,'' has reported a drop of 50 percent in receipts. The game, conducted on street corners, is popular among Brazil's working class. While early opinion polls showed as much as 87 percent of the public backed the plan, in recent days grumbling has increased, especially from those who saw their money confiscated. ``For the love of God, liberate my miserable money,'' Brasilia housewife Maria Laila reportedly wrote to Economic Minister Zelia Cardoso de Mello. On the other end of the spectrum, Antonio Ermirio de Moraes, one of Brazil's leading businessmen, saw $500 million caught in the bank freeze. An obviously distraught de Moraes recently told a TV talk show host he had considered leaving the country to start life anew overseas. A joke now making the rounds is that Collor's measures have made businessmen sleep like babies: ``One hour of sleep and two hours of crying, one hour of sleep and two hours of crying...'' Because of the freeze on accounts, businesses are having a hard time paying March salaries. Subsidiaries of some foreign companies such as General Motors and Nestle had to borrow money from banks to pay workers. But many observers say that if companies don't pay their workers soon strikes will break out. ``We'll invade the banks if money (for salaries) is not freed,'' said Vicente Paula da Silva, president of the Sao Paulo Metalworkers Union. ``It won't help because the banks don't have money,'' replied Leo Cochrane Jr., head of the Brazilian Banking Federation. But while much of Brazil struggles to stay afloat, one sector on the upswing is the spiritual. The Folha de Sao Paulo newspaper reported city churches have seen especially heavy traffic the past several weeks. Worshippers have packed the Church of Saint Judas Tadeu _ the patron saint of lost causes. ``Everyone from shantytown residents to big businesmen don't believe in anything anymore and are seeking the protection of the saint,'' Rev. Odilo Hoepers told the newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: HUD Gives Low-Income Tenants Waivers to Permit Census Work
DOC.TEXT: Low-income residents of federally subsidized housing may accept temporary jobs as 1990 census takers without facing possible rent increases because of the additional income. Jack Kemp, secretary of the department of Housing and Urban Development, said Monday he signed a waiver to allow the temporary jobs because it ``will help residents of rent subsidized housing earn extra income and will also help the Census Bureau secure a more accurate account of the number of low-income, rent-subsidized Americans.'' The Census Bureau hires the temporary workers to canvass homes in which residents did not return the 1990 census form received in the mail. The temporary jobs pay up to $8 an hour.
DOC.HEAD: U.S., Japan Reach One-Year Agreement on Drift-Net Fishing
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Japanese negotiators have agreed to triple the number of observers on Japanese drift-net boats and equip all the vessels with monitoring transmitters. However, critics of the one-year agreement announced Monday by the State Department said it would provide observers for only 10 percent of Japan's drift-net vessels and allow the Japanese to continue to fish the cold, salmon-rich waters south of the Aleutian Islands. The pact calls for 98 vessels from Japan's squid and large-mesh drift-net fleets to be monitored in the 1990 fishing season by 47 U.S., 41 Japanese and 10 Canadian observers. Last year, 32 Japanese drift-net vessels were covered by observers. The monitoring transmitters will send signals to satellites, enabling the government to tell when the vessels enter waters where drift-netting is illegal. Critics of drift-netting say the miles-long nets illegally capture North America-spawned salmon and kill thousands of marine birds and mammals.
DOC.HEAD: Ex-Police Chief Running for Mayor's Job
DOC.TEXT: Former District of Columbia Police Chief Maurice T. Turner is running for mayor of the nation's capital _ as a Republican in a city where Democratic voters outnumber Republicans nine-to-one. ``We need leaders who serve for the public good, not personal gratification,'' Turner said Monday in making his formal announcement of candidacy. ``We need leaders who surround themselves with people of integrity, not people who merely want a city contract.'' Turner, a policeman for 32 years and chief for the last eight, said improving the school system and fighting drugs and crime would be the top priorities of his administration. Turner, 54, switched to the Republican Party last July, fueling speculation that he intended to run for mayor. He is the only Republican in the race and is making his first run for public office. The former chief and Mayor Marion Barry clashed publicly over police staffing levels and other matters during Turner's final months in office.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rebound, Dollar Dips
DOC.TEXT: After wild ups and downs, share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange ended sharply higher Tuesday, while the dollar closed lower against the Japanese yen. The bellwether Nikkei Stock Average of 225 issues regained 757.65 points, or 2.7 percent, ending the day at 28,757.65. The index briefly lost more than 200 points during morning trading. The Nikkei had dropped 1,978.38 points, or 6.59 percent, to 28,002.07 on Monday in a plunge second only to the Oct. 20, 1987, drop that followed Wall Street's ``Black Monday'' crash. The dollar closed Tuesday at 158.95, down 1.00 yen from Monday's close. It had opened at 159.10 yen and ranged between 158.80 yen and 159.35 yen. Share prices rose back in the afternoon as market players decided that the market had bottomed out in the morning, when the index fell below the 28,000-point mark, said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. Dealers expect that the index will fall no lower than 27,200 points, 30 percent lower than where it ended trading last year. In currency dealings, the dollar was moving narrowly Tuesday morning following Monday's leap. It closed at 158.65 yen in New York overnight, up from 158.35 yen on Friday. Chizuko Satsukawa, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo, said a majority of currency players were making position adjustments, avoiding major moves due to uncertainties over the stock market. ``Instability in the stock market has made foreign exchange investors feel they are being thrown about,'' she added. Ms. Satsukawa said the yen edged up earlier as investment trust banks bought a substantial amount of dollars, reassured by the initial rise in the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index. A dealer with the Bank of Tokyo said, however, that the market's demand for the dollar remains strong, and participants were inclined to buy the currency whenever it made a downward movement. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said he is very concerned with recent market movements, and that he hopes stability returns to the market soon.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan President Optimistic About Peace in Central America
DOC.TEXT: Outgoing President Daniel Ortega says a two-day summit with four other Central American leaders in this new beach resort will bring good news for regional peace. The top item on the agenda was demobilizing the U.S.-backed Contras, who have waged a 10-year war against Nicaragua's leftist Sandinistas, who were voted out of office in February. As the meeting began Monday, President Rafael Leonardo Callejas of Honduras said the Contra's top military commander had agreed to disband the forces before Nicaragua's new government takes office on April 25. In another development, leftist Salvadoran guerrillas and that country's rightist government agreed to meet Wednesday in Geneva to renew talks under the mediation of U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Ortega said talks at the first session ``were wide-ranging and very good. There was ample discussion about the demobilization of the Contras and the democratization of El Salvador and Guatemala.'' He refused to go into details. ``I believe that tomorrow we will have an excellent declaration to make to the peoples of Central America, who want peace,'' Ortega said. Also at the summit were Presidents Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador, Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala and Oscar Arias of Costa Rica. Arias won the Nobel Peace prize in 1987 for working out the first of a series of Central American peace accords aimed at ending civil wars in the region. He will leave office on May 8, turning over the presidency of Central America's most stable democracy to Rafael Angel Calderon. He was barred by his country's constitution from running for re-election in the February vote. On Monday, Arias mirrored Ortega's enthusiasm: ``I am very optimistic we will have a magnificent declaration to make that will benefit the peoples of the region.'' A point of deadlock has been the demobilization of the Contras inside Nicaragua and in base camps in neighboring Honduras before Ortega turns over power to Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Ortega has indicated reluctance to hand over the military and police while the rebels are still active. In an accord March 23 with representatives of Mrs. Chamorro, a Contra commander agreed to demobilize. But deep divisions remain in the rebel ranks, with many rank-and-file fighters saying they won't lay down their arms soon. But Callejas said top rebel commander Israel Galeano, also known as Commander Franklyn, had assured him the Contras would disband by the time Chamorro is sworn in. There have been doubts about the viability of the March accord because Galeano did not sign it and thousands of Contras have since returned from Honduras to Nicaragua with their guns. A Contra spokesman in Tegucigalpa, the Honduran capital, announced late Monday that the rebels inside Honduras would surrender their weapons April 18 to a U.N. peacekeeping force at the border town of Yamales. Those inside Nicaragua are expected to gather in previously determined ``security zones'' and do the same around that date. In an open letter to the summit, Salvadoran guerrillas proposed a plebiscite on constitutional reform to reduce the armed forces, purge the military of right-wing elements and subject it to civilian authority. The letter proposed the plebiscite be held jointly with the 1991 elections for a new National Assembly. It also proposed the 60-member legislature be expanded and the elections and plebiscite be held without any military presence, and monitored by international observers. The letter said that, if an agreement is reached, the rebels will turn into peaceful political parties. ``The letter has positive aspects that we should take into account. All this will be discussed by our representatives with those of the front in Geneva,'' Cristiani said. The last peace talks on ending El Salvador's decade-old civil war _ which has claimed 72,000 lives _ were suspended in November.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Oh, thanks.'' _ Double murderer Robert Alton Harris, in response to the U.S. Supreme Court's stay of his execution, which would have been California's first in 23 years.

``The situation has caused dissension in our community for too long _ it's time to put it behind us.'' _ Conoco Inc. refinery manager Dennis Parker, after the company agreed to a $23 million buyout of Ponca City, Okla., residents who say the refinery is giving them cancer and other illnesses.

``It is important that the United States continue to call for the resolution of this issue through dialogue, through negotiations in a peaceful manner so that ultimately the people of Lithuania can indeed enjoy genuine independence.'' _ State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler, of the Soviet-Lithuania conflict over the Baltic state's independence.

DOC.HEAD: Barbershop Fire Kills 14, Injures 5
DOC.TEXT: A fire raced through a barbershop in the northern city of Taoyuan early today, killing 14 people and injuring five, police said. Police in Taoyuan, about 30 miles west of Taipei, said the charred bodies of six people were found in the barbershop, which occupied the second and third floors of a seven-story building. Eight more bodies were found in an apartment on the fourth floor. Authorities were attempting to identify the victims. Police said they were investigating the cause of the blaze, which broke out at 6:23 a.m. and was extinguished three hours later.

DOC.HEAD: Two Executed For Selling Panda Skins
DOC.TEXT: Two Sichuan farmers lost court appeals and were executed for selling the skins of giant pandas, a newspaper reported today. Liang Yongzheng and He Guanghai, from Pingwu County in the southwest Chinese province, were sentenced to death in October for dealing in the endangered species. The Legal Daily said the two were executed on Monday after losing appeals in the Sichuan provincial court and the Supreme Court. It said Liang bought a panda skin in January 1987 for 4,500 yuan ($957) and together with an accomplice sold it in Canton for 80,000 yuan ($17,000). He was caught later that year when he bought three more pelts for 7,000 yuan ($1,500) and tried to sell them for 280,000 yuan ($59,600). He Guanghai was involved in similar transactions in southeastern Guangdong province, where Canton is located, and coastal Fujian province. Two of Liang's accomplices were previously sentenced to life in prison. Only about 1,000 giant pandas still survive in the wilds of Sichuan and neighboring Tibet. The Chinese government has forbidden hunting of the species, and Sichuan courts have dealt out harsh punishments to people caught killing or selling the animals. Executions in China are usually carried out with a bullet to the back of the head.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Ryan White, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of 18-year-old Ryan White's battle with AIDS: December 1984 _ White, 13, is diagnosed as having contracted AIDS through a blood-clotting agent used to treat his hemophilia. July 30, 1985 _ Western Schools Corp. Superintendent James O. Smith bars Ryan from school. Smith says the health risk for other children is too great. Aug. 3 _ Ryan and his mother, Jeanne, are present when the State Board of Health announces guidelines for admitting children with AIDS to school. Officials urge Smith to allow Ryan to attend class as long as he's not severely ill. Aug. 8 _ The Whites sue in federal court to get Ryan admitted to school. Aug. 16 _ U.S. District Judge James E. Noland says the court cannot accept the case until Ryan's attorney exhausts all administrative appeals. Aug. 26 _ Classes begin at Western Middle School; Ryan is linked to school by a computer-telephone hookup. Nov. 1 _ The Indiana Department of Education hears testimony from attorneys for White and the school district. Nov. 25 _ Hearing officer Kathleen Madinger Angelone rules Ryan should be allowed to go to school when he is not intensely sick. Dec. 17 _ The Western School Board votes to appeal Angelone's ruling. Feb. 6, 1986 _ The Department of Education's appeals board rules there is nothing to prevent Ryan, now 14, from attending classes if he receives clearance from the Howard County health officer. Feb. 13 _ Dr. Alan Adler, Howard County health officer, certifies Ryan fit to return to school. Feb. 19 _ A Howard County judge turns down a request by parents and students to bar Ryan from school. Feb. 21 _ Ryan attends a half-day of school. A Howard County judge later in the day approves a temporary injunction preventing him from attending school. March 12 _ Ryan's attorney, Charles Vaughan, files a motion for a change of venue for an additional hearing. April 10 _ Clinton County Circuit Judge Jack R. O'Neill lifts the injunction, saying he had no evidence of a threat of irreparable harm to Ryan's classmates. Ryan returns to class later that day. April 30 _ O'Neill dismisses arguments from parents who oppose Ryan's attending school. June 17 _ O'Neill denies a motion by David Rosselot, the parents' attorney, thus blocking the first step in the appeals process. The motion was to correct what Rosselot said were errors in the judge's decision lifting the restraining order. July 18 _ The Indiana Court of Appeals dismisses the parents' appeal of O'Neill's ruling. Rosselot announces the parents are abandoning their five-month legal battle, blaming financial problems. Aug. 25 _ Ryan begins eighth-grade classes at Western High School. Summer 1987 _ Mrs. White moves her family to the small community of Cicero, about 20 miles from their home, saying they didn't want to stay where they were unwanted. In Cicero, they are welcomed by the community and school system. Aug. 31 _ Ryan attends his first day of classes as a freshman at Hamilton Heights High School. No protests are reported. Mrs. White says Ryan has been using the drug AZT for two weeks and is more alert. Sept. 29 _ The Ryan White National Fund, an educational and fund-raising program to fight misconceptions about children carrying the AIDS virus, is announced in West Hollywood, Calif. It is endorsed by pro football players and Hollywood celebrities. March 3, 1988 _ Ryan testifies before the White House AIDS Commission. Ryan says, ``I came face to face with death at 13 years old,'' but decided ``to live a normal life.'' Aug. 18 _ Filming begins in North Carolina of ``The Ryan White Story,'' an ABC TV movie. It airs on Jan. 16, 1989. June 1989 _ White receives a new Ford Mustang as a gift from a mysterious benefactor. Mrs. White says she believes the gift was from Michael Jackson. Dec. 6 _ Mrs. White says surgery to correct a hernia in Ryan has been delayed because of medical problems. She also says he has staph infections and has not attended school much during the semester. Dec. 16, 1989 _ Ryan turns 18 in continued ill health. March 29, 1990 _ Ryan is admitted to Riley Hospital for Children suffering from a respiratory infection. April 2 _ Hospital officials say Ryan is in critical condition on a life-support system.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's, City Argue Over Weight Labeling
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's, which years ago was challenged on the weight of its Quarter-Pounder, is facing a dressing-down for the way it sells salad. The city wants McDonald's to tell customers how much their salads weigh. ``It's as ridiculous as it sounds,'' McDonald's lawyer, Arthur Makadon, said Monday. ``It's a question of bureaucracy taking consumerism way beyond anything that was intended by policy or law.'' This weighty matter has reached the courts as the city tries to enforce Pennsylvania's Weights and Measures Act of 1965. ``The city requires of any food vendor that sells food in a package that it inform the customer what the customer is paying for,'' said Andrew P. Bralow, chief deputy of the city solicitor's enforcement division. That just toasts McDonald's croutons. ``It's in a transparent container _ you see what you're getting,'' Makadon said. But the city thinks this is a good time, great case to prove its point that the containers must be marked by weight. Last week, Common Pleas Judge Nicholas M. D'Alessandro ruled that McDonald's must post the weights on its menu board. McDonald's, refusing to wilt, asked him to reconsider. ``We're saying, first, the law doesn't apply to restaurants,'' Makadon said. ``Secondly, it does not apply where you customarily buy something by count _ one salad or two salads.'' When McDonald's introduced its Quarter-Pounder in the 1970s, someone pointed out that it didn't weigh a quarter pound when served. McDonald's now notes that the burger weighs a quarter pound before cooking. The state has issued similar warnings to McDonald's, Wendy's and Burger King restaurants in Allentown, Bethlehem and Easton. ``We haven't pursued them further until we get a precedent in the Philadelphia case,'' said Fred Yahner, director of the state Weights and Measures Bureau. ``One of the basic rules of weights and measures is that products like these should be sold by weight. We can't make exceptions.''

DOC.HEAD: Chronicle Loses Bid to Block Ad
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled Attorney General John Van de Kamp may use San Francisco Chronicle articles in a TV commercial for his gubernatorial campaign despite the paper's objection that such use implied an endorsement. U.S. District Judge John Vukasin on Monday denied a Chronicle request to bar use of the newspaper's name in the commercial. ``I suspect it (the ad) comes dangerously close to creating a false impression that that is the Chronicle speaking,'' Vukasian said. But he said the Van de Kamp campaign properly identified itself as the sponsor of the commercial and was clearly quoting the Chronicle as a source of information. Neil Shapiro, a lawyer for the Chronicle, said the newspaper still may sue for damages. The ad, first shown two weeks ago, attacks former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein, Van de Kamp's rival for the Democratic nomination, over her management of the city. Each subject is illustrated by a Chronicle clipping about a controversy. The paper's name appears several times at the bottom of the screen. The Chronicle sued last week to stop the use of its name and masthead, saying the ad violated the newspaper's trademark and was meant to mislead. ``If we wish to endorse someone we will, but we don't want somebody stealing the endorsement,'' Shapiro told the judge. Saying some angry readers had telephoned the paper to complain about its apparent endorsement, the lawyer declared that the ad ``confuses people into believing the Chronicle supports, endorses or even prepared'' it. But Kantor said Van de Kamp had an obligation, as well as a constitutional right, to quote the Chronicle as the source of material in his commercial. He also said the ad would be protected by freedom of speech even if it was misleading. Vukasin did not mention constitutional protections in his ruling, saying only the ad properly identified its sponsorship. Mickey Kantor, a lawyer for Van de Kamp, said the commercial's run was due to end Monday.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says American Linked to Coup Plot Was Not Involved
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Embassy said today an American linked in testimony to the December coup attempt works for the U.S. Air Force but denies involvement in the bid to topple President Corazon Aquino. Brig. Gen. Alejandro Galido, who the government says infiltrated the coup plotters' ranks, told investigators that Harold Maglio of Wrightwood City, Calif., offered to sell weapons to Mrs. Aquino's opponents a year ago. Galido says Maglio had identified himself as a U.S. Air Force colonel assigned to the Defense Intelligence Agency. In a statement today, the embassy said Maglio was a civilian quality assurance manager at Norton Air Force Base near San Bernadino, Calif., and that he met with Galido during a private visit here last year. ``Mr. Maglio has never had any connection with the Defense Intelligence Agency, nor was he ever a colonel in the U.S. Air Force,'' the statement said. ``He has no responsibility for policy, intelligence or political matters within the U.S. government and his work does not involve the Philippines,'' the embassy said. After the statement was released, Presidential Press Secretary Tomas Gomez said he would not rule out the possibility that Maglio was an American agent but said he believed the American was ``either a fake or a con man.'' ``I am not discounting that,'' Gomez said. ``But it is easier to believe that he is just a `con man' taking advantage of the situation. We are not giving importance to that issue.'' In its statement, the embassy said U.S. law enforcement agencies investigated Maglio at the request of Filipino authorities and ``there was no indication Mr. Maglio was actively involved in any coup planning or otherwise seeking to destabilize the Philippine government.'' Military Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa told reporters today the government was aware of Maglio's activities. De Villa stood by Galido's statement and said it was up to ``our civilian superiors'' to decide whether to take legal action against Maglio. The government has claimed Galido was a ``deep penetration agent'' who infiltrated ranks of military dissidents who launched a nine-day coup attempt Dec. 1 in which at least 113 people were killed and 600 wounded. In testimony given Jan. 23 and released by the Department of Justice last month, Galido said Maglio offered weapons in return for $20 million. There was no indication the deal was completed. ``We were able to talk with an American introduced to me as Col. Harold Maglio, U.S. Air Force, who claimed to be a member of the United States Defense Intelligence Agency,'' Galido said. Galido quoted Maglio as saying he was the DIA's representative in the Philippines and ``favors the overthrow of the Aquino government.'' According to Galido, Maglio claimed links to U.S. Ambassador Nicholas Platt and offered to telephone the embassy to authenticate his claims. Platt denies knowing Maglio. Galido quoted Maglio as saying ``that their group can promise to deliver to our forces, if we move against the government, shipments of firearms, ammunition, anti-tank missiles, anti-helicopter missiles and other armaments we will need for the government takeover.'' U.S. jets flew air cover for government forces during the coup attempt. Embassy spokeswoman Victoria Middleton said U.S. officials were cooperating with Filipino authorities in the Maglio affair. Galido's testimony has led to charges that Washington secretly supported the December coup attempt and then double-crossed the mutineers to make the government beholden to the Americans. ``The United States government does not support any activity aimed at destabilizing the Philippine government,'' the embassy said. ``Any representation that there is such official support is false.'' Last week, the majority leader of the Philippine Senate, Teofisto Guingona, urged the United States to make a full disclosure about Maglio before talks begin on extending the lease on six U.S. military bases in the Philippines. The lease expires in September 1991, and the talks are expected to begin next month.

DOC.HEAD: Supervisors Fill in as Strike Hits Nation's Largest HMO
DOC.TEXT: Supervisors and outside workers filled in today for 11,000 striking employees at Southern California hospitals and medical offices run by Kaiser Permanente, the nation's No. 1 health maintenance organization. ``There's no large crisis; things have gone pretty much as planned,'' said Jack Davis, director of Kaiser's regional hospital services. The 2-day-old walkout by nurses, technicians and maintenance workers affected seven hospitals and more than 40 offices in Los Angeles and Orange counties. But Kaiser officials said they were prepared for the strike. Supervisors and workers from unaffected Kaiser facilities worked many jobs held by the strikers, several clinics closed, services were cut and about 150 Kaiser patients or more were transferred to other hospitals, the HMO said. Kaiser, a nonprofit medical institute, has more than 2.2 million subscribers in Southern California. They pay a fee for comprehensive care rather than the traditional pay-per-visit system. It is the nation's biggest HMO. More than 100 workers quietly walked the picket lines at Kaiser's Anaheim hospital on Monday. The other affected hospitals are in Los Angeles, West Los Angeles, Panorama City, Woodland Hills, Harbor City and Bellflower. ``Most of us here have ourselves and families to support. It's hard on both sides,'' said Joyce Johnston, a licensed vocational nurse. Workers defied a union negotiating team's recommendation and rejected a contract offer Friday by a 3,067-to-1,474 vote. A six-hour negotiating session with a mediator ended Saturday without agreement, and the strike began Monday. The company offered a 5 percent to 6 percent raise the first year and a 3 percent to 5 percent raise the second and third years. The offer also guarantees wages 3 percent higher than the average at 12 Los Angeles-area hospitals. Top pay for a licensed vocational nurse under the old contract was $13.01 per hour, according to Kaiser. The union refused to outline its demands. ``Management knows what it will take to settle the strike,'' said union Vice President Dave Stilwell. Kaiser employees accepted a wage freeze three years ago, stood by the company during nine years of financial difficulty and deserve more ``now that Kaiser is back on their feet and prospering,'' said union spokesman Tom Ramsay.

DOC.HEAD: UNLV Routs Duke to Capture NCAA Tourney
DOC.TEXT: The University of Nevada-Las Vegas routed Duke University 103-73 to win its first NCAA basketball crown by the biggest margin in a championship game. ``It was one of those games you dream about,'' UNLV coach Jerry Tarkanian said Monday. The Runnin' Rebels became the first team to score more than 100 points in the championship; the first team ranked No. 1 in the preseason to win the title since 1982, and the first Western team to win since UCLA in 1975. The Rebels literally stole the title from Duke, breaking the tournament record for steals in a game with 16. Until Monday, the largest margin of victory in a championship was 23 points, when UCLA beat North Carolina 78-55 in 1968. ``We lost to the best team in the country playing at their best,'' Duke coach Mike Krzyzewski said. Duke has made the NCAA tournament's Final Four eight times without a title. For Tarkanian, getting the trophy capped a 15-year battle with the NCAA, which ordered the school to suspend him for recruiting violations. He went to court for an injunction and the case eventually reached the Supreme Court, which ruled in favor of the NCAA but said only the university could discipline him. ``You can call us bad. You can call us thugs. You can call us hoodlums. But at the end of that, please, call us national champions, too,'' said Larry Johnson, the school's top scorer and rebounder this season.

DOC.HEAD: Reuters Reporters Withhold Bylines
DOC.TEXT: U.S.-based journalists at the news agency Reuters are withholding their bylines from stories to protest management contract proposals. The byline strike begun Monday will last three days, said the Newspaper Guild, which represents about 500 Reuters employees around the country, including 150 journalists. Their contract expired Feb. 28. ``We hope this action will impress management with our anger that a company making so much money wants to severely cut the benefits and pay of those who are crucial to Reuters' success,'' said Barry Lipton, president of the Guild local. Lipton said the company's offer of a 2.5 percent raise would be offset by a proposed weekly increase of work time from 33.75 hours to 37.5 hours, with no overtime until after 40 hours. The company has also proposed having employees pay for part of the cost of health insurance. Reuters, in a statement, cited the rising cost of health care and said the company's benefits ``will remain competitive by all industry standards.''

DOC.HEAD: Guide Says School Hiking Group Should Have Turned Back
DOC.TEXT: A guide who helped lead a deadly climb of Mount Hood said the expedition likely would have ended safely if only it had been abandoned sooner in the face of a gathering storm. Ralph Summers testified Monday in a lawsuit brought by Richard Haeder, whose 16-year-old son was one of nine people to die in a blizzard during the Oregon Episcopal School trek in May 1986. Haeder has sued the Oregon Episcopal School and Summers, a part-time assistant, for at least 860,000 in damages. He alleged negligence in the planning and carrying out of the climb that led to the freezing deaths of seven students and two adults. Summers, 34, said all of the group members probably would have survived had they stopped climbing and turned around at the Hogsback area near the summit of the 11,237-foot peak, the second-most climbed mountain in the world behind Mount Fuji. Instead, the group of climbers continued its efforts to reach the summit in deteriorating weather and by the time it turned around a powerful snowstorm was lashing the mountain, he testified. ``The weather was worse on the descent,'' Summers testified. ``The wind was much stronger. It was easy to fall over and not know if it was because of the terrain or the wind.'' The Rev. Thomas Goman was leading the climb, but Summers said he takes responsibility for all of the major decisions on the expedition. He said he and Goman had an agreement that if the two differed on a question they would follow the more conservative approach. Summers said that as the group continued its descent, the storm grew worse and he and Goman decided to build a snow cave to wait out the blizzard. ``There was a crevasse on one side, a drop off on another, it was dusk and you couldn't navigate,'' he said. ``The decision to dig in was pretty easy.'' The 13-member party crawled into the snow cave and spent a harrowing night, marked by panic among people who feared they would suffocate, Molly Schula, 21, one of the survivors of the climb, testified Monday in Multnomah County Circuit Court. ``Everybody was panicking about air,'' Schula said. Another survivor, Brinton Clark, 19, testified that as the opening of the cave grew narrower as snow built up throughout the night, many of those inside became convinced they would die. The next morning, Summers decided to get help and Schula volunteered to accompany him. She said she owes her life to Summers. ``I said I'll go if you'll take me,'' she said. ``I couldn't have made it down without him.'' They made it to safety but the cave wasn't marked and Summers couldn't find it again once he reached help. It took rescuers three days to find the cave. By then, all inside were dead except for Clark and fellow Oregon Episcopal School student Giles Thompson.

DOC.HEAD: Greece to Hold Third Election in a Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one grafs after 12th pvs, `Recent acts...,' to UPDATE with new bombings. Picks up 13th pvs, `November 17th...'
DOC.TEXT: Greeks will vote again Sunday, for the third time in a year, in hopes of breaking a political deadlock that has created compromise governments unable to confront an economy in crisis and growing terrorism. Pollsters predict the election will end like those in June and November 1989, with no party winning enough seats to control the government. Coalitions formed after last year's elections took no effective action on foreign, domestic or economic policy. The European Community has said Greece is in danger of bankruptcy and the EC will not bail it out because Greece violated austerity requirements of a 1985 loan. Some Greek officials and economists fear the nation may have to surrender some of its economic sovereignty and seek help for the first time from the International Monetary Fund. ``Without a strong government, we are heading for economic disaster,'' said Stelios Argyros, president of the Federation of Greek Industries. He said Greece needs a government that can make the ``unpopular decisions'' required. The political stalemate began after 15 years of stable government, which followed seven years of military dictatorship that ended in 1974. In June 1989, the conservative New Democracy party and Communists united to oust Premier Andreas Papandreou's Socialists from eight years in power. A brief coalition of the unlikely allies presided over the indictments of Papandreou and several of his ministers on corruption charges stemming from banking and wiretapping scandals. No trial dates have been set. Another coalition formed after the November election was unable to stem a resurgence of terrorism, end labor unrest or resolve the problems of rising tensions with Turkey and Albania, rivals of long standing. Neither coalition was willing to negotiate a new military bases agreement with the United States or answer the U.S. extradition request for Mohammed Rashid, a Palestinian wanted for the 1982 bombing of a Pan Am jetliner that killed one person. Washington later simplified the bases problem by deciding to close two of the four. Recent acts of terror have included firebombings by anarchists and political killings and bombings by established terror groups. Today, at least five bombs exploded in Athens and Salonica, ripping through a government building as well as the offices of business groups and labor unions. Police said no injuries were reported and that anonymous callers claimed responsibility on behalf of two urban guerrilla groups. November 17th, a leftist group, claimed responsibility for the September murder of conservative lawmaker Pavlos Bakonvannis, son-in-law of New Democracy leader Constantine Mitsotakis. Social Resistance claimed responsibility for bombings last week that destroyed cars of foreign diplomats but caused no injuries. The coalition government of New Democracy, Communists and Socialists collapsed in February because of traditional hostilities among them. Some political scientists, citing generally low turnouts at rallies, say voters appear indifferent to the current campaign. ``Voters are apathetic now because they think politicians are incapable,'' said one, Dimitrios Katsoudas, director of studies at the Center for Political Research and Information. ``They have lost faith in the values of parties and how the political system works.'' Miltiades Evert, a conservative former finance minister, said Greece must make headway on its economic problems by the fall or turn for help to the International Monetary Fund, which often demands austerity in exchange for its aid. ``We won't have a Greek government, we'll have a foreign government,'' he said in an interview. ``The administration will be an executive arm of the IMF.'' Inflation is the European Community' highest, 14.8 percent last year and expected to reach 17 percent in 1990. This year's budget deficit is expected to be 2.5 trillion drachmas ($15.6 billion). Mihalis Hadzipavlou, director in Athens for the international accounting firm of Touche Ross, said foreign investors ``have not rejected Greece outright'' but are slowing investments because of the uncertainty. Zenophon Zolotas, the caretaker premier, has said Greece needs strong, clear leadership to restore investor confidence. ``If a climate of certainty, confidence and above all credibility is created, then we could be rid of the nightmare in 1991,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Ninja Turtles' Sliced and Diced the Competition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 10th graf, `The comedy...', to add graf introducing list. Picks up 11th graf, ``1. Teenage...'.
DOC.TEXT: Moviegoers shelled out $25.4 million for ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' in the biggest spring opening in Hollywood history. The live-action film about pizza-loving amphibians who live in a sewer scored an extra impressive opening over the weekend because most of the ticket buyers were kids paying $2.50 to $3 each, compared with $5.50 to $6.50 for adult tickets. ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' based on the heroes of cartoons and video games, fell behind only ``Batman'' and ``Ghostbuster II'' for the biggest box office take in a film's first three days, Exhibitor Relations Co. reported Monday. Both were early summer releases. Moviegoers, meanwhile, were still smiling on ``Pretty Woman,'' the story of a woman transformed by a businessman from a Hollywood Boulevard prostitute into a Rodeo Drive shopper. Starring Richard Gere and Julia Roberts, the film finished second and collected $12.5 million at the box office. ``The Hunt for Red October'' descended to third place as the underwater thriller grossed $6.5 million to bring its total take to $76.6 million. Winning the best picture and best actress Oscars on March 26 helped ``Driving Miss Daisy'' climb 41 percent to land in fourth with a gross of $5.2 million. The film, made for $8.5 million, should pass $100 million by month's end. ``My Left Foot,'' which picked up Oscars for best actor and best supporting actress, jumped 90 percent from a week ago. It finished ninth with $1.52 million. Italy's ``Cinema Paradiso,'' which won best foreign language film, made $344,000, up 86 percent. The comedy ``Opportunity Knocks'' starring Dana Carvey of ``Saturday Night Live,'' came in fifth with $3.5 million in its debut weekend. Here are the top 10 movie ticket sales with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. 1. ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' New Line, $25.4 million, 2,006 screens, $12,661 per screen, $25.4 million, one week. 2. ``Pretty Woman,'' Disney, $12.5 million, 1,538 screens, $8,109 per screen, $28.3 million, two weeks. 3. ``The Hunt for Red October,'' Paramount, $6.5 million, 1,817 screens, $3,596 per screen, $76.6 million, five weeks. 4. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Warner Bros., $5.2 million, 1,668 screens, $3,103 per screen, $82.1 million, 16 weeks. 5. ``Opportunity Knocks,'' Universal., $3.5 million, 1,275 screens, $2,755 per screen, $3.5 million, one week. 6. ``Joe vs. the Volcano,'' Warner Bros., $3.3 million, 1,691 screens, $1,937 per screen, $30.8 million, four weeks. 7. ``Nuns on the Run,'' 20th Century Fox, $2.15 million, 641 screens, $3,351 per screen, $4.2 million, three weeks. 8. ``House Party,'' New Line, $2.14 million, 700 screens, $3,056 per screen, $16.4 million, four weeks. 9. ``My Left Foot,'' Miramax, $1.52 million, 510 screens, $2,984 per screen, $10.7 million, 21 weeks. 10. ``Lord of the Flies,'' Columbia, $1.49 million, 916 screens, $1,626 per screen, $10.6 million, three weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Jiang Zemin Named To Top Military Post
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin was named to a top military post today, giving him one more rung in his tenuous climb to power. The National People's Congress, as expected, picked Jiang as new chairman of the state Central Military Commission, replacing senior leader Deng Xiaoping. The Congress, China's parliament, last week accepted Deng's resignation from his last official government post. Jiang, the only candidate, received 2,682 votes in his favor and 10 votes against him. There were 26 abstentions. One deputy wrote in Deng's name and another entered the name of President Yang Shangkun, a general with a strong following in the military. Jiang, Deng's hand-picked successor, in November succeeded Deng as head of the party Central Military Commission, a key policy-making body with nearly the same membership as the state group. The military has played an increasingly important political role in China since it was called in to crush the pro-democracy movement in Beijing last June, and Jiang's appointment to the two posts is crucial to his staying power as a leader. Jiang, a relatively unknown party boss in Shanghai, was named to head the 48-million-member Communist Party last June after Zhao Ziyang was purged for allegedly supporting the pro-democracy movement. Jiang, 63, has no political power base in Beijing and since June has loyally supported the hard-line policies espoused by retired but still-powerful party elders such as Deng. Deng, 85, still regarded as China's most powerful man, has declared that Jiang is the ``core'' of next-generation leaders, and has asked the military to give him their full support. Jiang has no experience in military affairs, and the People's Liberation Army remains dominated by old revolutionaries such as President Yang, 82, a general who last November was named first vice chairman of the party Central Military Commission. During the vote-counting today in the Great Hall of the People, a crowd of deputies gathered around Hu Qili, former member of the party Politburo Standing Committee purged along with Zhao last June for his pro-student leanings. Deputies extended warm greetings to Hu, asking for his signature and posing for pictures with him. Hu, like Zhao, was stripped of all party posts in June, but escaped official criticism and on a few occasions has been allowed to attend public functions. Zhao, still a party member and a deputy to the congress, has not been seen since he went to Tiananmen Square on May 19 for a tearful meeting with student hunger strikers.

DOC.HEAD: Bombs Explode in Two Cities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD extent of damage, political affiliation of terrorist groups; No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: At least five bombs exploded in two cities today, ripping through a government building and the offices of business groups and labor unions. Police said no injuries were reported. The early morning blasts went off simultaneously in Salonica and Athens, the capital. Police said anonymous callers claimed responsibility on behalf of the leftist guerrilla groups May 1 and the Revolutionary Popular Struggle. The groups have asked voters to boycott Sunday's crucial parliamentary elections, citing ``political mockery'' by the leading parties, the Conservatives and the Socialists. The Salonica blasts caused extensive damage at the European Community's northern Greece information center, located on the 6th floor of an office building, and the Industrialists Association of Northern Greece, police said. In Athens, bombs caused minor damage at the National Economy ministry, and buildings housing the General Confederation of Greek Trade Unions and the Federation of Greek Industrialists, they said on condition of anonymity. In the past, the attacks of the terrorist groups have focused on economic targets and none has ever caused fatalities. Both groups say they oppose capitalism, imperialism and the U.S. military presence in Greece. Greeks vote Sunday for the third time in a year, hoping to break a political deadlock that has created compromise governments unable to confront an economy in crisis and growing terrorism. But pollsters predict the election will end like those in June and November 1989, with no party winning enough seats to control the government.

DOC.HEAD: South, Southwest Get More Rain, Michigan, Wisconsin Get Snow
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to CORRECT Sunday to Monday. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Other reports...'.
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms brought high wind and hail to the South and Southwest, while snow fell in Michigan and Wisconsin and the high sizzled to 90 degrees near Miami. Rain was scattered Monday night in Florida, Texas, Louisiana, Georgia, South Carolina, Virginia, New Mexico, Arizona and Nevada. Parts of Pennsylvania, New York state, Ohio, Indiana and Michigan also received rain. Snow fell in northern Michigan and northern Wisconsin. A tree uprooted by high winds fell on a house Monday near Watson, La., and gusts overturned a trailer in Ingleside, N.C. In Virginia, Richmond and Charlottesville were pelted with hail the size of golf balls. So was Mebane, N.C. Temperatures were unseasonably warm in the Northwest. Record highs for the date were either tied or broken in several spots in Montana, Wyoming and Idaho. A high of 72 degrees in Kalispell, Mont., broke the record of 66 set in 1912. The high Monday in the Lower 48 states was 90 degrees near Miami. DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Arrest Warrant Was Outstanding For Happy Land Owner
DOC.TEXT: An arrest warrant was issued last year for the owner of the building that housed a club where 87 people died by fire, but he never was arrested, city records show. A Bronx criminal judge issued the warrant after the owner, Alex DiLorenzo III, failed to appear for a hearing on fire code violations at the illegal social club, The New York Times reported in today's editions. The warrant for DiLorenzo, who is an heir to one of the city's largest real estate fortunes, was low priority and never was enforced, police said. ``We are interested in all warrants,'' said Lt. Raymond O'Donnell, a police spokesman. ``But we are more interested in going after the guy who has committed a murder over a guy who has violations in a building.'' Of 100,000 yearly arrest warrants, those for building code violations are among the lowest priority, O'Donnell said. The warrant for DiLorenzo was issued Feb. 3, 1989, by Bronx Criminal Court Judge James E. Robinson. The violations listed in the warrant carried a fine of up to $5,000 and 90 days in jail. The club lacked adequate sprinklers, emergency lighting and an assembly permit for the entertainment of more than 75 people. A task force created by the city in 1988 after another fatal social club fire inspected Happy Land on Nov. 20, 1988, and ordered it closed. DiLorenzo has not returned telephone calls placed to his office over the past several days, the newspaper said. The man who allegedly set the fire, Julio Gonzalez, was being held in the psychiatric unit in the prison wing at Bellevue Hospital. A friend of Gonzalez's, Juana Ortiz, told the New York Post he was stricken with grief when told that one of his best friends died in the March 25 fire at Happy Land Social Club. The friend, identified only as Ramon, had comforted Gonzalez after he was evicted by the club's bouncer before the fire, Ms. Ortiz said. She said when she told Gonzlalez that Ramon had died, he shouted ``Oh my God! Please forgive me!'' and broke down sobbing, the newspaper reported in today's editions. Ortiz said Gonzalez is resigned to punishment and spends his day reading a Spanish-language Bible.

DOC.HEAD: Angry Judge Postpones Jogger Attack Trial Pending Analysis of New Evidence
DOC.TEXT: An angry judge criticized police for bungling evidence in the raping of a Central Park jogger and ordered the trial indefinitely postponed of three teen-agers charged in the case. The judge granted on Monday an adjournment that prosecutors had asked for while they await DNA test results from a newly discovered semen stain on the victim's sock. State Supreme Court Justice Thomas Galligan said he was ``very distressed'' that the sock had not been tested when the Police Department has had it for almost a year. ``It's the eve of the trial and it's something that should have been done a long time ago,'' he said. ``It seems to me almost negligence on the part of the police.'' Jury selection was to begin April 16 for three of the six teen-agers accused in the April 19, 1989, gang rape and beating of a female jogger. Prosecutors said it would take six to 10 weeks for the FBI to complete DNA testing on the stain. Galligan ordered the lawyers to return May 21 for an update. The stain was found Wednesday when an independent expert examined all the clothing, said law enforcement sources who spoke on condition they not be identified. The police lab apparently missed it because it was inside the jogger's white cotton sock, the sources said. The independent expert found the stain because it had discolored with age, they said. Assistant district attorney Elizabeth Lederer sent a hand-delivered letter to the judge and defense lawyers Thursday asking for the adjournment.

DOC.HEAD: Two Andy Warhol Works Stolen From Tokyo Exhibit
DOC.TEXT: Two Andy Warhol silk-screen prints were stolen from an exhibit of paintings, sculptures and other works of modern art in Tokyo, police said today. Warhol's ``Paramount'' and ``The New Spirit,'' reportedly worth $144,000 apiece, were reported stolen between 8 p.m. Sunday and 10 a.m. Monday at the Tokyo International Trade Center at Harumi, a police spokesman said. Police were investigating the theft, he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Naoyuki Nagayama of Nippon Bijutsu Shuppan, the sponsor of the five-day exhibition which ended Monday, said the prints were in their places on the walls with other works when sponsors checked before closing Sunday. After opening on Monday, the owner of the Warhol prints, Oliver Caldwell, 39, a gallery owner in San Francisco, discovered that the works were missing, Nagayama said. Warhol, an artist and filmmaker, was an initiator and leading exponent of the pop art movement of the 1060s. He died in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Ann Arbor Adopts Abortion Rights, Tougher Marijuana Law
DOC.TEXT: Voters have declared this university town a ``zone of reproductive freedom'' while making it a little less free for marijuana smokers. Ann Arbor voters approved Monday a token $5 fine on abortion, should state or federal laws ever ban the procedure, and boosted the city's 18-year-old $5 marijuana possession penalty to $25. Both the doctor and the patient would be subject to the abortion fine. The abortion proposal declaring Ann Arbor a ``zone of reproductive freedom'' passed 15,698 to 8,578. The marijuana measure passed 12,901 to 11,419. Sabra Briere, who gathered petitions in December to put the abortion issue on the ballot, said the vote reaffirms Ann Arbor's reputation as a pro-choice city. ``I think it's marvelous Proposal C won,'' Briere said. ``Once again it showed me that this is where I want to live and these are the people I want to live with. I'm very proud of Ann Arbor.'' ``I think it's a very clear expression of Ann Arbor voters saying we trust our women to manage their own personal lives more than we trust the politicians in Lansing,'' said state Sen. Lana Pollack, a Democrat from Ann Arbor. Rae Ann Houbeck of Right to Life of Washtenaw County said the measure would encourage ``back alley abortions.'' ``The measure trivializes the life of the child and the trauma of the woman,'' Houbeck said. The marijuana measure was put on the ballot by the city council. The $5 fine for possession and sale of marijuana was adopted in 1972 and reinstated through a voter-initiated city charter amendment in 1974 after Republicans on the city council repealed it. Opponents of the fine said the minor penalty has created a perception of the city as being a haven for drugs. The proposal to increase the fine to $25 was seen as a compromise between conservatives who wanted to treat marijuana possession as a criminal offense and those who wanted to retain the token fine. State law for a first offense of possession of a small amount of marijuana carries a maximum penalty of a $100 fine and 90 days in jail.

DOC.HEAD: Buffalo Transit System Bailed Out By State, City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from riders. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `The transit...'.
DOC.TEXT: A state- and city-funded bailout put Buffalo's transit system back in operation this morning after a two-day shutdown that forced thousands of bus and subway riders to put on walking shoes or get a lift from friends. The Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority voted unanimously Monday night to restart service this morning after the bailout package was put together. It includes a fare increase and taxes dedicated to transit. After the vote, NFTA Chairman Robert D. Gioia pleaded with the system's 120,000 riders, ``We need you, and we need you back immediately.'' Riders, many of whom said they had stayed home during the shutdown, were happy to oblige. ``I'm relieved,'' said accountant Connie Nicastro. ``I probably would have been unemployed if I didn't make it back (to work) today.'' ``People with low incomes need the subway,'' agreed computer operator Denise Matthews. ``I probably would have wound up on social services and had the state pay for my living'' if the shutdown had continued. The transit system, consisting of a six-mile subway line and 1,015 miles of bus routes, ran out of cash and shut down Sunday, its crisis blamed on rising operating costs, falling federal subsidies and the Erie County Legislature's refusal as recently as four days earlier to agree on a tax dedicated to the system. On Monday, commuters bicycled or walked to work through rain and fog or hitched rides with friends. ``My sister-in-law has this old junky piece of car and said we could use it if we could find out what's wrong with it,'' said Tequita Craig, a nurse's aide. ``We dished out $70 for a new battery.'' ``Everybody was walking together with sneakers on. Can you believe it?'' said Tennizee High, who walked 1{ hours to her job. Police said traffic was near normal, and few businesses reported any serious absenteeism. Schools in New York's second-largest city remained open and Buffalo's 25,000 elementary students rode private buses as usual. But up to 60 percent of Buffalo's 11,000 high school students missed classes, and many commuters worried about the effects of a long shutdown. ``It's inconveniencing my mother to come down and pick me up,'' said bank employee Lisa Cunningham. ``I hated to ask her, but what could I do? I couldn't have walked.'' Parts of the bailout are subject to approval by the Buffalo Common Council and the county Legislature. But council approval was expected, and county lawmakers said they had commitments in writing from the 12 members needed to pass the package. The bailout erased the last $3.7 million of a $15.6 million funding gap by a combination of accounting changes and grants of $1 million from the city and $750,000 from the state. Fares would rise from $1 to $1.10, and the county real estate transfer tax would more than double, a move industry spokesman Joe McIvor called ``grossly unfair.'' Next year, the agency would begin receiving a share of county sales tax revenue. Gioia said the package means that Buffalo's system will for the first time be supported by taxes dedicated to it. Most public transportation systems, including New York City's, are funded that way. ``We have been trying to find a dedicated stream of revenue for this institution for 11 years,'' Gioia said. The system, which costs $55 million a year to run, had depended on farebox revenue and state, county and federal grants. In 1981, federally subsidized bus systems in Youngstown, Ohio, and Birmingham, Ala., failed because they were unable to raise taxes. But Youngstown got an advance on state funding until the levy passed, and Birmingham was revived by a beer tax.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Close Polish-Lithuanian Border Crossing
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet government today closed the only border crossing between Poland and the Baltic republic of Lithuania, the Polish Foreign Ministry said. Soviet officials informed their Polish counterparts at the border that the crossing from the Polish town of Ogrodniki to the Lithuanian town of Lazdijai was temporarily closed at 9 a.m., the Polish news agency PAP said. A spokesman for the Polish Foreign Ministry confirmed that the border crossing was closed but said there would be no immediate comment. The border crossing, in the extreme northeast corner of Poland, can be used only by Poles and Soviet citizens. Late last month, the Soviet Union informed Poland that it was suspending visa-free travel for Poles and Lithuanians across the border. Polish border officials had reported reduced traffic at the crossing during the tense weeks after Lithuania declared independence from the Soviet Union on March 11, PAP said. On Sunday, 4,039 people and 810 vehicles used the border crossing, PAP said. Poland is the only foreign country bordering Lithuania. The Baltic forms a section of the republic's western border. Poles returning to Poland from the Soviet Union and Soviet citizens leaving Poland were allowed to continue to use the crossing today, PAP said.
