The agency also said workers with valid Soviet visas were permitted across the border for their jobs, and that cargo transportation was continuing. However, bus routes using the crossing were canceled, PAP said.

DOC.HEAD: Power Outage Halts Space Telescope Tests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th-6th grafs, `Some of...', with 3 grafs to UPDATE with charging of telescopes batteries resuming, spokesman calling that a good sign. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `NASA on...,'.
DOC.TEXT: A broken pipe sprayed water on electrical equipment, interrupting testing of the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope and threatening to postpone its launch aboard Discovery on Tuesday, NASA says. The water caused a temporary power outage that knocked out air conditioning at part of the Kennedy Space Center, the space agency said. The loss of air conditioning forced the shutdown of heat-sensitive equipment, including some computers. That in turn interrupted testing of the Hubble and space shuttle Discovery, on the launch pad awaiting liftoff. The 25,000-pound telescope was never in any danger from the cooling-system breakdown, said NASA spokesman George Diller. Some of the computers were back up early Monday evening, and testing was expected to resume later today. ``Since the full effect of the loss of the chillers is still being determined, we don't know whether there's an effect on the launch date,'' Diller said. Technicians began charging the telescope's batteries again Monday night, and Diller said the fact that the charging has resumed is a good sign. NASA on Saturday moved up launch from April 12 to April 10 since technicians had needed little of the contingency time built into the schedule. No contingency time was left as of today, however, Diller said. ``We can't afford even a hiccup'' if the launch is to be April 10, he said. The Hubble telescope, the most expensive unmanned spacecraft ever, will orbit 380 miles above Earth once it is deployed by Discovery's five astronauts. It will be capable of detecting objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory. Astronomers plan to use the telescope to study stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling toward Earth for 14 billion years.

DOC.HEAD: White House Rejects Housing Agency Candidate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout with confirmation that nomination rejected.
DOC.TEXT: The White House has rejected Housing Secretary Jack Kemp's choice of Mary K. Bush to head a new agency created as part of the savings and loan bailout, the administration said today. Her award of three no-bid contracts is under investigation. Ms. Bush has been serving as acting director of the Federal Housing Finance Board for seven months awaiting her promised appointment as its chairwoman. But the appointment was put in jeopardy by news accounts of three contracts she awarded friends from the Reagan administration. The contracts are being investigated by the Department of Housing and Urban Development's inspector general, with a report expected by week's end. An administration official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said today that Ms. Bush was no longer under consideration for the position. Mary Brunette, Kemp's top aide, said Kemp has offered Ms. Bush a full-time job as director of the agency. In that post, she would not be a voting member of the part-time board but would oversee the agency's day-to-day activities. Ms. Bush, who is not related to President Bush, has not responded to Kemp's offer. Her spokesman, Joseph Slye, said today that Ms. Bush has not been informed of the administration's decision, which was first reported today in The Washington Post. The Federal Housing Finance Board was created as part of the savings and loan bailout plan to oversee the 12 regional Federal Home Loan Banks, which must put a percentage of their profits each year into affordable housing programs. The agency is independent of HUD, but has been under Kemp's control because he is the only member of its board who has been named. Ms. Bush, a Treasury Department official during the Reagan administration, was a vice president of the Federal National Mortgage Association before leaving to head the new board last September. Publicly, Kemp aides continued to support Ms. Bush for the job even as they were informed Monday that the White House would not approve her nomination as chairwoman. But at least one top Kemp deputy expressed hope privately as far back as two months ago that Ms. Bush would leave the agency, which controls millions of dollars in new housing funds. Ms. Bush, according to sources, disagreed with Kemp's plans to seek a part-time board and also protested when the top Kemp deputy, HUD Undersecretary Alfred A. DelliBovi, forced her to hire a consultant she did not want to employ. Kemp's plans still face opposition in Congress, where lawmakers who drafted the legislation to create the agency say the board was designed as full-time. Kemp's aides have said that Kemp and others at HUD were not aware until two weeks ago of the no-bid contracts, one of which was awarded to Kemp's former chief of staff at HUD, Wendell Gunn. Gunn, however, said he personally told Kemp of the arrangment in November and offered to terminate his contract if Kemp wanted him to do so. And DelliBovi, in a memo about the Housing Finance Board written Feb. 5 to several top Kemp aides, twice referred to ``Wendell,'' once in a listing of people being paid by the agency.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Launches Ofek-2 Satellite
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with further details, new quotes and background; No pickup. Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: Israel today displayed its rocket and technological prowess, launching the Ofek-2 communications satellite, the second in a series of experimental spacecraft. The satellite is widely viewed in the Arab world as a spycraft that will allow Israel to have immediate intelligence on Arab military moves. The launch came one day after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein threatened to use chemical weapons against Israel if attacked. But Israel Space Agency head Yuvaal Neeman denied that the satellite had any military purpose or that the long-rumored launch was in any way a response to the warning. ``We don't send satellites because of threats,'' he said. Neeman described the new satellite as experimental and similar to the Ofek-1 launched aboard a gray, three-stage rocket Sept. 19, 1988. ``The only difference is that we can call the satellite and send it messages and receive answers back,'' Neeman said, adding: ``It is not a spy satellite and has no military significance.'' Witnesses said the rocket lifted off at 3:02 p.m., rising slowly above a ball of orange flame and leaving a zig-zag trail of white smoke. It was launched from an undisclosed site in the center of the country, and entered orbit 90 minutes later. The satellite's orbit will range from 125 miles at its lowest point to 923 miles at its highest, according to Space Agency spokesman Avi Sarhan. ``We said at the launch of Ofek 1 that there would be a whole line of satellites afterwards. Ofek 2 is just one more step, a successful step, in this program,'' Sarhan said. He said the Ofek 2 weighed 374 pounds, the same as Ofek-1. ``It is a technological satellite leading to a scientific satellite,'' Sarhan said. ``There is no equipment on it to examine space as NASA has. The next ones should have this ability.'' Analysts have said Israel needed its own satellite so as not to be dependent on the United States for satellite information. Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader who has been picked to head Israel's new government, told reporters the launch proved Israel's scientific ability. ``It shows that Israel is a highly developed country, and we are able to defend our lives,'' Peres said. ``We are not looking for wars. But we are looking for security and hopefully for a region and a time where nobody will need military equipment.'' He said the launch should remind Iraq's president ``that if he wants to deal with Israel, he should look for other means than the military one.'' Gerald Steinberg, a professor at Hebrew University and an expert on strategic technology, noted Israel had launched the rocket westward, toward the Mediterranean Sea, so as not to alarm its Arab neighbors. ``Israel has a policy not to send missiles toward Arab nations,'' he said, adding Israel also had a policy of not revealing characteristics of the missile to Israel's Arab enemies. Despite the secrecy surrounding the launch, civilians including a busload of school children stopped to watch the rocket rise on a curving arch into the partly cloudy skies. In launching the first satellite in 1988, Israel used a modified version of the Jericho II rocket and the lift-off demonstrated Israel's ability to use medium-range missiles, according to foreign reports. The first satellie rose to a height of about 155 miles, its closest point to earth, and reached a distance of about 620 miles. It burned up in the atmosphere returning to earth on Jan. 14, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Plants Shut Down as Fuel Spill Passes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with spill bypassing Pittsburgh intakes, other communities resuming pumping, raising reference to Harrison Township. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Birds carried...'. DELETES 11th graf, `The National...,' now redundant.
DOC.TEXT: Gel-like fuel creeping down the Allegheny River today fouled water supplies and stymied steel, glass and juice factories, but the water supplies of Pittsburgh and some nearby towns appeared to have been spared. Water had to be trucked into one community where intake valves were closed Monday because of the spill of up to 300,000 gallons of diesel, gasoline and kerosene that leaked after a landslide Friday ruptured a 10-inch-wide pipeline near Freeport, 35 miles north of Pittsburgh. But water service to Pittsburgh residents continued normally today. The slick hugged the south bank of the river when it reached downtown Pittsburgh during the night and missed main water intake pipes operated by the Pittsburgh Water Authority, which serves about 450,000 customers, authority spokeswoman Donna Sagmeister said. A number of communities near Pittsburgh reopened their intake pipes as the fuel passed, but still asked customers to use water sparingly. Pittsburgh and suburban water authority officials today said they were treating river water with increased amounts of chemicals for safety. ``We've been able to treat the spill as it has been passing us for now,'' Ms. Sagmeister said today. ``There are still pockets of oil floating, and if one of those pockets should park itself in front of our intake valves, we could be in trouble. But right now it's moving slowly and in a fashion that we can treat it and not shut down.'' ``There's a slight sheen on the river right now, but a lot of the fuel has evaporated,'' Environmental Protection Agency spokeswoman Carrie Deitzel said late Monday. The spill had threatened the water supplies of up to 1 million people. At least 2,500 workers in the industrial valley were told to stay home Monday, although the Coast Guard by nightfall reopened a 10-mile stretch of the river to barges and other vessels after a two-day hiatus. Later Monday, Harrison Township, the only suburban community to lose water service because of the accident, was able to resume pumping because petroleum concentrations had dropped. Township customers nevertheless should boil their water for drinking and cooking, the Allegheny County Health Department said. The National Guard had sent 100 water trailers and a brewery took bottled water to Harrison Township, where 20,000 people were without water Monday. Factories, offices and about 400,000 people were advised to conserve water as the 20-mile spill, a mass 5 to 21 feet deep, oozed into Pittsburgh at half a mile an hour or less, forcing communities to shut their intakes one one by one. Birds carried fuel to at least two nests, where eggs were coated and ``can be considered dead,'' said Environmental Protection Agency spokeswoman Carrie Deitzel. Dead fish are expected to rise to the surface later, she said. Daily Juice Products Inc. in Verona suspended production of pasteurized juice. The plant uses 100,000 gallons of water a day, said plant manager Bob Rivett. Five tanker trucks delivered water to make non-pasteurized drinks, he said. Steelmaker Allegheny Ludlum Inc. trucked in water for the toilets and other uses at its 2,600-employee plant in Brackenridge. PPG Industries Inc. halted production of automotive glass at its Creighton plant, which employs 360 people. Plants making made cough syrup, steel office furniture and electronic circuit boards also either cut production or were closed. Emergency officials trucked in water to replenish a 45,000-gallon reservoir at Allegheny Valley Hospital, which draws its water from the river. The hospital used paper plates and cups to serve meals to its 225 patients, closed its laundry and sent dirty linens to another hospital. At least nine school districts closed Monday, idling more than 21,000 students. Buckeye Pipeline Co. estimated 75,000 gallons of the mixed fuel flowed into the river. But John Kaus of the Allegheny County Emergency Management Authority and others said the amount was closer to 200,000 to 300,000 gallons. Buckeye permit manager Roy Haase Jr. said the company and its contractors had recovered 50,000 gallons of a fuel-and-water mixture. About 100 people worked to collect oil and build a dam below the spill site, where fuel continued to leach from a quagmire covering the pipe. ``They are trying to stabilize that soil,'' Ms. Deitzel said. ``It's a precarious situation because it's saturated with fuel. ... They're out there working with lifelines.'' Two years ago, an Ashland Oil tank ruptured, sending 713,000 gallons of diesel fuel into the nearby Monongahela River and affecting water supplies downtstream on the Ohio River as far away as Sistersville, W.Va.

DOC.HEAD: Bishops' Proposal Urges Reforms on Sexism
DOC.TEXT: A draft declaration by U.S. Roman Catholic bishops comes down square on the side of women, but backs off from pushing for their ordination. Men and women ``are equal in dignity before God and before one another,'' the proposed declaration stresses, and ``incapacity to deal with women as equals'' indicates lack of fitness for the priesthood. Women have been slighted by ``sexist patterns,'' and should have more equitable roles in ``leadership, ministry, teaching and policy-making,'' says the revised draft distributed to bishops on Monday. Nonetheless, it reiterates the church's stand against admitting women to the priesthood, and instead calls for more dialogue. Many women regard the ban as excluding them from church ``governance and authoritative teaching,'' the draft said, but it defended the practice as that of Jesus and his apostles. It ``is not arbitrary, nor is it rooted in a view that women are inferior as persons,'' the draft said. ``We pray that disagreement will not cause anyone to take leave of the church.'' On a related matter, the draft urges the Vatican to speed up study of admitting women to the diaconate, historically a preliminary step to the priesthood for men, and to ``the lay ministries'' of lectors and readers of Scripture at worship services. The Vatican should also examine further whether girls can be acolytes, or altar girls. ``The exclusion of women and girls from certain aspects of service at the altar ... seem to contradict our mandate that women be more visibly involved,'' the draft said. ``We encourage participation by women in all liturgical ministries that do not require ordination. Similarly we support the theological preparation of women to preach the gospel and to use their gifts as preachers in the church.'' A bishops' committee, authorized by the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, has been working on the proposed pastoral letter on women for about five years. The 99-page second draft, 65 pages shorter than a 1988 draft, was sent to the church's approximately 350 bishops asking for their responses. The bishops hold their annual meeting in November. The draft says numerous church practices have ``depersonalized and depreciated women'' and left them ``objects of suspicion, condemnation, condescension or simply ignored.'' ``We intend, therefore, to ensure that women are empowered to assume positions of authority and leadership in church life in a wide range of situations and ministries,'' it said. The document, called ``One in Christ Jesus _ A Pastoral Response to the Concerns of Women for Church and Society,'' was drawn up by a six-bishop committee headed by Bishop Joseph L. Imesch of Joliet, Ill. Five women served as consultants, and 75,000 women in 100 dioceses, 25 national women's organizations and 60 college campuses sent advice. The draft calls changes in ``power structures and lifestyles found within our own house that prevent the proper advancement of women,'' and asks each diocese to set up a commission to assure rights of women. It endorses sexually inclusive language in church materials referring both to people and to God, providing expressions that ``respect both the `masculine' and `feminine' attributes of God.'' ``Christians must reject all prejudicial attitudes that persist toward women, all structures and stereotypes that sublty or overtly perpetuate injustices, all practices that make women feel as if they are not accepted,'' it said. The draft touches on various other matters, applauding feminists for advancing women's rights, the value of both single and married life, church opposition to abortion and extra-marital sex, and prohibition of contraception. On birth control, it says studies suggest ``a considerable degree of non-compliance'' among Catholic women, but argues the ``marital act cannot be separated from openness to life.''

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Kills 31, Wounds 70 in Punjab
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE number of dead and wounded, inserts new quote; Picks up 10th graf, `Earlier today ...'
DOC.TEXT: A bomb hidden in a motor scooter exploded in a crowded vegetable market in Punjab state today, killing at least 31 people and wounding 70 others as Hindus celebrated a religious holiday, police said. The bombing, which police blamed on Sikh separatists, raised to 39 the number killed since Monday in the northern state. Sikhs campaigning for a separate nation have killed more than 500 people so far this year in Punjab, a rich northern farming state where they hold a slight majority over Hindus. Soon after the blast in Batala, 25 miles north of the Sikh holy city of Amritsar, Hindu mobs hurled stones at a police station 150 yards from the vegetable market, senior police superintendent S.K. Goel said. Goel was unsure whether any policemen were injured. The violence prompted officials to impose an indefinite curfew on the city, he said, adding that ``the situation is very tense.'' Most of those killed were Hindus and the wounded included both Sikhs and Hindus, said Sanjeev Gupta, another senior police official. Thirty-two of those wounded were in serious condition. Goel said the bomb exploded during a march by about 100,000 Hindus celebrating the birth of Rama, a heroic warrior-king. Rama is extolled in Hindu lore as an incarnation of Vishnu, a member of the supreme Hindu trinity of gods. Witnesses, contacted by telephone, said portions of bodies were hurled across the market, which was covered with blood-soaked pieces of vegetables. ``Some people were crying for help. Those who were lucky to survive ran away in panic. Many shops, scooters and one car were destroyed,'' said one witness who spoke on condition of anonymity. Earlier today, a bomb exploded on a bus in another town near Amritsar, killing the driver and one passenger, both Sikhs, senior police superintendent Anil Sharma said. Police blamed Sikh extremists for the blast near Taragarh, 17 miles northeast of Amritsar. Sikh Extremists initially targeted only Hindus in their campaign but now have also turned their guns on Sikhs who don't support the separatist cause. On Monday night, Sikh militants shot and killed four members of a Sikh family in another part of Punjab, police said. At Salghowal, 95 miles southeast of Amritsar, five or six Sikh gunmen burst into the farmhouse of a Sikh constable Monday night, killing the policeman, his parents and a younger brother, senior police superintendent Baramjit Singh said. Police also blamed Sikh extremists for an attack on a bus Monday night in Uttar Pradesh state, which is separated from Punjab by Haryana state, news agencies reported. United News of India said one police guard was killed and 11 passengers were wounded when five gunmen stopped the bus. But a second police guard killed one of the gunmen and the others fled, according to United News. Press Trust of India said police recovered a Chinese assault rifle bearing the inscription ``Khalistan Commando Force.'' Khalistan, which means ``Land of the Pure,'' is the name Sikh militants use for the independent Sikh nation they want to create in Punjab. The bus was halted while traveling between Bijnore and Muzaffarnagar, about 75 miles northeast of New Delhi and about 95 miles from the Punjab-Haryana state line. Most attacks by Sikh extremists have occurred in Punjab. Nationwide, Sikhs comprise only 2 percent of India's 880 million people, while Hindus account for 82 percent. The militants say members of the Sikh faith, which has roots in both Islam and Hinduism, are discriminated against politically and culturally by the Hindu majority.

DOC.HEAD: Troops, Police Deployed To Halt Black Factional Strife
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with with Mandela comments, CORRECTS spelling of first reference to Edendale. Pickup 5th graf `More than...'; DROPS grafs 12-14 `The African...recent weeks' to CONFORM.
DOC.TEXT: The government began deploying heavily armed soldiers and police today after President F.W. de Klerk ordered a major crackdown on black factional fighting that has claimed hundreds of lives. Police said army and police reinforcements were moving into the ravaged Edendale Valley in the southeastern province of Natal to halt virtual civil war between rival Zulu tribal factions. Police Maj. Piet Kitching said at least 55 people had been killed and hundreds injured in the area over the past week. Military officials said combat units were being moved into Natal and other regions, but declined to give numbers or other details. Police in Edendale said army troops would set up barricades and conduct patrols to stop the fighting. Black leader Nelson Mandela, wrapping up a two-day visit to Natal, said he welcomed the government's concern for restoring order but said officials should have talked to local black leaders about the move. ``Unilateral action by the government without consulting acknowledged leaders is bound to be ineffective regardless of merit,'' said Mandela, the deputy president of the African National Congress guerrilla movement. Mandela and President F.W. de Klerk are to meet Thursday to discuss ways to deal with the worst wave of violence since riots in the mid-1980s. Mandela defended the ANC's decision to pull out of April 11 peace talks with the government in protest against a recent police shooting of black demonstrators. At least 11 blacks were killed in the March 26 clash at Sebokeng, a township south of Johannesburg. If whites had been killed, ``white South Africa would be screaming at the top of its voice,'' Mandela said. ''But because it's blacks, whites think it is not important.'' The talks were to have focused on removing barriers to full-scale talks on extending voting rights to the 28 million black majority. More than 12,000 refugees, mainly women and children, had fled their homes in the Edendale area and were being sheltered at camps, police said. Rival mobs had burned hundreds of houses in the area, they said. The pro-apartheid opposition Conservative Party, which opposes de Klerk's attempts to end apartheid and scrap white-minority rule, denounced his moves today. It said he was pushing the nation into ``anarchy and chaos.'' But reaction to the government moves was generally positive. The liberal opposition Democratic Party endorsed the deployment of the security forces to end the violence. De Klerk told Parliament on Monday he had ordered security forces to launch a major drive to end unrest in black urban townships and rural areas such as Natal. He said the army had been ordered ``to act immediately, firmly and purposefully'' to end the unrest. South Africa has been hit in recent weeks by the worst wave of violence since riots in the mid-1980s. De Klerk legalized the ANC and other outlawed black opposition groups in February and released Mandela after 27 years in jail. The president says he wants to share political power with blacks and end all judicial forms of racial segregation _ though still maintain veto power for whites.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Aide Calls for Gas Mask Program; Iraqi Demonstrations Back Saddam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with pro-Saddam demonstrations in Iraq, further Iraqi comment, Iraq wants chemical ban linked with nuclear disarmament. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir urged the government today to issue a gas mask to every Israeli after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein threatened to use binary nerve gas against Israel. In Iraq, Saddam's ruling Baath Party held rallies today in Baghdad and major provincial cities in support of his statement Monday. Iraqi officials insisted the threat was meant to deter Israeli plans to attack. ``The people have the right to defend themselves,'' chanted some of the demonstrators, who waved banners quoting from Saddam's speech. The speech dominated the Israeli news. His statement and Israeli leaders' counterthreats led every newspaper and the state broadcast stations. Michael Dekel, an aide to Shamir and former deputy defense minister, said he urged the prime minister to order distribution of gas masks, now stored in warehouses. ``I simply want Prime Minister Shamir to move faster so that every Israeli citizen will feel safe in his home,'' Dekel said. ``We need to prepare the civilian population, not only with practice, but with equipment in the case of a surprise attack.'' An army spokesman confirmed a newspaper report that the Home Guard, in charge of civilian defense, has prepared instruction videotapes on how to use gas masks for broadcast on national television. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens told Israel radio Saddam's past use of chemical weapons concerned him. ``Unconventional weapons in the hands of a man such as Hussein, who has used chemical weapons in a massive way against Iran and the Kurds, should be a warning not only to every Israeli but to the world,'' Arens said. Iraq has been accused of using chemical weapons during its 1980-88 war with Iran, and against its Kurdish minority, an allegation Iraqi officials deny. Saddam denied Iraq was developing nuclear weapons but said Iraq possessed binary chemical weapons and would use them if Israel attacked. ``I also say that if Israel dares to hit even one piece of steel on any industrial site, we will make the fire eat half of Israel,'' he said in his Monday speech. Israel's Air Force bombed Iraq's Osirak nuclear reactor in 1981 while Iraq was at war with Iran, claiming the facility was being used to develop atomic weapons. Iraq denied the charge. The current issue of Newsweek magazine reported Israel was planning a new Jericho III missile with a 4,000-mile range easily capable of reaching Iraq. It quoted Western experts as saying Israel possesses at least 100 atomic bombs. Israel has said it would not be the first to introduce nuclear weapons into the Middle East conflict. An Iraqi official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said today his country's officials believe ``there is a military operation designed by the Israelis with the authorization and encouragement of the United States of America and Britain.'' He cited Israeli warnings in recent months about Iraq's growing military strength. The official termed Saddam's tough words ``a clear warning'' but added, ``Israel is fully aware that we have no intention to attack Israel.'' In Geneva, Iraq indicated today it will not join a global ban on chemical weapons unless it is linked to nuclear disarmament. While denying again that it sought to obtain triggers for nuclear warheads, it charged that the rights of developing countries are being violated by embargoes on transfer of products and know-how that could be used in the production of chemical weapons. Iraq ``has every right to acquire the means needed to defend itself'' chief delegate Abdel Rahim Al Khatal told the Geneva Conference on Disarmament. Al Khatal said a treaty banning the use, production and stockpiling of chemical weapons ``would be widely supported if it contains a binding commitment incumbent on nuclear weapon states.''

DOC.HEAD: American Heart Association Discontinuing Labeling Program
DOC.TEXT: Consumers could be the losers in the decision by the American Heart Association to drop its seal of approval, a nutritionist says. The association announced Monday that it would drop its HeartGuide seal program but would continue to work closely with the federal government on new food labeling regulations. The seal _ a heart with a checkmark inside _ was to be put on foods low in sodium, cholesterol and saturated fats, if their manufacturers paid a fee to the association. It was yanked after the federal Food and Drug Administration said it would not support the program. ``The FDA has made it clear it is against third-party endorsements,'' Howard Lewis, director of health and science news for the heart association, said. ``The government's only concern was that they did not like third party organizations entering into an area where they had legal responsibility.'' The FDA sent a letter to the association Friday saying it would not support the program. That followed a warning letter in February threatening regulatory action. The program was launched in January. The U.S. Department of Agriculture also refused to let the seal appear on any of the food it regulates, which included meat, poultry and frozen dinners. Consumer groups such as the Center for Science in the Public Interest had earlier expressed concerns that the HeartGuide seal might lull consumers into thinking they were buying an overall health food, rather than foods that were considered best only for the prevention of heart disease. ``The seal of approval was somewhat narrow,'' said Bonnie Liebman, director of nutrition for CSPI. ``It looked only at whether the food was good for your heart. Foods like vegetable oils, margarines and some oils, they're low in saturated fat and sodium, but we've been urged to cut back on all fats, not just saturated fats, to reduce the risk of cancer.'' Nonetheless, she called it a ``noble attempt'' to help consumers. ``If there's any victim, it's the befuddled consumer who's still trying to make heads or tails out of food labeling. I'm a nutritionist and I have trouble figuring out what's what at the supermarket,'' she said. Under the HeartGuide program, food companies paid $15,000 to $600,000 to submit their products for testing. Products which met heart association guidelines would get the HeartGuide seal of approval for their packaging. Consumer groups also said they were concerned that companies that chose not to pay the money would be shunned by shoppers, even if their products were identical to a product carrying the seal. The money was to be used for a nutrition hotline and education programs, as well as the cost of the testing itself. Heart association president Myron L. Weisfeldt of Baltimore said Monday that the association would announce a revamped HeartGuide program this summer, focusing on education, ``with added emphasis on legislative and regulatory actions,'' for clearer food labeling. Weisfeldt said the heart association was encouraged that the FDA plans to overhaul the government's labeling program. Ms. Liebman was skeptical. ``The FDA has actually said that it plans to improve food labels, but that could take another decade or two,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Matheney Trial Delayed After Jurors' Luggage Stolen
DOC.TEXT: The murder trial of a prison inmate charged in the death of his former wife while he was on brief furlough was postponed today after the jurors' luggage was stolen. Sgt. Dan Dallas with the Merrillville Police Department said today that the luggage was taken between Monday evening from two vans parked at a restaurant near Interstate 65. The jury of nine men and three women was sworn in Monday evening and was being transported to South Bend, about 60 miles east, where opening statements in the Alan L. Matheney case were scheduled to begin today. Lake Superior Court Judge James E. Letsinger said today that the trial would be postponed until Wednesday. ``Come hell or high water, we'll get the jury to St. Joseph County tonight,'' Letsinger said. The jurors spent Monday night at a hotel in Merrillville. Matheney, 39, is charged with murder and burglary in the March 1989 beating death of his former wife, Lisa Marie Bianco. The prosecution is seeking the death penalty. Letsinger presided over the daylong jury selection Monday. St. Joseph County Deputy Prosecutor John D. Krisor quizzed potential jurors about their views of the death penalty, while defense attorney Scott L. King asked their opinions of the insanity defense. Matheney has entered pleas of innocent and not responsible by reason of insanity. The St. Joseph County courtroom where jurors will hear testimony is a few miles from the city of Mishawaka, where Ms. Bianco, 29, was found beaten to death outside her home March 4, 1989. Matheney, who had been freed earlier that day on an eight-hour prison furlough, surrendered hours later. He was serving an eight-year term for assaulting Ms. Bianco, who was apparently unaware that a furlough had been granted. The decision to try to case in South Bend before a Lake County judge and jury was an unusual change of venue granted Matheney. Letsinger said the trial would last less than two weeks, but warned of long days in court and weekend sessions. The jury will be sequestered.

DOC.HEAD: 7 Policemen Slain After Traffickers Offer Rewards For Killing Them
DOC.TEXT: Seven policemen were killed in a 24-hour period in Medellin after drug traffickers offered rewards for the murder of policemen, the national police said today. Police killed seven gunmen in the rash of attacks Monday and today, national police said in the northwestern city that is headquarters for the Medellin drug cartel. There was no way to verify if the seven slain officers were victims of gunmen seeking the nearly $4,300 bounty that authorities said the Medellin cartel has offered for each policeman killed in Colombia. The traffickers also offered $100,000 for the murder of each member of the antinarcotics strike force of the national police, the police said last week. None of the special force, numbering about 2,000 men, has been killed yet. Drug barons are seeking to halt the government's policy of extraditing traffickers to the United States. Meanwhile, a Bogota newspaper hard-hit by the drug traffickers said in today's editions that new threats forced the daily to stop publishing editorials supporting government action against drug lords. El Espectador said it will suspend such editorials until the government could assure the newspaper of safety from traffickers' attacks. The newspaper urged government action against the drug traffickers long before President Virgilio Barco started a crackdown last Aug. 18 when a leading presidential hopeful was slain by drug lords. The traffickers killed the daily's publisher, Guillermo Cano, in a submachine gun attack in front of the newspaper's office Dec. 17, 1987. The traffickers detonated a truck bomb alongside the office last Sept. 2, seriously damaging the two-story building. The traffickers have killed four El Espectador employees in the past six months. The traffickers threatend in a communique last week to resume killing government officials, judges, policemen and members of the Cano family that owns El Espectador. The traffickers declared a unilateral truce last Jan. 17 in an effort to persuade the government to end its crackdown, but officials last week reiterated that they will not negotiate. From Aug. 17 through Jan. 17 the traffickers set off bombs and committed other terrorist acts that killed 210 people.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Says Eyes Improving After Treatment
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush said today that her eyes are showing improvement for the first time after radiation treatment for irritation resulting from Graves disease. ``Last week was the first week without seeing double,'' she told reporters this morning. She underwent 10 days of radiation treatment in January, and doctors said it would take several weeks to determine if the radiation had worked. ``I think the radiation worked. That's very good news,'' Mrs. Bush said. However, she said she had not been evaluated recently by her medical specialists. She made the comments after surprising tourists on the first floor of the White House by conducting a brief ceremony to receive a new historical book on the presidency. White House staffers gathered about 200 tourists in the main foyer of the White House to watch Mrs. Bush formally accept the new editions of ``The Presidents of the United States'' and ``The First Ladies'' from the White House Historical Association president. She signed several copies of the books for delighted recipients among the tourists. She joked that the family dog, Millie, lurking shyly in the background, ``doesn't like tourists.'' Mrs. Bush was diagnosed early last year with Graves disease, an immune system disorder that initially caused weight loss by affecting her thyroid. It also caused her eyes to be irritated and resulted in double vision, especially in the mornings. Treatment with a radioactive liquid cured the thyroid effects, but the eye irritation persisted even after doctors put Mrs. Bush on the steroid, prednisone. The radiation treatments, administered on 10 successive days, were the latest step in her treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Nears Agreement to Form New Governing Coalition
DOC.TEXT: A pivotal religious party today forged a coalition with Labor Party leader Shimon Peres, who said the move gave him the basis for forming ``a rather solid government.'' After signing the accord with the Agudat Israel faction, leaders of the left-of-center Labor met in Tel Aviv to consider requesting a parliamentary vote Thursday on a new government, Israel radio said. The accord with the ultra-Orthodox party created a political momentum that gave Peres a chance in breaking his 60-60 deadlock with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc in Parliament. Agudat Israel has five seats. ``This means that we have closed completely the agreement and have established the basis to form a rather solid government, whether narrow or wide,'' he told reporters in Tel Aviv after the signing. Peres was asked by President Chaim Herzog to compose a government after Shamir's Likud-Labor Cabinet was toppled in a Parliament vote of no confidence March 15. The crisis was triggered by a dispute over Middle East peace proposals. Agudat Israel legislator Rabbi Menachem Porush strongly hinted today that two breakaway Likud members, Avraham Sharir and Yitzhak Modai, were nearing an agreement with Peres, and that other ultra-Orthodox parties would also join a Labor government. But Modai denied he was joining a Peres government, army radio quoted a Modai spokesman as saying. A sticking point in negotiations remained Modai's demand that Israel refrain for at least six months from accepting Middle East peace proposals of U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, army radio said. Peres is a strong supporter of Baker's ideas for starting Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. His views and Shamir's reluctance to accept the proposals brought about the government's fall last month. In his remarks, Peres reiterated today that ``the real issue today is how to proceed with the peace process.'' Peres said he made no promises for controversial legislation that religious parties have sought in the past, such as a ``Who is a Jew'' amendment that would effectively outlaw non-Orthodox conversions to Judaism. ``On the religious side, we didn't sell and we didnt' buy anything. There is a legitimate status quo,'' Peres said.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Says Wires Cut Deliberately in Plane Being Assembled
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. is investigating an apparent case of industrial sabotage, after a jetliner failed tests because of wires that had been cut. ``It clearly seems to have been deliberate,'' T. Craig Martin, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group spokesman, said late Monday in an interview. ``The evidence at this point would suggest it would be an employee but we want to find out for sure.'' Boeing's security personnel are investigating, the company said in a statement. The Boeing 737 was in final assembly and undergoing testing at a Renton plant when the cut wires were discovered, Martin said. It had not been determined in what stage of construction the wires were cut, he said. Boeing released a statement Monday after KIRO-TV reported the cut wires. The damage was found about two weeks ago. ``Scores'' of wires were severed, KIRO reported. It said there was a pattern of one or two wires cut in a bundle of wires and the broken ends hidden deep inside the bundle to mask the damage. Boeing would not divulge the number of wires severed and Martin said he did not know the areas of the plane where the damage was found. The aerospace giant said in its statement that repairs have been scheduled on the aircraft. ``Because of the anomalies noted on this particular airplane, it will receive an especially intensive examination,'' Boeing's statement said. The Federal Aviation Administration has asked Boeing for information on the wire-cutting incident and on what the company is doing to ensure quality control at the plant, KIRO reported. FAA spokesman Dave Duff said it was unlikely that a deliberately damaged plane could be certified for flight. ``The system is working as it should,'' Duff said. The incident occurred as Boeing is laying off some of its production workers, mostly at its Everett plant, where it assembles widebody 767s and 747s. Tom Baker, president of Machinists union District Lodge 751, said, ``While members are angry at the company as a result of the layoffs _ when they know and I know it's not needed _ I doubt that anger would be aimed at any type of sabotage.'' There have been no been previous cases of sabotage at Boeing ``to our knowledge,'' said Boeing spokesman Mark Hooper. He said anyone found responsible for sabotage would be fired and possibly face criminal charges.

DOC.HEAD: Activists: U.S. Offer to Drop Indictment Lasted Until Invasion
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega says the United States offered to drop his drug indictment in exchange for military concessions and maintained that offer until it invaded Panama, according to two activists who interviewed him. The former Panamanian leader said an agreement dismissing the drug charges had been drawn up, but it fell apart when he balked at efforts to use U.S. bases in his homeland as a staging area for an invasion of Nicaragua, said Gavrielle Gemma, official of a group that opposes the U.S. action in Panama. ```The Panamanian government did not want to invade Nicaragua,''' she quoted Noriega as saying Monday. ```The United States was interested in continuing to place interventionist troops in the American continent that can be mobilized to control South America, Central America and the Caribbean.''' Ms. Gemma and another official of the Independent Commission of Inquiry on the U.S. invasion of Panama interviewed Noriega at the federal courthouse in Miami for just over a half hour Monday. Noriega told them that despite U.S. refusal to recognize his government after an election was invalidated last year, negotiations continued under both the Reagan and Bush administrations. Two issues _ using Southern Command facilities for intervention in Nicaragua, and U.S. pressure to maintain its Panamanian bases after the year 2000 _ blocked any agreement, Ms. Gemma quoted Noriega as saying. She also said Noriega told them he was aware the invasion was coming two days before the United States launched it on Dec. 20. Noriega also commented on his relations with U.S. intelligence agencies, Ms. Gemma said, but she said the commission would expand on that Thursday at a news conference in New York. She said Noriega did not complain of his treatment, but was concerned about the effects of the invasion on his homeland. Ms. Gemma and an assistant, Teresa Gutierrez, interviewed Noriega in the presence of his attorneys and federal marshals, they said. The commission _ which includes former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark, author Graham Greene and others _ has issued a report opposing the invasion and saying civilian casualties probably numbered in the thousands, not hundreds, as the Defense Department maintained. Noriega faces 145 years in prison if convicted of a variety of drug counts in a February 1988 indictment that accused him of accepting bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn Panama into a way station for U.S.-bound cocaine. The trial is scheduled for Jan. 28, 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Musburger Says Farewell to CBS After Championship Broadcast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Folks, I've...', and 11th graf, `The main...', to CORRECT spelling of Murburger. Version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Brent Musburger, closing out his 15-year career at CBS on top by doing the play-by-play of the NCAA basketball championship, bid goodbye to the network but not to sports broadcasting. ``Folks, I've had the best seat in the house. Thanks for sharing it. I'll see you down the road,'' Musburger said Monday in the final moments of CBS' broadcast of the University of Nevada-Las Vegas' 103-73 victory over Duke. CBS announced Sunday that it wouldn't renew Musburger's $2 million-a-year contract after it expires June 30. Musburger, CBS' signature sports voice for more than a decade, saved his brief farewell for the end of the game. ``As you know, this was my last assignment with CBS after 22 years with the television network, radio network and the stations,'' Musburger said. ``I had an opportunity to work with the greatest directors, producers, technicians in the world. Not to mention analysts, like my good friend Billy Packer. Billy, we have shared some great memories.'' Musburger then put his arm around Packer, his broadcasting partner on college basketball. After the broadcast, fans in McNichols Arena shouted encouragement to Musburger. ``You're a pro, baby,'' one yelled. Musburger saluted the fans with a thumbs-up and raised his index finger to signify No. 1. His assistant, Jimmy Tubbs, said the broadcaster would not discuss his departure from CBS while in Denver but would be available later in the week. The main issues in Musburger's contract dispute apparently were money and high-profile assignments, CBS said. Musburger, the network's most prominent sportscaster, wanted more of both than the network was willing to give. Musburger is in his sixth season as lead play-by-play man for the NCAA basketball tournament and has been host of ``The NFL Today'' since 1975. He also has broadcast college football and was anchorman of CBS' coverage of the Masters golf tournament, the NBA finals, the Pan American Games and U.S. Open tennis highlights. CBS' most pressing problem in replacing Musburger is finding another No. 1 baseball broadcaster before airing its first game April 14. Musburger was to have teamed with Tim McCarver on baseball telecasts. He was also in line to be host of the network's coverage of the 1992 and 1994 Winter Olympics. Al Michaels is considered the top candidate to replace Musburger if ABC lets him out of his contract, which runs into 1993. Michaels, an experience baseball broadcaster, is reportedly feuding with ABC's sports president. Michaels' agent, Art Kaminsky, would not speculate about his client's chances of switching networks. Another possibility is simply filling Musburger's roles with other CBS announcers. CBS Sports President Neal Pilson wants to give younger sportscasters such as Jim Nantz, Greg Gumbel and James Brown expanded duties. ``He's got a lot of talent there,'' Kaminsky said. ``He can take care of this internally, if he chooses.''

DOC.HEAD: Prisoners at Large After Guard Fell For April Fools Prank
DOC.TEXT: Two men were mistakenly freed from the Oslo jail after a guard fell for an April Fool's Day joke, and they were still on the loose Tuesday, newspapers reported. According to the reports, a friend of the prisoners called the jail Sunday. Pretending to be a police officer, the prankster told the guard the two men were being released and that the paperwork would arrive soon. ``The idea was that they would be told of the release, but that it wouldn't happen. I was trying to pull an April Fools' joke on them,'' the prankster told newspapers on condition he was not indentified. But the trusting guard gave the prisoners cash and clothing and freed them without waiting for the release papers, reports said. The men were awaiting trial on theft charges. ``I didn't think it was that easy to get people out of jail,'' the prankster said.

DOC.HEAD: Japan, U.S. Joint Venture to Sell Beef in Vending Machines
DOC.TEXT: Beef imported from the United States will be sold in vending machines in Japan under a Japanese-U.S. joint venture project, a Japanese official said Tuesday. ``Our aim is to supply imported beef at a cheaper price to consumers by reducing the costs of distribution-related personnel,'' said Naoki Sakai, a spokesman for Jackson Co. Jackson is a Japanese meat dealer based in the western port city of Kobe. It joined with the Hamilton Meat Co., a meat packer based in San Diego, to set up the joint venture, Sakai said. Sakai said it will be first time in Japan that beef has been sold in vending machines. Seasoned beef for steak and sukiyaki will be processed in the United States before being imported in frozen vacuum packages for sale in Japan, Sakai said. The machines, equipped with freezers, will be set up at 1,000 locations, mainly near railway stations and convenience stores, Sakai said. The company plans to sell a pack containing 17.5 ounces of beef for about $11.30, about half the price of locally produced beef. The company will install the vending machines starting next week.

DOC.HEAD: Former Vietnamese Vice Premier Dies
DOC.TEXT: Former Vietnamese Vice Premier Nguyen Lam has died of illness and old age in the capital of Hanoi, official Radio Hanoi reported. He was 68. Nguyen Lam, also a former top official of the ruling Communist Party, died Sunday in an army hospital, the radio said. A text of Monday's broadcast was seen in Bangkok on Tuesday. It said he had a serious brain infection due to many years of a cerebral blood circulation disorder. The radio quoted an official communique as saying the body will lie in state in Hanoi before being buried in a ceremony Thursday organized by senior party officials. The official Vietnam News Agency said Nguyen Lam was born Dec. 31, 1921 in the northern province of Ha Nam Ninh. It said he was a member and secretary of the party's Central Committee and was vice premier in 1976 _ a year after the Communists defeated the U.S.-backed South Vietnam government and reunified the country. The agency said Nguyen Lam had been a recipient of the Ho Chi Minh Order, the nation's highest award.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed When Military Plane Crashes Into Reservoir
DOC.TEXT: A military training plane crashed into a reservoir Tuesday during an exercise, and both the instructor and pilot were killed, the air force reported. The B-34 trainer crashed into the Tsengwen reservoir in Tainan, southern Taiwan, at about 11:30 a.m., the air force said in a brief statement. An air force official said an instructor and the pilot were the only people on board. Tainan is 185 miles south of Taipei. The cause of the accident was being investigated.

DOC.HEAD: Ancient Mosaic Stolen From Castle Floor
DOC.TEXT: A 1,300-year-old mosaic floor painting was stolen from an ancient castle, apparently by professionals who cut the 270-square-foot block into small pieces and fled without a trace, officials said Tuesday. The minister of tourism, Abdul Karim Kabariti, said the mosaic depicting a tree of life was ``priceless.'' He said the theft occurred Sunday at the Hallabat Castle, a popular tourist attraction in the northeastern desert. ``It appears to be a highly professional job,'' the minister said. ``They have left no traces whatsoever, not even tire tracks on the desert road.'' The colorful mosaic depicts a large tree surrounded by animals. It was lifted off a floor of the castle. A police expert, who cannot be identified under police regulations, said it would have ``taken at least four people to do the job.'' ``It involved applying a strong liquid glue on the surface of the mosaic, covering it with jute cloth and lifting the entire thing at one time off the floor,'' the expert said. Adnan Hadidi, former director of the Department of Antiquities, said it appeared the painting was ``cut into small blocks after it was lifted off the floor.'' Kabariti said all exit points of the kingdom, including airports and sea ports, were alerted. Authorities said there would be a reward for information leading to the recovery of the mosaic, but the amount was not disclosed. Kabariti said the work dates back to the 8th century A.D. rule of the Ummayads, an Arab dynasty based in Damascus, Syria.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Kills 4, Injures 22 in Lahore
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded in the eastern city of Lahore on Tuesday, causing four deaths and injuring 22 people, police said. No one claimed responsibility for the mid-afternoon explosion in a congested marketplace in Lahore's old city, said a police officer, who refused to be identified. The bomb was hidden in a cardboard crate left beside a fruit vendor, police said. The vendor spotted the abandoned crate and it exploded when he tried to move it, officers at the scene said. Bombs frequently explode in Pakistani cities but seldom in Lahore. Many explosions have occurred in Pakistan's Northwest Frontier Province, which houses more than 3 million Afghan refugees who fled a bloody civil war in neighboring Afghanistan. Police regularly blame those bombings on agents of Afghanistan's Communist government, a charge Afghanistan's president denies.

DOC.HEAD: Guards Retake Two-Thirds of Prison; More Inmates Surrender
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final 25th graf `The Home...' with graf to UPDATE with nine inmates involved in Long Lartin breakout attempt. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON3
DOC.TEXT: Guards drove back the last group of inmates holding a decaying Victorian prison and recaptured two-thirds of it today, while negotiators sought a peaceful end to the 3-day-old siege. Seven officers were injured trying to regain control of Strangeways Prison, said Ivor Serle, a prison guard and chairman of the local branch of the Prison Officers' Association. ``There were many broken bones, and one officer has a punctured lung,'' Serle said, adding that most of the injuries were caused by bricks, poles and other objects hurled by prisoners. There was no word on how many prisoners, if any, were injured. The guards' advance could not be seen by reporters outside the prison. At a second prison, 100 miles south of Manchester, 33 inmates who barricaded part of a building after an attempted breakout ended their protest peacefully this morning, the Home Office said. No injuries were reported. Authorities have said 56 people _ 37 inmates and 19 guards _ have been injured at Strangeways since rioting broke out at a chapel service Sunday morning. Though press reports have speculated that as many as 30 inmates had been killed, Serle said no bodies had been recovered. He said it was his ``gut feeling'' that there had been some deaths, but ``I hope to God I'm wrong.'' Thirty-five prisoners surrendered today, leaving 64 behind, a Home Office spokeswoman said. Serle said 84 inmates remained on the loose. Twenty inmates who wanted to surrender were physically prevented by other prisoners, Serle said. ``We have extended our control. Prisoners still control about one-third of the jail. They're in the upper space,'' Serle told reporters outside the prison. ``We're in control of all lower portions of the prison.'' In negotiations with prison governor Brendan O'Friel, the rebellious inmates had demanded their surrender be witnessed by a member of Parliament, and that they all be photographed to protect them from beatings afterwards, Serle said. O'Friel agreed to a request by some inmates for an independent witness to watch the surrender of prisoners, who are believed to be injured, the Home Office said. One dejected looking, bare-chested inmate, his hands bound in front of him, was led out on the prison roof this afternoon by a masked prisoner carrying a large blade. They remained outside in near-freezing weather for only a few minutes. Inmates displayed several banners on the roof of the prison including one which said ``Told We Will Die,'' and another which proclaimed ``Total War on E-Wing,'' the wing where sex offenders were held. It was not immediately clear what prompted the uprising, but one former inmate said conditions were poor. ``It's a hole, it's filthy, rotten, food is bad, it has no taste, and they treat you like dogs,'' said Mike West, who said he had been held at the prison a dozen times and was released just a week ago. ``Imagine being in a little box, two or three men, only one shower a week,'' West said in an interview outside the prison. By Monday afternoon, 1,458 inmates had been transferred to other prisons and 74 were awaiting transport, the Home Office said. The Strangeways riot began when prisoners at a religious service took keys from guards and used them to gain access to large areas of the prison. Relatives of inmates also said overcrowding added to tension at Strangeways, where up to three prisoners were housed in cells built for one. They cited unsanitary conditions, and prisoners being locked in cells for up to 23 hours a day. Red-brick Strangeways was built in 1868 to hold 970 men. It had 1,648 prisoners on Sunday. It contains inmates of all categories, from extremely dangerous to low risk. The Home Office said trouble at the minimum-security Long Lartin Prison began late Monday when inmates tried to escape. Guards stopped the convicts as they attempted to scale the 15-foot wire mesh perimeter. The guards led them back into the building without violence. But by then inmates in a wing of the low-security prison had begun demonstrating, forcing guards to retreat. The Home Office said nine prisoners were involved in the foiled breakout at the prison, which holds 430 inmates. No injuries were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Restauranteur or Restaurateur? The Latter's Preferred
DOC.TEXT: Restaurateur by any spelling, whether with an ``n'' or without, is not a favorite word of keepers of the language, according to a survey. But if they have to use the word for keeper of a restaurant, they'll take it without the ``n,'' said respondents to the 12th English language usage survey by the Indiana University School of Journalism. ``Many in the survey found it stuffy no matter how it is spelled, though its use is patently expanding in this country,'' Professor Richard L. Tobin wrote in the survey released this week. The 10-question survey was mailed to 100 newspaper copy editors and 50 magazine editors in the United States and Canada and got a 60 percent return, Tobin said. ``The consensus throughout this year's survey was mighty close to unanimous in almost every example, which just goes to show that copyreaders know what they're doing and do it like the sterling language-usage guardians they are put there to be,'' the survey said. Nearly all editors agree ``percent'' should be one word and not two. Most editors agreed the region Deep South should be uppercase. Most copydesks caught the misuse of ``tremblor'' instead of ``temblor,'' in a line from a Maryland newspaper reporting a Palm Springs earthquake. Most changed ``forego'' to ``forgo'' in the sentence: ``The university decided to forego the traditional faculty banquet because of the financial situation.'' Copydesks were asked whether ``gibe'' or ``jibe'' was correct in the following sentence: ``Three suspects were taken to police headquarters but detectives announced later that their stories didn't gibe.'' The verdict was almost unanimous that ``jibe'' was correct. ``Complacent'' was correctly preferred over ``complaisant'' in an item saying a soccer team had become ``complaisant'' after four straight victories. Most Canadians agree a person of Scottish descent is ``Scotch'' rather than ``Scot,'' which is preferred in the homeland. ``Several respondents in our survey said they'd given up trying to substitute `Scot' for `Scotch,' and anyway it really didn't matter all that much,'' the survey said. Editors chose ``theretofore'' over ``hitherto'' in the sentence: ``In 1864, President Lincoln spent the hitherto unheard of sum of $3,000,000 on naval construction.'' Almost no one chose ``peddle'' over ``pedal'' in the final question, which came from a Florida sports page: ``When you're riding a bicycle you use the brake and the peddle with caution on today's highways.''

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Kills 33 People in Punjab; Sikhs Blamed
DOC.TEXT: A bomb believed set by Sikh radicals exploded in the midst of a Hindu celebration Tuesday and killed at least 33 people, police said. Enraged Hindus went on a rampage afterward, and five police officers were reported injured. Most of the casualties from the bomb blast were Hindus, but some Sikhs who had been watching the procession were among the victims. Police said 68 people were injured in the explosion. The bomb went off as about 100,000 Hindus celebrating the birth of a god-king marched through a crowded vegetable market in Batala. The town is 25 miles north of Amritsar, the holiest Sikh city and the stronghold of Sikh militants fighting for a separate nation in Punjab state. Senior police superintendent S.K. Goel said the bomb was hidden in a scooter parked outside a cigarette kiosk. Goel said 30 of the injured were in serious condition. He said Sikh militants were probably responsible. The radicals have killed more than 500 people this year in their quest for a Sikh homeland. They are a minority in Hindu-dominated India but form the majority in Punjab, a farming state in northern India. Soon after the blast, angry Hindus went on a rampage, hurling stones at a police station near the market, said a police inspector. He said five policemen were injured. Officers fired into the air to quell the riot, and an indefinite curfew was imposed in Batala, a Hindu-dominated city of about 120,000 people. The annual procession marked Ram Navami, a Hindu holiday celebrating the birth of Rama. Rama is extolled in Hindu lore as an incarnation of Vishnu, a member of the supreme Hindu trinity of gods. Food vendor Prem Nath described the explosion from his hospital bed in Amritsar. ``There was loud sound. Then the entire area was covered with dark smoke and fire which rose as high as electric poles,'' he said. Earlier Tuesday, a bomb exploded on a bus in another town near Amritsar, killing the driver and one passenger, senior police superintendent Anil Sharma said. Police also blamed Sikh extremists for that blast. Both the victims were Sikhs. When the Sikhs began their fight in 1982, they targeted Hindus. In recent years they have turned their guns on fellow Sikhs who do not support the separatist cause. The militants say members of the Sikh faith, which has roots in both Islam and Hinduism, are discriminated against politically and culturally by the Hindu-dominated government.

DOC.HEAD: Wayward Lawyer-Pilot Released on Bond in Fraud Case
DOC.TEXT: Attorney Thomas Root was released on bond after pleading innocent to fraud and other charges Tuesday in a case his attorney said ``would not be that big a deal for the government'' if Root had not gained public attention last summer when his airplane plunged into the Atlantic Ocean. Root was released on $200,000 bond, ordered to surrender his passport and report semi-weekly by telephone to a probation officer and confined to the continental United States until a trial date is set. U.S. District Judge John Garrett Penn said he will set a trial date on April 23. Root was indicted March 22 on 20 counts of wire and mail fraud, seven counts of filing false legal documents with the Federal Communications Commission, four counts of using counterfeit and altered federal documents, and one count each of forgery and obstruction of a grand jury investigation. The charges against the Washington attorney arise out of his representation of FM radio stations seeking construction permits. If convicted of all the charges, Root, 37, would face a maximum 200 years in prison and an $8 million fine. Root's single-engine plane ran out of gasoline and plunged into the Atlantic off the Bahamas last July after a six-hour, 800-mile flight that began near Washington. He told authorities he was unconscious during most of the flight, but Navy fighter pilots flying alongside his plane reported seeing him moving about. He suffered an unexplained gunshot wound during the trip. The bond does not require Root to put up any cash, but his property could be forfeited if he violates it. Assistant U.S. Attorney David Eisenberg sought a more stringent bond, requiring Root to post $10,000. Defense attorney Eugene Propper argued that Root should be free on his own recognizance, saying the charges were ``a standard white collar case'' and ``would not be that big a deal for the government'' if the widely publicized plane ditching had not occurred. Eisenberg replied, ``It is a big deal for the government, not because somebody flew off ... but because it is a lawyer and a case of falsifying documents.'' The government attorney said that last April 24 officers serving a search warrant on Root at the nearby Manassas, Va., airport found numerous firearms, a knife, handcuffs and a marijuana leaf in and around Root's airplane. He said the weapons were not illegal, except for one unregistered silencer, but indicated that ``Root may very well be a danger to himself ... and possibly even a danger to the community.'' Propper said all of the guns were federally registered and Root loaned them to the Arlington, Va., police for target practice. He said Root kept them at the airport because he has a wife and three children at home. He said Root has since disposed of them. Root's attorney entered his plea for him. Root did not speak except to say that he understood the conditions of his release on bond. Propper asked to have the trial set six or seven months from now to give the defense time to prepare. Eisenberg said the government is ready to go to trial in 60 days to 90 days. Propper also said he needs time to consider a possible conflict of interest that could disqualify him from representing Root. He declined to say what it was. Eisenberg said Propper could be subpoeneaed to testify for the government because he may have inadvertently witnessed an attempt to interfere with justice in connection with the grand jury proceedings.

DOC.HEAD: Lava Threatens Hawaiian Neighborhood
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with lava flow slowed, homes not yet hit, picking up at the 6th graf pvs, `The second...'.
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of residents packed their belongings and left as lava from Kilauea Volcano crept to within 300 yards of their homes. Authorities had estimated the flow could reach the homes as early as today, but the lava's movement toward the Kalapana Gardens subdivision appeared to have slowed, said Hawaii County Civil Defense spokesman Bruce Butts. Civil defense officials evacuated 50 homes Monday and put all remaining residents of Kalapana Gardens on alert, meaning they could be ordered within 72 hours to evacuate. They would be given 24 hours to leave. Officials were watching two major flows from the volcano, which has erupted continually the past seven years. The flow posing the most immediate danger to the 125-home subdivision was coming from the west, said Harry Kim, Hawaii County Civil Defense Administrator. But a finger from that flow was draining into a crater almost 100 feet deep, slowing its progress, he said. Lava continued to pour into the crater early Tuesday, and Butts said it was impossible to say when the flow could reach homes as long as the diversion drained much of the power from the front of the flow. The second flow, from the east, was less than three-quarters of a mile from any residence, Kim said. Residents told to evacuate were leaving with as many possessions as they could take, and some hired container trucks to take everything they have. Many others were packing in anticipation of an eventual order to leave. ``I ran into a couple of people who didn't seem too concerned about it, but most people are concerned and moving whatever they can,'' said Civil Defense spokesman Allen Parker. Since its latest and longest eruption began in 1983, the volcano has destroyed 76 homes and a national park visitor center, causing $20 million in damage.

DOC.HEAD: Snipers Exchange Fire in Battle for Christian Sector
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian armies exchanged grenade and automatic weapons fire Tuesday in a battle for supremacy that has killed more than 800 people in two months, most of them innocent civilians. Police reported one person wounded. Christian sources said Nasrallah Sfeir, the Maronite Catholic patriarch, planned to ask Pope John Paul II to help end the fight for control of the 310-square-mile enclave north and east of Beirut, where 1 million Christians live. In Sidon, the ancient port and provincial capital 25 miles south of Beirut, three men killed a Lebanese army captain, using pistols equipped with silencers. Police said Capt. Youssef Naamani, a 32-year-old Sunni Moslem, died instantly and the motive for the attack was not known. They said the gunmen had not been identified. Automatic weapons fire and explosions of rocket-propelled grenades echoed across Christian east Beirut in exchanges between forces loyal to rebel Gen. Michel Aoun and militiamen of the Lebanese Forces, commanded by Samir Geagea. Smoke still billowed from storage depots in the Jal el-Dib suburb. The depots, containing 2.5 million gallons of fuel, were hit by phosphorous shells Monday. A three-man Christian mediation committee held separate meetings with Aoun and Geagea but made no progress toward a cease-fire. Since it began Jan. 30, the showdown between Aoun's 19,000 Christian army troopers and Geagea's 6,000 militiamen has claimed 839 lives. At least 2,291 people have been wounded. Material damage is estimated at $6 billion. The respected newspaper An-Nahar said Sfeir told the mediation committee Monday he would seek the pope's intervention if ``domestic efforts to contain the deterioratrion couldn't achieve a breakthrough.'' It said Sfeir wanted President Elias Hrawi's government, which has Syrian support, to ``spread its authority'' through the Christian enclave and halt the conflict. Syria has 40,000 soldiers in Lebanon under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate issued in 1976, a year after the Lebanese civil war began. Both belligerents and President Hrawi are Maronite Catholic, the largest Christian sect. Maronites have controlled key government posts, the army and judiciary since independence from France in 1943. Aoun does not recognize Parliament's election of Hrawi on Nov. 24 and demands changes in a peace agreement, mediated by the Arab League, that is intended to end the civil war. Parliament approved the accord in October after meetings in Taif, Saudi Arabia. Hrawi dismissed Aoun as army commander, but the general has refused to stop aside. His commands his troops from a bunker beneath the presidential palace in Baabda, a Christian suburb, where he also lives. The president has temporary offices and living quarters in Moslem west Beirut. Geagea declared in a radio interview Tuesday: ``The solution to Lebanon's crisis lies in recognition of President Hrawi as head of state.'' In an interview with the Ad-Diyar newspaper, Aoun said he sent letters proposing ``a serious dialogue'' about Lebanon to the leaders of Saudi Arabia, Morocco and Algeria, sponsors of the Taif negotiations. Foreign ministers of those countries are to meet in Rabat, Morocco, on Wednesday to consider a report from Salim Hoss, Hrawi's prime minister, on the situation in the Christian enclave. The United States and almost all nations with which Lebanon has diplomatic relations have recognized Hrawi and declared support for the Taif agreement, which provides for equal distribution of power between Moslems and Christians.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda Marcos: From ``Mother Of The Nation'' To Criminal Defendant
With AM-Marcos Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: During her husband's 20-year rule, Imelda Marcos was praised by a controlled media as the ``Mother of the Nation.'' On Tuesday, the widow of former President Ferdinand Marcos went on trial in federal court in New York as an accused embezzler and racketeer, facing up to 50 years in prison and fines up to $1 million if convicted. Mrs. Marcos is accused of taking part in the illegal transfer of $160 million from the Philippines and defrauding financial institutions of $165 million to finance the purchase of New York properties. Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi is accused of helping. Marcos died in September in Hawaii where he lived since he was ousted four years ago in the popular uprising that propelled Corazon Aquino to the presidency. ``The story of the Marcoses illustrates very vividly how fame, riches and power can build, then destroy,'' wrote the Philippine Daily Inquirer. ``It shows that wealth is no insurance for security, peace of mind and happiness.'' Mrs. Marcos had led a fairytale life, a glamorous beauty born in near poverty who used charm and steely determination to become one of the richest and most powerful women in the world. Imelda Remedios Visitacion Romualdez was born July 2, 1929, in Manila to Vicente Romualdez, a lawyer, and his wife, Remedios. Although the family was prominent, Imelda's father failed in several business ventures and the family often struggled to survive. At age 26, after romances with several prominent Filipinos _ including Mrs. Aquino's future husband, Benigno Aquino Jr. _ Imelda met and married Marcos, a rising political star 11 years her senior. She had three children: Imelda or ``Imee'' in 1955, Ferdinand Jr. in 1958, and Irene in 1960. Mrs. Marcos soon became her husband's indefatigable campaigner, charming audiences with her beauty and singing. When Marcos was elected president in 1965, he credited Imelda with drawing a million votes. Mrs. Marcos boasted she needed only a few hours sleep each night. ``We all wake up with the same energy,'' she once told The Associated Press. ``But for me, the moment I see beautiful flowers, a beautiful smile, a beautiful deed ... this energizes me, so by the time it's midnight I am just ready to take off.'' As first lady, her power and influence in the Philippines became second only to that of Marcos, especially after he declared eight years of martial law in 1972. In 1978, Mrs. Marcos won a seat in the National Assembly, defeating Aquino who campaigned from his jail cell. Aquino later went into exile in Boston, and was assassinated in 1983 moments after returning to the Philippines to challenge the Marcoses for national leadership. Marcos also named his wife ``presidential envoy plenipotentiary,'' and she made as many as 15 trips a year to confer with world leaders. Mrs. Marcos was credited with improving relations with the Soviet Union and China, negotiating oil deals with Mexico and cooling the Philippines Moslem rebellion by a meeting with Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. She so deeply charmed Cuban President Fidel Castro that he once told her admiringly: ``My lady, what is there that you cannot do?'' She had a fondness for American movie stars, including her close friend George Hamilton. As her influence grew, she declared that she would commit her life to improving Filipino culture, beautifying cities and towns and improving the lot of the impoverished masses. As the appointed governor of Metro Manila, Mrs. Marcos built a $10 million cultural center on reclaimed land in Manila Bay. She also built bridges, schools, hotels and hospitals. In her post of minister of Human Settlements, she built thousands of houses, planted hundreds of thousands of trees and loaned money for small-scale livelihood projects. Critics charged Mrs. Marcos used her trips abroad for massive spending sprees in fashionable boutiques. She frequently flew to the fun spots of the world, often with an entourage known as the ``Blue Ladies'' because of their dress.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Bush Says Double Vision Gone
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush said Tuesday that she no longer suffers double vision caused by Graves disease. ``Last week was the first week without seeing double,'' she told reporters at the White House. ``I think the radiation worked. That's very good news.'' However, Mrs. Bush said she had not been evaluated recently by specialists. She said she believes radiation treatment she underwent in January has affected the vision problem. Aides had said it would take two to four months before it would be known if the treatment was effective. Mrs. Bush was diagnosed early last year with Graves disease, an immune system disorder that initially attacked her thyroid, causing dramatic weight loss. It caused eye irritation and double vision, especially in the morning. The first lady chatted with two reporters Tuesday morning after she surprised tourists, showing up in the White House main foyer where the tours pass. Mrs. Bush decided to conduct a small ceremony at the foot of the grand staircase to receive the new editions of ``The Presidents of the United States'' and ``The First Ladies'' from White House Historical Association president Robert L. Breeden. About 200 tourists shushed one another and strained to hear Breeden and Mrs. Bush in the large, drafty foyer. Mrs. Bush autographed several copies of the books. She opened to a page with her husband's picture and held it up for the crowd's applause. When Breeden held up the page with her photograph, she wrinkled her nose and said, ``Yuck.'' After trying unsuccessfully to coax the family dog, Millie, down the stairs, Mrs. Bush joked: ``She doesn't like tourists. I do.'' Mrs. Bush said she was glad to be asked about her health, saying reports she is not doing well are fabricated. She has acknowledged frustration with the stubborn eye irritation, which persisted even after the thyroid condition improved. Doctors prescribed the steroid prednisone to treat her eyes, resorting to radiation treatments when the drugs had no effect.

DOC.HEAD: Not Many Humming `Lovely Rita, Meter Maid' On Seattle Streets
