Armored patrols moved through Edendale Valley in the southeastern province, where a 4-year-old battle for supremacy between two rival black groups has grown to virtual civil war. Police said at least 55 people had been killed in the past week. University of Natal researchers put the death toll at 80 and accused Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu group, of ``a systematic, coordinated and concerted onslaught.'' Another police report Tuesday said 13 more people had been killed, most of them in black factional fighting elsewhere in the country, but gave few details. The struggle in Natal is between Inkatha, headed by Zulu homeland leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi, and supporters of Mandela's African National Congress guerrilla movement. After a two-dy visit to troubled black townships in Natal, Mandela said Tuesday it was ``encouraging to see'' President F.W. de Klerk ``concerned about the situation.'' He added, however: ``Unilateral action by the government without consulting acknowledged (black) leaders is bound to be ineffective, regardless of merit.'' De Klerk and Mandela are scheduled to meet Thursday about ways to stop the worst outbreak of violence in South Africa since the mid-1980s. Hundreds of people have been killed in the past two months. Mandela said many of his supporters believe the police support Inkatha. ``There is a deeply entrenched perception that the police are directly involved in the violence that is raging in this province,'' he said. About 4,000 people have been killed in Natal since 1986, but there have been few prosecutions. Most neutral observers have blamed both Inkatha and ANC supporters for the violence. The University of Natal researchers claimed Inkatha was responsible for the latest fighting. They said more than 2,000 ``Inkatha warriors'' took part in one attack last week. Mandela defended the ANC decision to cancel April 11 peace talks with the government. The cancellation was to protest the killing of at least 11 blacks when police fired on demonstrators March 26 at Sebokeng, a township south of Johannesburg. If whites had been killed, ``white South Africa would be screaming at the top of its voice, but because it's blacks, whites think it is not important,'' he said. More than 12,000 refugees, most of them women and children, have fled the Edendale area and are being sheltered in camps, police reported. They said rival mobs had burned hundreds of houses in the area. Civil servants continued strikes Tuesday in the Gazankulu and Venda black homelands. Officials in Gazankulu said 29 people were killed and more than 200 huts burned during unrest last month. On Monday, de Klerk ordered a major effort by security forces to end the violence in Natal and elsewhere. Measures include reinforcing army and police units, setting up roadblocks, arresting more people and arranging for extra courts to handle cases related to the unrest. De Klerk legalized the ANC and other outlawed black opposition groups in February and released Mandela, who had spent 27 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: 20,000 Australians To Die This Year From Smoking, Conference Told
DOC.TEXT: A government study released Tuesday said 20,000 Australians will die this year from diseases related to smoking, an increase of more than 10 percent in three years. ``Tobacco is the leading addictive substance causing death and premature mortality in Australia,'' said the study by the Health Department of the state of Western Australia. The study was released at the opening of the seventh World Conference on Smoking and Health. It also said 9,652 smokers in Australia will develop cancer this year and that 100,000 others will be hospitalized with other health problems. Australians will lose 100,000 premature years of life from smoking in 1990 alone, the study said. Federal Health Minister Dr. Neal Blewett, among 800 experts from 70 countries at the conference, said 18,000 Australians died during 1987 as a direct result of smoking. The figure represents 71 percent of all drug-caused deaths, he said. In a keynote address at the four-day conference, Blewett said lung cancer caused by cigarette smoking is set to overtake breast cancer as the most common form of malignancy among Australian women by the early 1990s. He said that while lung cancer mortality rates among men had fallen over the last 30 years, the death rate among women continued to rise. Blewett said Australia was at the forefront of the battle against tobacco, which led the Labor government of Prime Minister Bob Hawke to ban smoking in all federal buildings, federally controlled hospitals and on domestic flights.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Envoy Says Army, Not Gorbachev May Be in Control
With AM-US-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's chief diplomat said Tuesday he believes the Soviet army may have taken the lead role from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in dealing with his country's independence crisis. Stasys Lozaraitis Jr., told a news conference that the Soviet military show of force in Lithuania has made him more pessimistic than before about his country's fate and added: ``Maybe the army is very unhappy with the situation in the Baltic and is doing something he cannot control and cannot stop,'' Lozaraitis said, referring to the closing of Lithuania's borders with Poland, the seizure of government offices and the buildup of troops and armored vehicles. ``I don't know if Mr. Gorbachev is really in control of these actions,'' he said. Lozaraitis, who is Lithuania's envoy in the United States, has been made his country's ambassador-at-large. He has been authorized to act for the Lithuanian parliament if it has been silenced. During a news conference at the former Lithuanian Embassy here, Lozaraitis said he is disappointed with Western Europe's lukewarm support for his country's declaration of independence. Lozaraitis, who returned this week from a trip through both Western and Eastern Europe, said support for Lihuanian independence is far greater in the East. ``I have the impression that in Western Europe they were living in a very calm, pacific period and they were getting rich _ and that these upheavals in Eastern Europe are worrying them,'' he said. ``They think any change in Eastern Europe is frightfully dangerous,'' he said. ``There are sympathetic attitudes, but great caution.'' He called on President Bush to indicate more clearly that he supports Lithuanian independence and to grant formal diplomatic recognition. He said he is ready to discuss Lithuania's fate directly with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze who is here to hold talks with President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``If he wants to see me, I'm here and I will be very glad to meet him,'' Lozaraitis said. ``I am today not so optimistic because I don't understand Mr. Gorbachev,'' he said. ``I think he is acting like a man with the mentality of the 19th century. You don't solve a problem with troops and armored cars.'' Lithuania is ready for a full discussion of all issues with Moscow but will not renounce independence, Lozaraitis said. ``If we were to renounce independence it would be like saying, `Shoot yourself; kill yourself; and then come to talk to us,''' he said and added: ``We can't do that.'' He said Moscow's call on Lithuania to follow the new Soviet law of secession is ``a trap'' because of its requirements of a two-thirds approval vote by Lithuanian voters and the Soviet parliament followed by a five-year waiting period. ``They ask us, `why not wait?''' he said. ``We have waited for years and years.'' ``If independence were reverse, everything we did for the last 50 years has no significance,'' he said. ``We can't discuss this fundamental and essential question.'' But he made clear Lithuania is willing to slow the process if Moscow needs time for its own internal political reasons. ``If Moscow needs time let them sit down and tell us about it,'' he said. In the meantime, he said, the Lithuanian people will exercise patience and restraint. ``We will wait, we will have very strong nerves, we will not do anything violent, we will not be provoked,'' Lozaraitis said.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Buying New Sorting Machines
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Postal Service board of governors approved spending $379.3 million Tuesday on new letter sorting machines. The board, meeting in Raleigh, N.C., voted to launch the program that will lead to bar-coding of all mail by 1995. Bar codes are a series of thin lines, similar to those used in supermarket pricing. The money approved Tuesday will cover purchase of 1,349 automatic bar-code reading machines which can sort mail carrying the codes. It is the first of a three-phase program to make the coding universal. Bar codes already are being used in sorting much business mail, and the company sending the mail applies the codes in the lower corner of the letter. The new machines will be able to read a code anywhere on the face of the letter, an advantage which is expected to encourage more businesses to use the codes. Individuals will not be expected to place barcodes on their mail. However, by the mid-1990s the postal service will begin placing the codes on letters that do not have them to allow the material to be sorted by machine.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Defends Iraq's Stand on Chemical Weapons
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's declaration that it possesses advanced chemical weapons is part of the legitimate right of self-defense, King Hussein said Tuesday. PLO chief Yasser Arafat also supported President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, who said Monday that Iraq possessed deadly nerve gas weapons and would use them to destroy half of Israel if the Israelis attacked. Saddam said Iraq developed the weapons during its eight-year war with Iran, in which a cease-fire was reached in August 1988, but did not use them. ``It is Iraq's legitimate right to defend itself against any assault aimed at its existance and its development,'' King Hussein said in remarks distributed Tuesday by Petra, the official Jordanian news agency. ``President Saddam Hussein did not direct any threats against anybody, but he affirmed his capabilities to face any concealed aggression,'' said the king, who supported Iraq in the war with Iran. The Iraq News Agency quoted Arafat as saying in Tunis, where the Palestine Liberation Organization has its headquarters: ``We say to our brother Saddam, go ahead. God save you. We are all with you until the Palestinian flag flutters above the liberated walls of Jerusalem.'' King Hussein and Saddam are said to be close and often exchange private visits. With Egypt and North Yemen, they formed an economic alliance in February 1989 called the Arab Cooperation Council. Jordanian television said foreign ministers of the council nations would hold ``an emergency meeting in Amman Thursday to discuss the British campaign against Iraq and other threats against Arab nations.'' In his remarks, the king criticized Israel for not signing the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, unlike Iraq, ``which was keen to join and endorse'' the agreement. Despite this, he said, criticism is directed at Iraq instead of Israel, ``the only nuclear state in the Middle East ... which simply means that there are planned hostile intentions behind this campaign.'' He said the campaign was a result of Iraq's ``victory in defending its national soil and the Arab regimes.'' Hussein's apparent reference was to British criticism of Iraq's execution of Farzad Bazoft, an Iranian-born British journalist convicted last month of spying for Britain and Israel. Britain also deported an Iraqi Airlines official accused of involvement in an attempt to smuggle trigger devices to Iraq that could be used in nuclear weapons. The alleged smuggling plot was uncovered by a joint U.S.-British operation. Iraq denied it was developing the ability to make nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Mud Keeps Flying in Texas Gubernatorial Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `Earlier, White...', to CLARIFY that White wouldn't say whether he would vote for Republican or sit fall election out if Richards nominated.
DOC.TEXT: The runoff campaign between two Democrats vying for governor began with talk of a peace treaty. But that didn't last long. Heading into the April 10 primary runoff, Treasurer Ann Richards and Attorney General Jim Mattox have attacked each other on personal finances and drug use, with only a gaffe by the Republican candidate to remind them of their common foe. The two cannot even agree on when to disagree in a debate. ``If Ann Richards is not tough enough to stand up and debate Jim Mattox and to answer the questions that are on the voters' minds, how is she going to be tough enough to stand up to the problems facing our state?'' demanded Mattox, who has accused Ms. Richards of refusing to debate him to avoid questions about drugs. Ms. Richards said she isn't trying to duck anything except the mud being thrown by Mattox. ``This campaign has taken on the predictable form that Jim Mattox campaigns always take. Whatever trash he can throw to try to detract from his poor performance, he will do that, and I expect it to continue until election day,'' she said. The ugly tone followed a bruising primary in which Ms. Richards narrowly edged Mattox, 39 percent to 37 percent. The primary dashed the comeback hopes of the third-place finisher, former Gov. Mark White, who was so upset he called a news conference today to bitterly denounce Ms. Richards. He said her tactics ``would make Himmler blush,'' alluding to the Nazi leader Heinrich Himmler. ``I will never endorse Ann Richards. I will never support Ann Richards. And I will never vote for Ann Richards,'' White told a Capitol news conference. He stopped short short of endorsing Mattox over Ms. Richards in the Democratic runoff, but did say he would be voting in that race. Earlier, White met with GOP nominee Clayton Williams. He said today his pledge not to vote for Ms. Richards would stand if she is the nominee in the fall, but he declined to specify whether he would vote for Williams or just sit the election out. Peace talks between the Mattox and Richards campaigns began shortly after the March 13 vote and went well enough that Texas Democratic Chairman Bob Slagle voiced optimism that the runoff would be ``a positive campaign.'' But their attacks have grown more bruising. Mattox has accused Ms. Richards of using illegal drugs 10 years ago. He offered no evidence but said his opponent must address the issue. ``She doesn't want to give a simple yes or no about cocaine, about marijuana, about other hallucinogens. She must answer what she used, how much, for how long and who supplied them,'' he said. The 56-year-old Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, passed a drug test and challenged Mattox to do the same. She also asked Mattox to follow her example and disclose his income tax returns. Ms. Richards said there are tough questions that Mattox is ducking _ such as how he could borrow $1.4 million on a $75,000 government salary. Neither of the survivors has developed a clear lead heading into the runoff. Downplaying the campaign's tone, Democratic leaders say either Ms. Richards or Mattox will make a better candidate than Williams, who is trying to escape the fallout from a remark he made March 24 likening bad weather to rape. ``If it's inevitable, just relax and enjoy it,'' Williams said during a cattle roundup. Although he apologized a day later, women's groups have protested and Mattox and Richards sharply criticized the Republican. ``Clayton Williams' campfire gaffe is just the tip of the iceberg, and after his so-called joke people are going to be looking very closely at him,'' said Ed Martin, the state Democratic party's executive director. It was one of the few things on which the two Democratic gubernatorial hopefuls agreed.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Takes Iraq Threat Seriously, But No Action Likely Now
With AM-Israel-Satellite, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto TLV1
DOC.HEAD: AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Israel is taking seriously Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's threat to use chemical weapons, with some officials calling for a gas mask in every house. But the new Middle East tensions are not likely to produce any immediate military conflict. One reason is that the signals coming from Israeli officials indicate there will be no attempt at this point to launch a pre-emptive strike like the June 1981 air raid on Iraq's Osirak nuclear plant. ``I think the message here is: cool things down, don't get into unnecessary escalation and a misreading of intentions,'' said Dore Gold, a Middle East analyst at Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies. Officials in Jerusalem have issued statements stressing Israel has ``no aggressive intentions'' and noting a pre-emptive strike would not be risk-free as it was in 1981 because Iraq now has missiles and warplanes that could reach Israel. Also, while there is concern about Iraq's nuclear program, it does not seem to be on the verge of producing an atomic weapon as Israel claimed in 1981. Jaffee Center expert Joe Alpher said Iraq's nuclear development was five to 10 years away while Space Agency head Yuval Neeman estimated that it was three to five years in the offing. Israel's reaction, for now, appeared confined to a strong showing of its technological superiority _ the launch of the Ofek-2 satellite, which required a powerful missile and sophisticated electronic capabilities. Analysts in Israel believe Iraq is also unlikely to initiate a military action because it would invite massive Israeli retaliation. ``I don't think the Iraqi motivation for this verbal escalation is a desire to fight with Israel at this point,'' said Alpher. ``It seems to us that the Iraqis are more concerned with the internal situation in Iraq,'' he added, suggesting the sharpness of Saddam's threat to ``eat half of Israel'' may have been an attempt to divert attention from social unrest at home. Writing in the liberal Haaretz newspaper, military commentator Zeev Shiff said Saddam's tough words may have been ill temper over the arrest in Britain of his agents who were while trying to smuggle electronic triggers that could be used for atomic weapons. Alpher said the Iraqi president's record was a reason for concern, both because he has used chemical weapons in the past and because he ignored the high costs in starting a war with Iran. ``Because he is unpredictable and has a record for taking on more than he can chew, we have to be concerned and be prepared and to take him seriously,'' said Alpher said. Gold said the Iraqi leader's remarks should shift the focus of concern away from the Palestinian uprising to the overall Arab-Israeli conflict. ``Saddam Hussein has thrust the larger Arab-Israeli conflict back onto the world agenda after the intefadeh (Palestinian uprising) seemed to put it into eclipse,'' he said. ``It will require reassessment by both the United States and Israel of how to cope with the security challenge posed by Iraq,'' he added. Right-wing politicians like Foreign Minister Moshe Arens picked up on the theme, saying the real obstacle to peace was Arab radicalism and not Israeli settlement building in Jerusalem and the West Bank. ``Where is the obstacle to peace in the Middle East?'' Arens asked a mayors' conference. ``Is it in Jerusalem? ... Or is it in Baghdad when Saddam Hussein says he has the chemical weaponry to wipe half of Israel off the earth?'' Although the threat of military conflict seemed distant, a variety of officials stressed that Israel should step up its preparedness. Michael Dekel, an aide to caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, urged the government to order the immediate disribution of gas masks to every home. For the past two years, Israel has been holding drills to train the 1.5 million school children about defense against chemical weapon attack. It issued gas masks throughout two towns on an experimental basis. The Israeli army has protective clothing for gas attacks, but the current instructions for civilians are to remain indoors, seal a room as much as possible and put on a gas mask. Even new Israeli telephone books give instructions on what to do in case of a gas attack. Dekel said Iraq's threats meant the program should be speeded up. ``We need to prepare the civilian population, not only with practice, but with equipment in the case of surprise attack,'' he said.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Nicolas B. Tatro, Associated Press bureau chief in Jerusalem, has covered the Middle East since 1977.

DOC.HEAD: Voters to Decide on Wisconsin Gov.'s Veto Power; Supreme Court Justice
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close in Kansas City at 7 p.m. EDT; at 8 p.m. EDT in Wisconsin, St. Louis and Tulsa; Matter below the dash will stand.
DOC.TEXT: Wisconsin voters went to the polls Tuesday to decide whether to limit the governor's unusually strong veto power and whether a state Supreme Court justice should be replaced by a deaf challenger. In northern Wisconsin, state Rep. Jim Holperin faced Republican Brian Sherren in a recall election stemming from a sometimes violent dispute over Indians' rights to hunt, fish and cut timber outside their reservations. On ballots elsewhere were a trash recycling proposal in Kansas City, Mo., and a plan to increase St. Louis' hotel-motel tax by 3.5 percent to help fund a planned 70,000-seat, $250 million domed stadium. In Bismarck, N.D., 18-year-old high school senior Lee Palmer was among three candidates running for mayor. In Tulsa, Okla., 20 people sought nine city council seats and two ran for mayor in a new strong mayor-council form of government. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed a lawsuit claiming the old commission form of government denied blacks a voice in decision-making. Wisconsin's so-called ``Vanna White veto'' has allowed Gov. Tommy G. Thompson to rewrite legislation by striking words and even letters, punctuation and numerals. Foes of the veto power _ nicknamed for the letter-flipping hostess of the television game show ``Wheel of Fortune'' _ said it gives legislative power to the executive branch, violating the constitutional separation of powers. A constitutional amendment on Tuesday's ballot would bar the governor from using his veto to strike letters to change the meaning of legislation. The governor could still strike words, numerals or entire sentences. In Wisconsin's state Supreme Court race, state Appeals Judge Richard Brown, who is deaf, challenged Justice Donald Steinmetz for a 10-year term. Brown's deafness wasn't an issue, but the unusually hotly contested campaign included sparring over abortion, court workloads and campaign funding. In northern Wisconsin, state Rep. Jim Holperin faced Republican Brian Sherren in a recall sparked by critics of Chippewa spearfishing who said Holperin had lost touch with his constituents over the issue that has caused five years of unrest _ Indian treaty rights.

The first-term Republican governor defended his authority to selectively eliminate letters and urged voters to retain it. The state constitution gives the governor the right to veto any appropriation bill ``in part.'' Thompson's most famous ``Vanna veto'' was when he reworked a bill in 1988 that limited the time a juvenile could be held in detention to 48 hours. The governor boosted the limit to 10 days by crossing out ``48 hours'' and most of the bill's next four lines, leaving intact only the word ``day'' and four other strategically placed letters: ``t-e-n day-s.'' The governor's record 290 partial vetoes in the 1987-89 state budget _ many of which changed appropriations bills by striking numbers and letters or merging words _ so angered Democrats that they sued Thompson. In 1988, they lost in the state Supreme Court. Supreme Court challenger Brown, a district judge since 1978, accused incumbent Steinmetz, 65, of backing out of a televised debate because he didn't want to discuss abortion, the environment and the Supreme Court workload. Steinmetz said the judicial code of ethics prevented him from stating his personal position of issues, but he was endorsed by the political action committee on Wisconsin Right to Life. The Wisconsin recall was rooted in a 1983 federal court ruling that said Wisconsin's six Chippewa bands retained the right to fish, hunt, cut timber and gather food on off-reservation public lands under 19th-century treaties that ceded northern Wisconsin to the U.S. government. The ruling is under appeal. Recall organizers, primarily Stop Treaty Abuse-Wisconsin, were especially critical of Holperin's support last year for a 10-year, multimillion-dollar payment to the Lac du Flambeau Chippewa in return for the band limiting their exercise of treaty rights. The tribe rejected the pact. On March 6, Holperin got 69 percent of the vote in winning a Democratic recall primary. Afterward, Holperin's defeated opponent said people were not as upset about treaty rights as he had thought. In North Dakota, Palmer entered the race at the urging of his Bismarck High School journalism class because he was willing to run for mayor and met the minimum age requirement.

DOC.HEAD: International Olympic Committee Member Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to CORRECT Alexander's age to 75, sted 86. Pickup 5th graf `Alexander entered...'
DOC.TEXT: Reginald S. Alexander, a politician, sports enthusiast and longtime member of the International Olympics Committee, has died of an undisclosed illness, relatives said Tuesday. He was 75. A family member said Alexander's will directed there be no published obituary. She declined further comment. A Kenyan sports official, who asked not to be further identified, said Alexander died Saturday in a Nairobi hospital, where he had been hospitalized nearly a week. Alexander was born Nov. 14, 1914 in Nairobi, the capital of what was then the British colony of Kenya. He served in the Royal Air Force during World War II. Alexander entered local politics after returning to Naibori, first in 1948 as a Nairobi city legislator and then as mayor of the city in 1954. When Kenya gained independence from Britain in 1963, Alexander served four years in Parliament. Alexander was best known for his enthusiasm for the development of sports. Kenya is known worldwide for its athletes, especially distance runners. Alexander was a founding member in 1954 of the Kenya Olympics and Commonwealth Games Association and served as its chairman up to 1968. The organization later changed its name to the Kenya Olympics Association. He led the East African nation's first Olympics team to Melbourne, Australia, in 1956 and joined the IOC executive board in 1972. He was also a successful businessman in Kenya's tourism and oil industries. Alexander's wife, Marie, died two years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sequesters Poindexter Jury After Phone Calls From Reporters
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs graf 13, Kaiser said, to CORRECT statement that Kaiser called judge.
DOC.TEXT: Two jurors deliberating Iran-Contra charges against John Poindexter were contacted by the news media, the trial judge disclosed today. He ordered the jury sequestered because of the ``irresponsible behavior of the press.'' U.S. District Judge Harold Greene said the jurors hung up on the reporters. They were ``alert and intelligent,'' he said. Greene ruled that the jurors, Leroy Witherspoon and William Harris, would continue to participate in the deliberations, which began Monday. Poindexter's lawyer, Richard Beckler, said he had no objection. The judge said that ``some now might think this'' contact during jury deliberations ``was an obstruction of justice. I will think about that.'' Witherspoon told a hearing today that Washington Post reporter Nora Boustany telephoned him late Monday afternoon just as he arrived home from jury deliberations. He said she wanted to know when the jury would deliver a verdict. He hung up on her, but she called back. He hung up again, he testified. Greene said he was told the reporter had just come to the United States from Lebanon and didn't know the ``ground rules.'' Greene called that ``a lame excuse.'' ``I have no confidence that these rules will be obeyed,'' said Greene. ``I understand the Post has many more reporters ready to call the jurors,'' said the judge. ``None of us has any confidence that these regulations will be observed.'' ``I have decided to sequester the jury,'' Greene said. ``The irresponsible behavior of the press leaves me no alternative.'' Asked about Boustany's call to the juror, Bob Kaiser, the Post's assistant managing editor for national news, said, ``She made a mistake.'' Kaiser said editors instructed Boustany to find out how to get in touch with Witherspoon after the verdict was decided in the trial. ``She did this by calling him up to ask him,'' said Kaiser. ``We immediately called Judge Green's chambers to tell them what had happened and to apologize,'' Kaiser said. Kaiser said the second juror was not contacted by a Post reporter. Harris said he hung up on a woman who called Monday night identifying herself as a reporter. It was not immediately known what news organization she represented. The judge's order means that jurors will be brought to the U.S. courthouse each day by deputy U.S. marshals and will be housed at a hotel by the government until they reach a verdict. Jurors deliberated for four hours Monday afternoon after receiving final instructions about the law from Greene. Their first note to the judge requested more than 50 trial exhibits admitted into evidence during the three-week trial, as well as copies of the judge's instructions and the five-count indictment against Poindexter. Poindexter, who was national security adviser to then-President Reagan from late 1985 to November 1986, is accused of five counts of conspiracy to obstruct Congress, making false statements to lawmakers and obstructing congressional inquiries. The indictment charges that he lied to congressional committees by denying in 1986 that White House aide Oliver L. North was orchestrating private military aid to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels at a time direct U.S. assistance was banned by Congress. After the U.S.-Iran arms-for-hostages deals were disclosed in the fall of that year, Poindexter is accused of lying to Congress by saying he was unaware of a 1985 shipment of Hawk anti-aircraft missiles to Iran until two months after it occurred. Prosecutors contended that Poindexter lied about this shipment to conceal the existence of a politically embarrassing document signed by Reagan that described the arms deal as part of an effort to free U.S. hostages believed to be held in Lebanon. The prosecution argued that Poindexter tore up the document after lying to Congress to prevent its disclosure just eight days after the president assured the American people he had not traded arms for hostages. Beckler argued that Poindexter did everything he could to give Congress the facts it sought, denying that his client ever broke the law.

DOC.HEAD: Estonia Supports Lithuania and Calls for End to Military Pressure
DOC.TEXT: Estonia declared support Tuesday for the declaration of independence by its Baltic neighbor, Lithuania, and appealed to Mikhail S. Gorbachev to end military and political pressure against Lithuania. The Estonian Supreme Soviet, or parliament, also elected Edgar Savisaar, the chairman of the Estonian People's Front, as premier. That effectively put the Estonian government in the hands of the grassroots political movement that has been pressing for independence. Savisaar, 40, a former teacher and member of the Estonian Planning Commission, received 54 votes, one more than he needed for a majority in the 105-member assembly. Savisaar told deputies he would present a list of Cabinet members next week and pledged cooperation with all ethnic groups. But sources said the new government is unlikely to include any of the 27 legislators representing the non-Estonian population. Tensions between ethnic Estonians, who make up some 60 percent of Estonia's 1.6 million people, and the other nationalities were apparent in Tuesday's session. Delegations from the northeast city of Sillamae, a largely Slavic area, said they would not accept a declaration by the Supreme Soviet on Friday that Estonia is an occupied state. They also called on Gorbachev to protect the rights of all Soviet citizens. Estonia said it would seek to re-establish independence at the end of a still-undefined transition period. Viktor Andreyev, deputy chairman of the Estonian Supreme Soviet, said he would demand a referendum if Estonia pushes for independence. Unlike Lithuania, the Estonians are treading a more careful line on secession and have called on Moscow to start negotiations. But they gave their backing to Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. They said the realization of independence was not a domestic matter of the Soviet Union, ``but a matter of international character.'' The Estonian Supreme Soviet urged Gorbachev to support negotiations ``on an equal footing'' between the Soviet Union and the Lithuania. ``It is necessary to stop without delay the military pressure from the Soviet side and political provocations, the purpose of which ... is to perpetuate the occupation of the Lithuanian republic,'' the declaration said. Moscow has set armored vehicles rumbling through the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius, and has arrested a handful of the hundreds of Lithuanian deserters who have left the Soviet military. The Estonian declaration, adopted 71-22, also offered Estonia's cooperation with Lithuania but did not elaborate. On Monday, legislators decided not to participate in debate in the national Supreme Soviet parliament in Moscow on legislation concerning the status of Soviet republics and secession. ``That would amount to recognition of the illegal annexation of the republic of Estonia,'' a Supreme Soviet statement said. Instead, the legislature decided to send two observers to the talks. Tiit Made, an independent deputy and leading economic reformer, said he did not believe Moscow would use force to stop the Baltic drive for independence. ``What can they do to us? No, the tanks won't come,'' Made said. ``We have put the idea to Moscow and now we just have to wait long enough for them to think it's their own.'' The three Baltic republics, including Latvia, were independent from the end of World War I until Josef Stalin annexed them in 1940. Savisaar ran unopposed, but other candidates would have been nominated if he did not receive a majority vote. Savisaar replaces Indrik Toome, elected head of the Supreme Soviet's foreign affairs committee on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The results of the latest poll are in on the saga of the divorcing billionaire: thumbs up for Ivana Trump and a mixed bag for Donald. The alleged other woman, Marla Maples, gets massacred. Twelve percent of those questioned said they think very favorably of The Donald, the nickname Mrs. Trump favors, and 30 percent said they regard Trump in a mostly favorable light. The Gallup Organization conducted the poll of New York City residents for New York Newsday. But 19 percent of the 1,010 respondents had very unfavorable impressions of Trump, while 17 percent were mostly unfavorable, Newsday reported Tuesday. Nineteen percent had no opinion. And, in an indication that a self-promoter's work is never done, 3 percent said they'd never heard of Trump, who has his name on apartment houses, casinos, an airline and hotel. ``It seems to show his name is bigger than ever,'' a Trump spokesman said. The jilted Mrs. Trump scored very favorable responses from 14 percent and mostly favorable from 34 percent. Twelve percent fell into the ``mostly unfavorable'' category and 9 percent had very unfavorable feelings. Four percent claimed never to have heard of her. The rest had no opinion. Maples, alleged Trump mistress, apparently has no reason to emerge from hiding. Her unfavorable rating was a combined 41 percent, versus 14 percent in the favorable category. Thirty-one percent couldn't rate Maples, 14 percent never heard of her. Maples' agent, Chuck Jones, blamed press coverage. Ivana Trump aides weren't talking.

The judge who ordered Zsa Zsa Gabor to work at a women's shelter as part of her sentence for hitting a policeman wants a detailed accounting of her hours of community service. ``Kindly send me copies of all records kept to document her community service activities as to dates, times and activities performed,'' Municipal Judge Charles Rubin wrote to the director of the homeless shelter. In the letter released Monday, Rubin gave Vera Davis, executive director of the Venice-area LIEU-CAP shelter until April 13 to document Miss Gabor's work there. Ms. Davis filed a three-paragraph letter with the court Friday stating Miss Gabor completed her 120 hours of community service but provided no detail. Last month, the shelter director said Miss Gabor worked about 50 hours at the center but completed the rest of her sentence through guest appearances and in planning a June 8 celebrity auction at her Bel-Air home to benefit the shelter. Deputy District Attorney Elden Fox said substituting guest appearances and the auction for hands-on shelter work was unacceptable. Miss Gabor was convicted Sept. 29 for slapping Officer Paul Kramer during a traffic stop. She also was convicted of driving without a license and having an open container of alcohol in her Rolls-Royce. She was sentenced to four days in jail, but that portion of the sentence is being appealed.

Scott Carpenter, one of America's first astronauts, says the United States needs to embark on a new space mission _ to planet Earth. The astronaut-aquanaut told a Hastings College audience Monday that if the world doesn't take action soon to preserve the forests, air, streams and oceans of ``spaceship Earth,'' life as we know it will not survive. Carpenter said viewing Earth from the window of his spacecraft in 1962 allowed him to see the grand order of the universe and the ``excruciating beauty but extreme fragility'' of the planet.

People who want to change society violently and those with a peaceful approach are worlds apart, says philosopher and author Sissela Bok. Mrs. Bok was interviewed Monday by public television executive Bill Moyers at the 41st annual meeting of the Council of Foundations. More than 1,800 philanthropists from around the world are attending the three-day meeting of the organization for more than 1,000 American philanthropies and grant-makers, who want to promote organized philanthropy. ``The greatest difference in the world is not so much the balance between East and West, or the different religions, but within each tradition between those who want to take a violent road to social change and those who want to take a non-violent approach,'' said Mrs. Bok. She is author of ``A Strategy for Peace,'' teaches philosophy at Brandeis University, and is the wife of Harvard University President Derek Bok.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Figure skaters Katarina Witt and Brian Boitano, rehearsing for their upcoming 34-city international tour, say there's a special chemistry in their performance on ice. Boitano said they anticipate each other's movements and share similar feelings about how the partner's role fits in with his or her own. ``The way we conceive of each part is the same,'' Boitano said. ``So if I say, `I really feel like I'm doing this,'' she'll go, `I feel the same way.' And when I look at her I can see that she feels the same way.'' ``In some ways, we are the same,'' Witt added. ``We always want to be good, to be perfect. We put a lot of heart into the skating.'' Boitano, of the United States, and Witt, of East Germany, began two weeks of rehearsals here Monday preparing for the show in which the reigning Olympic gold medalists will skate together for the first time before a live audience. The skaters won gold medals in the 1988 Olympics in Calgary.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Bill Cosby wears Ramon Ramos' jersey on this week's episode of ``The Cosby Show'' as a tribute to the Portland Trail Blazers basketball player who was critically injured in a automobile accident. Cosby requested the jersey from the Trail Blazers' office and wore it while Thursday's episode was being taped. Ramos' car hit an icy patch of road Dec. 16 and flipped several times. The rookie forward, who starred at Seton Hall University in New Jersey, suffered severe head injuries. ``He is still in a state between a coma and full consciousness,'' said Chuck Williams, communications director for Good Samaritan Hospital. ``We are seeing improvement from day to day, but the progress is very slow. He's getting stronger, gaining weight and is basically getting more healthy.''

DOC.HEAD: Residents Threaten to Boycott Voting Precinct with Devilish Number
DOC.TEXT: Harris County commissioners were considering a resolution Tuesday to renumber Precinct 666 because some residents are threatening to boycott elections if the number wasn't changed. Precinct 666 was established Jan. 1 with about 1,500 residents who once lived in Precinct 470. Some suburban Deer Park residents view the number as symbolic of the Antichrist referred to in the Bible. ``Deer Park is a fairly conservative, religious community, and it's just a stigma they don't want,'' said Harvey Petree, a Deer Park councilman who lives in the precinct. Petree said he has fielded a dozen or so complaints from residents who have threatened to stop voting if the number is retained. ``I don't believe it should be the intention of elected city and county officials to discourage voting, and that's the effect it has had,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Says Stealth Fighter-Bomber Cost $6.26 Billion
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon on Tuesday partially lifted the veil of secrecy surrounding the futuristic F-117A Stealth fighter bomber in an attempt to boost confidence in the handling of top-secret weapons programs. With the release of an 8{-minute videotape, a series of 10 photographs and two fact sheets, the Pentagon revealed it has spent $6.26 billion to develop and build 59 of the dark, delta-winged aircraft. That translates into a $106.2 million per-plane cost. Although the plane has been flying since 1981, the Pentagon refused to even acknowledge it existed until November 1988. The fighter, which is about the size of the F-15 Eagle fighter jet, was designed to penetrate any radar defense and bomb targets before enemy forces can react. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams confirmed that three F-117As have crashed over the years and that two pilots died. He declined to say what caused the problems. But he hailed the F-117A program as a successful venture that demonstrates the Pentagon can develop and build reliable, high-tech aircraft in a classified environment. ``I think it's persuaded us that full-scale development program can be used very successfully,'' he said. When asked if he meant the secret funding programs known as the Pentagon's ``black budget,'' Williams responded, ``Yes.'' The release of the information comes amid weakening support in Congress for the Air Force's B-2 Stealth bomber program, and as the service is developing yet another super-secret aircraft, the supersonic Advance Tactical Fighter. Many in Congress expressed ``sticker shock'' last year when the B-2's long-classified figures revealed its $530 million per-plane price tag, raising questions about the Pentagon's use of such ``black budget'' programs. Williams defended the Pentagon's success with the F-117A, amid such controversies. The F-117A program ``tells us Stealth can be developed, can be used on an operational aircraft, is a successful technology, that it works,'' Williams said. While pointing out that the Stealth fighter has a tactical mission and the B-2 Stealth bomber is used for longer-range, or strategic, targets, Williams argued that the radar-evading Stealth characteristics ``help to make us one of the most capable air forces in the world.'' The aircraft got its first combat mission in December. Two of the aircraft bombed a field near a Panamanian Defense Forces barracks to stun and confuse the Panamanians while U.S. paratroopers landed nearby. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, derided the use of the plane as ``show biz'' by military officers eager to show off their sophisticated weaponry. Lockheed Corp., won the contract to build 59 of the single-pilot, two-engine jets in 1978 and the first planes were delivered in 1982. The last two jets still under construction will be delivered in the fall of 1990, an Air Force statement said. Although the Pentagon had touted its efforts to declassify much of the information about the plane, Williams said he was unable to disclose the jet's speed, exact range, weapons payload, or just how much of the aircraft can be seen on radar. Nor would he say if the plane is capable of carrying nuclear weapons. The spokesman did, however, describe the jet as being capable of flying in the ``high subsonic range,'' or about 600 mph. He refused to say whether the jet could carry air-to-air weaponry but did say it is carries ``the full range of tactical fighter ordnance'' and is capable of ``defending itself.'' The single-pilot, dual engine plane weighs 52,500 pounds. Its wingspan is just a little over 43 feet. It is just over 65 feet long, but only 12 feet, 5 inches high, the Pentagon said. The so-called ``stealth'' technology in popular understanding refers to design and materials that reduce the ability of enemy radar to detect the craft. This can be achieved by using designs that avoid the direct impact of radar, and by using composite materials that can absorb the radar's energy. The packet distributed to reporters included a series of photographs of the plane, showing its angled exterior and slim profile in flight and on the a desert runway. Because the aircraft are going to be used more openly, the Air Force has proposed that the planes be moved from the Tonopah Test Range to the Air Force base at Holloman, N.M., where its personnel can live nearby and not be flown in by commuter aircraft, an Air Force official said.

DOC.HEAD: Union Objects to Workers at Rally Opposing Clean Air Bill
With AM-Clean Air, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Union members were offered company-paid trips to Washington to oppose provisions of proposed clean air legislation that were backed by the United Steelworkers, union officials said Tuesday. About 150 workers, many from USX Corp. facilities, attended the rally on the Capitol steps Tuesday as the Senate began moving toward passage of the legislation. USX said it paid the expenses of its workers who attended. ``We look at this as sponsoring a rally for employees who have expressed concern about this legislation and what it might mean for them and their families,'' said company spokesman Ernie Glenn. The union leadership had tried to persuade members not to join the rally. ``The steel companies are attempting to take advantage of our basic steel local unions by planning an all-expenses, company-paid rally in Washington,'' union president Lynn Williams said in a memo to union directors across the country last week. ``It is not a rally which the United Steelworkers of America supports. The steel companies are not themselves opposing the act, but are using our members to front for them.'' Charlie Grese, president of the local at the USX plant in Clairton, Pa., said in a telephone interview that he changed his mind about attending after speaking to Williams and other union officials. ``There's no question we were about ready to come down,'' Grese said. ``I told the company I would have to take this past the international union and would not come down without authorization from the international president.'' Demonstrators at the rally opposed a portion of the legislation requiring that people living near steel plant coke ovens not be exposed to a cancer risk of more than 1-in-10,000 over 70 years. They expressed concern that such a guideline was unrealistic, and could force the mandatory shutdown of dozens of coke ovens. Coke, which comes from coal, is a raw material of steel. Coke ovens can emit benzene, a carcinogen. While the major steel companies oppose the bill, the union says the measure provides enough time and leeway for steelmakers to avoid hardships. Under the bill, steel companies that make extraordinary efforts to control leakage from coke ovens would be given until 2020 before non-complying ovens would be closed.

DOC.HEAD: Senator, Actresses Tell How Alzheimer's Diminished Loved Ones
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Mark Hatfield, in an emotional plea for increased money for Alzheimer's research, told Congress Tuesday how the disease had affected his powerful father. Television actresses Angie Dickinson and Shelley Fabares also testified about how Alzheimer's has hurt their families and urged increased spending on research of the disease. The actresses were upstaged by the Oregon Republican, who drew loud applause during a hearing before the House Select Committee on Aging and the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. The panels are considering legislation that would double and eventually triple the $148 million a year the government now spends on research into Alzheimer's disease. Alzheimer's is a mental disorder which strikes older people. Medical science has found no cure for it. ``He was a man of extraordinary strength. He was a blacksmith in the days of the anvil, bellows and hammer,'' said Hatfield in relating the story of his father who worked 40 years for the Southern Pacific Railroad. He said his father remained active and jogged daily at the age of 80. ``Then one day my mother got a telephone call from a woman who said, `Your husband is here and he has lost his way back home.' That was the first indication that something was awry,'' Hatfield said. ``My father insisted on jogging every day and more frequently than not, my mother would have to pick him up a block from our home where he had lost his way,'' he said. Hatfield said he had a difficult time deciding whether to visit his father while he spent the last four years of his life in a health care facility. ``He did not know who I was. I tried to decide whether it was worth it to see this powerful man reduced to almost nothing _ a vegetable _ or whether I would feel better if I would just go on home. ``Out of a sense of duty and love, I always stopped to see him. So you could say I speak from experience about Alzheimer's,'' the senator said. Hatfield said the state of Oregon is moving toward centralized research and services for victims of Alzheimer's and their families. Last year 29,000 taxpayers used a check-off on their state income tax form to donate $140,000 in tax refunds for Alzheimer's programs, said Hatfield. Dickinson, an actress who starred in movies as well as the long-running television series ``Police Woman,'' said Alzheimer's should be treated like other diseases, with government programs and insurance coverage. ``Alzheimer's disease has touched my life through my beautiful sister Mary Lou Belmont. And, I have to tell you it has changed my life forever,'' she said. ``Alzheimer's is more horrible and horrendous than most of us can imagine. Its victims don't know where they are,'' she said. Dickinison said her sister has an early stage of Alzheimer's and now has daily care but eventually will need round-the-clock care. Fabares, co-star of the television series ``Coach,'' said she and her sister recently made the hardest decision they have ever made by placing their mother in a nursing home. ``One of the worst memories is of my mother opening her mouth, hitting her cheeks and pointing desperately at her tongue, then breaking into tears. She could no longer speak. She knew in stages what was happening to her, but she was trapped inside her own body,'' Fabares said. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said a new study indicates the disease affects 4 million Americans, double earlier estimates. He said by the middle of the next century, 14 million Americans will have the disease. ``With Alzheimer's disease costing society over $88 billion a year, it is becoming the biggest of the `misery diseases' plaguing and impoverishing older Americans and the families who care for them,'' said Rep. Edward Roybal, D-Calif., chairman of the Committee on Aging. He said a federal commitment to fighting Alzheimer's is long overdue.

DOC.HEAD: Brite & Brief
DOC.TEXT: The rummage sale ad was attractive, especially if you were looking for an armor-plated limousine or some high-tech security equipment. But it was a joke, and somebody tried to play it on Mayor Coleman Young. A classified ad in Sunday editions of The Detroit News and Detroit Free Press and Monday's editions of the Free Press pitched rare guns, gold coins, fully appointed limousines and a state-of-the-art security system. About 25 garage-sale buffs showed up Sunday at the address listed in the ad _ Manoogian Mansion, the mayor's residence, said mayoral spokesman Bob Berg. The goods ``for sale'' were right out of the headlines following revelations in January that the city spent about $164,000 to buy armor-plate mayoral limos and Uzi machine guns for bodyguards. The coins apparently referred to reports last month that an attorney for Young's private company sold South African Krugerrands to an Oakland County coin dealer in 1988. Dave McDade, classified advertising manager for the Detroit Newspaper Agency, said Monday the ad was scheduled to run again Tuesday and had been pulled. It was purchased for $60 by a man who did not identify himself, McDade said. Young wasn't impressed. ``They didn't play it on me,'' Young said, laughing. ``They might have played it on whoever answered the door.''

Marine Capt. Dianne Davis was surprised when a colonel asked her if she wanted to spend the day playing golf. She was even more surprised when she learned that President Bush was going to be her partner. Col. Dennis Herbert interrupted Davis during a meeting Friday and said he had to talk to her immediately. ``The colonel asked me if I had my golf clubs with me, and I told him I did,'' she said. ``He said, `How would you like to play golf with the president of the United States?' ``I know I turned ashen white. It was a question I couldn't even conceive of being asked. When I was finally able to stammer, I said, `Yes Sir!' Ms. Davis, who is stationed at the Quantico Marine Corps base, met Bush, Herbert and the commandant of the Marine Corps at the base golf course. ``The temperature was in the 40s, it was gloomy and cloudy, not one of your ideal golfing days, but I would have played in a blizzard,'' Ms. Davis said. She said she shot a 92, and ``the president's score was very close. I don't think it is my place to say what it was. The other foursome beat ours by one point.'' After the game, Bush signed the score card, ``Certified to be almost true. Thanks for the lesson, George Bush.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Partly Close Polish-Lithuanian Border
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet government Tuesday turned up the pressure on independence-minded Lithuania by restricting traffic at the republic's border with Poland. The Polish Foreign Ministry, which announced the action, said it was surprised by the Soviet action. The Polish Embassy in Moscow was told to seek an urgent explanation from the Soviets. ``The Polish Foreign Ministry reminds that free border traffic is regulated by international conventions, which should be respected,'' it said in a brief statement. ``Poland is ready for talks on this issue.'' Poland is the only country bordering Lithuania. The Baltic forms a section of the republic's western border. Soviet officials informed their Polish counterparts that the crossing was ``temporarily'' closed Tuesday morning, the Polish news agency PAP said. It did not say how long it would remain closed. The agency said Soviets and Poles could continue crossing the border to return home. The border crossing, in the extreme northeast corner of Poland between the Polish town of Ogrodniki and the Lithuanian town of Lazdijai, can only be used by Poles and Soviet citizens. Poles, sharing centuries of common history with Lithuania, have rejoiced in the republic's drive to join Poland in shaking off the Soviet yoke imposed after World War II. After the March 11 independence declaration by Lithuania, Polish officials offered vigorous support for the republic's right to self-determination. But the non-communist Polish government did not actually recognize the Lithuanian government, a move that could endanger relations with the Soviets. Lithuania was the subject of lengthy debate Monday in the Solidarity-led Cabinet. Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski reported no change in the Polish position that the ``requirements to recognize the Vilnius government have not yet been met and we recognize the Lithuanian right to statehood.'' The Polish reaction has been complicated by the anxiety that surging Lithuanian nationalism has caused among the 260,000 ethnic Poles in Lithuania's population of 3.8 million. Poland and Lithuania were linked from 1386, when a Lithuanian ruler married a Polish princess, until 1795, when the commonwealth was broken by Russia. After World War I, the newly independent states of Poland and Lithuania argued over Vilnius, where the population was largely Polish and Jewish. Poland finally seized Vilnius and held it until World War II. When Lithuania and Poland fell under Soviet domination, the Polish border was moved west and the Polish population largely uprooted. Vilnius is now the capital of Lithuania. Polish border officials had reported reduced traffic at the crossing recently. On Sunday, 4,039 people and 810 vehicles used the crossing, PAP said. The agency also said despite the closing, workers with valid Soviet visas would still be permitted across the border for their jobs. It said cargo transportation and train travel were continuing but that bus routes had been halted.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: Bush Urged Marcoses to Invest
LaserPhoto NY26
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos' attorney contended Tuesday that George Bush urged her husband to invest in U.S. real estate and that the CIA ``was aware of every transaction'' for which she is on trial on racketeering charges. In opening arguments, defense attorney Gerald Spence also said he plans to call Bush as a witness. The lawyer said that Bush, then the vice president, was concerned about the Marcoses negotiating an oil deal with Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi and suggested to Marcos during a 1981 meeting in Manila, ``Why don't you invest in American properties?'' The Marcoses, ``who saw themselves as children of America,'' took the advice, Spence said. ``They abandoned any further attempt to invest in Libya and began to put their money into New York real estate.'' In Washington, White House spokesman Steve Hart had no immediate comment on the attorney's statements. Earlier Tuesday, a prosecutor portrayed Mrs. Marcos as an uncontrolled spender who treated the Philippine National Bank as her ``personal piggy bank.'' The former Philippines first lady and her late husband, Ferdinand, were named in the 1988 indictment that charged them with stealing millions of dollars from their homeland's treasury to buy Manhattan real estate, jewelry and art. Marcos died in exile in Hawaii last September. On trial with Mrs. Marcos is Saudi arms dealer Adnan Khashoggi. Spence said Marcos was warned by the CIA that he might not have enough money to marshal a force to recapture the Philippines if it was taken over by the Communist insurgency. Without going into specifics, Spence claimed that the CIA was worried that the Philippines would fall to the Communists as Cuba had been taken over by Fidel Castro. ``The evidence in this case is that the CIA was aware of every transaction that took place in this case,'' Spence said without giving details. Prosecutors objected repeatedly as Spence gave a rambling discourse of Philippine history. U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan sharply rebuked the defense attorney several times. At one point, Keenan told Spence: ``We're not going to go back to Philippine election campaigns. We're going to try the case before this court.'' Mrs. Marcos broke into tears as Spence told the jury that she was a devoted wife committed to defending the honor of her late husband. ``This is a woman who lived with her beloved husband for 35 years. She was with him in sickness and in health and when he took his last breath,'' Spence said. ``It is her position: `I am going to defend my husband.''' Although Spence said he was not going to use an innocent-spouse defense, he claimed Mrs. Marcos, 60, did not understand the ``intricacies of finance.'' ``She would say over and over again, `Ferdinand, what is happening here? What are you doing in this situation?''' he said. Assistant U.S. Attorney Debra Livingston, however, told the jurors that the Marcoses were ``partners in crime'' who had exported ``fraud on a colossal scale'' to the United States. Livingston said the couple ``grabbed from a dollar-poor country to satisfy Imelda Marcos' voracious appetite for real estate, jewelry and art.'' The prosecutor repeatedly referred to Mrs. Marcos' ``multimillion-dollar purchases,'' implying greed was the motivation for the alleged fraud. She said Mrs. Marcos treated the New York branch of the Philippine National Bank as her ``own personal piggy bank. Every time she descended on New York ... she cracked it open, (taking) bundles and bundles of cash.'' Livingston said the Marcoses, who earned modest salaries, amassed great wealth in their homeland through kickbacks, bribes and outright theft from the Philippine treasury. The money, more than $160 million, was then placed in secret bank accounts around the world before being transferred to shell corporations that acted as owners for four Manhattan buildings, the prosecutor charged. ``They were not small apartment buildings,'' she said. ``They were three huge skyscrapers and a large shopping center. One building was a gold encrusted skyscraper on Fifth Avenue.'' Livingston said the Marcoses also defrauded banking institutions of $165 million to finance the upkeep of the properties. The prosecutor said the ``gigantic web of fraud'' was held together by secrecy and accomplices who acted as fronts for the Marcoses. Spence countered that argument by saying most people keep their business dealings private. ``If everyone concerned with keeping their investments private were prosecuted, this courthouse would be pretty busy,'' he said. Livingston said Khashoggi entered the conspiracy after Marcos was ousted from power in 1986 and the new Philippines government sued to recover the Manhattan real estate. She said Khashoggi helped the Marcoses bypass a court order that forbade any transfer of their holdings by creating false documents to make it appear he owned the four buildings and part of an art collection that was purchased with stolen funds. If convicted of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice, Mrs. Marcos would face up to 50 years in prison and a $1 million fine. Prosecutors also are seeking forfeiture of the alleged illegal proceeds. Khashoggi, once described as the world's richest man, is being tried for mail fraud and obstruction of justice and would face up to 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine if convicted. The trial is expected to last three to four months.

DOC.HEAD: Too Little Rain In Northern Plains; Too Much Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Northern areas of the Great Plains still suffer from lack of moisture for crops and pastures, but farther south the story was too much rain, the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said Tuesday. ``Rain improved winter wheat condition in portions of the central Great Plains'' during the week of March 26-April 1, the facility reported. ``Crop condition was mostly good in Colorado and Kansas. Nebraska's winter wheat was fair to good.'' In the southern plains, too much moisture caused some yellowing of the wheat crop and hampered fertilizer application. The crop condition was said to be good to fair in Oklahoma and Missouri. Rain improved winter wheat in northern Texas but excess moisture was a problem in some areas. ``Winter wheat was mostly good in the Corn Belt and good to fair in the Southeast,'' the report said. ``Powdery mildew was a continuing problem in Georgia.'' In the West, lack of moisture put stress on winter wheat in the Columbia Basin of Oregon, the report said. Washington's wheat was in good-to-fair shape, although Russian wheat aphids were a problem in the eastern part of the state. The facility is operated by the departments of Agriculture and Commerce. Weekly reports cover crop conditions but do not include production forecasts.

DOC.HEAD: Siamese Twins Undergo Separation Surgery
DOC.TEXT: Siamese twins born last month connected at the chest and abdomen underwent separation surgery Tuesday. Jakob and James Watkins went into the scheduled 10-hour operation at All Children's Hospital shortly before 11 a.m. Doctors scheduled a post-operation news conference for Wednesday to discuss the results. The twins, born Feb. 28 to Raquel and Scott Watkins of St. Petersburg, had already been diagnosed as good candidates for the surgery because they have separate hearts, lungs and kidneys. Joined in an area from the breast bone to the navel, the twins appear to share only a liver and parts of their intestinal tract. The twins' were listed in stable condition prior to surgery. They spent their first two weeks of life in critical condition. Siamese twins appear about once every 100,000 births, with more than 50 percent dying within the first 48 hours.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Expanding Registry Of Bone Marrow Donors
DOC.TEXT: The House on Tuesday voted to spend $6 million this year to expand the national registry of bone marrow donors. The lives of many victims of leukemia, aplastic anemia and other blood diseases can be saved with marrow transplants. But many have died because a good match cannot be found in time. The House by voice vote approved an amendment offered by Rep. Bill Young, R-Fla., to provide money to expand the National Marrow Donor Program from its current registry of 90,000 donors to about 150,000. Part of the money would go toward expanding the Navy's laboratories so volunteers throughout the military could be typed and listed. About $4.5 million would be put toward registering other people who would volunteer but can't afford the $75 cost of the tests. Harry Glenn, Young's spokesman, said it was estimated the Navy would add up to 4,000 people to the registry and the public effort about 60,000. The eventual goal was a registry of 250,000 in the United States and a system for tying in with overseas lists of donors, he said. The marrow amendment was added to the House version of the fiscal 1990 supplemental appropriations bill.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Says Justice Unit Will Review Findings of Gray Leak Probe
DOC.TEXT: Faced with congressional pressure, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said Tuesday he would ask the Justice Department's internal disciplinary unit to review the results of an FBI leak investigation. Thornburgh said the Office of Professional Responsiblity would review the inconclusive results of an FBI probe of leaks about a criminal investigation involving alleged financial irregularities in the office of Rep. William Gray III, D-Pa. The leak to CBS News while Gray was running for House majority whip last spring produced a storm of criticism from Democrats on Capitol Hill who charged it was politically inspired. It forced the Justice Department to take the unusual step of saying that Gray was not a target of the investigation and was cooperating with the FBI. The extensive leak investigation ordered by Thornburgh failed to identify the source with certainty. The attorney general's decision in December not to refer the matter to the OPR for possible disciplinary action was criticized by several lawmakers, including Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee. At a hearing of the panel Tuesday, Thornburgh told Biden that he would ask OPR to review the report produced by the FBI investigation. ``I do not believe that the FBI's investigation provided any basis for disciplinary action,'' Thornburgh told Biden. ``Notwithstanding this view ... I have asked the Office of Professional Responsiblity to review the report and to provide me with their advice.'' ``At that point, I will then assess whether any disciplinary action is warranted,'' the attorney general said. Biden made the request during a meeting with the attorney general last week, according to comments by both the senator and Thornburgh. Asked after the hearing why he had reversed his previous positition, Thornburgh said: ``There was an apparent misunderstanding of what my position was, so I thought I'd better clear it up.'' The department had stated previously that its regulations did not provide for turning over the results of a criminal investigation to OPR, which conducts internal probes of alleged impropriety by Justice Department lawyers. OPR has the power to conduct grand jury investigations of its own and to recommend that the attorney general take disciplinary action against specific employees. In a March 7 letter to Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., chairman of the House criminal justice subcommittee, the Justice Department said that the applicable 1980 regulation ``does not contemplate the referral of investigative findings in a mater appearing to involve a violation of law from the Criminal Division to OPR.'' ``The purpose for referring a report to OPR is obviously to consider whether an individual whose misconduct was not serious enough to constitute a violation of law, should nevertheless be subject to some disciplinary sanction,'' said the letter by Bruce C. Navarro, acting assistant attorney general in charge of the Office Of Legislative Affairs. ``Consequently, no further disciplinary investigation could form a basis upon which to consider disciplinary action,'' Navarro wrote. ``Forwarding the report of the investigation to OPR would thus not serve any purpose.''

DOC.HEAD: More Child Labor Violations Uncovered by Sweep
DOC.TEXT: Fines against fast-food restaurants and other businesses are climbing toward the $3 million mark for thousands of child labor law violations uncovered in a three-day federal sweep, officials said Tuesday. One businessman called the effort by the Labor Department ``nitpicking'' and a ``crusade.'' But spokeswoman Johanna Schneider said the department's ``responsibility is to enforce the letter of the law.'' She said companies had the right to appeal the fines if they thought they were unfair. The number of violations grew from 7,000 to nearly 11,000 after federal investigators gave the case files further review, officials said. The total is about half the number for all of 1989. Civil fines on the businesses involved are expected to total $2.9 million, up from the $1.8 million originally predicted following the March 12-15 sweep, said William Brooks, an assistant secretary of labor. Most of the violations involved teen-agers working more hours or later hours during the school week than is allowed under federal law. But there were also 1,450 youngsters age 14-17 who were illegally employed in dangerous jobs, such as using power-driven meat-slicing machinery, dough mixers and paper-balers, the department said. An Arby's fast food restaurant in Santa Fe, N.M., was fined $12,550 for various violations, including some for putting youngsters to work in dangerous tasks. A similar fine was levied against a Sizzler Steakhouse in Omaha, Neb., for the same type of violations, officials said. Larry Pabian, who runs four Sizzler Steakhouses in Omaha and one in Lincoln, said most of the violations came from a discrepancy between Nebraska law and federal law on how late 15-year-olds can work. He said the Nebraska law sets a 10 p.m. limit while federal law is more restrictive. Pabian called the federal regulations regarding operating meat slicers ``antiquated'' because the rules prohibit workers under 18 from operating the machines. ``Operating the machine _ that's a fine, and then wiping off the machine _ that's another fine,'' he said. Reams food stores in Utah were fined about $20,000 for violations involving about 80 youngsters. General manager Dick Cheney noted that none of the violations involved hazardous jobs and instead stemmed from letting youngsters work too long or from employing children under 14. ``The violations were not flagrant at all. In most cases, they involved kids working 10 minutes beyond their three hours,'' Cheney said. ``We feel that we've obeyed the spirit of the law, and that they're nitpicking. They're on some kind of crusade.'' Cheney said one store was fined because parents let their 12-and 13-year-old children carry inventory sheets at once-a-year stock counting events. The businesses identified Tuesday involved 170 cases that investigators have completed; some of the biggest cases are still open, the agency said. The stiffest fine so far _ $29,050 _ was against GFF Foods grocery store in Moore, Okla., which was accused of hazardous-occupation and record-keeping violations involving 47 youngsters. The store owner could not immediately be reached for comment. Dozens of companies were listed from around the country, including individual restaurants that are part of the following fast-food chains: McDonald's, Taco Bell, Jack in the Box and Burger King. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said the new findings reinforce ``our belief that the trend toward violations is growing.'' Nearly half of the fast-food restaurants and other businesses targeted in the sweep were found to be employing children illegally, Brooks said. Of the 3,776 firms investigated, violations were found at 1,750, he said. About 225 youngsters under 14 were found to be illegally employed, Brooks said. Children under 14 are barred from most jobs, with a few exceptions such as certain farm work and newspaper routes. Federal law forbids 14-year-olds and 15-year-olds from working more than three hours on a school day or 18 hours a week during the school year. Eight hours are permitted on weekend days and 40-hour weeks are permitted in summer and during vacations. When last month's sweep was announced, Labor Department officials said 500 inspectors had visited businesses in all 50 states. Most of the violations were at service businesses, such as restaurants, grocery stores, pizza and donut shops or dry cleaning firms, the agency said. Last year, the Labor Department's wage and hour division, which enforces child-labor provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act, found 22,508 minors to be illegally employed, an all-time high.

DOC.HEAD: EGerman Groups Agree to Form Governing Coalition Before Easter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with coalition talks concluding, agree to form governing coalition before Easter, details, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's main political groups agreed Tuesday to try to form the nation's first non-Communist government before April 15 and resolve lingering differences over unification with West Germany. The conservative Alliance for Germany, winner of the most Parliament seats in the March 18 elections and closely allied with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, met for formal talks with the Social Democrats, who finished second. Party leaders said following the afternoon session they had agreed on a framework for talks that they expected would result in a governing coalition of this nation of 16 million residents by Easter Sunday, April 15. They agreed too to form smaller groups to discuss the issues that divide them, particularly the pace of reunification. The talks are aimed at forging a ``grand coalition'' that includes both conservatives and liberals. East Germany's disparate political factions had suddenly united this week to demand that West Germany give 1-to-1 value to East German marks when the nations reunify and the powerful deutsche mark becomes the common currency. Unification talks with West Germany had been temporarily on hold while the newly elected Parliament chose a leadership to replace the caretaker Communist government. The caretaker government has been running the country since the fall revolution toppled the hard-line Communist regime of Erich Honecker. The talks also follow the resignation of the Social Democrats' leader, Ibrahim Boehme, amid allegations he had links to the hated Stasi secret police. The controversy surrounding Boehme had hampered negotiations. Social Democratic officials met with Alliance for Germany negotiators just hours after the Social Democrats announced they were ready to begin formal talks. Officials from the tiny Free Democratic Party also participated in the meeting. The Alliance for Germany is a three-party coalition that favors quick reunification with West Germany. It received the most votes in parliamentary elections March 18 but not enough to form a majority in the 400-seat Parliament. A two-thirds majority is needed to make major decisions for rapid unification. Rainer Eppelmann, leader of Democratic Awakening, one of the parties in the Alliance for Germany, said he was hoping for a quick agreement ``so people in East Germany know where they stand.'' The Social Democrats and the alliance have already held ``exploratory talks'' about forming a government. But progress was hindered by the Social Democrats' insistence that one of the three parties within the alliance _ the ultra-conservative German Social Union _ be excluded from any government. The Social Democrats have now dropped that demand, but they are seeking to limit any Cabinet posts the German Social Union would have in a government. The third party in the alliance is the Christian Demcratic Union. Meckel said a key reason for the Social Democrats' decision to enter formal coalition talks is the dispute over introducing West Germany's mark as East Germany's currency. West Germany's central bank has insisted most East German marks be exchanged at a 2-to-1 ratio. That has angered many East Germans who were expecting to benefit from a 1-to-1 exchange rate. Lothar de Maiziere, head of the Alliance for Germany, said Monday he was disappointed with the West German proposal and made clear he favors a 1-to-1 conversion rate. Meckel said de Maiziere's stand leads Social Democratic officials to believe the two sides could be successful in coalition negotiations. ``For the first time, I have seen that Mr. de Maiziere has publicly said something which is seen differently in Bonn. We see this as a sign of hope,'' Meckel said. The Social Democrats have previously complained that the Alliance for Germany is letting the West German government call too many of the shots in drafting plans for German unification. Nonetheless, negotiations between the two sides could be tricky because the Social Democrats have opted for a slower pace to German unity than the Alliance for Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Unified Germany Must Stay In NATO, U.S. Official Says
DOC.TEXT: A united Germany must remain a full member of NATO, an organization that will play a vital role in maintaining stability in Europe, a State Department official said Wednesday. James F. Dobbins, deputy assistant secretary of state, told senators NATO should not be abolished even though the military threat has receded in Europe with the disintegration of the Warsaw Pact.
