But NATO will continue to play an important role, he said. ``We need NATO now for the same reasons NATO was created,'' he said at a meeting of the Helsinki Commission. ``NATO remains necessary for European balance.'' It is likely NATO will play more of a political than a military role in the future, Dobbins said. ``Many of the positive changes we are seeing in Eastern Europe are not yet anchored in law and practice,'' he said. ``European stability will continue to be best served by the maintenance of a multinational defense structure, and by a Germany soundly grounded in Western institutions _ in particular by its full membership in NATO,'' he said. NATO, he said, will guard against instability and fragmentation in the region, and give the Americans a place in Europe. ``Without NATO, U.S. public and congressional support for this engagement would be difficult to maintain.'' Dobbins' comments came at a meeting of the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, known as the Helsinki Commission. Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., chairman of the congressional CSCE group, said CSCE, a group of 35 nations, will play an important role in the shape of the new Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Third House Panel Approves Disabilities Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House Public Works and Transportation Committee voted 35-5 Tuesday to approve legislation to protect the civil rights of millions of disabled Americans, including those infected with the AIDS virus. The committee vote is the third out of four needed to bring the Americans With Disabilities Act to the House floor. The Senate passed the bill last September by a 76-8 vote. The House Judiciary Committee, the final committee, is expected to take up the bill near the end of this month, and a vote by the full House could occur in May. The bill protects disabled people from job discrimination. It guarantees equal access to public and private transportation as well as stores, restaurants, business and professional services. The hearing- and speech-impaired would be guaranteed access to special telephone services. Backers say the law is carefully constructed to avoid undue hardships on businesses. They say it provides lenient timetables for implementation. Critics say the bill is too vague for the ordinary businessperson to understand, leaving interpretation of the law up to activists and judges. They also say the bill provides nothing to offset the high cost to businesses. The two previous House committees _ Education and Labor, and Energy and Commerce _ also passed the bill by similarly large margins. Although the bill does protect people with the AIDS virus against discrimination, it does not protect homosexuals and bisexuals against discrimination. It protects former but not current drug users. AIDS is known to be spread by certain homosexual contact, contaminated hypodermic needles and transfusions of infected blood. A woman who is infected during pregnancy passes the disease to her infant. President Bush referred last week to the bill in a speech in which he urged Congress to ``get on with the job of passing a law'' to protect people with the virus or with the disease. Bush did not mention, however, the conflict between the administration and congressional supporters over an effort by the Justice Department to change important language dealing with employment provisions of the law. The administration wants to decouple the disabilities bill from the 1964 Civil Rights Act. The reason is that civil rights advocates have introduced an update of the Civil Rights Act that would enable people who are intentionally discriminated against to sue employers for damages. The administration opposes that change. Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, which is referred to in the disabilities bill, currently limits relief to non-damage remedies such as back pay and injunctive relief.

DOC.HEAD: National Debt Hits More than $3 Trillion for First Time In History
DOC.TEXT: The national debt on Monday totaled more than $3 trillion for the first time in history, the Treasury Department reported Tuesday. That's $3,000,000,000,000. Count them: a three and 12 zeroes. A person counting a $1,000 bill each second would take 133 years just to reach $1 trillion. And when the national debt reached $3 trillion, it meant that it would cost every man, woman and child $12,000 to pay it off. ``The debt subject to limit did go over $3 trillion on Monday,'' confirmed Peter Hollenbach, public affairs officer for Treasury's Bureau of Public Debt. The actual level of public debt subject to statutory limit at the end of the day Monday was $3.023 trillion. That's just $99.59 billion under the statutory limit of $3.123 trillion. The national debt stood at $2.989 trillion last Friday. Hollenbach said that despite a growing number of income tax receipts at this time of year, he expected the debt to continue to grow as long as the budget is not balanced. Congress enacted the current debt limit last November. The debt reached $1 billion in 1916 during World War I, climbing to $278 billion at the end of World War II. It reached its first trillion on Oct. 1, 1981, and rose to $2 trillion on April 3, 1986. The rapid growth in the debt stems from fact that the government been running huge deficits for the past decade. The inability to reduce the federal deficit was considered the major economic failure of the Reagan administration. Democratic opponents often pointed to the fact that President Reagan ran up more public debt in this eight years in office than all of his predecessors put together. The federal deficit has continued to grow since then and totaled $152.1 billion during the fiscal year ended last Sept. 30. By the end of February, the deficit had reached $97.52 billion, just $2.48 billion less than the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction target for the entire year. Interest on the deficit during February totaled $17.32 billion and is expected to reach $254.85 billion for the year. Analysts have said the target for fiscal 1990 has all but been abaondoned, with some suggesting the actual imbalance for the year will total $160 billion to $165 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Kunin Latest Northeast Governor to Opt Out of Running for Re-election
LaserPhoto MR2
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Madeleine Kunin on Tuesday opted out of seeking a fourth two-year term, becoming the latest of the Northeast's governors to back out of a troubled economic situation. ``It is time for me to move on to new challenges,'' said Kunin, a Democrat. Her surprise announcement came two weeks after Connecticut Gov. William O'Neill decided not to run again and a year after Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis, Kunin's closest political associate, opted against seeking re-election this November. Kunin, 56, elected in 1984 as Vermont's first female governor, gave an upbeat review of her years in office. ``We have made history here in Vermont,'' she said. ``We have shown that women are strong and capable leaders.'' Kunin has built a national reputation as one of the most outspoken governors for abortion rights and the environment. ``Never has Vermont stood so proudly, both at home and throughout the nation, as a strong environmental state,'' she said. Her decision not to run gives instant front-runner status to her predecessor, former Gov. Richard Snelling, a four-term Republican. Snelling, who did not run in 1984, has said one reason he is campaigning this time is deep concern about the state's budget woes. The three best-known Democrats considering running are Lt. Gov. Howard Dean, former state Sen. Peter Welch and former U.S. Attorney William Gray. The primary is Sept. 11. In Vermont, sagging state revenues have prompted sharp reductions in this year's budget and a proposed 12 percent increase in the personal income tax for the coming year. The state's situation is not unique. A surging economy in the 1980s yielded huge surpluses for the Northeast states and allowed the governors many initiatives. But a sharp economic downturn prompted cutbacks and tax increases and sagging popularity for governors. In Connecticut, O'Neill, a Democrat, announced March 20 he would not seek a third full term in office. He said his decision not to run again came after an evaluation of the ``political realities of the day.'' His popularity was at an all-time low after raising taxes by nearly $1 billion in 1989. Dukakis, whose ``Massachusetts miracle'' was trumpeted in his 1988 presidential bid, announced more than a year ago he would not seek re-election. The state now faces a deficit officially pegged at $780 million. In New York, Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo is facing his third straight year of deficit problems and is talking about more than $1 billion in higher taxes and sharp spending cuts to deal with the latest budget crisis. The region's three Republican governors _ John McKernan of Maine; Judd Gregg of New Hampshire and Edward DiPrete of Rhode Island _ all are seeking re-election, and all are handicapped by hard financial times. Maine faces a $210 million shortfall through the end of this budget cycle in 1991 and McKernan has gotten a strong challenge from Democrat Joseph E. Brennan, his predecessor, who has made the budget woes a chief issue. New Hampshire has a $160 million deficit, and the state's lack of a general sales and income tax is bound to be a big issue in this year's campaign. Gregg is against such a tax. Eric Davis, a political science professor a Middlebury College, said the tough economic times have taken the fun out of being governor in the Northeast. ``This is not a good time to be governor,'' he said. ``Almost all the Northeastern governors are facing the same sorts of budget problems. ``Madeleine Kunin has spent her whole career talking about what government can do for the people. It didn't look like fun.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Ryan White, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of 18-year-old Ryan White's battle with AIDS and his struggle to attend school: December 1984 _ White, 13, is diagnosed as having contracted AIDS through a blood-clotting agent used to treat his hemophilia. July 30, 1985 _ Western Schools Corp. Superintendent James O. Smith bars White from school near Kokomo, Ind., saying the health risk for other children is too great. Aug. 3 _ The State Board of Health sets guidelines for admitting children with AIDS to school, saying White should attend class as long as he's not severely ill. Aug. 8 _ White's family sues in federal court to get him admitted to school. A judge says administrative appeals must be exhausted first. Aug. 26 _ Classes begin at Western Middle School; Ryan is linked to school by a computer-telephone hookup. Nov. 25 _ Indiana Department of Education hearing officer rules White should be allowed to go to school when he is not intensely sick. Feb. 6, 1986 _ An appeals board rules White, now 14, can attend classes with clearance from the Howard County health officer. Clearance is granted. Feb. 19 _ A Howard County judge rejects request by parents and students to bar White from school. Feb. 21 _ White attends a half-day of school. A Howard County judge later in the day approves a temporary injunction preventing him from attending school. April 10 _ A Clinton County Circuit judge lifts the injunction. White returns to class later that day. Summer 1987 _ White's family moves to Cicero, about 20 miles away, saying they didn't want to stay where they were unwanted. Aug. 31 _ White attends his first day of classes as a freshman at Hamilton Heights High School. No protests are reported. Dec. 16, 1989 _ White turns 18 in ill health. March 29, 1990 _ White is hospitalized in Indianapolis suffering from a respiratory infection. April 2 _ White is in critical condition on a life-support system.

DOC.HEAD: Foley Says He Would Vote Against Flag-Protecting Constitutional Amendment
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said Tuesday that if the Supreme Court throws out the federal law against flag burning, he will vote against a constitutional amendment to protect the flag. By tradition, the Speaker of the House rarely votes and Foley has not done so since becoming speaker 10 months ago. But Foley said he would come off the speaker's podium and vote ``no'' if the House considered a constitutional amendment. Foley last year supported passage of the law against flag burning. But he said amending the Constitution, and especially the First Amendment definition of ``elemental freedoms of this country,'' was not justified. The First Amendment ``is the most sacred part of the constitutional document, and to amend it for these reasons would be extraordinarily unwise,'' Foley said. ``I think the judgment of history would be unkind on the Congress or the state legislatures if that were to occur.'' The Supreme Court has scheduled oral arguments for May 14 on whether it will uphold the judgment of two federal courts that the flag burning statute passed by Congress last year is unconstitutional. Foley has promised a House vote on a constitutional amendment within 30 days if the court rules against the statute.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Urges End to Violence in Natal
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government called Tuesday for an end to violence in South Africa after a week of black factional fighting in Natal province. ``We recognize that the situation in Natal is extremely serious,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said when asked about President F. W. de Klerk's increased use of security forces to quell the violence. ``We understand that the decision taken by President de Klerk to deploy additional security forces to areas of growing violence in South Africa was taken to begin the process of restoring order,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. She said it was in the interests of all the people of South Africa to support efforts for negotiations between the white-led government and the black majority on the country's future. ``At a time when the climate for negotiations is otherwise improving, it is encumbent upon all parties to exercise restraint,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``We call for an end to violence from all sources and the quickest possible end to the state of emergency.'' Soldiers and police in armored vehicles patrolled in Natal province on Tuesday to head off clashes between Inkatha, headed by Zulu homeland leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi, and supporters of the African National Congress guerrilla movement. Police said at least 55 people had been killed in the past week. About 4,000 people have been killed in Natal since 1986. Ms. Tutwiler commended de Klerk for announcing Monday that the South African government would propose legislation authoritizing amnesty for politically motivated criminal acts. ``This is another positive move by President de Klerk towards fostering a climate conducive to beginning the negotiating process,'' Ms. Tutwiler said, noting that the ANC wanted such a law to enable its members to return from exile. ``The bill, when it becomes law, apparently will allow the state president to grant returning members of the opposition amnesty for the full range of their anti-apartheid activities,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. She urged the ANC to reschedule a meeting for peace talks with the government as soon as possible. Last week the organization canceled a meeting that had been scheduled for April 11. Ms. Tutwiler said the U.S. government applauded ANC leader Nelson Mandela's agreement to meet with de Klerk on Thursday to seek ways to end the violence in Natal.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Committee OKs Higher Mileage Requirements
DOC.TEXT: A Senate panel, ignoring protests by automakers, Tuesday approved a bill that would require a 40 percent improvement in fuel efficiency by 2001. ``It's so potentially devastating to our industry and to consumer choice, we're concerned that it exists,'' said General Motors spokesman Bill Noack. ``It's an attempt to legislate the family car out of existence.'' Automakers contend the provisions of the bill would force them to stop making all but the smallest vehicles. However, supporters of the bill sponsored by Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., say higher mileage standards are needed to force production of more fuel-efficient cars and reduce U.S. dependency on foreign oil. ``The auto industry is lining up a phalanx of lobbyists to oppose it,'' Bryan said. ``They'll be trying to convince people it would be a disaster. We're going to have a tough battle.'' The Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation approved the bill 14-4, but it is not expected to reach the floor until June. Under current law, new car fleets _ all models produced in a year by one manufacturer _ are required to average 27.5 miles per gallon. The Bryan bill would require manufacturers to improve their average fuel economy by 20 percent beginning with the 1995 model year and 40 percent by the 2001 model year. The typical new car fleet would average 34.4 mpg in 1995 and 40.2 mpg by 2001, although some would be higher and some lower because the increase would be based on improving the mileage from a makers' current level. Bryan said the bill would save 49.1 billion gallons of oil between 1995 and 2001. ``We are now importing more oil from foreign sources than when the Arab countries cut us off with their oil embargo in 1973,'' he said. The bill also would save more than 483 million tons of carbon dioxide, 20 pounds of which are emitted with each gallon of gasoline a car burns, he said. Carbon dioxide is believed to be a leading contributor to global warming. When mileage requirements originally were imposed in the mid-1970s, automakers met them by reducing the average car's weight by 1,000 pounds, said Tim McCarthy, a lobbyist for the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association. The average weight now is 3,000 pounds. ``We can make cars right now that meet the Bryan standards,'' he said. ``But to cut out another 1,000 (pounds) you're looking at the Honda CRX, the Geo Metro. I don't see them satisfying all the needs of the public, either families or business. The consumer will not be happy.''

DOC.HEAD: Actress Liv Ullmann Testifies on Plight of Children
LaserPhoto WX17
DOC.TEXT: Actress Liv Ullmann told a Senate subcommittee Tuesday that every other movement of the second hand signals the death of a child from neglect, disease or war. ``Every day in our world, from neglect, from preventable disease, from war, 40,000 children die,'' the film and stage star told the Senate Labor and Human Resources subcommittee on children, family, drugs and alcoholism. Ullmann spoke as a goodwill ambassador for the United Nations Children's Fund, better known as UNICEF. The subcommittee was receiving testimony on the effects of war on children. Ullmann included in that category ``the terrible wars on the streets,'' which is how she described homelessness.

DOC.HEAD: Oscar and Barbara Help ABC Capture First Place
DOC.TEXT: Oscar and Barbara teamed to lead ABC to first place for the week in the Nielsen TV ratings, while Carol Burnett returned triumphant to prime time on NBC, according to figures released Tuesday. ``The 62nd Annual Academy Awards,'' a 3{-hour foot-dragger on Monday night, was No. 1 in the ratings for the week ended April 1. The follow-up ``Barbara Walters Special,'' featuring interviews with Chevy Chase, Arnold Schwarzenegger and Warren Beatty, ranked sixth. Season-ranked No. 1 NBC had occupied the top spot for 23 weeks. Its last drop to No. 2 was during ABC's World Series coverage the week of Oct. 9-15. ``The Academy Awards clearly lifted us up there,'' said ABC spokesman Jim Brochu. For the week, ABC was first with an average rating of 14.8, NBC was second with 13.3 and CBS was third with 11.7. Each rating point represents 921,000 homes. ``Carol & Co.'' a half-hour, comedy-variety show featuring Miss Burnett and an ensemble company, was in ninth place for the week after a Saturday night debut on NBC. Another well-turned debut was ``Bagdad Cafe,'' a series starring Whoopi Goldberg and Jean Stapleton based on the movie about a German tourist stranded at a remote desert diner. The half-hour show on Friday nights was ranked No. 18 for CBS. ``Equal Justice,'' ABC's Wednesday night case for an hourlong lawyer drama, was tied for 44th place in its debut show. A two-hour ``Equal Justice'' movie on Tuesday night was tied for 37th place. The re-introduction of ``FM'' on NBC was in a three-way tie for 51st place. Here are the top 10 shows for the week: ``The 62nd Annual Academy Awards,'' ABC; ``Cheers,'' NBC; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC; ``The Barbara Walters Special,'' ABC; ``A Different World,'' NBC; ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC; ``Carol & Co.,'' NBC; and ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC. With ``The Simpsons'' taking Sunday off at Fox Network, a special showing of ``Roseanne'' on ABC after ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' managed to hang on to some of the hit show's audience for a 13th place rating. Fox aired a one-hour version of ``America's Most Wanted'' on Sunday night. Without the Simpsons, the Bundys suffered. ``Married ... With Children'' was in a three-way tie for 39th place. Last week ``Married'' was 13th. The highest-rated movie for the week was ``Down and Out in Beverly Hills'' Sunday night on ABC, tied for 16th place. The top special for the week after the Academy Awards and Barbara Walters was ``The Magic of David Copperfield'' on CBS, ranked 21st for the week. ABC's ``World News Tonight'' was the first in average ratings for the network news shows, but after seven weeks in third place, the ``CBS Evening News'' edged into second place. It beat the ``NBC Nightly News'' by one-tenth of a ratings point, averaging a 9.4 rating to NBC's 9.3. ABC's broadcast easily beat both programs with a 10.6 average.

DOC.HEAD: Northeast Governors Face Tough Times
With AM-Vermont Governor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at the political fortunes of Northeastern governors:

Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo is talking about more than $1 billion in higher taxes and sharp spending cuts to deal with his third straight yearly budget crisis. On March 26, Standard & Poor's Corp. dropped the state's credit rating for long-term bonds to the worst in New York history. Cuomo has said he expects to seek re-election this year to a third four-year term. However, the man many consider a potential 1992 presidential contender has made no formal announcement for re-election.

Democratic Gov. William A. O'Neill, his popularity at an all-time low after raising taxes by nearly $1 billion in 1989, announced March 20 he would not seek a third full term in office. The 59-year-old governor had raised $600,000 for his re-election campaign and spent at least $250,000 on television commercials. But he dropped out after coming up last in separate three-way polls pitting him against Republican U.S. Rep. John Rowland and former Republican Sen. Lowell Weicker, who is running as an independent.

Republican Gov. Edward D. DiPrete is seeking his fourth two-year term under the cloud of a $100 million revenue shortfall this year and a budget next year that doesn't raise taxes but that cuts numerous social programs favored by Democrats. The Democrat-controlled General Assembly has refused to enact many of the budget-balancing measures DiPrete wants this year, although it did agree reluctantly to raise auto and truck registration fees. And the latest March revenue figures indicated the sales, corporation and income taxes all were not increasing as rapidly as needed to support even a pared-down budget. DiPrete's popularity in a recent Brown University poll dipped to its lowest ever _ about 30 percent, compared with 43 percent in July. DiPrete predicts his popularity will rebound with an economic upturn this summer.

Democratic Gov. Michael Dukakis announced in January 1989 that he would not seek another term. The state faces a deficit officially pegged at $780 million, but projected to be over $1 billion. The race for governor is wide open. Democrats include Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, former Attorney General Francis X. Bellotti, Boston University President John Silber and House Taxation Chairman John Flood. GOP candidates include House Minority Leader Steven Pierce and former federal prosecutor William Weld.

Gov. Judd Gregg has all but said he will seek a second two-year term. He has said that if people vote for him they would be voting against a broad-based tax; if they vote for Democrats they would be voting for such a tax. New Hampshire has neither general sales nor income tax. The legislature has decided to deal with the $160 million state deficit with cuts in services, including layoffs, and increases in taxes on cigarettes, beer, gasoline, rooms and meals, business profits, real estate transfers and higher fees on car registrations.

Gov. Madeleine Kunin on Tuesday opted against seeking a fourth two-year term. Former Republican Gov. Richard Snelling is the likely Republican nominee. Lt. Gov. Howard Dean, former state Sen. Peter Welch and former U.S. Attorney William Gray are the leading Democratic possibilities. Vermont's economy has been sliding steadily for the past year, with economists now forecasting it will bottom out a year from now. The state's budget for this fiscal year has been cut dramatically, and a 12 percent increase in the personal income tax proposed for the coming year.

Gov. John R. McKernan said Tuesday his re-election campaign remains on track but he will defer a formal announcement until the Legislature adjourns to avoid worsening partisanship. The Republican former congressman swapped jobs with Democrat Joseph E. Brennan in 1987 and now faces a strong challenge by Brennan, whose campaign has fastened on budget problems. McKernan has said Maine faced a $210 million shortfall this budget cycle.

DOC.HEAD: United States Will Not Rejoin UNESCO
DOC.TEXT: The United States has decided not to rejoin UNESCO because of a continuing dispute over its management and what the Bush administration considers its political bias, U.S. officials said Tuesday. The United States withdrew from the U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in 1984, accusing the Paris-based agency of politicization and anti-Western bias. ``The time is not right for the United States to reopen the question of renewing its membership in UNESCO,'' said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. The department will submit a full report to Congress on April 17 explaining its reasons, she said, declining to elaborate further about the decision. After reviewing UNESCO's actions at its recent general conference and analyzing the restructuring proposals raised there, the United States concluded that ``very little has changed since the United States withdrew at the end of 1984,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. The United States and Britain, which also withdrew from UNESCO, accounted for some 30 percent of the organization's budget. Britain too reportedly has decided to stay out of UNESCO. There had been some speculation the United States would resume its membership after UNESCO got a new director general, Federico Mayor of Spain. Mayor visited Washington several months ago to lobby for the United States' return, meeting with administration officials and members of Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Plants Tree to Symbolize Clean Air; Dedicates It to Ryan White
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs EMBARGOED until 7:05 p.m. EDT, with Bush remarks in Michigan
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Ryan White and AM-Clean Air
DOC.TEXT: President Bush planted a tree in an urban park on Tuesday as a symbolic gesture for clean air and new life and dedicated it to an 18-year-old Indiana youth dying from AIDS. ``Let this be Ryan's tree,'' Bush said as he planted an American elm and paid tribute to Ryan White. White, who became a nationally known advocate for the rights of children with the deadly virus to attend public schools, was near death in the intensive care unit of an Indianapolis hospital. ``He's been fighting a courageous battle against a deadly disease and also against ignorance and fear,'' Bush said. ``Ryan has helped us understand the truth about AIDS and he's shown all of us the strength, the bravery, of the human heart.'' The president, on a fund-raising swing through the Midwest for Republican candidates, used the tree-planting ceremony to observe the last-minute Senate passage of compromise clean-air legislation that has the blessings of his administration. He called the expected Senate approval later Tuesday a ``historic vote'' that he said would ``affect generations to come as we work to build a cleaner, safer America.'' It would be the first major overhaul of the Clean Air Act in 13 years. Trees, also, ``can also help ensure clean air,'' Bush said as he planted the tree in a downtown Indianapolis park in unseasonable near-freezing weather. Bush, who has also planted trees in a half-dozen other U.S. cities, has asked Congress for $175 million in fiscal 1991 to start a national program to plant a billion trees a year. ``As we plant this beautiful American elm, this symbol of new life, let it be Ryan's tree. God bless that young man. God bless his family,'' Bush said. The president delivered a major policy speech on AIDS last Thursday in which he called for legislation to ban discrimination and protect the rights of victims. Because of the seriousness of Ryan's condition, White House officials said Bush had abandoned plans to visit Riley Hosptial for Children, where the sick youth's family and friends were keeping a vigil. Later, at a fund-raising luncheon for Republican Sen. Dan Coats, Bush said Senate passage of clean-air legislation would help begin ``to build a cleaner, safer America.'' But he cautioned, ``It's going to take a lot of work to protect this great planet without throwing hard-working Americans out of work.'' ``I reject the extremists in the environmental movement who would burden our economy by mindless regulation,'' Bush said. ``And I reject those in industry who do not recognize their obligation to clean up the environment.'' ``Common sense tells us to find a needed balance. We will find that balance,'' he added. Coats was appointed to fill Dan Quayle's Senate seat and now is running for the job in his own right. Bush, speaking with reporters aboard Air Force One en route from Indianapolis to Detroit, sharply criticized Iraq President Saddam Hussein's threat on Monday to destroy ``half of Israel'' with chemical weapons if Israel attacked his country. ``This is no time to be escalating tensions in the Middle East. I find these statements to be bad and I would strongly urge Iraq to reject the use of chemical weapons,'' he said. On other topics, Bush: _Thanked the House leadership for moving toward a vote on his $800 million aid request for Panama and Nicaragua and urged ``the Senate to act immediately'' before they head home at the end of the week on an Easter recess. To Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell's criticism that Bush's foreign aid request was ``a jigsaw puzzle'' without an over-all view, Bush said, ``There's no jigsaw puzzle when it comes to what is best for democracy in Nicaragua and Panama. ... These are laser-like urgent requests to help Nicaragua and Panama.'' _Said he has not yet heard back from Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to the message Bush sent last Thursday on Lithuania. But Bush said his meeting Friday with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze ``will be the chance ... to see how that message went down in Moscow.'' _Reiterated that he hopes the situation in Lithuania will be ``handled in a cool fashion _ freedom, democracy and self-determination all goes forward, but where it's handled in a way (that) the result is peaceful and no use of force.'' Bush said he was ``a little encouraged by some comments that I read out of Lithuania yesterday. I just would encourage the Soviets to remember the pledge to achieve a peaceful resolution to this very difficult question.''
DOC.HEAD: Embargoed until 7:05 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: In his final stop on his two-day trip, Bush told a GOP fundraising dinner in Dearborn, Mich., a Detroit suburb, that he was proud of the clean-air legislation headed for Senate approval. ``Some think we must choose between a sound ecology and a sound economy. Republicans say: We need both. America can have clear air and good jobs,'' Bush said in prepared remarks. And, commenting on the so-called ``peace dividend'' that will come from reduced military spending because of decreased tensions in Eastern Europe, Bush asserted: ``The greatest peace dividend is peace itself.''

DOC.HEAD: Space Telescope Testing to Resume, Launch Date Unchanged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with telescope tests resuming, inserts quote from telescope's chief engineer; picks up 7th graf pvs, `The 25,000-pound ...'
DOC.TEXT: Testing of the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope resumed Tuesday after NASA technicians switched over to a backup power system to prevent another interruption from a power outage. Space shuttle Discovery is scheduled for launch April 10 provided the tests are concluded by Thursday and there are no further problems, said George Diller, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ``We're on thin ice, but it's do-able,'' Diller said. NASA must complete a 52-hour test of the telescope's scientific instruments before the shuttle can be launched. ``We won't know the condition of the Hubble Space Telescope until we get power to it. (But) we have no reason to suspect the Hubble Space Telescope suffered any damage'' from Monday's power outage, said Bill Taylor, the telescope's chief engineer at Kennedy Space Center. ``The schedule still shows it can be met,'' Taylor said of next week's scheduled launch. Technicians were in the middle of the telescope testing Monday when a broken pipe sprayed water on electrical equipment, resulting in the temporary power failure. The outage knocked out air conditioning at the launch control center and elsewhere, forcing the shutdown of heat-sensitive equipment, including computers used in the test. A system that backs up power to computers in the launch control center's four firing rooms was taken over by a newer system able to withstand an outage. Testing of the telescope resumed shortly afterward. The 25,000-pound, 43-foot-long telescope, the most expensive unmanned spacecraft ever built, was never in any danger from the cooling system breakdown, Diller said. Technicians began charging the telescope's batteries again Monday night, a positive sign, Diller said. On Saturday, Discovery's launch date was moved up from April 12 to April 10 because technicians believed they needed little of the contingency time built into the schedule. As of Tuesday, no contingency time was left, Diller said. Discovery's five astronauts will deploy the Hubble on the second day of the five-day mission. It will orbit 380 miles high for 15 years, free of atmospheric distortion. The telescope will be capable of detecting objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory. Images radioed from the telescope will enable astronomers to study stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling to Earth for 14 billion years.

DOC.HEAD: Return of Adoptive Boy Has Experts Scrambling For Explanations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, ```It's every ...' to CORRECT quote to `orphanage' sted `group home.'
DOC.TEXT: An 11-year-old boy whose adoptive parents separated him from his brother and sent him to a shelter during the Thanksgiving season wonders what he did wrong. But a judge ultimately will decide why things when awry. ``There's going to be a lot of finger-pointing,'' said Bill Pierce, president of the Washington, D.C.-based National Committee for Adoption. Cook County Public Guardian Patrick Murphy last week filed a lawsuit alleging the adoptive parents separated the two young brothers they adopted in 1984, putting the older boy in an group home and forbidding him from seeing his 8-year-old brother. The lawsuit filed in Circuit Court seeks visitation rights for the boys and $50,000 in damages for the child the couple gave up. The lawsuit refers to the child as Rick, not his real name, and says the parents _ identified as Joseph and Pamela Doe _ gave him back to the custody of the state because he hadn't ``bonded'' well with them. A hearing will be held Wednesday in which Murphy will ask for a ruling on the request for Rick to visit his brother, Murphy said. ``It's every little boy's nightmare,'' Murphy said after filing the lawsuit. ``Rick's parents told him they were going to put him into an orphange and they did it. It's like telling a kid you're going to send the bogey man after him and then doing it.'' ``Mom and dad were talking about something, and they said they were going to put me up for adoption,'' the boy said in a tape recording made available by Murphy. ``I thought they were kidding. They weren't.'' The parents put Rick in the group home on Nov. 20 and got approval March 9 from Circuit Court Judge Walter Williams to surrender their parental rights to Williams. The parents' attorney, Mary C. Martin, did not return a phone call Tuesday. Williams declined to comment on the case. Ron Morman of the Springfield-based Child Care Association of Illinois said the case is particularly troubling because of effects of the parent's action could have on the child. ``We view it with a great deal of concern because the whole point of adoption is to help the child find permanence ... to give him some sense of belonging, some sense of family,'' Morman said. Murphy said Rick is now in a temporary foster home and blames himself for his new circumstance. Officials at a number of adoption agencies noted that the boys in this case were not infants, but were older children adopted after their biological mother abandoned them. They said these children come to adoptions with problems and it is important that they are matched with parents capable of coping with their particular needs. Murphy, whose job as public guardian is to act on behalf of children such as Rick, calls the child a ``normal kid'' who has never been in trouble with the law. Pierce said it ``would be like malpractice to place a child in anything but'' that type of home that best fits the child's needs. But matching children to families is ``an imprecise art,'' he said. Agencies under the gun to place children rather than leave them in costly foster care arrangements may take risks and place a child despite misgivings about the home, Pierce said, adding that they also can make mistakes. A November report by the National Committee for Adoption said U.S. court records showed that 104,088 American children and 10,019 foreign children were adopted in the country in 1986, the last year such figures are available. A study done several years ago in five U.S. cities showed a 74 percent success rate _ meaning one in four adoptions were later dissolved _ said Joyce Johnson, a spokeswoman for the Washington, D.C.-based Child Welfare League of America. ``People bring children back,'' Johnson said. ``Children, for whatever reason, come back into the system and it's always a horror-type story when it happens.''

DOC.HEAD: Navy Concludes Nuke Blast Simulator Won't Harm Gulf Coast Environment
DOC.TEXT: The Navy wants to know whether ship electronics can survive a nuclear explosion in space and has decided a simulator test in the Gulf of Mexico would have no significant impact on the environment. But the service said one of three alternative sites in the Gulf has too much air and sea traffic to be appropriate for the tests of the Electromagnetic Pulse Radiation Environment Simulator for Ships (Empress II) program. In a draft environmental impact statement the Navy this week said the two sites it deemed acceptable both are located southeast of Mobile, Ala. The unacceptable site is located southwest of Mobile about 40 nautical miles from the coast. Empress II is a barge-mounted pulser that can simulate the electromagnetic field that would be generated on earth by a nuclear blast in space. The system sends out an electromagnetic pulse (EMP) that lasts just 10 billionths of a second, but measures 50,000 volts per meter at 100 meters from the barge in all directions. The Navy plans to fire the EMP at passing ships to test the effectiveness of measures designed to protect electronics systems from the EMP that would result from a nuclear explosion in space. Critics of the program contend that the EMP would endanger marine and plant life in the Gulf, the Navy personnel aboard the test ship, and the electronic systems of airplanes and ships that might be in the area But in the draft study on the program the Navy concluded that no such dangers exist. ``The collective potential environmental impact of the proposed Empress II action is estimated to be minor,'' the Navy said. ``Within this minor category, the potential impact is greater on the socioeconomic issues and less on both the natural resources and the physical site itself.'' Ships would be barred from passing within two nautical miles of the simulator barge in any direction, and airplanes would be excluded from a zone 6,000 feet above the two-nautical-mile exclusion zone. Plans call for the final environmental impact statement to be completed by June 15, clearing the way for a decision by the secretary of the Navy on whether to permit the testing program to begin in the Gulf next winter, said Capt. William Mahew, manger of the EMpress II program. The tests would be conducted up to 10 hours a day for no more than 60 days a year between November and April.

DOC.HEAD: Tight Senate Vote Predicted On S&L Regulator
DOC.TEXT: Supporters and opponents of President Bush's choice as top savings and loan regulator said Tuesday the nominee's admission of past drug use will play little role in the Senate decision on his confirmation. Senate leaders are aiming for a Wednesday vote on the nomination of T. Timothy Ryan Jr. to direct the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. In advance, most senators and industry lobbyists are predicting he will be confirmed by a narrow margin. Two Democrats joined Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee to endorse Ryan by an 11-10 vote on Friday. The administration, if it holds all Republican senators, would need to attract only three more Democrats for victory in the full Senate. Such an outcome would not necessarily upset Democrats, according to Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America. ``In terms of Democratic politics, you have someone in office who you can point your finger to and say, `I told you so,''' he said. Backers and detractors of the 44-year-old attorney say the debate will focus on his professional qualifications and not on his admission that he tried marijuana and cocaine in the early 1970s, when he was in law school. ``Nobody who I talked to on our side ... thought it was of significance,'' said Sen. Jake Garn of Utah, senior Republican on the Senate Banking Committee. Both Democrats and Republicans discussed the nomination in private luncheons Tuesday. In the Democratic caucus, according to a source who spoke on condition of anonymity, ``There was a lot of loud talk (about professional qualifications) but the expectation was he will get by on a tight vote.'' Republicans ``were all aware of the cocaine situation and there wasn't anyone who spoke who didn't say, `Hey ... in the context you look at it, we're not troubled by it,'' Garn said. ``I took it as something that should be looked at. I wanted to see if it was a pattern of behavior that extended beyond his college years. I did not find that,'' said Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas. ``I made my judgment based on the lack of qualification,'' said Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the banking panel. He and other opponents of Ryan point to his lack of experience in banking. Ryan served as the top attorney in the Labor Department early in the Reagan administration and as a private lawyer has specialized in pension and employee benefit law. ``I don't think any of you would pick this man to run your own bank,'' Riegle told bankers attending a trade group meeting. Many savings and loan executives are leery of Ryan because at his confirmation hearing he said he was unsure if the S&L industry should survive. However, S&L trade groups say they've been staying out of the battle, not wanting to campaign against the man likely to be the industry's chief regulator. Lincoln Savings and Loan Association owner Charles H. Keating Jr., at the center the nation's worst thrift failure and the subject of a $1.1 billion fraud suit filed by regulators, wrote letters to all senators opposing Ryan. ``I submit this is hardly the time to shrink from the challenge of finding competent people to handle the important affairs of our government. ... I fear for the future of the Republic,'' he said. Republicans are stressing Ryan's strength as a manager and his role, while serving as Labor Department solicitor, in cleaning up the Teamsters Union Central States Pension Fund. The administration circulated more than a dozen endorsements of Ryan from prominent Republicans and Democrats. They included Frank C. Carlucci, former secretary of Defense in the Reagan Administration, and George D. Gould, former under secretary the Treasury Department under Reagan. Among the Democrats were Hodding Carter III, assistant secretary of state under Jimmy Carter, and W. Harrison Wellford, former associate director of the Office of Management and Budget under Carter. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady continued a telephone campaign, urging senators to vote for Ryan, who spent the day visiting senators' offices. He declined comment to reporters who spotted him in the corridor of a Senate office building.

DOC.HEAD: Sextuplets Born to 20-Year-old in Venezuela
DOC.TEXT: A 20-year-old woman married to an unemployed oil worker gave birth Tuesday to sextuplets, and the hospital in this western city claimed they were the first ever in South America. All six were reported in satisfactory condition, though doctors placed them in intensive care because of their low birth weights. The mother had been pregnant for only 29 weeks. ``The father was happy _ although somewhat disoriented _ when I told him the good news and showed one of the babies,'' said Dr. Jaime Leon. A doctor said there are already triplets on both sides of the family. ``Both have contributed with their genes to this multiple delivery,'' said Leon. In addition, the mother had been taking fertility drugs. At a press conference, hospital spokesmen said they are the first sextuplets in South America. Dr. Henry Fuenmayor said there have been 12 other recorded cases in the world. The children were born from 6:30 a.m. to 7:07 a.m. The heaviest weighed 2.4 pounds and the lightest 1.8 pounds, the Paraiso Medical Center announced. They were delivered by Caesarean section. ``The mother and the sextuplets _ two girls and four boys _ are all in satisfactory condition, but at least 48 more hours are needed for a firm prognosis on the offsprings,'' said Leon. It was the second delivery for Elaine Paz de Medina, the mother. She is already the mother of a 3-year-old boy. Daniel Medina, the 29-year-old father, lost his job at a private oil company late last year. He hopes to find work at one of the state-owned oil companies in this oil-rich region. ``The couple has had a very positive reaction throughout all these months,'' Leon told The Associated Press in a telephone interview. Ms. Medina has been hospitalized since January, when doctors realized the pregnancy was exceptional. Public and private companies in Maracaibo have organized a foundation to help the sextuplets through their adult life. ``Had they been born after the 30th week, probably they would have required less precautions,'' Leon said. ``But I think chances are good for their survival.'' According to the 1989 Guinness Book of World Records, the highest number of babies reported at a single birth is 10. But it said nine was the greatest number medically recorded.

DOC.HEAD: More Victims of Mysterious Poisoning Hospitalized in Kosovo
DOC.TEXT: About 30 ethnic Albanian children in Kosovo on Tuesday were hospitalized claiming symptoms of a mysterious poisoning that last month threatened to trigger intercommunal clashes in the troubled province. The state Tanjug news agency and sources said the children from Podujevo, 18 miles north of the provincial capital of Pristina, complained of lung and skin irritations and claimed they were poisoned. Yugoslav authorities and some Western doctors had turned up no evidence of an alleged epidemic that hospitalized about 2,990 teen-agers _ most of them ethnic Albanians _ with the same symptoms last month in Kosovo. Some doctors suggested a feeling of insecurity and public hysteria may have played a part. Ethnic Albanians, who represent 90 percent of Kosovo's population, claimed minority Serbs were poisoning them with a mysterious gas. Serbs said ethnic Albanians stage-managed the poisoning to drive them from Kosovo by igniting major ethnic clashes. At least 60 ethnic Albanians have died in clashes with security forces in the past 12 months in Kosovo after Serbia, the largest Yugoslav republic, changed its constitution to assume near-total control over its province. Kosovo had enjoyed wide autonomy. Claiming Kosovo officials failed to protect Serbs from harassment by ethnic Albanians, Serbian authorities purged Albanians from leading police and government functions there. The Borba daily said Tuesday that Kosovo's Premier Jusuf Zejnulahu and Police Chief Jusuf Karakushi announced their resignations.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Choice Bill Goes to Governor; Veto Expected
DOC.TEXT: The state Legislature passed a largely symbolic measure Tuesday aimed at ensuring women will be able to continue getting legal abortions until the fetus is able to live outside the womb. Gov. Judd Gregg said he would veto the bill. After a brief debate, the House voted 200-135 for the bill, passed by the House earlier and amended by the Senate. The margin was shy of the two-thirds that would be needed to override Gregg's promised veto. The key vote in the Senate last week, 14-10, also was short of a two-thirds margin. The bill may not reach Gregg until next week, but he repeated Tuesday that he'll veto it. Under the U.S. Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision, abortion is legal and widely available in New Hampshire despite three 19th-century anti-abortion statutes that have not been enforced. The National Abortion Rights Action League considers the bill pro-choice advocates' best chance for abortion rights legislation in the country this year. But Peg Dobbie, the group's New Hampshire spokeswoman, said it would be a ``long shot'' for the Legislature to override a veto. Though not giving up hope, she said pro-choice advocates are now focusing on the November election. ``We plan to go out and elect more pro-choice legislators so we can be veto-proof,'' she said. The original House bill called for no restrictions on abortion until the 25th week of pregnancy. The Senate changed that to allow unrestricted abortion until the woman's doctor determined that the fetus could live outside the womb on its own. Both versions would allow abortions after fetal viability to protect the life or health of the mother or if the fetus has a life-threatening physical or congenital abnormality. Gregg believes the bill would foster ``doctor-shopping'' because doctors will differ on what constitutes viability, spokesman Brian Grip said. Gregg reiterated his stand that abortion should be limited to instances where the mother's life is in danger, there is a serious problem with the fetus or the pregnancy stemmed from rape or incest. State Rep. Thomas Gage, head of the Judiciary Committee, supported the amended bill, saying it set a ``medical standard in place of a political one ... rather than a hard line drawn in statute by black letter.'' But state Rep. Shawn Jasper said the medical community disagrees about when a fetus can survive outside a mother's womb and urged defeat of the bill. Elsewhere Tuesday: _In the Nebraska Legislature, anti-abortion lawmakers succeeded in keeping alive a proposal that would require a 24-hour waiting period before a woman has an abortion. They moved it to the second stage of floor consideration without allowing opportunity for amendment. _A Louisiana state senator introduced an anti-abortion bill that provides exceptions for saving the mother's life during birth, but allows no exceptions for cases of rape or incest. ``Just as being raped and becoming pregnant is a traumatic experience, so is aborting a child,'' said state Sen. Mike Cross. _In Minnesota, a second Senate committee rejected a measure that would prohibit most abortions in the state. The 1990 legislative session tentatively is scheduled to adjourn next week. _Voters in Ann Arbor, Mich., declared their university town a ``zone of reproductive freedom.'' Voters also approved on Monday a token $5 fine on abortion, should state or federal laws ever ban the procedure.

DOC.HEAD: Study Beefs Up Link Between Diet, Heart Disease
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The advice...' to CORRECT name of journal. Picks up 4th graf, `The study...
DOC.TEXT: A study of more than 12,800 men at high risk for heart disease found the death rate from heart attacks was 24 percent lower for those who received advice about nutrition or other health matters. About half of the 12,860 men studied at 22 clinics nationwide received the counseling several times a year. The others were examined annually and only received additional treatment if needed. The advice included information about lower cholesterol levels, counseling on quitting smoking and improved drug therapy to control high blood pressure, researchers reported in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. The study of men ages 35 to 57 began in 1973 and ended in 1982. The results reported in JAMA stem from a follow-up review in December 1985, after the treatment ended, said Marcus O. Kjelsberg, a statistician at the University of Minnesota's School of Public Health, where the data was analyzed. Initial examinations in 1982 showed no significant differences between the two groups, which surprised researchers and prompted the follow-up, Kjelsberg said in a telephone interview Tuesday. But the follow-up found the death rate from coronary heart disease after 1982 was 10.6 percent lower in men who had received the treatment, and the overall death rates were 7.7 percent lower. The biggest difference was in the death rate from heart attacks, which killed 106 of those in the special treatment group, 24 percent fewer than the 140 deaths noted in the other group. The ultimate results were not surprising, given the multitude of data showing a link between diet, smoking and heart disease, said Dr. Jeremiah Stamler, a cardiovascular epidemiologist at Northwestern University and a principal investigator in the study. ``Everything I know about all of this leads me to the inference that this should happen,'' Stamler said. Researchers expected to see the results earlier, at the end of the study, but they failed to anticipate several factors that may account for the delay, Stamler said. One reason may have been that all the volunteers for the study were relatively healthy, despite facing a higher than normal risk for heart disease because they smoked, had high blood pressure or high cholesterol levels or a combination of the three, Stamler said. Another reason for the delayed results may have been a change in drug treatment for high blood pressure that occurred toward the end of the study. The later treatment was considered more effective, Kjelsberg said. Researchers did not determine how many of the men who had received special treatment continued to seek it after the study ended, he said, but they asssumed that many stuck to their healthier lifestyles. ``The bottom line in this report is an encouraging one for the notion that intervention on these three risk factors does lead to a lower risk of death from either all causes or from coronary heart diseases,'' Kjelsberg said. The study was funded by the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute in Bethesda, Md.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Nazi Mass Murderer to Face West German Legal Authorities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD details, camp survivors' testimony, background on Schwammberger, Wiesenthal Center reax; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A former SS captain accused of killing thousands of people when he commanded Nazi labor camps is expected to be extradited from Argentina next month to face trial, the government said Tuesday. Argentine authorities approved the extradition last month of Joseph Schwammberger, who has reportedly been in ill health since his arrest outside the north-central city of Cordoba on Nov. 13, 1987. He had been living in Argentina for decades, most of the time in La Plata, near Buenos Aires. ``Schwammberger's case proves that even after long years, no one who has heaped guilt upon himself during the Nazi dictatorship is safe from justice's grip _ no matter where they are hiding,'' said Justice Minister Hans A. Engelhard. Schwammberger, 78, had been a fugitive since he disappeared from a train in 1948 while being taken from Germany to American military authorities in Austria for trial. He reportedly found a way to Argentina, when it was encouraging immigration of Europeans, and entered the country in about 1950. Prosecutors allege he was responsible for the deaths of up to 5,000 people, mostly Jews. Camp survivors who traveled to Buenos Aires in 1988 from Miami, Chicago and Toronto testified to court authorities that he shot to death starving prisoners or set dogs on them. Schwammberger was finally tracked down with the help of famed Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal. Wiesenthal learned in 1971 that Schwammberger was living in La Plata, where he had worked in a factory for years. The Nazi hunter informed Stuttgart prosecutors, who issued an arrest warrant, but apparently little action was taken by Argentine authorities until 1987. Schwammberger's name was on a list of 10 most-wanted Nazi war criminals published in 1987 by the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles. The list appeared in Argentine newspapers, which led authorities to Schwammberger, according to Wiesenthal. Schwammberger, apparently tipped off that police were on his trail, fled to a German-Argentine community outside Cordoba, where Argentine police later arrested him without incident. Rabbi Marvin Hier, dean of the Wiesenthal Center, said Tuesday the extradition comes at a ``very opportune time'' because of the imminent reunification of Germany. The trial will be an important educational event for East Germans ``who have never been exposed to the truth about the `final solution,''' he said. ``I would say this is going to be the last major Nazi war criminal trial, certainly of that proportion, in West Germany,'' he added. Engelhard said ``all arrangements have been made to pick up Schwammberger in Argentina.'' He said two law officials and an attorney will accompany Schwammberger on the trip to West Germany, scheduled May 3. Schwammberger will be handed over to justice officials from West Germany's Baden-Wuerrttemberg state, which has jurisdiction in the case, Engelhard said.

DOC.HEAD: Hong Kong Fashions in Snappy French Debut
DOC.TEXT: From glitz to snappy, colorful silk outfits, Hong Kong's first full-blown style show in Paris was an auspicious moment for the Oriental city. ``Hong Kong has progressed beyond bargain-basement clothes,'' said Dame Lydia Dunn, president of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council, before the show Monday evening in an ornate foyer of the old Paris Opera. Hong Kong is shucking its image as a producer of low-cost, low-quality clothes. ``We are also now exporting high-quality fashion to big international stores like I. Magnin and Bloomingdale's in the U.S., Harrod's in England, Seibu in Japan and Hertie in West Germany,'' said Dame Dunn. ``And now, the Galeries Lafayette in France, a fabulous showcase.'' The show was part of a Hong Kong promotion at the Galeries Lafayette department store to last through April 28. It was staged against a backdrop of Hong Kong high-rise buildings and began with a tableau of traditional Chinese silk robes. The 20 young designers represented in the show brought out clothes ranging from sporty sun-gear in dressy, full shorts, billowy shirts and culottes to pearl-and-sequin-embroidered split sheaths. They would have done honor to Suzie Wong, the appealing post-war bar girl featured in a film made from the book, ``The World of Suzie Wong.'' ``Fashion is our biggest export,'' said Dame Dunn, a high-powered figure in Hong Kong, the British colony due to come under mainland Chinese rule in 1997. Trained as a lawyer and now a director of several conglomerates, including Swire Pacific Limited and Cathay Pacific Airways, she was named O.B.E. (Order of the British Empire) in 1978, Commander of the British Empire in 1983 and Dame of the British Empire in 1989. Dame Dunn is optimistic for Hong Kong's business future, in spite of a drastic slump following the repression in Beijing's Tiananmen Square last June 4. ``Commercially, we're coming back nicely, and the stock market has reached its previous level,'' she said. In any case, Hong Kong is currently doing well in Paris. An early Galeries Lafayette preview of the exhibition last Friday looked like a post-Christmas Macy's bargain-basement sale. Galeries guests were snapping up everything from cat-shaped porcelain teapots to wicker baskets, rugs and satin evening bags, priced very reasonably by Paris standards. ``Just say that our daily sales since the opening have picked up about 10 percent over our usual turnover,'' said Jean-Michel Girardin, Galeries Lafayette's director of sales promotions. The show is also attracting store clients to an art exhibition of antique snuffboxes, porcelains, tapestries and paintings from private collections.

DOC.HEAD: Theft of Jurors' Belongings Delays Trial
DOC.TEXT: The theft of the jury's luggage delayed the start of a trial Tuesday for an inmate charged with killing his former wife while he was free on furlough. The judge said the jurors, who were being brought from another county, would have their lost belongings replaced and would be seated Wednesday. ``Come hell or high water, we'll get the jury to St. Joseph County tonight,'' said Lake Superior Judge James E. Letsinger on Tuesday. The defendant, Alan L. Matheney, 39, is charged with murder and burglary in the March 1989 beating death of Lisa Marie Bianco. The prosecution is seeking the death penalty. The 12 jurors and two alternates had been selected Monday in Lake County and was being brought 60 miles east to hear the case in St. Joseph County. The luggage was taken Monday evening from two vans parked at a restaurant near Interstate 65, while the jurors were inside having dinner, said Merrillville police Sgt. Dan Dallas. ``It must have been during the (NCAA championship) basketball game, because no one was paying any attention,'' he said. As part of standard questioning of prospective jurors to uncover potential bias against the prosecution or defense, the jurors had been asked earlier Monday if they had ever been victims of crimes. Letsinger said the jurors would be quizzed again to ensure the thefts would not affect their willingness to hear the case fairly. The judge said he expects the jurors will say they have not been affected. ``Can you think of anybody who hasn't been a victim of crime?'' he said. ``I didn't know that was possible. Every time a politician takes money in this county, the people are victims. There's no such thing as a person who's never been a victim.'' Defense attorney Scott L. King did not ask for a mistrial, and Letsinger said he did not anticipate a motion for a mistrial. Ms. Bianco was found beaten to death outside her Mishawaka home. The slaying occurred several hours after Matheney was granted an eight-hour furlough from a Pendleton prison where he was serving an eight-year term for assaulting Ms. Bianco. Matheney surrendered to police later that day.

DOC.HEAD: Snow And Rain In East
DOC.TEXT: Rain and snow were scattered over the eastern half of the nation Tuesday and cold weather headed into the deep South. At midday, snow fell over eastern Michigan, Indiana, northeastern Kentucky, Ohio, West Virginia and western Pennsylvania. Rain extended from Vermont and southern New England across eastern New York state, New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania. The heaviest rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT was 1.10 inches at Islip, N.Y. Elsewhere, showers and thunderstorms extended across southern Florida. Showers also were scattered from southeastern New Mexico into southwestern Texas. During the night, scattered frost was forecast in the upstate and midlands of South Carolina and by daybreak Wednesday frost was possible over much of Georgia and into Alabama. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 31 at Mansfield, Ohio, to 86 at Homestead, Fla. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 11 above zero at Duluth, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Mladenov Elected President, June Vote Set, Communist Party Renamed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with background on new president, elections, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Tuesday adopted legislation for free elections and unanimously voted Petar Mladenov, who initiated democratic reforms in Bulgaria, to a newly created presidency. The ruling Communists also renamed their disgraced party the Bulgarian Socialist Party in an apparent effort to distance themselves from their hard-line past and decades of unpopular rule in Bulgaria. The legislation for multiparty elections scheduled this June sets the terms for the first free balloting in Bulgaria since World War II. The legislation was agreed to last week following three months of tough talks between the Communists and the opposition, and was ratified by Parliament along with constitutional amendments abolishing all references to ``Communist'' and ``Socialist.'' Both the Communists and the opposition agreed last Friday to Mladenov's election to the new presidency. Mladenov had served as the Communist president of the State Council that was formally dissolved Tuesday. As in neighboring Romania and other East European countries, the State Council under the Communists acted effectively as the legislature in between infrequent sessions of the countries' rubber-stamp parliaments. Mladenov, 53, was elected to the new temporary presidency. He is to be replaced after the newly elected parliament approves a new constitution. Elections have been set for June 10, with runoffs scheduled for June 17. In his acceptance address, Mladenov said guaranteeing peaceful transition from totalitarianism to democracy ``is the most important and the most complicated task at this stage,'' the state BTA news agency reported. He said Bulgaria's first test of democracy would be the June elections. ``People should be provided with conditions to have their fair and open say, proceeding from their own aspirations and acting on their own free will on the future they prefer for (Bulgaria),'' BTA quoted Mladenov as saying. He also said implementation of a radical economic reform would require ``tremendous efforts.'' ``Years of complications, strain and difficulties lie ahead, but there is no other way out. We should not delude ourselves with false hopes of miracles,'' Mladenov was quoted as telling Parliament in his speech. Mladenov is relatively popular, according to recent polls, because he is considered responsible for ousting longtime hard-line Communist leader Todor Zhivkov in a leadership reshuffle last November when he became party leader. He relinquished that party post in February. After taking over the party leadership, Mladenov elevated reformists to top positions and began a dialogue with the opposition toward the transition to democracy. The constitutional amendments that were adopted anchor political pluralism in the constitution and describe Bulgaria as a ``democratic, parliamentary and law-abiding state,'' BTA reported. The constitution was also amended to declare any form of censorship illegal. The party's name change was announced by Stefan Prodev, editor of former Communist Party daily Rabotnichesko Delo, or Workers' Affairs, which changed its name Monday to the Duma, or the Word. Former Communist Party leader Alexander Lilov, now a Socialist, told a rally in downtown Sofia late Tuesday that the party was ``breaking with the mistakes, the abuses and the crimes of the past.'' ``We want radical reforms in everything, including the party,'' Lilov was reported to have said, adding, ``Certain right-wing forces are trying to push the country toward a new totalitarianism.'' He did not elaborate. Mladenov served as foreign minister from 1971 _ when he was 35 _ until last Nov. 10, when Zhivkov resigned after 34 years in power. Born into a peasant's family in 1936 in a village in northwestern Bulgaria, Mladenov studied philosophy at Sofia Univesity and was graduated from the prestigious Moscow State Institute of International Relations in 1963. He joined the Communist Party a year later. A regional party secretary of the Vidin county in northwestern Bulgaria, he quickly made his way up through party ranks and became a Central Committee member in 1971. He was appointed a full Politburo member in 1977.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan House Committee Approves Ban on Sobriety Check Lanes
DOC.TEXT: Michigan's government went to the U.S. Supreme Court in its fight for the right to set up roadblocks to nab drunken drivers, but Michigan lawmakers are moving to ban the checkpoints. The House Judiciary Committee, citing a violation of civil liberties associated with randomly pulling over drivers to check for illegal activity, voted 11-7 Tuesday to prohibit the sobriety check lanes. Such a ban, if approved by the full House and the Senate, would take effect even if the nation's high court rules that the checkpoints are constitutional. The court heard oral arguments on the case last month. The state is appealing a February 1989 Michigan Supreme Court decision that let stand lower court rulings declaring the procedure unconstitutional. At issue is whether the random stops violate the Fourth Amendment's protections against unreasonable searches and seizures. Gov. James Blanchard had issued an executive order in 1986 directing the Department of State Police to use roadblocks to combat drunken driving. Only one checkpoint was set up before a group of lawmakers won a court order blocking the procedure. ``I believe that sobriety check lanes are an invasion of the Constitution, an invasion of human and civil rights,'' said the bill's sponsor, state Rep. Morris Hood. ``Today when we scan the globe and see what's taking place in Eastern Europe, in Central America and hopefully soon in South America, we see the cry for freedom, the cry for democracy, the cry for civil rights. ``I don't think you give away your liberty and your freedom under the guise that it may save some lives.'' State Rep. William Van Regenmorter said the right not to be harmed or killed by a drunken driver also ought to be considered. He proposed an unsuccessful amendment which would have permitted the roadblocks in predesignated high-risk areas during the night, when most drunken driving incidents occur. If the Democrat-led House passes the bill it will face a tougher hurdle in the Republican-led Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Shots Fired At Bus On A Greyhound Route, Same Road Where Driver Wounded
DOC.TEXT: At least five shots struck a Southeastern Trailways bus Tuesday as it traveled along a Greyhound route. No injuries were reported, state police said. A bus on the same route was shot at Saturday and its driver seriously wounded. There have been reports of sporadic violence and other shootings since 6,300 Greyhound drivers went on strike March 2. The company blames the union and says there will be no contract talks until a week goes by with no violence. The drivers union has suggested the company's refusal to negotiate is partly to blame for the violence. Kentucky State Police Trooper Eddie Lair said the shooting occurred along Interstate 65 somewhere between Upton, LaRue County, and Sonora, about 45 miles south of Louisville, as the bus headed from Nashville, Tenn., to Louisville. Lair said all five shots hit the bus on the driver's side, but none of them penetrated. Officials believe a .22-caliber rifle was used. The driver, who was not identified, could not say from which direction the shots were fired, Lair said. The driver and the lone passenger were not injured. On Saturday, another Southeastern Trailways bus was shot at and the bus driver was struck in the left arm, requiring six hours of surgery. That bus had not yet entered Kentucky when it was attacked.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Guerrillas Call for Election Strike in Lima
DOC.TEXT: Maoist guerrillas are calling for a two-day general strike in this capital to keep Peruvians from voting in Sunday's general elections. Leaflets in the name of the Shining Path movement found Tuesday in two Lima markets warned voters to boycott the polls. The rebels called their strikes for Saturday and Sunday. The government has urged voters to ignore the strike calls. It says it will guarantee the safety of voters. Voting is mandatory in Peru. Shining Path rebels earlier had called strikes in two mountain regions Saturday through Monday. A police spokesman said the leaflets found in the Lima markets said ``No elections,'' and ``No more tricks. Arms will lead the people to power. Down with the government of hunger.'' The country is governed by the popularly elected center-left Aprista Party. The rebels called for an ``armed strike,'' which carries the threat to kill those who disregard it. The guerrillas have mounted a wave of attacks to sabotage the campaign. Late Monday, suspected guerrillas shot and wounded a guard outside the house of a minor presidential candidate, police said. The candidate, Ezequiel Ataucusi, is leader of a small religious sect. Peruvians go to the polls Sunday to elect a president, 60 senators and 180 members of congress. They will take office July 28. In the presidential race, novelist Mario Vargas Llosa holds a wide lead in opinion polls. But most analysts predict he will fall short of a majority, requiring a runoff. The Shining Path launched its armed insurgency against Peru's elected governments in 1980. The government says more than 18,000 people have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Hard-Core Rioters Control Prison Wings in England; Injured Inmate Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with new figures, talks suspended for night, details. Picks up 17th pvs, `As darkness...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON3,5,MAN1
DOC.TEXT: Die-hard mutineers held fast to a large part of Strangeways Prison on Tuesday for the third day and kept other inmates from surrendering, the government said. A wounded prisoner died in a hospital. Thirteen guards were injured by flying bricks, poles and other missiles in an operation Tuesday to regain control of sections of the decaying Victorian structure, said Ivor Serle, chairman of the local branch of the Prison Officers' Association. He said six were hospitalized. Serle said about 20 ``hard core of the hard core'' prisoners were stopping the other inmates from giving up. Prison negotiators suspended talks with the holdouts Tuesday night but were ready to resume at any time, said Charles Keseru, a spokesman for the Home Office, the Cabinet-level department with responsibility for prisons. Keseru and Serle said Tuesday night that 31 prisoners surrendered during the day. Serle said 68 convicts remained in the red-brick prison. Keseru said fewer than 40 convicts were left defying prison authorities. There was no explanation for the discrepancy. Authorities have said 37 inmates and 19 guards at the crowded prison have been injured since rioting broke out at a chapel service Sunday morning. Strangeways, built in 1868 to hold 970 men, had 1,648 prisoners Sunday, ranging from dangerous convicts to men awaiting trial. Manchester-born Derek White, 46, who had been in a segregation wing for his own protection awaiting trial on sex offenses, became the first fatality. He died at North Manchester Hospital where he had been in intensive care since Sunday, suffering from head wounds and chest pains, the Home Office said. Serle said the guards regained control of one wing on Tuesday and all the lower floors of the four other wings held by inmates. ``There were many broken bones, and one officer has a punctured lung,'' he reported. Advancing guards carried only shields and truncheons, he added. ``That's all. This is England, not America,'' he snapped at an American reporter. But the Home Office's Keseru said Tuesday night that prisoners still controlled four of the nine wings at the prison and the administrative area. Guards regained control of the other wings and the prison kitchen on Monday. As darkness fell, about a dozen young prisoners remained on the prison roof in the cold, shouting through a megaphone to friends and family gathered behind a police barrier below. ``The jail's going up tonight, believe it!'' inmates shouted. People behind the barrier shouted out names of relatives. ``Come bleeding down!'' a woman yelled. ``Who's shouting?,'' asked a voice from the roof. ``His mother!'' responded the woman, who refused to give her name. She wept. British newspapers have speculated that up to 30 people died in the rioting. Serle said no bodies had been found inside the prison. He told reporters his ``gut feeling'' was that some men had died, but ``I hope to God I'm wrong.'' The father of a youth who was in the same wing as sex offenders, segregated because of his age but on a different landing, said on BBC-TV news his son told him he witnessed six murders. The youth was transferred to a jail in the south of England where the father said he saw him on Tuesday. Shown in silhouette, the father, who refused to be identified, relayed his son's account of kangaroo courts in which makeshift ropes made from sheets were tied around prisoners' necks. They were lined up against the railings on the jail landings. ``The charges were read out against them and they were pushed over. My son said he couldn't see any way they could possibly have lived,'' the father said. Prisoners opened negotiations Tuesday with warden Brendan O'Friel and demanded a member of Parliament witness their surrender. They wanted each inmate photographed, as a protection against beatings by guards. At Long Lartin Prison, 100 miles south of Manchester, 33 inmates who barricaded part of a building after an attempted breakout ended their protest peacefully Tuesday morning, the Home Office said. No injuries were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Tackle Legislation to Aid Farm Prices
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 4, `The legislation ...' to CORRECT that Sen. Conrad from North Dakota, sted South Dakota.
DOC.TEXT: Five Midwestern senators introduced legislation Tuesday to include in the 1990 farm bill that they said would protect farmers against the rising costs of growing food. Meanwhile, a House Agriculture subcommittee approved a dairy program for the farm bill that revamps price supports in order to stop excessive production of butter fat.
