The Senate bill, dubbed the Farm Income and Flexibility Act, will be the basis for the target price section of the massive legislation Congress writes every five years to set agriculture policy, said the group of Democratic senators. The legislation is necessary to preserve family farming, which is the best protection against rising consumer food costs that the government can devise, said the senators. The group includes Sens. Robert Kerrey and James Exon, of Nebraska; Tom Daschle of South Dakota, Tom Harkin of Iowa and Kent Conrad of North Dakota. Kerrey said the legislation would cost about $12 billion annually. The Bush administration wants to lower the cost of target prices and has recommended spending no more than about $10 billion next year. Target prices are the amounts the government sets for wheat, corn, cotton, soybeans and rice. If the market price does not reach the amount, the government pays the farmer the difference. Under the House dairy program, the government would buy up to 7 billion pounds of milk products, at $10.60 per hundred pounds, if they can't be sold on the open market. Farmers who produce more than their share of the government's limit would get a lower amount. The Senate has not approved a dairy plan yet. Kerrey, who has led the battle against the administration's target price proposals, said there are three basic reasons why consumers should want the government involved in the farm business. _Government management of surpluses protects against unstable weather conditions. _U.S. food prices are kept the lowest in the world by a strong government program. _The subsidy is a bargain at less than the 1 percent of the annual federal budget. People who live in urban areas have an interest in seeing the family farm preserved as a guard against the higher food prices likely if farms were consolidated, said an aide to Daschle. If agricultural production were in the hands of just a few people, food prices would also be under their control, said Mark Ulven. If farmers don't have the government's help in covering their production costs, they might easily go out of business and sell their farms to a corporation, he said. ``U.S. consumers today spend just 10.4 percent of their disposable income on food, the lowest level in history and less than consumers in any other country,'' said Kerrey. But the producer's share of each dollar spent on food has dropped to an all-time low, he said. ``In 1988, according to USDA, farmers and ranchers received only 30 cents of each dollar spent on food consumed at home,'' Kerrey said. Conrad said that once inflation was taken into account, net farm income in the 1980s was the lowest it's been since 1910 when the government started keeping records. ``We keep hearing from the administration that the farm crisis is over and farm income is at record levels,'' said Conrad. ``That's just a bunch of Washington happy talk.'' Provisions in the senators' bill include: _tying target prices to increased production costs. _raising loan rates (which help determine market prices) by more than 20 percent next year, and setting a floor on the loan rate for corn of $2.10 and for wheat of $2.75. _establishing a normal crop acreage base for each farm that is the total of the farm's current crop-specific bases, plus the average acreage planted to soybeans during the last five years. _raising income support levels on oilseeds, oats and barley to levels comparable with wheat and corn.

DOC.HEAD: House Urges Bush To Win Release of Hostages
DOC.TEXT: The House approved a resolution late Tuesday calling on President Bush to accelerate efforts to win the release of Americans held hostage in Lebanon. The resolution, approved on a voice vote without dissent, also called on countries with ``direct or indirect influence'' over the kidnappers, including Iran and Syria, to press for the hostages' release. The non-binding measure was sent to the Senate. An earlier version of the resolution had called for Bush to designate a special envoy to negotiate the release of hostages, but that provision was opposed by the administration. The document approved Tuesday called instead for Bush to accelerat efforts through increased State Department and other diplomatic activities and by enlisting the United Nations and the European Community to exercise their influence. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., a senior Foreign Affairs Committee member, said the administration had no objection to the revised language and that it was not intended to revise U.S. policy against making concessions to terrorists. The measure's sponsor, Rep. Louise Slaughter, D-N.Y., represents the home district of hostage Terry Anderson, the Associated Press Middle East bureau chief, who has been held for five years the longest of eight American hostages. She said it was ``important that we go on record'' to say, ``We won't forget. We want you back.''

DOC.HEAD: Golub Convicted In Slaying of 13-Year-Old Neighbor
DOC.TEXT: A man was convicted Tuesday of second-degree murder in the slaying of a 13-year-old neighbor whose beaten, sexually mutilated and strangled body was found stuffed into a storage closet. The nine-week trial had pitted neighbor against neighbor and included obscene outbursts from both sides. The jury found Robert Golub, 22, guilty in the 1989 beating and strangulation of Kelly Ann Tinyes. Victoria Tinyes, the girl's mother, pounded the courtroom railing and screamed after the verdict. Other Tinyes family members shouted obscenities at Golub, who sat quietly at the defense table. ``Who's the animal here?'' screamed one man before court officers took him from the courtroom. The Golubs and the Tinyes family sat on opposite sides of the court each day of the trial. About 25 court officers were in the room for the verdict because the families had confronted each other several times since Golub's arrest. ``I'm just sorry I didn't get my hands on him,'' said Miss Tinyes' grandfather, Victor Giordonello, outside the courtroom. Golub's parents sat crying as their son was led away in handcuffs. Both sets of parents left without speaking to reporters. Golub faces up to 25 years to life in prison when he is sentenced June 1. Miss Tinyes' battered body was discovered March 4, 1989, in a basement closet of the Golub home, which is on the same block as the Tinyes home in Valley Stream, N.Y. She had disappeared a day earlier. Prosecutors said Miss Tinyes was lured to her death by a telephone call from the Golub household. The prosecution contended Robert Golub forced her into the basement and killed her as she fought off a sexual attack. Her beaten, sexually mutilated, strangled body was found wrapped in a sleeping bag and stuffed into a storage closet. Her clothing, ripped from her body in the attack, was found in three nearby attache cases. Golub, who did not testify, told police he spent the day sleeping and reading muscle magazines in his upstairs bedroom. Defense attorney Salvatore Marinello said Golub was a scapegoat for police desperate to make an arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Lodges Protest with Panama Over Claims to Legitimacy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with further criticisms, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Mexico lodged a formal protest with Panama on Tuesday in the latest round of a bitter quarrel over which government has the shakiest claim to legitimacy. Mexico's ``energetic'' protest followed an assertion by President Guillermo Endara of Panama that Mexico's governing party used electoral fraud to stay in power. He made the remark after Mexico and six other Latin American nations said Panama should hold elections to ``legitimize'' his government. He took power in December during the U.S. invasion that ousted dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. Foreign Minister Julio Linares of Panama said Mexico and the other countries are picking on the wrong guy. ``Has any of these countries broken relations with the United States? Has any of them retired its ambassador from the United States?'' he said in an interview Tuesday with Notimex, the official Mexican news agency. ``It's easier to condemn the victim because the United States is a powerful country, a country with money, a strong country.'' For 21 years, Panama's dictators had the blessings of ``all Latin America and the United States, too,'' he was quoted as saying. He added, however, that Panama was not considering breaking off relations with Mexico. Columnists and editorial writers in both capitals have joined the fray, as have politicians. Mexico's official government newspaper, El Nacional, used the words ``bluster,'' ``swagger'' and ``stupid'' Monday to describe Endara. Newspapers in Panama, meanwhile, said Mexico's ``party dictatorship'' had been a model for Panama's bygone military regimes. ``What kind of explanation does Mexico want?'' Panama City columnist Boris Barrios asked Tuesday. ``An explanation because President Endara spoke a truth that bothers them?'' But a lawmaker from Panama's opposition Revolutionary Democratic Party suggested in Panama City that Endara spoke unwisely. ``The president's advisers are saying he shot off his mouth,'' said Gerardo Gonzalez. The Mexican Foreign Ministry refused to disclose the text of the protest note but said it called on Panamanian authorities to ``guarantee the security'' of Mexican diplomats and anyone under Mexico's diplomatic protection in Panama. The battle began after the Rio Group _ Mexico, Colombia, Uruguay, Argentina, Venezuela, Brazil and Peru _ said Friday that elections should be held in Panama. Mexico, Peru and Argentina have refused to send ambassadors to Endara's government. The Rio Group's statement, issued in Mexico City, angered Endara. His ticket easily won a May election in Panama, according to election observers, but Noriega nullified the results. On Saturday, Endara issued a retort to the Rio group's statement. He said his own government was ``legitimized by the people at the polls on May 7.'' ``We don't want the legitimization of the Mexican government ... because it is a government that came to power through sheer electoral fraud,'' he added. The Panamanian president touched a raw nerve in Mexico, where the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, has been in power for 61 years and has often been accused of cheating at the ballot box. Unlike Panama under Noriega or Nicaragua under the Sandinistas, Mexico has not permitted international observers to monitor its elections. The outcome of the 1988 presidential race is still clouded by accusations the PRI resorted to electoral fraud. The PRI on Monday acccused Endara of presiding over the ``persecution, torture, jailing and execution of thousands of Panamanians,'' presumably during the invasion. There have been no reports of torture or execution. Even the two main opposition parties in Mexico _ which accuse PRI of cheating at the polls _ said Endara had spoken out of turn. Being sworn in by an invading force ``is not the best way to to demonstrate the independence and sovereignty of Panama,'' said Luis Alvarez, president of the conservative National Action Party or PAN. Sen. Cristobal Arias Solis of the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party described Endara's authority as ``spurious'' because of the way he came to power.

DOC.HEAD: Honduran Immigrant's Dream Ends in Fiery Death in New York
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Progress has been slow in coming to this small, dusty town, and Jose Manuel Marquez Hernandez was among its young people who turned to the United States to seek their future. For Marquez, 24, the immigrant's dream of a better life ended on March 25 in a fire at the Happy Land social club in the Bronx, New York City. He and six other young Hondurans were buried this week in El Progreso, a town of 30,000. They were among 87 people killed in the fire. At least 78 were Hondurans, most from the northern Atlantic coast region. The local victims came from poor families and had limited choices: a lowly job at one of the U.S. fruit companies that made Honduras the original ``banana republic;'' a dead-end job in San Pedro Sula, a coastal industrial center of 600,000 people, or New York, a promised land of jobs, education, opportunity. Marquez left six years ago, when just a teen-ager. ``He wrote me last month,'' said Gregorio Hernandez, his uncle. ``He had gotten his high school equivalency diploma; he was applying to go to college.'' Meanwhile, Marquez worked at a factory, cutting leather to make clothing, handbags, shoes. Even at minimum wage, he earned enough to survive and send money home to his mother. ``I wrote him back,'' Hernandez said. ``I said: become a professional. A professional never goes hungry. A professional lands on his feet anywhere life throws him.'' Hernandez was the first person in his family of nine children to finish high school. ``My three older brothers only finished the eighth grade because back then there wasn't a high school here and my father didn't have the money to send them to San Pedro Sula,'' Hernandez said. The brothers worked for the Tela Railroad Co., a subsidiary of Chiquita Brands, which has extensive banana plantations in Honduras. Hernandez became a supervisor at a textile factory in San Pedro Sula and assumed the leadership of the extended family clan because of his education and his job in the big city. Wanting something better for his own children and those of his brothers and sisters, he sent his daughter and Marquez to New York to live with relatives. ``He never once failed with his monthly money for his mother and his brothers and sister,'' said Hernandez. When Marquez's older sister, one of four children, started college in San Pedro Sula, Marquez sent her a new typewriter. When he came home for Christmas, he brought gifts: a book for an aunt, sunglasses for his twin younger brothers, a small stereo for the family, money for his mother, who has been separated from his father for years. ``He was her sole support,'' said Hernandez. Marquez's Christmas visit was the first since he left El Progreso. Last Sunday he returned in a slate blue coffin on a Red Cross charter jet that carried the bodies of 47 other Hondurans as well. The Hernandez clan and neighborhood friends met him, as they had at Christmas. ``We've had to borrow money to pay for the funeral and the plot in the cemetery, about 1,200 lempiras ($300),'' said Hernandez. ``We're not rich. but we had to give him a proper burial.'' At the crowded cemetery in El Progreso, a boyhood friend, Jose Cardenas, 24, perched on one of the simple, cement-covered graves painted pink, blue and white and overrun with weeds and dust from unpaved streets. Cardenas had also gone to New York, but was deported last year as an illegal alien. ``Leaving here for New York is a change of life for the better, because there is nothing here,'' he said as Marquez's funeral procession arrived. ``You stay here and do this,'' he said, pointing to a rag-clad grave digger, ``or you go to New York.''

DOC.HEAD: Building Owner Surrenders on Old Warrant
DOC.TEXT: The landlord of a social club destroyed in an arson fire that claimed 87 lives surrendered Tuesday on an arrest warrant issued 14 months ago when he failed to appear on charges of safety violations. The building owner, Alex DiLorenzo III, could face 90 days in jail and a $5,000 fine if convicted of knowingly allowing an illegal club in his building. The Happy Land Social Club was destroyed March 25 when a Cuban refugee allegedly torched the place after a fight with his girlfriend, police said. He has been charged with 87 murders. DiLorenzo is accused of lacking a club permit and failing to install sprinklers and emergency lights. He was released without bail by Bronx Criminal Court Judge Harold Enten, with a hearing set for April 20, police said. He is accused of lacking a club permit and failing to install sprinklers and emergency lights. The city ordered the club closed in November 1988, to no avail. Officials said they had notified DiLorenzo in writing of the violations; on Feb. 3, 1989, when he failed to appear for a hearing, the warrant for his arrest was issued by Criminal Court Judge James E. Robinson.

DOC.HEAD: 6.5 Quake Rocks Nicaragua, Costa Rica, No Casualties Reported
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with location of epicenter off Costa Rica near Nicaragua border, quake felt from Managua to San Jose. Picks up 5th, `Several aftershocks...'
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake measuring 6.5 on the Richter scale rocked Nicaragua and neighboring Costa Rica on Tuesday, causing panic in Managua and along its Pacific coast. Authorities said they had no reports of casualties. The quake, which began at 5:57 p.m. (6:57 p.m. EDT), caused damage to a building and pool in the new beach resort of Montelimar, where five Central American presidents are holding a two-day meeting to negotiate peace in the region. One of the seven swimming pools and the still-unfinished complex center in Montelimar sustained serious cracks from the intensity of the quake. The other pools swayed from the 30-second tremor, and water spilled over the sides in small waves. The U.S. Geological Survey Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., said a preliminary reading showed the earthquake occurred off the coast of Costa Rica near the Nicaragua border with a magnitude of 6.5. The USGS spokesman said the epicenter was about 70 miles south of Managua and 175 miles northwest of San Jose, Costa Rica. He said the quake was felt throughout most of Nicaragua, northern Costa Rica and even in San Jose. Several aftershocks followed about 15 minutes later. In Managua, people fled into the streets in fear, and the National Legislature suspended its session. The downtown part of the capital was razed and 10,000 were killed by an earthquake in 1972. There were no immediate reports of damage or casualties in Costa Rica. In Montelimar, outgoing President Daniel Ortega and President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro were walking down the stairs together from a meeting with the presidents of Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador and Costa Rica when the stairway started swaying. The two Nicaraguan leaders waited until the earth stopped rocking, then continued without incident to a hall on the ground floor where they planned a news conference with about 100 journalists. Long-distance telephone operators said the quake was felt as far away as Corinto, in the northwest. The devastating quake last October in the San Francisco Bay area measured 7.1. A quake of magnitude 6 can cause severe damage in populated areas, and one measuring 7 is considered a major earthquake, capable of widespread, heavy damage in populated areas.

DOC.TEXT: Dixon was among only the 11 senators who voted against the legislation. ``I cannot vote for legislation that will destroy the livlihood of thousands of hard working men and women ... that will bring economic ruin to communities throughout Appalachian and midwestern states,'' said Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., who unsuccessfully had sought financial help for coal miners affected by the bill. The final vote came after a brief flurry of excitement over an attempt by Sen. Don Nickles, R-Okla., at the last minute to change the permit requirements of the bill and make it easier for businesses to comply. Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., called the 34-page amendment ``an ambush'' that would hamper enforcement of the new requirements and hinder civil suits against polluters. The amendment was narrowly defeated by a vote of 51-49.
DOC.HEAD: Pickup 6th graf a0629: The clean air...
Fan Pleads Innocent in Armed Break-in at Actress' Home
DOC.TEXT: A fan obsessed with actress Sharon Gless pleaded innocent Tuesday to breaking into her home and holding police at bay with a rifle. Joni Leigh Penn, 30, entered the pleas before Municipal Court Commissioner Gerald T. Richardson, who set an April 12 preliminary hearing. Ms. Penn remained silent during the 10-minute hearing, with her attorney answering questions for her. She was charged with two counts of residential burglary to commit theft. Both charges included firearms allegations. If convicted on both counts Ms. Penn could face 10 years in prison. Prosecutors sought $1 million bail for Ms. Penn, but Richardson decided after hearing arguments to set no bail in the case. Ms. Penn was arrested March 30 after a seven-hour standoff with police officers. She was armed with a .22-caliber rifle but there was no shooting. Miss Gless, who played a tough police detective on the old ``Cagney and Lacey'' television series, was staying at another home and was not at the single-story stucco residence at the time of the break-in.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Fighter Jet Crashes, Pilot Safely Ejects
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Air Force F-16 fighter jet crashed Tuesday afternoon near Kunsan Air Base 110 miles south of Seoul, according to an Air Force press release. The pilot, Capt. Stephen R. Howell, 34, was reported in good condition after ejecting from the jet. At the time of the accident, the plane was on final approach for landing at the air base before it went down about seven miles south of the base, the release said. It said Howell is assigned to the 80th Tactical Fighter Squadron and that his family lives in Longview, Texas. The Yonhap News Agency said the plane crashed into a rice paddy and was destroyed. Cause of the accident has not been determined.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia University Enters Lawsuit Over Treasure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `On one...' to CORRECT name of group to Columbus sted Columbia. Picks up 5th graf, `Now, attorneys...
DOC.TEXT: Columbia University and two businessmen were last-minute additions Tuesday to a lawsuit over ownership of gold ingots and coins found 1{ miles deep on the ocean floor. U.S. District Judge Richard B. Kellam ruled the school and the businessmen could intervene in the lawsuit to establish ownership of the treasure that went down with the SS Central America in 1857, 160 miles off the South Carolina coast. The trial began Tuesday with testimony after both sides agreed to dispense with opening arguments. On one side is the Columbus-America Discovery Group, which used space age technology to find and recover the treasure; on the other is a group of insurance companies, which paid out claims 132 years ago for the insured cargo and argue it still belongs to them. Now, attorneys for the New York City school said data provided by one of their researchers led the Columbus-America Group to the site of the shipwreck, resting 1{ miles deep in the Atlantic Ocean. John Richardson, an attorney for the school, said a sonar survey by Dr. William Ryan, an oceanographer at Columbia, was done for two businessmen in search of the wreck in 1984. Richardson said Harry John, who once held 47 percent of the stock in Miller Brewing Co., and Jack Grimm, a Texas oil man, funded Ryan's research. Richardson said Ryan later exchanged the data with Thomas G. Thompson, a president of Columbus-America, and that Thompson used the data to locate the wreck site. The university claims Columbus-America then misled the public by saying the wreck was discovered when it hadn't been. Based on Columbus-America claims, Ryan informed John and Grimm that the search was over and they had been beaten. Attorneys for Columbus-America denied the Ryan data was of any use. Thompson said sonar surveys in 1986 pinpointed one target that ``we felt very good about.'' The Ohio-based group recovered artifacts from the site consistent with the time period the Central America sank. On the basis of those artifacts, Kellam gave the group exclusive rights in 1987 to the site. Thompson said that while reviewing the 1986 data in preparation for a 1988 search, experts found a second target that looked even better than the first. Since the second target was on the way to the original search site, Thompson said he decided to test out the equipment on the second target. The new sonar survey show the second site, 33 miles from the first, was most probably the Central America. Further surveys showed it was. Richardson argued the second site was one identified by Ryan, and asserted the New York City school had an interest in the gold. ``It's a lot like an astronomer taking a picture of the sky. That picture might contain an unknown planet, but the astronomer never sees it. Then, 30 years later, after exhaustive research, a second astronomer identifies the unknown planet, and the first tries to claim he found it 30 years earlier,'' said Richard T. Robol, a Norfolk attorney representing Columbus-America. It was unclear how long the trial might take or when a decision could be expected. Attorneys originally said the case would take at least a week to try. When the Central America sank in a hurricane, it was loaded with passengers and gold from the California gold fields. The value of the cargo was estimated at $1.6 million at the time. The Columbus-America Discovery Group estimates the current value could reach $1 billion. More than a ton of gold has been recovered. Columbus-America officials estimate more than 2 tons remain on the ocean's floor. Efforts to raise the rest of the treasure are on hold awaiting the outcome of the legal battle, Columbus-America officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Orders 20 Areas to Cut Budgets After Tax Revolt
DOC.TEXT: British officials, trying to limit the upheaval caused by its unpopular new local government tax, on Tuesday ordered the 20 highest-spending authorities to impose lower taxes and cut budgets. The move came in the aftermath of violence in central London on Saturday night after a rally against the so-called poll tax turned into a mob riot through the capital's West End. Environment Secretary Chris Patten set the top-spending authorities a 28-day deadline to reduce the tax for this fiscal year. If they refuse, Patten will impose the cuts. ``It is deplorable that local authorities have chosen to budget at these levels putting an unacceptable burden on the local people,'' Patten told the House of Commons. ``It is little wonder that strong feelings have been expressed up and down the country.'' The opposition socialist Labor Party described the move as a ``final admission of the poll tax's failure.'' Labor controls 18 of the councils targeted and the other two have no party with overall control. No council run by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party was included in the list. ``This charge-capping list will be universally regarded as a political fix,'' said Labor's Bryan Gould, who leads the socialist party's attack on the tax _ officially known as the community charge. ``They (the government) have given up trying to make the poll tax work ... their sole and squalid aim now is to shift the blame for the whole poll tax fiasco for which they alone are responsible,'' said Gould. The cuts ordered by Patten ranged from $161 lopped off the $691 tax levied by a west London district, Hammersmith and Fulham, to a modest $46 off the $733 tax set by St. Helens in northwest England. Patten said he selected the districts, out of more than 400 in England in Wales, because their budgets were the highest above government targets. Councilors from the districts singled out described the move as vindictive and said they will mount legal challenges. Some warned they would have to cut services, ranging from running schools and old age homes to garbage collection. Mrs. Thatcher's original aim was to undermine support for Labor-run councils because they set high tax rates. But instead both Labor and Tory councils have set tax levels over the government targets and Mrs. Thatcher is being blamed. The average tax level, including in Conservative-run districts, is $592 a person, about one-third higher than the government target. Both government and Labor lawmakers have condemned Saturday's riot in which mobs tore though London's West End, burning cars, looting, smashing shop windows and terrifying shoppers, theatergoers and sightseers. Police say the violence, which began with an attempt to storm Mrs. Thatcher's 10 Downing Street residence, was organized by extreme left-wing groups and anarchists. The riot appears likely to benefit Mrs. Thatcher. ``You can barely conceal your delight at the diversion the uproar provided,'' Labor leader Neil Kinnock declared in angry exchanges with Mrs. Thatcher in the Commons before Patten's announcement. ``When it comes to extremists the difference is this: I fight them, you need them,'' Kinnock added, his voice nearly drowned by Tory lawmakers shouts of protest. Mrs. Thatcher retorted that Kinnock talked ``nonsense.'' She argues that the tax, which came into effect April 1, is fairer because most of Britain's 38 million adults are liable instead of only property owners under the previous system of local taxes. But the tax has become a major political liability for the government, now trailing Labor by more than 20 points in popularity ratings. Most families are paying about one-third more than previously, but it benefits people who live alone and paid the same as neighboring households of three or four adults.

DOC.HEAD: Central American Presidents Demand Contras Start Disbanding
DOC.TEXT: The presidents of Central America on Tuesday called for the Contra rebels to begin disbanding now and surrender their weapons to international monitors. The arms should be destroyed immediately in the presence of observers from the five Central America countries, the presidents said in a joint statement. Foreign Minister Miguel D'Escoto of Nicaragua read the statement at a news conference at the close of a two-day meeting on Central American peace. The sessions in Montelimar, a beach resort 40 miles from Managua, brought together the presidents of Nicaragua, Honduras, Costa Rica, El Salvador and Guatemala. The close of the summit was jarred by a strong earthquake measuring 6.5 on the Richter scale that rocked the capital, Managua, the Pacific coast area and parts of neighboring Costa Rica. The resort itself sustained structural damage to a complex center building and one of its swimming pools. Contra rebel leaders based in Honduras had already announced Monday they would disband by April 18, a week before conservative President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro takes office in Nicaragua. Several thousand rebels inside Nicaragua are expected to follow suit, rallying at predetermined ``safety zones'' in line with an agreement reached by the five presidents at a previous summit. The demobilization will end nine years of Contra war, supported by the United States, against outgoing President Daniel Ortega's leftist Sandinista regime. Mrs. Chamorro won by a landslide in elections Feb. 25. According to the presidents' agreement announced Tuesday, the demobilization and surrender of the weapons ``should start immediately and end by April 25 at the latest.'' All rebel weapons surrendered to the U.N. peacekeepers and other international monitors ``should be destroyed on the spot in the presence of representatives from other Central American governments invited for that purpose,'' the agreement said. The earthquake began just as Ortega and Chamorro were walking down the stairs together from the meeting hall after the last session of the summit. They both halted and waited until the earth stopped rocking. Then they walked down to a hall on the ground floor where the news conference was held with about 100 journalists.

DOC.HEAD: Up to 10 Colombian Policemen Killed by Drug Traffickers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with higher death toll, edits to trim. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Drug traffickers killed up to 10 police officers and wounded at least eight Monday and Tuesday in Colombia's cocaine capital of Medellin, authorities said. At least nine attackers were reported slain. Gunmen kidnapped a federal senator, and a leading Bogota newspaper left its editorial column blank after threats from the traffickers. The government of President Virgilio Barco pressed on in its U.S.-backed war against the drug dealers. It announced it would soon extradite three more drug suspects, including a congressman, El Tiempo newspaper reported. Last week, the traffickers threatened to explode a five-ton bomb in Bogota for every new extradition. Battles between authorities and cocaine barons intensified over the past week after the government renewed its program of extraditing drug suspects to the United States. In January, the Medellin cocaine cartel had claimed it was defeated and curtailed attacks. The military also announced Tuesday the capture of Marlon Perez Madrid, who allegedly ran the Medellin cartel's murder squads in Envigado, four miles south of the city. Envigado, with 80,000 residents, is under martial law. The government disbanded the town's police force last week, accusing nine of its 27 officers of working for cartel leader Pablo Escobar. In the northwestern city of Medellin, terrorists working for the cartel killed nine police officers Monday and Tuesday, Medellin police spokeswoman Ana Arestizal said. At least nine of the terrorists died when police returned fire. National police put the number of police killed at 10. At least eight police officers were wounded, police said. The chief of the national police, Gen. Miguel Gomez Padilla, told reporters late Tuesday police reinforcements will be sent to Medellin. Gunmen on Tuesday killed a police bodyguard for Mayor-elect Omar Florez, an official statement said. Florez, who takes office in August, is a member of the governing Liberal Party. The bodyguard was standing outside his home in Medellin when two men on a motorcycle fired. They took the victim's gun before fleeing, police said. Hours earlier, assailants threw grenades at a police patrol in the Medellin suburb of La Estrella. Four policemen were injured, the statement said. Assailants killed two police officers on Tuesday in the suburbs of Copacabana and Bello, Ms. Arestizal told The Associated Press by telephone. She said a third person, not yet identified, also died in the Copacabana attack. Last week, police told the AP the Medellin cartel had offered $4,290 for each death of a national police officer in Bogota and Medellin. The cartel also offered to pay $100,000 for each member of a 2,000-man anti-narcotics police force they kill, police said. No members of that force have been killed, though. Two gunmen pulled a federal senator, Frederico Estrada, from his car early Tuesday in Medellin and fled with him in another vehicle, Police Chief Col. Alberto Otalora told a news conference. Anonymous callers to local news media said the Medellin cartel kidnapped Estrada and would release him soon with a message for the government. Otalora said Estrada had opposed traffickers' attempts to persuade the government to open peace talks with them. Last week, the Medellin cartel threatened to resume killing government officials, judges, policemen and the owners of Colombia's second largest newspaper, El Espectador, of Bogota. On Tuesday, the morning daily said in a front-page statement it would suspend its entire editorial column until the government gives the paper adequate protection. The editorial column, often filled with denunciations of traffickers, was a strip of blank, white paper two columns wide and 12 inches long. The Medellin cartel killed El Espectador's publisher, Guillermo Cano, in a submachine-gun attack in 1987. In the last four months, six El Espectador employees have been killed by traffickers' hit squads. More than 200 people have been killed in bombings and other terrorist attacks since the latest government crackdown began in August, when drug lords killed a leading presidential candidate. El Tiempo newspaper said the new suspects to be extradited include Jacobo Marino Mendez, a congressman for the northern state of Magdalena. He is wanted by a Puerto Rican court on charges of distributing marijuana in U.S. territory. The government has extradited 15 drug suspects since August.

DOC.HEAD: Supervisors, Workers from Non-Struck Areas Fill In on 2nd Day of HMO Strike
DOC.TEXT: Supervisors and outside workers filled in for 11,000 striking workers Tuesday at the largest U.S. health maintenance organization, which said it had potential substitutes on standby as far away as Oregon. In the second day of the walkout, services were cut and some clinics closed by Kaiser Permanente of Southern California, which has more than 1.5 million members. ``I've cleaned as many toilets (in two days) as I've ever cleaned in my life,'' said Elisabeth Breegle, who usually spends her days in meetings at Kaiser Permanente's largest facility, on Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles. Ms. Breegle, a construction coordinator, said many supervisors were working 12-hour shifts. ``We've all been called. We've all been chosen,'' she said. Kaiser Permanente, like other HMOs, offers its members medical care for a prepaid, fixed price, rather than on a pay-per-visit basis. Its emergency services were unaffected, but some patients had appointments postponed or moved to open clinics, officials said. About 150 Kaiser patients had been transferred to community hospitals, Kaiser spokeswoman Janice Seib said. No contract talks were scheduled with the striking nurses, technicians and maintenance workers. Negotiations with a federal mediator ended Saturday without agreement between Pasadena-based Kaiser Permanente and Service Employees International Union Local 399. Workers defied a union negotiating team's recommendation and rejected a $44 million, three-year contract offer Friday by a 3,067-to-1,474 vote. The company had guaranteed a 5 percent raise the first year and 3 percent the second and third years. Top pay for a licensed vocational nurse under the old contract was $13.01 per hour, according to Kaiser. The walkout began Monday and affected hospitals in Anaheim, Los Angeles, West Los Angeles, Panorama City, Woodland Hills, Harbor City, and Bellflower, and more than 40 satellite medical offices. Seib said about 1,100 Kaiser workers had been brought in from non-struck Kaiser facilities in Fontana, Riverside, San Diego and Northern California. Additional workers were on standby in Oregon, added Kaiser spokeswoman Jayne Marlatt.

DOC.HEAD: Two Scientists Claim to Have Produced Cold Fusion
DOC.TEXT: Two Idaho State University physicists claimed Tuesday that they produced a cold fusion reaction with a different element than those used in experiments by two chemists from Utah and England. Physics professor Kenneth Faler said he and Stanley Vegors produced the reaction March 13 by saturating a small rod of titanium metal in a bottle of deuterium gas cooled to minus 300 degrees Fahrenheit. The device produced bursts of neutrons, ``presumably the fusion of two deuterons into as yet undetermined products,'' Faler told a news conference. A deuteron is the nucleus of an atom of deuterium, an isotope of hydrogen. In one type of fusion reaction, two deuterium nuclei fuse to form helium. ``This is a physical process in which deuterium gas stored in a bottle is absorbed into titanium metal at low temperatures and low pressure and as the metal heats up, it emits neutrons,'' Faler said. ``It appears we have produced cold fusion reactions in a different way,'' he claimed. ``There are now two techniques.'' The two researchers were spurred by reports a year ago that chemist B. Stanley Pons of the University of Utah and British colleague Martin Fleishmann of the University of Southampton had achieved sustained nuclear fusion in a seemingly simple experiment. The Pons-Fleischmann device consists of a palladium electrode wrapped in platinum wire and immersed in deuterium oxide, or heavy water, then charged with electricity. Pons and Fleischmann's seeming breakthrough was questioned when researchers in other laboratories had trouble duplicating their results. While many scientists say they doubt cold fusion exists, experiments continue around the world. The Idaho State researchers observed neutrons using instruments at the school's Low-Energy Accelerator Facility Laboratory. ``The emission of neutrons is generally believed by the scientific community to be an almost positive guarantee that nuclear reactions have taken place,'' Faler said. ``Such a reaction, if it takes place on a large scale, might be able to produce enormous amounts of energy,'' Faler said. John Knox, acting director of the Idaho State physics department, said that although the fusion experiments are important, science requires that results must be repeatable. ``I'm still skeptical about cold fusion in the original sense that was talked about a year ago. But it appears something is happening,'' he said. The Idaho report, which has not been published in any scientific journals, apparently confirms the discovery reported recently by a group of Italian scientists working at the Frascati research laboratory near Rome, Faler said. The ISU information was compared with the Italians' findings in a March conference at the National Cold Fusion Institute in Utah. Four labs worldwide have seen similar results. Scientists at the Los Alamos facility in New Mexico and the Bhabha Atomic Research Center near Bombay, India have viewed neutron bursts under similar conditions.

DOC.HEAD: Haitian Soldier Threatens to Blow Up American Airlines Jumbo Jet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with soldier still alone on plane, expert's view it unlikely plane could be blown up. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A soldier carrying grenades seized a New York-bound jumbo jet at Haiti's airport and threatened to blow it up Tuesday if he was not flown to the United States. A radio report, however, said the 20-year-old soldier let the small number of passengers and crew aboard American Airlines Flight 658 get off. Officials confirmed he was alone on board the craft. Pvt. Pierre Gerald, an airport security guard, boarded the Airbus A300 on Monday afternoon as it was preparing to leave for New York, said Radio Haiti Inter and an American Airlines spokesman. The radio said the young soldier had grenades when he commandeered the plane in an attempt to desert the army after an officer reprimanded him for alleged insubordination. It said Gerald had been in the army two years. U.S. Ambassador Alvin Adams, Minister of the Interior Joseph Maxi and Police Commissioner Jean-Claude Duperval went to the airport Tuesday. After a popular uprising drove Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril from power last month, Adams reportedly helped persuade the fallen military ruler to leave the country. Haiti now has a civilian government. The radio said negotiations with military and airport officials Monday night were fruitless and Gerald spent the night alone in the aircraft. No flights were arriving or taking off from the airport Tuesday. On Tuesday night, it appeared authorities would let Gerald sleep inside the empty jet a second night. No special security measures were taken at the airport. A military expert, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he doubted the soldier could blow up the plane with grenades because the engines were turned off and the fuel remained under the wings. He said seats would probably cushion a grenade explosion and he doubted that fragments could reach the fuel tank. The Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste said in a telephone call from the Haitian capital Tuesday that he found out about the incident when he went to board a plane Tuesday and discovered the airport closed. According to Jean-Juste, the soldier had grenades and possibly an Uzi submachine gun. Gerald gave officials until noon Tuesday to fly him to Miami. A few minutes before the deadline, he appeared in the plane's doorway and shot once into the tarmac, Haiti Inter said. No injuries were reported. American Airlines spokesman Al Becker said Gerald got on board by means of a catering truck that was servicing the plane. In June, four unarmed Haitians tried to hijack to New York an Antillean Airlines flight en route from Haiti to the Dutch Caribbean island of Curacao. The plane landed in Curacao, where the Haitians were arrested. The airline said the plane's captain fooled them into believing Curacao was New York.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Threatens War Over U.S. Television Signals
DOC.TEXT: President Fidel Castro of Cuba told the United States on Tuesday not to interfere with his jamming of Voice of America television broadcasts because it could lead to war. The hard-line Communist leader was referring to U.S.-funded Voice of America programs beamed from Miami to Cuba. The island's government has been jamming them since they started March 27. ``If the U.S. undertakes a surgical operation against the systems of interference of its anti-Cuban television, we will try and make the surgeon come out of it as badly as possible,'' the Cuban government news agency Prensa Latina reported Castro as saying. At a news conference, ``he warned that Cuba can also carry out surgical operations and remarked that such a U.S. action could end in war,'' Prensa Latina said. The dispatch, monitored in Mexico City, only paraphrased Castro's words. It gave no direct quotes. Castro said Cuba ``seeks no military confrontation.'' But he said it ``does not fear the U.S. and is ready to confront them on any ground,'' the dispatch added. In other remarks to an Associated Press reporter and other journalists in Havana, Castro raised the possibility Tuesday night that his government will retaliate by blocking U.S. radio transmissions to the island. Speaking for more than two hours, Castro assailed the Voice of America TV project as a ``gross instrument of subversion.'' Although he did not announce new responses, he said Cuba reserves the right to exercise that option if ``this aggression continues.'' Castro left the impression that one of the moves under consideration would involve Radio Marti, the 5-year-old Voice of America project that broadcasts news and entertainment to Cuban listeners. ``TV Marti can make Radio Marti surface again,'' Castro said. ``We can't exclude this possibility. This problem is still unsettled.'' Previously, Castro threatened to retaliating by interfering with American broadcast signals in Florida. On Monday, President Bush hailed TV Marti as the latest U.S. effort to broadcast ``the truth'' to Communist countries. The television station is named after Jose Marti, a hero of Cuban independence. The Cuban dispatch Tuesday reported, ``Fidel Castro said the U.S. decision to name its anti-Cuban television channel with the name of the national hero Jose Marti is the same as if he we named a garbage can `George Washington.'''

DOC.HEAD: Kemp Choice No Longer In Line For Top Slot On New Housing Board
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Ms. King accepting position as agency's permanent managing director; picks up 7th graf pvs, `Kemp asked ...' ^By JOHN KING
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Tuesday it will not nominate Housing Secretary Jack Kemp's choice to lead a new housing agency. Kemp's selection, Mary K. Bush, is under investigation for awarding no-bid contracts to friends. Ms. Bush met Kemp later Tuesday and accepted his offer to stay on as managing director of the new agency, the Federal Housing Finance Board, said her spokesman Joseph Slye. She will remain in charge of its day-to-day activities, but without a vote on its five-member board, which controls up to $100 million a year in new housing money. The administration said Ms. Bush would not be nominated as chairwoman because she was seeking a fulltime post and the White House has decided the agency's board should serve part time. ``The interests were not compatible,'' said White House deputy press secretary Stephen Hart. He echoed comments from Kemp aides in saying the investigation of Ms. Bush's conduct regarding the contracts was considered ``a separate matter'' from the question of her nomination. Ms. Bush has been serving as acting director of the new agency for seven months awaiting her promised nomination as fulltime chairwoman. During that wait, however, Kemp aides decided to push for a part-time board and instead create the fulltime position of managing director for Ms. Bush. As the only named board member, Kemp has remained in sole control of the agency. Kemp asked HUD Inspector General Paul A. Adams last week to review three no-bid contracts Ms. Bush awarded during the past seven months as part of her effort to get the fledgling agency running. Adams' report is expected later this week. Unclear on Tuesday was whether the offer of the managing director job would be withdrawn if Adams criticizes Ms. Bush in his report. Several Kemp aides did not return telephone messages. The three contracts were given by Ms. Bush to friends with whom she worked in the Reagan administration. Although the Housing Finance Board by law does not have to put contracts out for competitive bidding, Kemp aides have criticized Ms. Bush for awarding the no-bid contracts, including one to Wendell Gunn, Kemp's former chief of staff at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Kemp aides insist that the housing secretary did not know about the no-bid contracts until two weeks ago. HUD Undersecretary Alfred DelliBovi also said he first became aware of the contracts two weeks ago, as did Mary Brunette, Kemp's closest advisor. Gunn, however, insists he told Kemp in November and offered to end the agreement if it bothered Kemp. And DelliBovi, in an internal memo to Ms. Brunette and five other Kemp aides two months ago, listed ``Wendell'' among those being paid by the Housing Finance Board. The DelliBovi memo, obtained by The Associated Press, also offers evidence that at least DelliBovi at HUD wanted Ms. Bush to leave the agency as far back as Feb. 5 despite repeated public assertions that she remained Kemp's choice for the job. ``If he goes let's hope he takes Mary,'' DelliBovi wrote after a passage about the plans of ``Wendell'' to leave the agency. The Housing Finance Board was created as part of the savings and loan industry bailout to oversee the 12 regional Federal Home Loan Banks and to funnel a percentage of their profits each year into affordable housing programs _ $78 million this year and rising to $100 million a year. Ms. Bush, according to sources, has protested the decision to make the board part time. She left a vice presidency at the Federal National Mortgage Association for the Housing Board job after being lobbied by Kemp. When details of the DelliBovi memo were first reported last week, HUD sources, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said Kemp deputies had determined the housing secretary would have more influence over a part-time board because of his Cabinet ranking. Members of Congress who authored the law creating the agency said they envisioned a full-time board. But it is unclear whether they will resist the administration attempt to name a part-time panel.

DOC.HEAD: White Won't Back Richards
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Mattox saying he has witnesses to Richards' alleged drug use. Picks up 5th graf, pvs, `White said ...'
DOC.TEXT: Mark White, whose gubernatorial comeback bid died in the Democratic primary, accused Treasurer Ann Richards on Tuesday of dirty politics and likened her behavior to Gestapo chief Heinrich Himmler's. ``I will never endorse Ann Richards. I will never support Ann Richards. And I will never vote for Ann Richards,'' White told reporters. White stopped short of endorsing state Attorney General Jim Mattox over Ms. Richards in the April 10 Democratic runoff for governor, but said he would vote in that race. He declined to criticize Mattox's tactics during the mudslinging primary. ``I've always thought he was one of the toughest campaigners I've ever seen,'' White said, ``but what Ann Richards has done would make Himmler blush.'' Mattox said Tuesday night that he has signed statements from witnesses alleging Ms. Richards has used illegal drugs. ``Yes, I do, as a matter of fact,'' Mattox told reporters questioning him about proof for allegations he has made regarding Ms. Richards. But Mattox refused to say who his informants are. Mattox made the comments during a televised half-hour ``debate'' that Ms. Richards declined to attend, citing a previous engagement in Austin. Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, has refused to answer directly the question of her alleged drug use, saying she has not used any ``mood-altering'' drugs in 10 years. ``My response has been my message to the people out there that if you need help you can get help,'' Ms. Richards earlier in March. Ms. Richards did not immediately answer three messages left on an answering machine at her headquarters, and calls to Ms. Richards' press secretary and campaign manager were not immediately returned. Before the debate, she said, ``I have a big rally in Austin that we had planned for a very long time. The television people knew that. We told them that I couldn't come.'' White said he wouldn't vote for Ms. Richards should she win the nomination to challenge Republican Clayton Williams. ``If she gets the nomination it will be without my help. And I think if she's able to be elected, she'll have it in the same fashion,'' White said. The former governor blasted Ms. Richards for TV commercials and speeches in which she alleged he had profited from public service and helped his old law firm obtain state bond business while he was governor. ``I think I've been probably been madder from time to time, but this one ... they pretty well ripped their britches with me,'' he said, saying Ms. Richard had made remarks that were ``patently false, maliciously made and she should have had better judgment.'' In the primary, Ms. Richards captured 39 percent of the vote, to 37 percent for Mattox and 19 percent for White, who was governor from 1983 to 1987. ``I feel very badly about any time there is hard feelings,'' Ms. Richards said at a campaign stop in Mercedes before White's comment. ``I feel badly about any personal feelings that ever get into a campaign. I feel sure that all of those wounds will be healed and the Democrats will be together in November.'' Her campaign spokesman, Monte Williams, did not immediately return calls seeking comment about White's remarks. White said Ms. Richards deliberately distorted his record and ran campaign advertisements that lied about him. ``Ann Richards willfully and knowingly smeared me with false accusations that she knew at the time to be untrue. She didn't do it just once in the heat of an argument. She did it with inexcusable regularity in the last days of the campaign,'' he said. He said Ms. Richards ran the dirtiest campaign he ever witnessed. ``I know tough politics ... I have been in some rough campaigns in my career and I know how to dish it out and I know how to take it,'' he said. ``But there is a difference between negative advertising and unfounded, vicious, personal attacks that are out-and-out lies. ``I think she overstepped the bounds of decency by smearing my name in such a vicious way,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS Wade. SUBS 5th item in package to ADD detail on cause of death for Wade.
DOC.TEXT: Reginald S. Alexander, a politician, sports enthusiast and longtime member of the International Olympics Committee, died Saturday at age 75. The cause of death was not disclosed. Alexander entered local politics, first in 1948 as a Nairobi city legislator and then as mayor of the city in 1954. When Kenya gained independence from Britain in 1963, Alexander served four years in Parliament. Alexander was a founding member in 1954 of the Kenya Olympics and Commonwealth Games Association and served as its chairman up to 1968. The organization later changed its name to the Kenya Olympics Association. He led the East African nation's first Olympics team to Melbourne, Australia, in 1956 and joined the IOC executive board in 1972. He was also a successful businessman in Kenya's tourism and oil industries.

Willie Musarurwa, a veteran journalist who spent 10 years in jail for his political activities, died Tuesday of a heart attack at age 62. Musarurwa was jailed without trial for 10 years because of political activism against white minority rule before Zimbabwe's independence in 1980. He was fired from his job as chief editor of Zimbabwe's main Sunday newspaper in 1985 after President Robert Mugabe accused him of being overly critical of the government.

Nguyen Lam, former Vietnamese Vice Premier, died Sunday of natural causes at age 68. Nguyen Lam was a former top official of the ruling Communist Party. He was a member and secretary of the party's Central Committee and was vice premier in 1976. Nguyen Lam had been a recipient of the Ho Chi Minh Order, the nation's highest award.

Eva Ione Nettleman Dygert, the widow of a pioneer Idaho attorney and one of the state's oldest residents, died Monday at age 103. A school teacher before marrying Roy Dygert in 1910, Mrs. Dygert moved with her husband later that year to Blackfoot, where he practiced law and farmed before moving south to Soda Springs in 1917, then to Payette in western Idaho in 1956. Dygert died in 1969.

Otha D. Wearin, a former congressman and author elected to the Cowboy Hall of Fame, died Tuesday of congestive heart failure at age 87. He began his political career at age 25 with a successful campaign to become the youngest person to serve in the Iowa Legislature. The Democrat served two terms before achieving a similar distinction in Congress by winning election in a heavily Republican southwest Iowa district in 1932. Wearin remained in the House until 1936, when he made an unsuccessful run for the Senate. He also failed to win the Democratic nomination six years later. He wrote a series of newspaper articles about his travels in Europe, which became the basis for his first book, ``An Iowa Farmer Abroad.'' He followed that with other writings including a series of essays on country living and essays for a succession of books _ ``Before the Colors Fade,'' ``Along Our Country Road,'' ``I Remember Yesteryear'' and ``Grass Grown Trails.'' His books were cited in his induction into the Cowboy Hall of Fame in Oklahoma City in 1985. A fifth book, ``A Place for Living,'' is to be published.

Norman W. Patterson, who designed the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, died Wednesday of a heart attack at age 73. Patterson founded a firm of architects in San Francisco in 1942 that became Stone, Marraccini and Patterson. He was president and board chairman until retiring in 1982. He spent several years working on the medical center's design, the single biggest job of his career. Patterson designed several military or civilian hospitals in northern California, including Letterman Army Medical Center at the Presidio, the Army base in San Franciso.

Charles ``Big Chick'' Huntsberry, rock star Prince's former bodyguard who switched to evangelism, died Monday of heart failure at age 49. Huntsberry was hired by Prince in 1981 and traveled with him on three tours. He gained a reputation as a bodyguard with the rock group AC-DC, professional wrestler Hulk Hogan and oil barons. He left the rock world because of a cocaine habit and underwent a spiritual conversion, traveling across the United States and overseas to preach at youth rallies, prisons and church services.

Dr. Robert H. Felix, the first director of the National Institute of Mental Health and a former assistant surgeon general for the U.S. Public Health Service, died Saturday of Parkinson's disease at age 85. From 1944 to 1949, he headed the mental hygiene division of the Public Health Service, developing the Mental Health Act of 1946, which in part created the National Institute of Mental Health. He was director of the institute for 15 years. From 1965 to 1975, Felix was a professor of psychiatry and dean of the medical school at St. Louis University. He then became research director of the Scottish Rite Psychophrenic Research Program in Lexington, Mass., retiring in 1985.
DOC.HEAD: Lawrence Wade
DOC.TEXT: Lawrence Wade, a reporter and editorial writer for the former Dayton Journal Herald, died Saturday of a brain tumor at age 41. Wade wrote for the Journal Herald from 1980 to 1982. He also worked for the Cleveland Press, The Wall Street Journal, The Miami Herald, The Orlando Sentinel, and The Washington Times. He was communications director for the U.S. Civil Rights Commission in 1984 and 1985. Survivors include his wife, Deborah Burstion-Wade; a son, Lawrence K. Wade of Cleveland; parents, John and Clara Wade of Cleveland Heights; and a brother, Bruce, of Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Cruising Ordinances Become Law
DOC.TEXT: Teen-agers who insist on cruising in the city that inspired the film ``American Graffiti'' risk fines under a pair of ordinances that won final approval on Tuesday. Under the new rules, which take effect May 5, motorists would face fines of $75 to $250 for passing a designated checkpoint more than once every four hours. Pedestrians gathered in parking lots and along sidewalks would risk equal fines for loitering between 6 p.m. and 6 a.m. Officers will enforce the rules within a marked no-cruising zone on the popular McHenry Avenue when traffic moves slower than 5 mph or intersections are blocked. The ordinances do not affect the annual Graffiti Night, which celebrates the cruising tradition in grand proportions with up to 100,000 people in 30,000 cars. The rules were sought by residents and business owners who complained that the good-natured pastime of the 1950s had grown unmanageable with the influence of drugs, gangs and vandalism. But the rite of passage was defended by teen-agers who grew up with the legacy of George Lucas' 1973 film. They argued their motives were as innocent as their parents': showing off cars and meeting dates.

DOC.HEAD: Lava From Kilauea Volcano Edging Towards Homes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with flow 50 yards from homes, quotes from residents, evacuation order issued, ADDS byline. Picks up 5th graf, pvs, `Another flow, ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HU1
By STEVE ELLIOTT
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: A meandering flow of molten lava from Kilauea Volcano had residents of this coastal community packing their belongings Tuesday and preparing to leave. A flow from the west, the most serious threat, advanced within 50 yards of five homes in the Kalapana Gardens subdivision, according to Hawaii County Civil Defense spokesman Bruce Butts. The flow moved 200 yards during a 12-hour period ending early Tuesday, Butts said. The flow picked up speed by mid-morning. Residents of 50 of the 125 homes in Kalapana Gardens evacuated Monday, and an order affecting seven more homes was issued later Tuesday, Butts said. Many residents were stoic about the encroaching lava, drinking beer and laughing with friends while watching the molten earth edge toward their homes. ``Morale is really high; we're just sticking together,'' said Craig Heiser, who built his home in 1987. ``It's a little like a party atmosphere,'' he said. ``You can't do anything about it, so you might as well enjoy it.'' ``People who live here are emotionally prepared for it, but you still hope it's not going to happen,'' said Donna Olson, whose home was destroyed in the 1986 flow and lives with her three children in a rented house threatened by the west flow. ``What else can you do? This is the Hawaiian style of doing things. I just want to get it over with,'' said Julie Beardsley, who lives in one of the five homes immediately threatened. Another flow, on the eastern side of the community, was moving toward the subdivision along the path of a 1989 flow, and was about a half-mile from nearest homes, Butts said. Some of the residents hired container trucks to carry their belongings away. Many others were packing in anticipation of an eventual evacuation order. ``I ran into a couple of people who didn't seem too concerned about it, but most people are concerned and moving whatever they can,'' said Civil Defense spokesman Allen Parker. Civil Defense Administrator Harry Kim also ordered the Kalapana area closed to tourists and other visitors. Scientists said about 650,000 cubic yards of lava was being pumped out of the volcano's Kupaianaha Vent each day. Tom Wright, chief scientist at the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory, said the lava began spreading over the slope a week ago. ``Now it has gathered itself into a couple of significant flows,'' he said. Wright said that based on the topography of the area, the two flows could join and send a single stream of molten lava into Kalapana Gardens. Since the east rift zone eruption began on Jan. 3, 1983, 76 dwellings and a national park visitor center have been destroyed, causing more than $20 million in damage. Kilauea Volcano is near the southeast coast on the island of Hawaii, which is about 200 miles from Honolulu on the island of Oahu.

DOC.HEAD: State's Top Court Slaps State for Inadequate Welfare Grants
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo's administration set welfare rates so low that some families were forced into homelessness, the state Court of Appeals ruled Tuesday. The high court unanimously reversed a lower court verdict and ordered a new trial in the case of Barbara Jiggetts, a New York City woman who complained about low welfare rates. The court agreed with welfare advocates who argued the shelter allowance in the state's basic welfare grant was set far below market rates for even the cheapest housing available. ``A schedule establishing assistance levels so low that it forces large numbers of families with dependent children into homelessness does not meet the statutory standard,'' Judge Richard Simons wrote. State Social Service Commissioner Cesar Peraes, in a prepared statement, said the state will discuss the welfare rates before a lower court. Attorneys for Jiggett said they believed the Court of Appeals' strong language in the decision would make it hard for a lower court not to order increased welfare rates. ``It's a great decision and it's very important for the welfare population of New York,'' said Allan Gropper of the state Bar Association's Project for the Homeless of the City. He said studies have shown as many as one-third of New York City's homeless population had been evicted from apartments. Jiggetts, a single mother of three from the borough of Queens, sued New York City social service officials in 1987 when she was being evicted from her apartment. She has since found housing, but other families joined the lawsuit and the jurisdiction was switched to the state, said Matthew Diller, a lawyer for the New York Legal Aid Society. Christopher Lamb, another Legal Aid Society lawyer, said the shelter allowance for a family of four in New York City is $312 a month. However, the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development reports the average market rate for a two-bedroom apartment for poor people in New York City is $566. ``People shouldn't be sent out into the New York City market and be told you have to find an apartment for a family of four at $312 a month,'' Lamb said. ``It's like hitting your head against the wall.''

Seeking to ease rising tensions, President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania has struck a conciliatory chord by saying his republic intends to move toward independence gradually and through negotiations. Landsbergis told Lithuanian lawmakers on Monday that their March 11 declaration of independence ``may seem to some people ... a demand that power be handed over the very next day. '' ``We did not expect this and did not count upon it,'' he said, retreating somewhat from the recalcitrance that had characterized the Baltic state's drive for divorce from the Soviet Union. Landsbergis said his republic intended to ``consolidate'' its independence ``by means of agreements and a gradual takeover of certain functions.''

Conoco Inc., in one of the biggest settlements of its kind, has agreed to pay $23 million to buy 400 homes and compensate families who say its refinery is giving them cancer and other illnesses. Under the settlement announced Monday with families who had sued the company for allegedly contaminating the air and water, Conoco would buy the properties for about $18 million and establish a $5 million compensation fund. Homeowner Mike Gallagher said his family was ready to move. ``The sooner, the better. Now we can go to the other side of town. No more nosebleeds. No more headaches. We can live with good-smelling air,'' he said.

The runoff campaign between two Democrats vying for governor began with talk of a peace treaty. But that didn't last long. Heading into the April 10 election, Treasurer Ann Richards and Attorney General Jim Mattox have attacked each other on personal finances and drug use, with only a gaffe by the Republican candidate to remind them of their common foe. The two cannot even agree on when to disagree in a debate. ``If Ann Richards is not tough enough to stand up and debate Jim Mattox and to answer the questions that are on the voters' minds, how is she going to be tough enough to stand up to the problems facing our state?'' demanded Mattox, who has accused Ms. Richards of refusing to debate him to avoid questions about drugs.

Greeks will vote again Sunday, for the third time in a year, in hopes of breaking a political deadlock that has created compromise governments unable to confront an economy in crisis and growing terrorism. Pollsters predict the election will end like those in June and November 1989, with no party winning enough seats to control the government. Coalitions formed after last year's elections took no effective action on foreign, domestic or economic policy. The European Community has said Greece is in danger of bankruptcy and the EC will not bail it out because Greece violated austerity requirements of a 1985 loan. Some Greek officials and economists fear the nation may have to surrender some of its economic sovereignty and seek help for the first time from the International Monetary Fund.

DOC.HEAD: Lone Scientist Provides The One Certainty In Global Warming Debate
DOC.TEXT: How fast will global warming raise Earth's temperatures? How much will temperatures rise? Will coastal cities be flooded by rising sea levels? At the center of the stormy debate over the greenhouse effect, one bright area of calm remains: Charles Keeling's curve. The curve is a record of the slow, inexorable climb of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere during the past 30 years. Keeling, a chemist at the University of California at San Diego, has made it his life's work to develop the most detailed and accurate measurements possible of carbon dioxide. Carbon dioxide traps the sun's heat in the atmosphere, and Keeling's curve charting its rise is at the heart of the debate over how much the Earth's temperature is likely to rise, and how fast. ``Today this ever-lengthening record, Keeling's Curve, provides a sort of time-lapse X-ray movie of the workings of the spheres, a surprising inside view of our planet's metabolism,'' says writer Jonathan Weiner. Weiner tells the story of the self-effacing Keeling for the first time in a lucid and compelling book, ``The Next One Hundred Years.'' Keeling, Weiner says, is measuring ``the breathing of the world.'' Keeling's findings are sobering. The amount of carbon dioxide in the air has increased by 12 percent just since 1958. Thanks to Keeling's thoroughness, that figure is ironclad. Researchers debate the effects of that rise, but they don't argue with Keeling's numbers. For his part, Keeling sticks to his work. He hasn't played a large role in the national debate, which has grown in intensity as the 20th anniversary of Earth Day approaches April 22 and concern over the environment increases. But he does have words of warning for those who wave off the fuss and argue that the Earth's temperature may not be climbing. ``To suppose it isn't going to go up at all would indicate that somehow the Earth just naturally gets this warm and then stops warming,'' Keeling said in a telephone interview. ``There shouldn't be any reason we know of that the Earth wouldn't continue to warm up,'' he said. ``Furthermore, we know from geological history that it was warmer once upon a time. So logic suggests that the greenhouse warming has to take place. But how much warming? And how soon? What's demanded now by political realities is some fairly hard numbers, and those are not forthcoming.'' The average temperature of the Earth is about 60 degrees Fahrenheit, Keeling said. With no carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, it would be 0 degrees, and the Earth would be a frozen wasteland unable to support human life. The rise in carbon dioxide is due largely to the increasing use of fossil fuels _ coal and oil _ during the industrial age, Keeling said. As carbon dioxide has risen, the production and burning of fossil fuels also has increased, he said. ``In fact, the shape of the (carbon dioxide) curve looks very much like the shape of the curve for fossil fuel production,'' Keeling said. Research also suggests the Earth's temperature is rising, but researchers can't be sure. Despite all the concern about global warming, no one is making an effort to measure temperatures the way Keeling measured carbon dioxide. ``There is no explicit program to measure air temperatures to look for these changes,'' he said. Airport temperatures are distorted because they are taken close to cities. ``The way around that is to establish some very good stations that are not near cities,'' he said. A government agricultural weather monitoring network that could be adapted for that purpose is being cut back to save money, Keeling said. ``They're compromising the system we already have just at the time you'd like to know if it's getting warmer,'' he said. Keeling now is busy trying to determine how variations in the sun's heat affect carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. As always, he sticks to the data. ``I don't think I'm in a position to make a strong stand on the greenhouse warming effect,'' he said. But he does place himself with those who ``see danger ahead.'' ``There are people who say the Earth is robust and there's a technological fix for almost anything,'' he said. Keeling is not among them. ``I do subscribe to the position that most of the things we would do if we were worried about the greenhouse effect are worth doing _ for instance, conserving energy,'' he said. Beyond that, Keeling won't venture an opinion where he doesn't have sound, scientific data to back him up. How much will Earth's temperatures rise, and how fast? ``I have personal feelings on it, but they tend to change as I hear what other people say,'' he said. ``I can be pushed around like all the rest of you as new facts come to light.''

DOC.BYLINE: Peter O'Toole In CBS Movie and Pondering Book ^By JAY SHARBUTT
DOC.TEXT: Peter O'Toole once planned to be a newspaperman. On the positive side, he's been puttering around with what old-school newspapermen always claim they're puttering around with: a book. He beams and nods when asked if it might be his thoughts on friends and life, perhaps written in the style of a pal, Spike Milligan, whose first such effort was entitled, ``Hitler: My Part In His Downfall.'' The title of O'Toole's tome? ``Loitering With Intent,'' says the actor. He would have much to write about. He has loitered and taken the waters with hearty companions like Richard Burton, Richard Harris and John Huston, and tells wonderful tales about all. Has he set himself a deadline for the book? O'Toole, who no longer takes the waters, shook his head. ``Not a deadline, a start line,'' he said. He was a bit weary when interviewed. He'd risen at dawn in London and zipped across the Atlantic via Concorde jet to help drumbeat for ``Crossing To Freedom,'' a two-hour CBS film. He left the next day for a film in Tunisia. In the CBS movie, airing Sunday, he plays a sad, grumpy old Englishman who reluctantly shepherds seven children to safety early in World War II when Hitler's armies invade France. Upon arriving here to tout the film, O'Toole taped an interview for ``CBS This Morning.'' Then he was shepherded to the United Nations, where the United Nations Children's International Fund hailed the movie and served him lunch. Then he and a squad of urchins posed for pictures, sticking out their tongues for one shot. Then came more interviews, some with more intense grilling about his 1962 rush to fame as T.E. Lawrence, the sandy mystic warrior dramatized in David Lean's Oscar-winning ``Lawrence of Arabia.'' O'Toole, still so gaunt he'd be marked absent if he turned sideways, was good-natured and gracious about it all. Like many who've begun on the British stage, he realizes publicity is part of the actor's territory. But he isn't sure why he became an actor. His first desire was to fight Hitler. That would have been difficult, though; he was only 8 when the war began. So he did the next best thing. At 16, he went to work at a newspaper in Yorkshire, England, where he'd grown up after his family left Ireland. ``I did love it _ we shot out four editions a day,'' he says of his days as an ink-stained wretch. O'Toole, who still has pals from those days, one now the assistant editor of the Times of London, learned all phases of newspapering, from pressroom to pub-crawling. His first big interview was with the actress Margaret Lockwood. ``But something happened, I don't know what, and I joined the Navy,'' he says. He served on a submarine, and later a corvette, the latter the small, always-rolling ship about which Nicholas Monsarrat wrote in ``The Cruel Sea.'' ``My dream, when I was 17, was a big one,'' O'Toole says. ``I couldn't make up my mind whether I was to be editor of Paris Match or of Life.'' A sigh. His eyes twinkle. ``I finished up as a typist on a corvette during the cod wars.'' That isn't the usual preparation for the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts. But after leaving the service, he attended that distinguished school, where he began learning his actor's craft, Shakespeare and all that. In time, he also learned of the slings and arrows of outrageous critics. How does he regard critics now? He smiles. ``I disregard them. When you've been punching along in the game as long I have . .. you find they go away and die.'' Beside paying the rent and then some, acting has enabled him to see the world and meet fascinating people. High on his list of great characters is Huston, the late film director, whom he calls ``a magnanimous and good friend to me.'' ``He struck wonderful poses, John,'' O'Toole says. He smiles at the memory of a time he and the director emerged from a London studio and found a young man lying on the street, a small crowd gathered around him. Neither of them knew the man, who lay very still, not moving a muscle. ``So John walked up to him'' _ O'Toole imitated the director leaning over and examining the fallen with a seemingly professional eye _ ``and pronounced, `Kurt'll be fine. Kurt'll be just fine.' ``Standing in the group was a man who said, `Sir, I'm a doctor. And''' _ O'Toole's voice took on a dramatic edge, ```that young man has been dead for 30 minutes.''' __ Elsewhere in television ... YET ANOTHER REASON TO SAY `OH WOW': NBC on May 6 will show a TV movie, ``Archie: To Riverdale and Back Again,'' based on the long-running cartoon strip, ``Archie.'' The strip's teen-agers, who include Betty, Veronica and Jughead, have yet to graduate from either high school or innocence. But in the movie, a spokesman says, they will be thirtysomething, facing such woes of the '90s as divorce, career changes and single parenthood.
