DOC.HEAD: Resurrection of Nations
Part I: Rise of Eastern Europe From Despotism
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto Illustration
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: An unexpected resurrection of nations from totalitarianism has swept Eastern Europe in recent months, reintroducing long-trampled freedoms and reducing international distrust. The first story in a five-part Easter series, ``Resurrection of Nations,'' examines the surprising upheaval and its religious threads.

In a blink, the landscape heaved and the world changed. People could hardly believe it. Amazed, incredulous, they saw a new reality dawning over the earth, surmounting old fears and fatalism. The grim, immutable facts of their existence were suddenly not what they had seemed. That baffled astonishment among Eastern Europeans at their burst from bondage also resonates in the recorded reaction to the resurrection of Christ and the liberating word of Easter. ``It has indeed been miraculous, a miracle that happened in the souls of people,'' said the Rev. John Meyendorff, a scholar of the Russian-derived but independent Orthodox Church in America. ``It has been a resurrection from a long deadening of individual creativity and the God-given dignity of being human for millions of people.'' No one could have predicted its suddenness and sweep, he said. ``I never thought I'd live to see it. People are finding it hard to believe.'' An ``idle tale,'' the apostles scoffed at first reports of Christ's resurrection. It made no sense, the buried restored to life? They couldn't conceive of it until it confronted them, directly and plainly. Likewise, it had seemed impossible that half a continent could so rapidly be raised from its deep abyss of totalitarian repression. Yet in a swift, seismic wave of decisive events, the whole posture of nations took another form. In a seeming instant, a new era of expanding rights and greater international trust yawned wide. Symbolizing the far-reaching phenomenon, the Berlin Wall _ that barrier of cold war that for three decades had divided humanity, literally and figuratively _ at last came tumbling down Nov. 9. Among rejoicing throngs, an East German friar said with a chuckle, ``The iron curtain is not so much iron anymore.'' The wall's demise and the rest of the whirlwind that freed nations and eased superpower antagonisms symbolically reflected a Scripture passage on Christ's crucifixion and resurrection: ``For he is our peace, who has made us both one, and has broken down the dividing wall of hostility.'' The changes came in tidal profusion in the Soviet Union and its satellite countries, one after another, like some pent-up force breaking loose, uncontainable, overflowing, toppling tyrants, unleashing multitudes from their chains. Almost magically, the changes came generally without violence, in so-called ``soft'' or ``velvet'' revolutions. ``Not by might, nor by power, but by my Spirit, says the Lord of hosts,'' the biblical prophet Zechariah said. Just as Christ's resurrection defied logic, so on another plane did the breakthrough of nations. The sweeping transformation of 1989 contradicted all prior analyses and predictions. It went against the prognostications of the keenest thinkers and the gloomiest doomsayers. ``It is difficult to think of any series of developments more astonishing,'' said Roman Catholic historian-theologian Richard McBrien. Harvard historian Richard Pipes wrote: ``The recent events there have surpassed the wildest fantasies of any observer of Soviet affairs who was willing to go on record.'' The facts, those grim facts of life in the Soviet bloc, were suddenly turned upside down. Just as Christ's followers rejoiced when he rose from the dead, Eastern Europe's long coerced and silenced millions lurched forth into the exhilarating, yet bewilderingly unfamiliar light of new freedom. ``We are like children waking from a nightmare in the middle of the night,'' Emilian Mercan, a member of the hastily formed provisional government of Carisova, Romania, said after the mid-December collapse of the harsh Ceausescu regime. ``All we want is reassurance that it won't happen again.'' Gradually, the countries of Eastern Europe are permitting such gifts to the spirit as the freedoms to speak out, assemble, organize and vote. But the daybreak atmosphere, like life itself, is loaded with risk and uncertainty. ``It happened so quickly,'' said Petar Darliev, a Bulgarian imprisoned for nine years who at 74 is helping plan the country's first multiparty elections in 45 years, scheduled for June. ``The hard part starts now.'' It ``is a peculiar drama, which no Earthling could have written,'' said previously imprisoned playwright Vaclav Havel, chosen to be Czechoslovakia's president by a new parliament in December. General elections are set for June 8. Of the times before the crucifixion, the apostle Paul wrote, ``We know that the whole world has been groaning in travail until now.'' For much of the 20th century, the globe has been groaning, caught in a tightening nuclear stranglehold, with no apparent way to escape. But the metamorphosis provided by Christ has come, in a different order, for nations. Writing after Christ rose from the tomb, Paul said, ``So then you are no longer strangers and sojourners, but fellow citizens ... and members of the household of God.'' The pace and scope of the changes have left statesmen and pundits groping for reasons, scrambling to adjust to the transfigured scene. They came in such a mounting crescendo as to seem almost sheer revelation. ``One sees evidence of divine providence in human events like this,'' said church historian Robert T. Handy. ``Who could have thought it would happen?'' Handy, historian emeritus of New York's Union Theological Seminary, said he was ``worried about a backlash. We're still dealing with politics.'' But he cited church involvement in Eastern Europe's reform movements in saying: ``The ferment for freedom has always been very strong in the Jewish-Christian tradition. It boils up again and again, and has throughout history. It can be put down, but it boils up again. .. . ``The hand of God can be seen in these developments,'' Handy added. ``God does work in history.'' So do people, what Scripture calls God's co-workers. Jesus, in giving up his life for a greater one at Easter, said people would have to endure oppression and pain, but a better time beckoned. ``You will be sorrowful,'' he said before his death at the hands of an occupation military regime that dominated a subjugated people. ``But your sorrow will turn into joy.''

DOC.HEAD: Resurrection of Nations
Part II: Change at the Core
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto Illustration
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: All at once, democratic processes have come alive in the Soviet Union, its monolithic communist system starting to crumble after 72 years of regimentation. That enormous change at the core of communism, the Soviet Union, is the focus of the second story in a five-part Easter series, ``Resurrection of Nations.''

When Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Wyoming last fall, they exchanged gifts. Baker gave cowboy boots to Shevardnadze, who presented Baker with an enameled picture of Jesus teaching the people. ``You see,'' Shevardnadze remarked, ``even we communists are changing our world view.'' Recalling the incident later, Baker surmised that some innate ``resurgence of faith'' may have been at the roots of the revolutionary changes sweeping Eastern Europe. The lightning-like reformation that has flashed over the Soviet colossus and its peripheries is ``so striking that it marks the beginning of a new era of world affairs,'' President Bush said in his state-of-the-union address. It is a kind of metaphor for Easter, a rebirth of worldly hopes, a resurrection of regimented millions from capitivity. ``It has raised the spirits of oppressed people all over the world, not only in Eastern Europe but in South Africa and elsewhere,'' said the dean of U.S. Roman Catholic historians, Monsignor John Tracy Ellis. The reanimation swelled in the Soviet heartland after racing around its borders at the end of 1989. The Soviet parliament voted Feb. 27 to surrender the Communist Party's constitutional monopoly of power as society's ``guiding force,'' a step approved last month by the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies. This was an historic turning point for Soviet communism, a reversal of a constitutionally enshrined belief that only the party controlled the nation. Abandoning that dogma, said Roman Szporiuk, Russian studies director at the University of Michigan, had seemed as implausible as a declaration from ``the pope in Rome that there is no God.'' Measures also were adopted to create a Western-style presidency and executive branch cabinet. The Congress of People's Deputies, a popularly elected body established only a year ago, includes several church leaders and many non-communists. It meets annually and elects the 542-member standing parliament, the Supreme Soviet. The deputies elected Gorbachev to a five-year term as president; in 1995, the office becomes subject to national voting. Popular elections and other freedoms, including approval of long-banned individual property rights and budding free enterprise, have proliferated across that once totalitarian nation. Sergei A. Kovalev, who spent a decade in labor camps, said of his March victory in the first round of voting for the Russian republic's parliament that he could not previously have imagined such change. An unseen ``mole of history'' has been digging, he said. ``People could not foresee this fast time frame. The most optimistic of us only could hope for such changes across 100 years.'' Communist repressions had weighed for nearly three quarters of the 20th century on the Soviet Union. For its satellite nations, the Nazi occupation that began in 1938-39 gave way to Soviet domination after World War II. Tens of thousands of Soviet citizens were tortured, herded into slave labor camps or executed under the ruthless 24-year rule of Joseph Stalin. He established an absolutist police state that controlled every aspect of society. The despotism continued with varying degrees of severity through Stalin's successors. The party was a tiny minority of 19 million in a population of 287 million, but its bureaucrats, KGB agents and informers restricted religion; muzzled speech, print and broadcasts; forbade ownership or assemblies; jailed dissenters, and promoted atheism as the state religion, an official belief of disbelief. In March 1985, a different kind of communist _ Mikhail S. Gorbachev, charismatic and tactically nimble _ took over the party. The rigid communist autocracy began loosening its grip. ``We need spiritual values, we need a revolution of the mind,'' Gorbachev said on the eve of his unprecedented meeting with Pope John Paul II last Dec. 1, at which the Soviet leader agreed to end 45 years of suppressing Ukrainian Catholicism. ``We have changed our attitude about some matters such as religion.'' Gorbachev himself was baptized in infancy and reared in Russian Orthodoxy by a devout mother. ``Now we not only proceed from the assumption that no one should interfere in matters of individual conscience,'' he said. ``We also say that the moral values that religion generated and embodied for centuries can help in the work of renewal in our country.'' All around Gorbachev, strains of liberty burst forth. In his homeland, political prisoners went free, debate flew wide open, diversity bloomed, the superstructure loosened and private initiative took toddling steps. People emigrated more freely _ 71,196 Jews left the Soviet Union in 1989, the most ever, and 100,000 are expected to do so in 1990 _ while regular religious programming began for the first time on radio and television. This ``is the day of resurrection for our church,'' Bishop Innocent Lotocky of Chicago's Ukrainian-rite Catholics said of the lifted ban on the church in the Ukraine. ``Our church was crucified by the communists and sealed in the tomb,'' but now it lives again. Russian Orthodoxy reported the number of its active churches increased by almost 3,000 in 1989 to a total of 9,734. Seminaries and enrollments multiplied fourfold. Similar expansion occurred among Protestant churches. Baptists received permission to open their first seminary. Churches began the previously forbidden religious instruction of children. Soviet policy has shifted in 18 months ``from tolerance to active promotion'' of churches, said Philip Oke of the interdenominational Christian Peace Conference and a frequent visitor to Eastern Europe. Bibles and other religious literature poured into the Soviet Union. Bible societies formed, and the Academy of Science approved a research project on personal values, using the Ten Commandments. The Society for Scientific Atheism changed its name to the Society of Religion and Atheism. A Baptist choir performed at a government cultural center, and a U.S-produced evangelistic movie, ``Jesus,'' dubbed into Russian, drew big audiences. The striking changes were presaged at the 1988 celebration of Christianity's thousandth anniversary in Russia. Fervent crowds, the presence of 500 church leaders from around the world and the participation of Soviet officials, as well as Gorbachev's wife, Raisa, left a lingering influence. ``You are entering a new period of history for the nation,'' American evangelist Billy Graham said then. Since then, one after another, old communist orders have fallen _ gradually in Poland and Hungry, swiftly in East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Romania. Impulses of independence have flared in some of the 15 Soviet republics, chiefly the Baltic states led by mostly Catholic Lithuania. God's Spirit, Jesus said, is like the wind which ``blows where it wills.''

DOC.HEAD: Resurrection of Nations
Part III: Breakout in East Germany ^With LaserPhoto Illustration
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: In rapid succession, Eastern Europe's communism-shackled countries last year shook off their chains. The third story in a five-part Easter series, ``Resurrection of Nations,'' concentrates on the breakaway of East Germany, preceded by renewals in Poland and Hungary.

Against formidable odds, the people prayed and marched. Week after week, they kept at it, coolheaded and persevering. Against dangers and initial reprisals, church throngs repeatedly poured into the night streets of East German cities, flickering candles aloft. And they won. In a steel-handed communist state, ruled for 40 years by a despotic regime and its dreaded secret police, the ``Stasi,'' the churches harbored a peaceable but unflinching dynamism that overthrew a seemingly immutable system. ``Everything is new! Everything is new!'' a young Baptist minister, Siegfried Rosenmann, rejoiced in East Berlin after the regime collapsed. The ``candlelight revolution'' was one of the strangest of all in a year of utterly strange revolutions that unleashed winds of democratic rights across Eastern Europe. ``A miraculous experience,'' Lutheran theologian Jurgen Ziemer of Leipzig said of those tenacious confrontations at which riot squads and plainclothes secret police abruptly stopped interfering and simply stood by. ``We do not know what held them back.'' Contrary to engrained practice, the enforcers just didn't act, perhaps something like the benumbed Roman guards at Jesus' tomb. In a differing sense, East Germans and others emerged from smothering confinement into open air. Crushed human liberties are now ``alive again,'' said the Rev. Leonid Kishkovsky, president of the U.S. National Council of Churches, who recently visited East Germany and other Soviet bloc countries. ``I see a miracle rooted in the way of the Cross that has been lived by these people for decades,'' Kishkovsky said. ``Despite suppression and great difficulties, the church has stood for another vision of the world in contradiction to totalitarianism.'' That vision insists that no worldly authority may violate God-bestowed rights of individuality and conscience. The theme reverberates through the Bible, epitomized in Moses' demand of Pharaoh, ``Let my people go!'' The demonstrations were nurtured by East German churches, where discussions on peacemaking, justice and environmental concerns had gone on for years. Last Oct. 9 at St. Nicolas Church in Leipzig, Monday night services flowed outside, drawing a crowd of 100,000. Despite arrests and police beatings, the weekly services grew, attracting non-believers as well; the Nov. 6 demonstration drew 480,000. By then, demonstrations had spread to churches in Dresden, East Berlin, Schwerin, Halle and Wittenberg. Word had circulated: ``On Monday night, something is happening at the churches.'' In the land where 15th century reformer Martin Luther fired his protest against Rome's ecclesiastical domination, the churches became havens, rallying places and an umbrella for political as well as religious voices of reform. ``No other social force in the country had independence from the state and party'' and could thus supply space for dialogue and inspiration, said pastor Werner Widrat of Lutheran Gethsemane Church in East Berlin. Bolstering their peaceful tactics, the pre-demonstration services often included Scripture readings from the Beatitudes: ``Blessed are the peacemakers. ... Blessed are those who are presecuted for righteousness sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.'' The churches had adopted the non-violent tactics of Martin Luther King Jr. and Mohandas Gandhi. Typical of church messages issued in the crisis was this from Thuringia's Lutheran Bishop Werner Leich: ``I beg you ... no matter what happens, do not deviate from the principle of non-violence. ... Do not let yourselves be intimidated any longer. ... No renewal in the truth can come about unless we are willing to be bold and make sacrifices. ... God has given us the spirit of strength. ... Our present way will not be easy. But we shall succeed. ... Let us stand together.'' Crowds in Bitterfeld and elsewhere sang the American civil rights anthem, ``We Shall Overcome.'' Communist ruler Erick Honecker, whose iron-fisted rule lasted 18 years, was deposed Oct. 18. The Berlin Wall was opened Nov. 9. On Jan. 14, church mediators stopped the storming of East Berlin's secret police headquarters. Church leaders were credited for a pivotal role in the whole affair by world leaders, including Secretary of State James A. Baker III and former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt. In ensuing sessions of the caretaker government, New Forum, church figures led the transition prior to last month's elections. East Berlin Lutheran pastor Rainer Epplemann, an early leader in church opposition to the regime, served as minister without portfolio in the interim government. He also headed the Democratic Reawakening Party, allied with the March 18 winning coalition favoring reunion with West Germany. At the same time, Lutheran pastor Christian Fuehrer of Leipzig's St. Nicholas Church warned against resurgent nationalism and obsession with Western riches, saying: ``The Coca-Cola culture is taking over and people are rushing blindly to change one set of chains for another.'' And in a gesture of basic Christian compassion, Lutheran Bishop Gottfried Forck of Berlin-Brandenburg temporarily sheltered the fallen Honecker. He and his wife, Margot, were declared ``homeless'' after a court ruled that the 77-year-old dictator's illness prevented jailing him on charges of high treason. Forck arranged for them to stay in two spare rooms at the home of Lutheran pastor Uwe Homer, noting that the shelter was offered in the spirit of Christian mercy to sinners. The broad turn to democracy started earlier and proceeded more gradually in Poland and Hungary. In Poland, visited three times by the pope, stubborn strikes and demonstrations in 1980 gave birth to the Solidarity labor union, the first in Eastern Europe. The union, backed by the church, was outlawed in 1982 under martial law. Its leader, Lech Walesa, was arrested and other union leaders were driven underground, but the union maintained pressure on the government. The pressure, coupled with a disastrous economy, forced negotiations last year that led to the June 4 elections when Solidarity swept into control of parliament. In May 1988, Hungary ousted its puppet party boss, Janos Kadar, who had ruled for 32 years, ever since Soviet tanks crushed a Hungarian uprising in 1956. A national catharsis came June 16, 1989, when bodies of executed leaders of the revolt, including that of Prime Minister Imre Nagy, were exhumed from unmarked graves and reburied with honors. In January 1989, Hungary cut the electrified barbed wire along its border with Austria, opening it to vacationing East Germans and others fleeing communist oppression. All Soviet troops are to be withdrawn from Hungary by June 30, 1991, and last month's multiparty elections were seen as the advent of working democracy. God ``gives power to the faint,'' wrote the biblical prophet Isaiah. They ``shall renew their strength, they shall mount up with wings like eagles.''
DOC.HEAD: NEXT: Rise of ``Wenceslas''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wednesday AMs, April 11
$Adv12
For Release Thursday AMs, April 12, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Resurrection of Nations
Part IV: Rise of `Wenceslas'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The rout of communism spread swiftly but peaceably to Czechoslovakia. The fourth story in a five-part Easter series, ``Resurrection of Nations,'' concerns the Czech surge to freedom and the rise of a `Wenceslas' heritage, as well as Bulgaria's repudiation of communism.

He was a beloved king, Wenceslas, sainted and celebrated in song and story, elevated to Czechoslovakia's throne in 922 in a popular uprising against an anti-religious tyrant who had seized power by force and murder. A statue of the good king presides over Prague's historic gathering place, Wenceslas Square, where 10 days of huge protest marches culminated Nov. l7 in the overthrow of another dictatorship and the choice of another leader named Wenceslas. That is the Latinized form of the Czech name ``Vaclav,'' which is the first name of Vaclav Havel, the repeatedly imprisoned playwright and straight-talking dissenter against authoritarianism, now the country's president. Plainly surprised, even awestruck at the spontaneous rise of the populace against 40 years of Soviet-armed communist rule, Havel called it one of those strangely true contradictions, ``the power of the powerless.'' This is the sort of paradox manifested in the Easter events, the crucifixion of Jesus, his disciples scattered, in hiding, but then his resurrection in glory. ``He was crucified in weakness, but lives by the power of God,'' Scripture says. On a temporal level, the sweeping overturn of communism across Eastern Europe has brought another kind of rebirth, also astounding. ``It's a spiritual resurrection,'' said Olga Hruby, Czech-born editor of the U.S. documentary journal, Religion in Communist Dominated Areas. ``Freedom had been buried for a long time. Now it's alive. ``People ... underwent terrible agonies and suffering. Now they have been restored to citizenship and given back their spiritual freedom. They've been resurrected.'' In cobblestoned Wenceslas Square, a half-mile long and 200 feet wide in the ``golden city'' of medieval towers and baroque domes, Havel's Dec. 29 elevation to the presidency was greeted by firecracker salutes, streamers and an embracing, singing throng. ``Your government, my people, has been returned to you,'' he said in his first televised address to the nation Jan. l, paraphrasing a 17th century Moravian religious reformer, John Amios Comenius. ``Everywhere in the world, people were surprised at how these malleable, humiliated, cynical citizens of Czechoslovakia ... found the tremendous strength to cast off a totalitarian system in an entirely peaceful and dignified manner within a few weeks,'' Havel said. ``We ourselves were surprised at it.'' Proclaiming amnesty for political prisoners and those convicted of non-violent crimes, he urged people ``to help them in a Christian spirit ... to find in themselves what our prisons could not instill: repentance and a desire to lead a good life.'' Havel, 53, who served five years in prison for criticizing repressive rule, ascribed the new freedom to the suffering of others who had struggled courageously in the Soviet Union, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and elsewhere. Referring to the years of persecutions, with many dying in prisons, many executed and thousands of lives destroyed, he said, ``It was these great sacrifices which wove ... the backdrop of our newly charged freedom. ``All human suffering concerns each human being'' he said. This is a biblical principle, that humanity is interlinked and that abuse of anyone, anywhere, imperils everyone, everywhere. Christianity holds that those who share the cross of Christ, in bearing their own cross for others, share ultimately in his triumph of resurrection. ``Upon him was the chastisement that made us whole,'' Scripture says. Czechoslovakia's aging, once imprisoned Catholic Bishop Fratisek Tomacek helped lay the groundwork for upheaval in 1985, gathering 600,000 signatures on petitions demanding religious freedom. When the November demonstrations prompted beatings and arrests, Tomacek risked new arrest by recalling the previously ignored plea and commending ``this huge protest against injustices committed against us for decades.'' All around, he said, countries ``have broken out of the prison of totalitarian systems. We must not wait any longer. It is necessary to act.'' Such encouragement helped push crowds in Wenceslas Square to a half million despite 20-degree weather. ``For the first time we aren't scared anymore,'' exclaimed Martin Jestrik, a cinema student and demonstration organizer. The undaunted marchers forced out the communist autocrat, Milos Jakes, and the entire party resigned Dec. 3. It was replaced by a provisional non-communist coalition, Civic Forum, whose initial moderator and chief spokesman was he once imprisoned Catholic priest Vaclav Maly. In the Prague demonstrations, he leaped to the platform and led demonstrators in the Lord's prayer. Freely competing political parties were authorized and a new cabinet was installed Dec. l0, involving several prominent Christians. Among them were Jan Carnogursky, a Catholic lawyer freed from prison in November, as deputy premier and Czech Brethren theologian Josef Hromodka as vice president. Havel, seen making the sign of the cross at worship services in St. Vitus Cathedral celebrating the downfall of communist rule, told an interviewer: ``I have observed that our revolution, thanks to its heavenly director, has several elements of classical drama and theater of the absurd.'' In customary black denims and sweater at his rather disarrayed third-floor offices in Hardcany castle, he grinned, puzzling over his ``curious passage from jail to the castle.'' With mail piled on the floor and young assistants bustling about, he occasionally called time out. ``Let's all laugh for a minute.'' A papal visit to Czechoslovakia is scheduled April 21-22, and multiparty elections are set for June 8. Havel got the Soviets to agree to remove their troops by July 31, 1991. Concurrent with Czechoslovakia's renewal, presistent demonstrations in Bulgaria, initially crushed, forced out the communist ruler of 35 years, Todor Shivkov, on Nov. 10. He is in prison charged with murder and other crimes. Subsequent demonstrations in December demanded greater democracy. A score of opposition groups hopes to end communist control in June elections, the first in 45 years. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, visiting the Bulgarian capital of Sofia on Feb. 10, told a cheering crowd, ``You are the people who have brought Bulgaria to a new age of democracy.'' Havel, addressing Congress in Washington on Feb. 21, observed, ``It is all very extraordinary.'' He added: ``The only genuine backbone for all our actions, if they are to be moral, is responsibility _ responsibility to something higher than my family, my country, my firm, my success.'' If ``this voice'' of conscience is put ahead of politics, economics or whatever, he said, the new leadership ``can't go far wrong.'' A sign seen in Prague ticks off a timetable of the accelerating democratic upsurges: ``Poland l0 years, Hungary l0 months, East Germany l0 weeks, Czechoslovakia, 10 days, Romania, 10 hours.'' ``The bows of the mighty are broken,'' records the prophet Samuel, ``but the feeble gird on strength.''

DOC.HEAD: Resurrection of Nations
Part V: Tempest Ousts Romanian Tyrant
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Last year's swirl of political change not only raised Eastern European nations from oppression but also released liberating currents elsewhere. This is the last story in a five-part Easter series, ``Resurrection of Nations.''

In Opera Square in Timisoara, Romania, people these afternoons place lighted candles before wreaths and wooden portraits of Jesus, then kneel to pray _ in sorrow for those who died there, in hope for the future of their nation. That country, where Nicolae Ceausescu had vowed communism would never budge, not ``until pears grow on poplar trees,'' broke free in one spontaneous instant, when the despot was jeered in public, forced to flee and, four days later, executed by a firing squad. The upheaval, which began with a lone pastor in Timisoara, was both tame in origins yet wild, unplanned and headlong, murderously repulsed yet successful, fervently keen yet stained with vindictive passion, a maelstrom producing a democracy. The events were ``surprising, fantastic and dreadful,'' all at the same time, the Rev. Wolfgang Hermann Rehner, a Romanian Lutheran pastor, told a clergy meeting. It was the resurrection of a trampled, prostrate people, an Easter-hued rising from despair. The Romanian Orthodox Church, after its collaborationist leaders had resigned, said in a message to the world's Christians: ``After decades of slavery under the Communist dictatorship and after immense suffering ... God has turned his eyes toward our people. ... He has raised us from the shadow of death and set us free.'' Romania's rocky stampede to liberty began in mid-December in Timisoara, where the soft-spoken but courageous Rev. Laszlo Tokes, 37, had been threatened, his church and home raided, for criticizing the regime. He sent his pregnant wife and young son to live with relatives. On Dec. 15, Tokes was served with a court-ordered eviction notice, backed up by his subservient Protestant Reformed bishop. To keep their pastor, his congregation ringed the church. By dusk of the next day, the crowd had grown to 5,000. By then they were surrounded by the detested security police, the Securitate, armed with automatic weapons and small tanks. ``We want liberty! Down with Ceausescu!'' the crowd chanted. The Securitate responded with bullets, and the first victims fell. But the crowds returned the next day. They numbered 50,000 in the city center Dec. 17. Most of the killing in Timisoara occurred that day amid repeated bursts of gunfire and tear gas. Screams and falling bodies punctuated the chaos. Demonstrations quickly flared in other cities and met similar reprisals. In Timisoara, slayings continued Dec. 18. Thirty youngsters were reportedly mowed down as they stood with candles on the cathedral steps. Figures revised from much higher early estimates indicate about 100 died in Timisoara and more than 300 were wounded. Officers of the regular army, a second-class outfit given low pay and shoddy equipment, refused to join the elite Securitate in the slaughter. As demonstrations spread to Arad, Sibiu and other towns, including the capital of Bucharest, the Securitate kept up the killing, firing from buildings, running cars and from atop armored personnel carriers, raising the toll to 746 dead. ``The solidarity demonstration for me changed into a general protest against the regime,'' Tokes said later. On Dec. 21, Ceausescu staged a rally outside party headquarters, the ornate former palace of the Romanian monarch. Workers and party functionaries were herded into Palace Square with placards hailing Ceausescu. In a raspy voice, the 71-year-old dictator railed against ``foreign enemies'' and ``terrorist subversives.'' Suddenly from far back, boos sounded. Like a wave, boos and jeers rolled up to the balcony. Ceausescu froze, and fear crossed his face just before he ordered the television cameras cut off. When the army refused to shoot, he and his despised wife, Elena, fled, first in a helicopter, then in a red car. Captured Dec. 22 in a grain silo, the Ceausescus were given a two-hour trial and shot on Christmas Day. Tokes, kept on the run all that tumultuous week, became a member of the unity council of the provisional government, the National Salvation Front. It outlawed the feared Securitate and set multi-party elections for May 20. Among celebrating crowds, a continual chant memorialized the events and the city that started it all: ``Timisoara! Timisoara!'' For the first time in decades, full Romanian Orthodox liturgies appeared on television, along with special services for those who died. Tokes later was named bishop, replacing the collaborating prelate who had sought his ouster. But the falls of Ceausescu brought new chaos and failed to banish old anxieties. Romanians have no experience with democracy, and the Front is constantly challenged and second-guessed. Hardships and scarcities remain, scars of past horrors and suspicions in a country long thick with informers and ``mincuini,'' the lies that characterized the past regime. Arduous reconstruction lies ahead in the liberated countries, including the latest one, Mongolia. In that land of herdsmen between the Soviet and China, the Communist Party on March 14 surrendered its constitutional monopoly and prepared for multiparty elections later this year. Besides the dismemberment of communism, liberating currents also stirred in Latin America and South Africa. In Nicaragua, voters on Feb. 26 ousted Marxist-leaning Daniel Ortega. The new president, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, assumes office April 25. In Haiti, former Supreme Court Justice Ertha Pascal Trouillot last month became the first civilian president since dictator Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier was toppled in 1986, ending 29 years of Duvalier dictatorship. In Chile, Patricio Aylwin's election victory Dec. 14 made him the first civilian president since 1973. The 17-year rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet had been marked by torture, political killings and disappearances. In Brazil, the first popularly elected president in 29 years, Fernando Collor de Mello, assumed office March 15. In Namibia, independence was achieved March 21 after 75 years of military rule by bordering South Africa. In South Africa, President F.W. de Klerk in February lifted a 30-year ban on the African National Congress, which has fought minority white rule, and released its leader Nelson Mandela from 27{ years in prison. ``Hallelujah! Hallelujah!'' cried South Africa's Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who did a little dance. ``Freedom is coming!'' ``There's no single explanation'' for it all, said Monsignor John Tracy Ellis, a noted U.S. Catholic historian. ``It's a univeral phenomenon of the human spirit that longs to be free. ``Freedom is in the air and please God that it will sweep the whole planet and embrace the poor people of Cambodia and China and North Korea.'' In the daybreak of change many horizons remain clouded, but glow with promise. ``You will know the truth,'' Jesus said of his crucifixion and resurrection. ``And the truth will make you free.''

DOC.HEAD: Racial Violence Results From Influx of Immigrants
DOC.TEXT: Carlo Testi remembers when the problem of illegal immigration came to his door, right on the Via de' Calzaioli, one of the most fashionable streets in this Renaissance city. A few African immigrants spread blankets on the pedestrian mall, putting out sunglasses and fake Louis Vuitton bags for sale. Others came, and soon there were 400 vendors. ``People couldn't pass any more,'' Testi said, gazing down the street from his family's century-old hat shop to the Ponte Vecchio, a 14th century bridge. ``It was a desperate situation.'' These days, not an African vendor is in sight. City hall sent hundreds of police to round up illegal immigrants and vendors. Newspapers called it a ``witchhunt for blacks.'' The police sweep, which followed a bloody attack by youths on African immigrants, raised an outcry and made Florence, the birthplace of Renaissance humanism, the symbol of a national debate on immigration and racism. ``Italy has given the world 26 million emigrants,'' Deputy Premier Claudio Martelli said. ``Is it possible that the fifth or sixth industrial power loses its bearings, is torn apart or reacts with furor and malice before the difficulties and problems raised by a few hundred thousand immigrants?'' Violence against immigrants has been a problem in central and northern European countries as they have absorbed citizens of former colonies and workers from poorer countries. France experienced a wave of racist attacks on North Africans in recent weeks. Florence's immigrants are poor Africans and Latin Americans attracted to countries in southern Europe that have enjoyed economic booms but still lack the immigration controls imposed in recent years by France, Britain and Scandinavia. Experts say Italy, with about 100,000 illegal immigrants arriving each year, has become the focal point of the new migration. It has difficulty absorbing them, despite a strong economy, because of scarce housing and poor public health and education systems. This ethnically homogeneous country has seen ugly racial attacks in recent years that many Italians had thought occurred only in the United States, or at least outside Italy. The government now hopes to stem the immigration with an amnesty, its second in four years. Immigration in the past year ``has been huge and unforeseen,'' said Giorgio Morales, a Socialist who was forced to resign as mayor of Florence after the police sweep. ``These new phenomena have come in a short time in Florence, and because of this there has been a reaction of intolerance,'' he said. Estimates of the number of illegal immigrants in Italy range from 500,000 to 1.5 million. Ugo Vittorio Saibante of the government's National Council of the Economy and Work, said he believed the number was about 1 million, up 100 percent from 1985, and that only about half had work permits. Authorities say many illegal immigrants take jobs Italians no longer want, particularly in the countryside, where they pick tomatoes, help fishermen or work in small factories. Saibante, however, spoke of ``a tendency among people from less developed countries to go to the cities,'' where ``there are many fewer possibilities. Here is where the problems of racism begin.'' Trouble developed in Florence about a year ago, as African vendors filled the streets around the pink-and-green Duomo cathedral and the 14th century city hall, the Palazzo Vecchio, which attract thousands of tourists daily. Police ignored the newcomers at first, but strictly regulated souvenir and handicraft vendors were furious. Shopkeepers also complained. ``To see all these people here in the center wasn't good for tourism,'' Testi said. ``The image was ugly.'' African vendors say they merely wanted to earn a living while looking for steady work, and accuse the shopkeepers of racism. ``We must sell to pay the hotel,'' said a 26-year-old Senegalese who shares a cheap room with another vendor. ``Otherwise we have to sleep on the street.'' In February, about 4,000 residents held a ``March of Defenseless Citizens'' against a crime wave many people attributed to immigrants working for Italian-run drug and prostitution rings. Days later, dozens of masked young ``avengers'' armed with baseball bats and iron bars went on a rampage during pre-Lent Carnival celebrations, beating up African immigrants. In mid-March, spurred by citizen complaints, authorities ordered the large-scale police operation to pick up illegal immigrants and chase African vendors away. The vendors responded with a hunger and sit-down strike. The assault by youths and massive police action shocked Italians, who are proud of their tolerance and have a long emigrant tradition. Other racist attacks have taken place in major cities. ``People also yelled crook, swindler, invader at my father in Boston,'' Monsignor Luigi Di Liego, Rome director of the charity organization Caritas, said in an interview in the newspaper La Repubblica. Officials hope to ease tensions with a new amnesty law sponsored by Deputy Premier Martelli, a Socialist. It would allow foreigners who arrived before Dec. 31 to get work permits and benefits. Unlike an unsuccessful 1987 amnesty, the new law imposes heavy penalties on employers who do not legalize their workers, and establishes strict rules about who can enter the country. Critics predict it will not slow the flood of immigrants, who often come by sea and do not pass through border controls. ``With the amnesty ... Italy has sent a message: Whoever enters this country not only will never be thrown out, but sooner or later will be regularized,'' said Giorgio La Malfa, head of the Republican Party, part of the governing coalition. His party opposed the amnesty measure in Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Civil War Interest Thrives, 125 Years After Appomattox
DOC.TEXT: When Gen. Ulysses S. Grant's troops chased the Confederate government from Richmond, a slave named James Wilder hid in a tobacco silo. ``He almost suffocated in that silo,'' recalls the slave's grandson, Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, recounting the story passed down through his father. Instead, James Wilder emerged to find himself suddenly a free man, and the city, which had been bombarded for months, wrapped in flames. Grant rode on 95 miles to Appomattox, where Gen. Robert E. Lee surrendered the South's main army seven days later on April 9, 1865, and Wilder went on to beget the father of the nation's first black elected governor. Though 125 years have passed since the end of the Civil War, it still is ingrained in the consciences of many Southern natives. Stories about the war are reaching more people than ever through a growing number of battle re-enactments, battlefield tours, books and specialty magazines, and through the celebrated movie ``Glory,'' about the Union's first black regiment. ``There are so many events being re-enacted that we can't keep track of them,'' said David Roth, editor of Blue and Gray, a magazine with the motto ``For Those Who Still Hear The Guns.'' The regional and racial divisions exacerbated by the ``War of Northern Aggression,'' the term still used by some southerners, are beginning to close, and the symbols of the Old South are becoming more anachronistic. Trucks with Confederate flags on the rear windows and bumper stickers reading ``Forget, Hell!'' and ``The South Will Rise Again'' are becoming endangered species, but the ironies of the South in transition still pervade Richmond, the capital of the Confederacy. Residents celebrate the birthdays of Lee, Gen. Stonewall Jackson and Martin Luther King Jr. on the same day. Mary Sue Terry, the state's first female attorney general, is fighting a U.S. Justice Department lawsuit seeking to force Virginia Military Institute to admit women. VMI cadets fought to secede from the federal government, and many of the southern generals were graduates. One of only two buildings in Richmond's commercial district that survived Grant's 10-month siege is a granite structure that housed offices of the Confederate government. Occupying the building now is the federal court, the institution that helped rid the South of segregation. Across the Martin Luther King Bridge and a block to the left are the Museum of the Confederacy and the Confederate White House, now surrounded by high-rise university buildings. The museum's sign-in sheet is replete with the names of visitors from cities to the north, as well as Canada and Europe. Attendance never has been better, spokeswoman Barbara Hyde said. ``There always has been a high interest in the Civil War, but in the past four years, it has increased tremendously,'' she said. On Richmond's Monument Avenue, two black women and a white man who attend a karate class nearby practice their moves at the base of a towering statue of Lee on horseback. In between kick punches, Carrie Britton relates how she cried when she saw the movie ``Glory'' and only then learned there were black soldiers who died fighting for the Union. ``There was a white woman who made a point of holding the door for me when I was leaving the theater,'' Ms. Britton said. ``She was touched, too.'' The provocation for the Civil War was at first largely the labor-intensive South's objection to tariffs favored by the industrialized North, although the issue of slavery bitterly divided the regions. Only later did the focus shift to the constitutional issues of secession and the abolition of slavery. Those issues led to the poignant human drama of brother fighting brother, father fighting son and friend fighting friend, particularly in border states. The cost of the war was tremendous. More than 600,000 Union and Confederate soldiers died over the four-year period, nearly equaling the number of Americans killed in all other wars combined. Because of the high number of casualties, almost everyone who had forebears in America in 1861 can associate with the war, said Ed Bearss, chief historian of the National Park Service. Charles Bryan, director of the Virginia Historical Society, said he and other Civil War scholars on the lecture circuit are being asked to explain why people continue to be fascinated by the struggle 125 years later. To answer, he pulls a cone-shaped rifle bullet from his pocket, a Minie ball recovered at a battlefield outside Richmond that's now a residential development. ``A young boy brought it to the Historical Society,'' Bryan said. ``One of the reasons the war is so fascinating is that it happened in our own backyard, both literally and figuratively.'' The war destroyed the economic and social system of the South. The 12 years of Reconstruction that followed, a period in which the 11 secessionist states were regarded as conquered territories, solidified the region's antagonism toward the North. ``I don't think there would have been a solid South had there not been what southerners saw as a harsh Reconstruction,'' Bearss said. ``The feelings were so visceral that it went past just disagreement on political ideologues,'' Wilder said. ``Rather, it was almost a lifestyle to be different. The only thing that can change that is the passage of time.'' An increasingly mobile society and the commonality of mass communications also are softening the divisions, Bryan said. ``Little by little, the separate identities of the North and South are beginning to change,'' he said. Bryan said the lingering prejudices became apparent to him when the topic of a speech he gave on the commemoration of Lee's birthday _ the 18 native Virginians who served as generals in the Union army _ was publicized in advance. ``I got angry phone calls from people who said, `How dare you talk about Yankee generals on General Lee's birthday?' '' he said. ``The Civil War still lives in the minds of many people. It will never be forgotten.''

DOC.HEAD: A Look Back at Appomattox 125 Years Later
With BC-Civil War Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: ``Welcome To Historic Appomattox, Where Our Nation Reunited.'' Other than the wooden sign at the side of the highway, Harry Lillie's Civil War souvenir and relic shop adjoining the Lee-Grant Motel is the only reminder of what happened two miles outside town on April 9, 1865. In the Victorian parlor of a private home, with the Confederacy's main army surrounded and starving, Gen. Robert E. Lee surrendered to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant, ending, for all intents and purposes, the War Between the States. On the muddy main road of the tiny village of Appomattox Court House three days later, exactly four years after the war started at Fort Sumter, S.C., Confederate Gen. John Gordon marched his 28,231 ragged, emaciated troops one last time. As Union troops from the 100,000-strong Army of the Potomac lined the muddy road, the Rebels stacked their guns, hung their ammunition pouches on the sights, furled their Confederate battle flags and began the long trek home. In a re-enactment commemorating the 125th anniversary Sunday, the solemn sound of soldiers marching again will be broken by the crisp order ``Stack ... arms.'' But the skirmishes will be re-enacted 150 miles away in Fredericksburg. Neither local residents nor the National Park Service, which operates the Appomattox Court House National Historical Park, wanted to restage the battles. Lillie, a well-meaning carpetbagger from New Jersey, is perplexed by what he considers residents' apathy about the role their county played in American history. ``Appomattox was big enough to handle the actual battles and surrender, but is not big enough to handle the re-enacted battles. That ought to tell you something,'' he said. About 110,000 people visit Appomattox Court House annually, but few tarry because Appomattox has only two small hotels and few places to eat, said Jon Montgomery, the park superintendent. In 1865, there were 8,900 residents. Now there are about 12,800. A publicity pamphlet issued by the chamber of commerce describes Appomattox as ``an old-fashioned town where progress is slow and measured.'' But a chain hotel now is under construction across the street from Lillie's, and a shopping center, Historic Junction, recently was completed. Fast-food restaurants beckon on the main highway, and there are plans to lure more people into the main part of town, with its freshly painted, century-old wooden homes and stores. Montgomery and Mayor Ronnie Spiggle said it takes a sense of history to understand the reluctance over the years to commercialize the park and the decision this year to ignore the battles that took place 125 years ago. Spiggle agrees with the shrine-like treatment of the park, which continues to be surrounded by miles of undeveloped pastures and looks nearly identical to what the soldiers saw in 1865. ``We don't want to emphasize the battles. They were insignificant compared to other battles of the war,'' Montgomery said. ``The story here is the peace that came here.'' After the war, Southern opposition to a park at Appomattox kept the federal government from establishing one for 75 years. A new highway skirted the deteriorating village. Buildings disintegrated and burned. Some were torn down. In 1940, the National Park Service acquired the land for the park, and the main buildings of the village eventually were restored or reconstructed in time for the 100th anniversary of the surrender. The 10 historic structures, most red brick surround by split-rail or white picket fences, include the McLean House, where the terms of surrender were signed, the courthouse, a tavern, a jail, a general store, a tiny law office and several residences. ``The southerners wanted to forget what happened here,'' Montgomery said. ``It marked the end of their hopes of having a separate country.''

At the Movies: `A Shock to the System'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Released in 20 U.S. cities March 23, with more to be added later.
DOC.TEXT: Graham Marshall in his middle years appears to have an enviable life: important post at a Manhattan ad agency, wife and home in the suburbs. But on closer examination we see that his job is threatened by a younger, ruthless executive, his wife is a nagging shrew and he is drowning in debt. Then one day in the subway, a tragedy makes Graham realize that crimes can go undetected. He cooly plans complicated schemes to rid himself of his enemies. His plot is triggered when he loses a much-needed promotion to the young conniver, causing his wife's comment, ``I forgive you for your failure.'' ``A Shock to the System'' (a word-play on Graham's mode of execution) might have been minor-league Hitchcock. But the movie bears watching, if only to observe a master performer at work. Michael Caine is Graham Marshall, and it is a pleasure to see a real pro make more of a script than what is on the pages. Caine's bland face reflects all the maddening frustrations that drive him toward his devilish deeds. When he rages against the yuppie who usurped his job, Caine is Olympian in his wrath. When he cooly executes his remote-control murders, he is as menacing as Freddy Kreuger. ``A Shock to the System'' marks a promising entry into feature films for Jan Egleson, who has directed prestige films for public television. He skillfully plays the murderous events against the normality of New York high rises and peaceful suburbia. Andrew Klavan wrote the script, adapting Simon Brett's novel. The plot is cleverly devised, but it's hard to believe that Caine's acts would not attract more police suspicion. His only pursuer is a suburban detective (Will Patton) who seems slow to round up a case. The film is well cast. Elizabeth McGovern is convincingly vulnerable as the co-worker who becomes Caine's lover and potential victim. Peter Riegert (the pickle salesman in ``Crossing Delancy'') is ideal as the upwardly mobile ad man. John McMartin has strong moments as the executive whose life burns out when he is forced into early retirement. Swoosie Kurtz offers a convincing argument for uxoricide. ``A Shock to the System,'' a Corsair Production release, is rated R for language and adult material. Running time: 87 minutes.

Video View: Home Video News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT: With spring comes baseball. And what better way to celebrate America's favorite sport than by taking home a few videos. Hollywood once considered baseball movies box-office poison because movie moguls thought women, who constitute a large part of film-goers, wouldn't want to see them and foreign audiences simply didn't understand the mechanics. Before the late 1980s, studio heads may have had a point. Some of the all-time baseball classics, though warmly embraced by fans, did lousy box office. Such movies as 1942's ``The Pride of the Yankees,'' starring Gary Cooper as Lou Gehrig were big disappointments. However, ``The Natural,'' Robert Redford's allegorical movie in 1984 about a gifted player, and ``Bull Durham'' (1988), an amusing and lusty tale of the minor leagues starring Kevin Costner and Susan Sarandon, helped turn things around. The biggest grossing baseball movie of all time is last year's ``Field of Dreams,'' which had taken in $53.3 million by August. ``Bull Durham'' was second with $50.3 million. And the comedy smash, ``Major League'' (1989), ran third with $48.5 million. All three are on video. There are other baseball movies hard-core fans might want to watch that will even be enjoyed by those who've never downed a hot dog at the park. Here's a list of other baseball movies that are available on video:

``College'' (1927): Buster Keaton as the unwitting jock who tries to woe the love of his life through sports.
``Take Me Out to the Ballgame'' (1949): Gene Kelly, Esther Williams and Frank Sinatra in a lackluster musical directed by Busby Berkeley. ``The Jackie Robinson Story'' (1950): A poignant and hard look at baseball's ugly history: racism. One of best biographical baseball movies ever made, starring Jackie Robinson as himself. ``Damn Yankees'' (1958): Lola gets whatever Lola wants. Stars Gwen Verdon, Ray Walston and Tab Hunter.
``Bang the Drum Slowly'' (1973): Excellent performances by Michael Moriarity and Robert de Niro as two baseball buddies who together face tragedy. ``The Bingo Long Traveling All-Stars and Motor Kings'' (1976): A delightful romp of a group of black baseball players touring rural America in the 1930s. Nice touches by James Earl Jones, Billy Dee Williams and Richard Pryor. ``The Bad News Bears'' (1976): The first of a string of kiddie baseball flicks. But the first is definitely the best and the funniest. Stars Tatum O'Neal and Walter Matthau. ``The Bad News Bears Go to Japan'' (1978): O'Neal and Matthau wisely dropped out. ``The Bad News Bears in Breaking Training'' (1977): Bad news. ``It's My Turn'' (1980): A limp love story starring Jill Clayburgh and Michael Douglas. ``Eight Men Out'' (1988): John Sayles tough look at the 1919 Black Sox scandal with a wonderful ensemble cast. ``Stealing Home'' (1988): A rambling study about a talented baseball player whose life takes a turn when he learns about the suicide of a young woman from his past.

In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Here Comes the Groom'' (Sire) _ John Wesley Harding
``Bob Dylan is my father. Joan Baez is my mother. And I am their bastard son,'' sings John Wesley Harding. Harding, who takes his name from a Dylan album, is a gleeful musical vandal. On his debut album, he sounds eerily like Elvis Costello, and even shares Costello's music publishing company and two members of his former band, the Attractions. Harding's song ``Cathy's New Clown'' quotes from the Everly Brothers classic. But faster than anyone can spell ``derivative,'' Harding is laughing. His thievery is so blatant, and he makes such a joke about it, that it's thrown back in the face of people overly concerned with originality in rock 'n' roll. Besides, it's awfully hard not to like this album. ``Wes'' is the real-life Wesley Harding Stace, a 24-year-old Englishman who once aspired to be a sportscaster. His backup band, the Good Liars, features former Costello rhythm section Bruce and Pete Thomas and shares the Attractions' mastery of several different styles. Harding doesn't hesitate to take them in all sorts of directions: ``Affairs of the Heart,'' with its accordion and pedal steel guitar, sounds like French country music. Some of ``Here Comes the Groom'' is like ``Get Happy'' with a brass section, some is clearly folk-influenced. On ``The Devil in Me,'' about the darker side of human nature, it's both in the same song. Like Costello, Harding has the gift of gab. Words often pour out faster than most human ears can pick up. There's little of Costello's bitterness, however, as this couplet suggests: ``If there's a nuclear winter, at least it will snow.'' The cassette has 15 songs, and many of them are crackling good. There are slower moments _ such as the uninspired folkie duet with Peter Case, ``Things Snowball,'' and other cuts buried on Side 2. But Harding has an unexpectedly high batting average on this audacious debut.

``Pale'' (Columbia) _ Toad the Wet Sprocket
Toad the Wet Sprocket's new album, ``Pale,'' exemplifies everything that's wrong about the wheezing alternative rock scene. Far from the cutting edge, the underground scene has too many imitators instead of innovators. The reigning gods are still R.E.M., which methodically built a successful career with originality and relentless work. Since the early 1980s, R.E.M. has had more impersonators than Elvis Presley. Toad the Wet Sprocket is only the latest to emulate the form rather than the substance of R.E.M. ``Pale'' is loaded with moody, slightly incongruous lyrics. The guitar rock mixes the jangle and the drone. The cover's a grainy picture of something indistinguishable and the band photo is blurry. Sound familiar? Admittedly, the failure of an entire genre is a tough burden to place on the shoulders of an unassuming California rock band. They're somewhat adept interpreters; the sound is more muscular than ``Murmur'' era R.E.M. though the songs, of course, lack distinctiveness. But it would be far better to see bands try to make their mark with their own visions rather than someone else's.

DOC.TEXT: In 1936, the photographer Walker Evans worked with author James Agee in Hale County, Ala., preparing an article on sharecropping that later became their book ``Let Us Now Praise Famous Men'' (1941). Artist Williams Christenberry was greatly influenced by the book as a University of Alabama graduate student in 1960, and he began photographing Hale County buildings and countryside primarily as studies for his paintings. Evans and Christenberry met in 1961 and returned to Hale County together in 1973. Photographs the two artists made in Hale County over a 50-year period will be on display at the Amon Carter Museum in Fort Worth, Texas, from April 27 to June 24. Following its run at the Amon Carter, ``Of Time and Place: Walker Evans and Williams Christenberry'' will travel to the Wichita Art Museum, Kansas, Dec. 1, 1990-Jan. 20, 1991; the Portland Museum of Art, Maine, Feb. 17-April 14, 1991; and the Friends of Photography, San Francisco, July 2-Sept. 9, 1991.

Star Watch: Locke Has the Key for Movie Directing
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: On her emergence as a film director, Sondra Locke makes an observation about gender. ``Women have to work twice as hard to be taken seriously,'' she said. ``From my experience, what I had to fight against was my association with Clint (Eastwood), because it automatically disqualified me in some ways as being a separate entity or having had to fight on my own. I was doing things before I met Clint. ``You have to fight harder. People don't stop and think how long you have been around or what you may be on your own. There is a wall. But if you just know who you are and keep plugging along, sooner or later the little crack in the wall gets bigger. Pretty soon you can put your foot through. Then you are able to emerge as yourself.'' With her second film as a director, ``Impulse,'' Sondra Locke does emerge as a filmmaker who can be taken seriously. Unlike her first effort, the largely unseen ``Ratboy,'' ``Impulse'' has the elements for popular appeal. It's a cop movie, with Theresa Russell as an undercover vice officer who can be as tough as Dirty Harry. The comparison to Clint Eastwood movies is unavoidable. But Miss Locke's long professional and personal association with Eastwood having reached a bitter ending, she is making strides in establishing her own life and career. Breaking up was hard to do for both parties. Over 13 years she had appeared in six Eastwood films, from ``The Outlaw Josey Wales'' to ``The Gauntlet,'' and they were close companions despite her marriage to another man. They parted amid acrimony in December 1988, and last April she filed a palimony suit alleging cruel treatment by Eastwood. It is still pending. Locke established her own fame in her first movie, ``The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter,'' winning a 1968 Academy Award nomination as supporting actress when she was only 17. Her ``discovery'' by Hollywood is so cliche-laden that it's hard to believe. ``It's like a movie, bigger than life,'' she admitted. ``But it's actually true. I was this girl in (Shelby) Tennessee. I wanted to be an actress but was just out of school and didn't know how to go about it. ``Suddenly Warner Bros. is having this talent search, and the casting director, Marion Dougherty, is going from city to city. The nearest city was Birmingham, Ala. I read about it in the paper. I auditioned. The next thing I knew I was in New York, then I was in Selma, Ala., shooting with Alan Arkin. ``The next thing I knew, I was in Hollywood, and then I was nominated for an Academy Award. It was an amazing experience, enough to confuse the brain.'' More films followed (``Run Shadow Run, ``Willard''), then the association with Eastwood. During those years she remained in the shadow of a superstar, subordinating her own ambitions. How does that reconcile with her strong feelings about a woman's role in society? ``I've thought about that a great deal,'' she said. ``We go through certain phases in our lives; we grow and change and get different perspectives. For a time I thought that the only thing that can be counted on is your work. You know exactly what you can do, and you have control over it to some degree. ``That's not right, either. A relationship is very important; sometimes that is how we find out about ourselves. From the breakup of a relationship we find out even more. Hopefully, we can turn that into creativity if we try hard. ``For a period in my life, a relationship was the most important thing. Everything else was just very, very secondary. ... There's no doubt that professionally I did go into a tunnel. Then it can be exhilarating and challenging and exciting to try to come out of it.'' At 42, Sondra Locke has the same willowy blond beauty that she displayed as the 14-year-old Mike Kelly in ``The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter.'' Don't be fooled by her seeming fragility. On a movie set she can be commanding and decisive. For ``Impulse'' she prowled the mean streets of Los Angeles with a homicide squad to soak up how the police operate. And she scorns any suggestion that women cannot direct action. ``The thing that posed the challenge in my mind was not the action per se,'' she said. ``When I think about action, I only think about `what happens.' I see it in my head as a movie. I don't stop and say, `Ooo, this is action!' If you tell the story of what's happening, it kind of takes care of itself.'' Are the wounds of the Eastwood affair beginning to heal? ``I think I've learned a lot,'' she said hesitantly. ``I'm proud of that. I had to be a lot stronger than I ever knew that I could be. I had to learn to stand up for myself and decide who I am, what I need and what's right. If you look on that as a positive instead of a negative, then I would say that yes, I am healing.''

The Artists: Classical Singer Reaches for Allah's Message
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Nustrah Fateh Ali Khan rocks back and forth as he sings in a machine gun-like style. The low beat of tabla drums provides an eerie backbeat to the staccato rhythms of his voice. Six handclappers provide more cadence, and two harmoniums flesh out the tune as Khan stretches his arms to the heavens to receive Allah's ``direct message.'' The all-male crowd, assembled in this village near Lahore in eastern Pakistan, rocks to the beat. Several bearded men, wearing intricately-crocheted skull caps, sway to the front. One collapses on the earthen floor, twitching in a religious trance. Listeners throw rupee notes on the singer and his band. By the time the night is through, Khan has collected 40,000 rupees ($2,000). He is one of Pakistan's great singers. He practices an art called qawalli, part of Pakistan's rich tradition of classical music. Today, Khan's art form is going through a revival of sorts, a byproduct of the increasing availability of cassette tapes and the failure of fundamentalist religious thinkers to impose their strict ideas on the masses. Khan and his band came to Alama Iqbal to commemorate the death of the town's largest landlord, who died four years ago. Following Islamic tradition, peasants and workers from a nearby scrap metal plant have been invited to the show. A huge tent houses the guests, about 2,000 in all. Women are not present. Strict Moslem tradition bans them from casual contact with male strangers. Still, several little girls in brightly colored shalwar kameez, the traditional baggy pants and knee-length tunic, flit through the crowd, clutching their fathers' hands. Khan comes from a family that has been singing for more than 600 years. From Ghazni, now part of Afghanistan, his family went to India during the time of the great Mogul empire that dominated the subcontinent for centuries. Soon Khan's relatives were singing for the Mogul court. Moslem rulers used Khan's forefathers to spread Islam through India, combining Islam's tradition of religious poetry with the wild music of India. Khan's family came to Pakistan in 1947, following the partition of the subcontinent into a Moslem country, Pakistan, and a largely Hindu nation, India. At that time, his father and uncle were the leaders of a famed qawalli band and played in mosques and villages throughout Punjab province. ``In the beginning, they wanted me to become a doctor because classical singing is too hard,'' Khan said in an interview at a small hotel in the heart of Lahore. But the young boy persevered, listening to his father teach other pupils from behind a curtain in the family's house. ``One day he caught me. First he scolded me but then he encouraged me,'' he said. Khan's training was cut short by his father's death in 1964 when he was 16. A heavy mantle passed to his shoulders. ``I remember his first concert,'' said Khalid Asghar, a senior music producer at Pakistan Broadcasting Corp. ``He was a little round-faced chap. He sang with vigor.'' As he grew older, Khan became enormously fat. He now weighes 350 pounds. Khan is not blessed with a beautiful or melodic voice, but it has a haunting power and his rhythm, a key element of qawalli singing, is impeccable. ``His voice is like an ugly woman who becomes a great actress,'' said Asghar. ``Tghere is so much art in him that you forget about the ugliness.'' When he sings, Khan says, he forgets who and where he is. ``It is a direct message,'' he says, pointing to the sky. In the past few years, Khan has achieved some international stature. Rock artist Peter Gabriel released a Khan record on his Realworld label last year. He has sung in Paris, London and at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in New York. Over the past few years his music has become increasingly popular in Pakistan, partly a result of its good beat and the ambiguity of his lyrics. ``Your eyes have made me drunk,'' goes one song. ``Your willingness and your love make me a drunken man.'' Some would interpret the couplet as a celebration of Allah, the Moslem god. Others imbue it with more earthly charms.

Books and Authors: Living Like Thoreau in the Backyard
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When John Hanson Mitchell's marriage ended in 1986, he abandoned the modern world and moved alone to a cabin in the woods to live like his ``mentor,'' Henry David Thoreau. But during his year without electricity and running water, Mitchell discovered what he calls a timeless truth that may be more suited to this generation. In an upcoming book based on his experiment in the woods, Mitchell decries the materialism of modern times and advocates a return to the simpler values of Thoreau's mid-19th century. ``The essence of civilization is not the multiplication of wants, but the elimination of needs,'' says Mitchell, 49, standing on his land, just 16 miles from Walden Pond. That sentiment may sound a bit ponderous and pretentious, but Mitchell is not. He is the first to tell you that his year in the woods, titled ``Living at the End of Time,'' involved more than just giving up a CD player and the Cuisinart. Though he continued work as editor of a small magazine, Mitchell returned home to his cabin every night. It was there that he gained a peace and contentment he says comes from living close to the land. He calls it a ``satisfying feeling, a comfort'' that he believes is difficult to achieve in the fast-track world. But the hardest part came before Mitchell even moved into his cabin _ when his wife decided they should separate. At the time, the couple lived in a house on the edge of dense woods in this rural suburb 35 miles west of Boston. Mitchell moved to a nearby apartment but found he missed his land. His attachment to the land, a square-mile of nearly undeveloped woods of which Mitchell owns four acres, is more than sentimental. Several years ago, he chronicled the 15,000-year history of the land, called Scratch Flat, in a book. ``There does seem to be some sort of draw here, some sort of historical presence,'' he says. ``This place seems more alive than others.'' Mitchell says he and his wife separated amicably. His son and daughter often stayed with him in his cabin. ``I look at these things as more tribal,'' he says of the split. ``Marriages don't break up. People just move into different huts.'' Mitchell also had a practical reason for building his one-room gingerbread-style cabin. He needed some ``affordable housing.'' The Gothic-style cottage was built by Mitchell using Thoreau's shack and the designs of mid-19th century architect Andrew Jackson Downing for inspiration. It was constructed on a ridge hidden behind thick woods, about 400 yards from his former house and the road. In the winter, Mitchell had to ski through the woods to get to his house. In the warm months, Mitchell often spent hours sitting outside his cottage, contemplating the surrounding meadows and trees. He took long walks in the woods and met an assortment of characters: a family of Eastern European refugees who lived on a small farm, a mysterious man who dressed partly in animal skins and said he lived in a cave. In the winter, he stoked his small camp stove for warmth and huddled under heavy blankets. He reread the classics and read the journals kept by Thoreau as well as his own father. Most important, he said, was his feeling of oneness with nature, a feeling that all the ``windows and walls separating me'' had been removed. ``Sometimes I would even go for night walks ... picking my way along the trail by watching the sky. The stars had never seemed so bright,'' Mitchell writes. ``I became acutely conscious of the changing position of what quarter the moon was in. Some nights, when I was alone in the cottage, I wouldn't bother to light the lamps. I would simply sit there in the dark, watching moonlight spill in through the windows ... listening to the sounds around me.'' Mitchell's spartan life in the woods was made ironic by the construction of a huge Digital Equipment Corp. plant nearby. Mitchell grew obsessed with the encroachment of the plant and ``the loyal penitents, the programmers and the engineers,'' who worked there. After weeks of attempts, he finally befriended an employee who took him on a tour of the plant. Mitchell has since moved to a new house he had built just a few yards from the cottage. This one has electricity and modern comforts but Mitchell says he has retained what he learned in his one room. ``The lesson is, you don't have to live in a cottage in the woods to strip yourself of a lot of material possessions,'' he says. ``There are deeper satisfactions.''
