DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: Ronstadt Expands on Musical Style Once Again
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In Linda Ronstadt's 23-year career she has changed from a lovesick pop covergirl into a soulful country crooner, a 1940s-style torch singer and a caballero-outfitted Mexican folksinger. Now she's re-entered the pop scene and stolen hearts with the album ``Cry Like a Rainstorm, Howl Like the Wind.'' The first single from the album, a duet with Aaron Neville called ``I Don't Know Much,'' won a Grammy award this year for best pop vocal by a duo or group. Despite her chameleon-like, seemingly whimsical career moves, there's a method to Ronstadt's madness: She just has to sing, no matter what the style. ``I feel pressure to make order out of chaos and I do this with music. I mean it. That is what I need to do. I think that is why people make art,'' she said. ``If I didn't make a living trying to make order out of chaos with my music, I would get a job selling hot dogs, or whatever else I could find that would do it.'' Ronstadt said the songs on ``Cry Like a Rainstorm'' have been her ``friends'' for years, and the time was right to record them. The same could be said for all the songs she's recorded. ``It becomes kind of your best friend and you think about it and talk to it every day. And then you have to record it,'' she said. ``It's just those songs became ripe, in their way, and they became current, and I needed to sing them.'' Sitting in the office of her longtime manager and friend, Peter Asher, Ronstadt does not look like a veteran star. Her face remains unlined, and she wears playful cowboy boots adorned with multicolored designs. In the two decades she's been in the business she's learned that the songs are the important thing, not what people think. ``The singing that I do with my hands in the dishwater is just as meaningful to me, and maybe a little bit more, than the singing I do in front of 40,000 people.'' Her new LP gave Ronstadt the opportunity to work with Neville, who is one of her idols. Neville, an angelic-sounding singer who had a Top-10 song in 1967 with ``Tell It Like It Is,'' is a part of the Neville Brothers, a critically acclaimed band known for a contemporary New Orleans sound. Ronstadt first met Neville when she went to the World's Fair in New Orleans several years ago to perform with Nelson Riddle. The members of the orchestra all wanted to see the Neville Brothers, so they ventured out to find them. ``We found them playing at this club and Aaron found out somehow I was there and dedicated a song to me,'' Ronstadt said. ``I was certain I was the only female on the planet and I was sure I was the only person in the room listening to him sing. Just me and him. It was one of those moments _ those transcendental moments.'' Later in the evening, Ronstadt and Neville sang a duet, and their voices ``clicked.'' ``I thought, well, maybe this is really happening,'' she said. ``Then I thought maybe every singer in the world would just like to think their voice sounded good with Aaron's, because Aaron sounds so good.'' For years the two tried to find a project together, but the opportunity didn't arise until ``Cry Like a Rainstorm.'' Ronstadt envisioned the songs on the album as stacked orchestral arrangements recorded in a huge, natural-sounding studio. Unfortunately, she discovered, there aren't many of those around. Still, she refused to give up. ``I just kept thinking BIG. I needed a big room because I wanted big sound and a big orchestra and a big choir and I wanted big voices and I wanted big guitars and big drums.'' Ronstadt got her wish. She recorded the album at Skywalker Ranch, a compound in California's Marin County owned by filmmaker George Lucas. She also got a 100-piece orchestra, an authentic gospel choir and the haunting voices of Neville and former Beach Boy Brian Wilson. The ``Cry Like a Rainstorm'' album is a definite departure from her past work, but Ronstadt admits she's never been content to sit still with her career. In 1967, Ronstadt first surfaced with the group The Stone Ponies, a sort of country-pop-folk group that landed their sole hit with ``Different Drum.'' The Stone Ponies were the forerunners of the laidback Southern California sound captured by the Eagles, Jackson Brown and Fleetwood Mac. Ronstadt went solo soon thereafter and scored hits with songs such as ``Heatwave,'' ``You're No Good'' and ``When Will I be Loved.'' She was so well known she sang at the 1977 inauguration of President Jimmy Carter. Then in the early 1980s Ronstadt departed from her pop roots and took on a role in the musical ``The Pirates of Penzance.'' Though it wasn't much of a leap of faith for fans to accept her part in the musical, Ronstadt then took her craft another step beyond and became a 40s-style torch singer and recorded with the Nelson Riddle Orchestra. The songs, the orchestra and the prom-style 40s dresses were unexpected but not rejected. The album gave her maturing voice a new forum and gained new respect from critics who dismissed her in the '70s as just another pretty face. From there she moved into country music with the ``Trio'' album, teaming her with Emmylou Harris and Dolly Parton and featuring 17th-century Appalachian folk songs. She went her own way again and moved into traditional Mexican folk music with the album ``Canciones de mi Padre.'' Ronstadt, who is half German and half Mexican, said the songs she sang in Spanish made her feel grounded. Now, there's work with Neville. ``When Dolly, Emmy and I sang together there was that buzz. We'd all sang with other people before but when we sang together _ the three of us _ we liked it. And we felt, `This is special. We have to do this.' I felt the same way about Aaron.'' Ronstadt says she's not an innovator or trendsetter. She's a singer and that's all she ever wanted to be. ``When I was in first grade I flunked arithmetic. Since then I have developed a great awe and appreciation for mathematics. But in first grade it wasn't happening and I remember looking at my report card and thinking, `It doesn't matter, I'm going to be a singer.'''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Nashville Sound: Clint Black Misses Fishing
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Clint Black has one regret about being the hottest emerging country music star of 1990. ``I don't get to fish much anymore,'' the 28-year-old singer says. There's little time to head for a lake and cast for a big one. For the past year, he's been crisscrossing the country on a whirlwind schedule as the most promising country performer since Randy Travis blossomed in 1986. His debut album, ``Killin' Time,'' sold 1 million copies in nine months. Three cuts from the LP all were No. 1 on the country music popularity charts: ``A Better Man,'' ``Killin' Time'' and ``Nobody's Home.'' ``I'm spoiled rotten,'' he jokes about his quick success. How is he handling it? ``With a bullwhip.'' It's not just Black's voice that has caught the fancy of country fans. It's also his looks. He has a friendly face accented by dimples and a mischievous grin. And with his omnipresent black cowboy hat, many people believe he looks like a young Roy Rogers. He has the familiar background of a dirt-to-diamonds country singer. He was born in Long Branch, N.J., where his father had a temporary job working on a pipe line. He grew up in Houston where he was a frequent sight on the streets riding a skateboard while playing a harmonica. He first performed for guests at his parents' backyard barbecues. He dropped out of high school in Houston and toiled as an ironworker and fishing guide. He sang in nightclubs after sending out fliers to advertise his performances. He finally drew the attention of RCA Records, which signed him to a recording contract. But he hasn't forgotten his hardscrabble days. ``I think about it all the time,'' he said. ``There's always something that takes me back to that. I used to sing five hours a night, sometimes seven. Iron working was hard and dangerous enough to run me off. But it all shaped my life.'' His album, which has been No. 1 on the country charts, is mostly well-crafted country weepers about lost love, with a background of beers and barrooms. The music, much of which he wrote himself, is rooted in the Western swing and honky-tonk style of Texas. The cut ``Killin' Time'' deals with drinking to forget a broken romance. ``A Better Man'' is about recovering from the pain of losing a lover. ``Nobody's Home'' is about the emotional letdown after failing at love. ``The first thing a country music listener latches onto is whether the words mean anything to them,'' Black says. ``You need to be able to say something anybody can relate to. ```Nobody's Home' was written after a seven-year split-up. I had regrets. We got back together and split up again. This inspired `A Better Man.' Other than that, the songs are just somebody else's story. We took their perspective.'' His music and tireless work have paid off rapidly. In October, he won the Horizon Award from the Country Music Association for achievement by a rising performer. In January, he won an American Music Award for favorite new country artist. He's performed at Carnegie Hall in New York City. And he was especially thrilled to sing for a crowd of 56,000 in Houston in February. ``It was etched in my mind for a long time since it was a hometown show and everything,'' he said. His future schedule is packed. He'll tape a Bob Hope TV special in Acapulco, Mexico. He'll be on the road an average of four nights a week doing concerts with the superstar group Alabama. He's working on a second album due out this fall. ``It's satisfying to make it through a crazy week,'' he said. ``The only frustration I have is if I can't perform because my vocal chords are worn out from too much use. ``I've been careful to shape my attitude. I travel with my band, and we hold nothing back. If anyone gets out of line, we answer to each other. We pay attention to what we do and how we act. ``I don't want to be a temperamental artist. The band lets me know if I'm being unreasonable about something. I want to make sure people are proud to be with me 10 years down the road. ``I really have believed in my songs. I feel I know when they are good or just OK. It's pretty scary to think that there's got to come a time when a song won't be number one. It's inevitable.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: The original stars of the London production of Andrew Lloyd Webber's new musical ``Aspects of Love'' will recreate their roles in the Broadway production opening April 8 at the Broadhurst Theater. The two American actresses, Ann Crumb and Kathleen Rowe McAllen, and two British actors, Michael Ball and Kevin Colson, are part of an ongoing exchange between American and British Actors' Equity. Directed by Trevor Nunn, ``Aspects of Love'' originally opened in London's West End on April 17, 1989, where it continues to play to capacity houses. Set in France in the 1950s and based on David Garnett's novel, ``Aspects of Love'' traces the course, over 18 years, of a romance between a young English boy and a penniless French actress, through an affair that involves all those whose lives it touches.

Millions know Mickey Hart as a virtuoso percussionist for the Grateful Dead, one of the world's best-loved and most enduring rock bands. Ten years ago, Hart embarked on a quest to unlock the secrets of the drum's power. His forthcoming book, ``Drumming at the Edge of Magic: A Journey Into the Spirit of Percussion,'' reveals Hart to be not only a player, but an ardent student of his craft. His compelling narrative, written with collaborator Jay Syevens, is a modern drummer's odyssey to understanding the historical and spiritual tradition of his instrument. ``Drumming at the Edge of Magic'' has more than 90 photographs and illustrations.

Award-winning gospel music stars Amy Grant, Take 6 and Michael W. Smith will perform on the 21st Annual Dove Awards show on TNN: The Nashville Network. The 90-minute show, with actor Clifton Davis and Sandi Patti, Grammy-winning gospel artist, as co-hosts, will be telecast on April 5 from the Tennessee Arts Center in Nashville. Take 6, the a cappella sextet who entertain both gospel and jazz audiences, is currently nominated for a Dove Award for ``Group of the Year.''

The Harvard Lampoon will dub Steven Wright as its Comedian of the Year at an April 6 ceremony. Wright joins such entertainers as Bill Cosby, Robin Williams, John Clease, Jay Leno, John Candy and Christopher Guest who all have come to Harvard to receive humor awards from the Lampoon. Wright will be presented with his award in a ceremony following his concert at Harvard's Sanders Theater. The Harvard Lampoon, founded in 1876 by seven undergraduates, is America's oldest humor magazine. It is published five times a year, and is best known for its annual best-selling parodies of national publications.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Release Anytime

DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc. said it expects to report a securities industry record loss of around $900 million for the first quarter because of real estate and junk bond writeoffs and retrenchment costs. The loss for the January through March period, which Shearson said Monday would include a loss of $110 million to $130 million on operations as well as $787 million in one-time charges, would be more than twice as large as the industry's biggest quarterly loss to date. Merrill Lynch & Co. set that mark with a loss of $362 million in the fourth quarter of 1989, mainly because of charges to cover big cutbacks.

The U.S. industrial sector remained weak in March but declined at its slowest rate since June, a possible indication that the overall economy may be poised for a pickup, a survey of purchasing managers says. The National Association of Purchasing Management, which tracks economic trends by polling its members, said Monday its overall index rose to 48.8 percent in March from 48.3 percent the previous month. A reading below 50 indicates the manufacturing economy generally is declining; above 50, that it generally is expanding.

Mild weather helped lift spending on residential, non-residential and government construction projects in February, the government said. The Commerce Department said Monday that construction spending rose 2.6 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $436.5 billion. That followed a revised 2.5 percent jump in January, first reported as a 1.8 percent gain.

An index measuring the typical American family's ability to buy a house increased in February as lower prices and rising income offset higher mortgage rates, a real estate trade group said. The National Association of Realtors said Monday its index rose to 105.1 in February, meaning that a family with a median income of $33,816 had 105.1 percent of the income needed to buy a median-priced existing home costing $95,400.

U.S. and Japanese negotiators, who just a month ago were at loggerheads over a variety of contentious trade issues, report good progress is being made toward resolving many of the disputes. However, U.S. officials insisted Monday that true success will come only if the negotiations achieve a reduction in America's huge $49 billion trade deficit with Japan.

Torchmark Corp. withdrew a $6.4 billion bid for American General Corp., a week after proposing the buyout, choosing instead to work to elect its own nominees to American General's board of directors. The Birmingham, Ala.-based insurance and financial services company said Monday it decided to withdraw the offer for the much larger American General because it never received a response to its proposal.

A division of Farley Inc. formed to acquire West Point-Pepperell Inc. said it had defaulted on a $796 million bank loan and would be unable to pay interest owed to holders of $705 million in junk bonds. The announcement Monday increased doubts about the ability of Chicago industrialist William Farley to complete his $3 billion acquisition of Pepperell, the giant textile maker based in West Point, Ga.

First Executive Corp. said the plummeting value of its junk-bond portfolio had caused an $836 million loss in its final quarter and a $776 million loss for the year. The insurance holding company, whose subsidiaries include Executive Life Insurance Co. of Los Angeles, announced in January that it anticipated an after-tax charge of $515 million to 1989 earnings due to junk bond losses. It said Monday they were so bad it had added another $344 million.

Fleet-Norstar Financial Group said it expects its non-performing loans to increase by at least $200 million in the first quarter, making it the latest bank to be hit by New England's sagging economy. The company said Monday its level of non-performing loans would reach at least $600 million and could go higher as a result of an examination now being conducted by federal regulators. Fleet also said it would sell about half of its credit card portfolio of about $500 million to Norwest Corp. of Minneapolis.

The stock market posted a broad loss in light trading Monday as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 6.76 to 2,700.45. Bond prices finished mixed. The dollar ended mostly higher against other major foreign currencies. Most pork futures prices rose their permitted daily limits; cattle futures advanced; soybean futures fell sharply while grains were mixed; oil futures gained; and precious metals retreated slightly.

DOC.HEAD: Rates Fall on Short-Term Treasury Securities
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in the latest auction to their lowest level in several weeks. The Treasury Department sold $8.0 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.83 percent on Monday, down from 7.85 percent last week. Another $8.0 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.81 percent, down from 7.83 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.72 percent on Feb. 26, and six-month bills averaged 7.79 percent on March 5. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.10 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,802.10 and 8.24 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,605.20. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable-rate mortgages, fell to 8.34 percent last week, down from 8.35 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Expects Loss of $897 Million to $917 Million in 1st-Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc. hopes a record Wall Street loss of around $900 million for the first quarter will put the bad days of overexpansion firmly behind it. The nation's second largest securities firm said the stunning loss would include $787 million in one-time charges, including writeoffs of its real estate and junk bond holdings as well as provisions for the costs of shutting down scores of offices and dismissing 2,000 employees. The red ink also will include a loss of $110 million to $130 million on operations, the company announced late Monday. ``The steps that Shearson Lehman Hutton is announcing today signal the start of a new era for the firm,'' said James D. Robinson III, chairman and chief executive of Shearson's parent, American Express Co. Much of Wall Street is struggling to cut costs because of a slowdown in trading since the 1987 stock market crash and a big decline in securities underwriting and merger activity. But Shearson expanded more rapidly than any firm during the go-go 1980s, making its current retrenchment more painful and more costly than any other firm's. Merrill Lynch & Co., the nation's biggest investment firm, posted the industry's biggest quarterly loss to date only three months ago _ a fourth-quarter 1989 loss of $362 million after charges for major cutbacks. Shearson's staggering charge was bigger than the $450 million to $700 million many analysts forecast last month after Shearson announced plans to close offices, cut jobs and write down its real estate and junk bond portfolios. Shearson said restructuring charges would amount to about $630 million. That includes $200 million for estimated losses at its commercial real estate subsidiary, The Balcor Co.; $230 million for office consolidation and closings worldwide; $115 million to cover losses on the planned sale of $480 million in junk bonds, and $45 million in employee severance costs. The securities firm said it would close 67 domestic branch offices, up from a previously announced target of 50. In addition, Shearson said it would take a $157 million charge for an accounting change relating to software development expenses. The change would bring the way Shearson accounts for such expenses into line with how American Express does it. The total charge would exceed the industry record of $470 million taken by Merrill Lynch in the 1989 fourth quarter. Shearson said its actions would reduce annual costs by ``well in excess of $400 million.'' ``They seem to be clearing the deck and then will go forward from here,'' said Perrin Long, who follows the securities industry for Lipper Analytical Services Corp. The charges and cutbacks will help Shearson focus on its four core businesses of individual investor services, investment banking, capital markets and asset management, said Howard L. Clark Jr., a former American Express executive who was installed as Shearson's chairman earlier this year. Shearson cited a marked slowdown in business activity in January and February for its expected first-quarter operating loss of $110 million to $130 million. Overall, the firm said it expects to post a loss of $897 million to $917 million for the quarter. Shearson lost $15 million in the 1989 first quarter. After Shearson's announcement, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said it had confirmed its senior debt ratings on about $4.8 billion in Shearson debt. ``Both the special provisions as well as the operating loss were consistent with expectations in view of Shearson's problem asset exposures and depressed conditions in the wholesale and retail securities markets,'' Moody's said. It also cited Shearson's ``close relationship'' with American Express. After an initial recapitalization plan to breathe life into Shearson fell through early this year, American Express abandoned plans to reduce its stake in Shearson and decided to take full control of its securities unit to avoid a credit downgrading. Last week, American Express said a previously announced $750 million capital infusion had been made available to Shearson. American Express will have pumped about $1.35 billion into Shearson in recent months once the recapitalization plan is completed. The company also installed Clark as Shearson's chairman and embarked on the cost-cutting program. Shearson has excess capacity because of its 1988 acquisition of E.F. Hutton & Co. and diminished stock trading. Shearson, with about 33,500 employees, is the second largest Wall Street firm behind Merrill Lynch.

DOC.HEAD: Farley Unit Defaults On Pepperell Buyout Loan
DOC.TEXT: After defaulting on a bank loan and saying it couldn't pay interest on its junk bonds, analysts say Farley Inc. may be forced to sell more assets if it ever hopes to complete its buyout of West Point-Pepperell Inc. ``This makes it more difficult,'' said Edward Johnson of Johnson Redbook Service Inc., a New York research firm. ``The rumors are that he might sell off Fruit of the Loom to get his interest out of it,'' Johnson said, referring to William Farley, chairman of the closely held Chicago-based manufacturing conglomerate. A Farley division that was created to acquire Pepperell said Monday it had defaulted on a $796 million bank loan and would be unable to pay interest owed to holders of $705 million in junk bonds. The announcement increased doubts about Farley's ability to complete his $3 billion acquisition of the big Georgia textile maker. Farley officials did not return telephone calls seeking details on the moves outlined in the company's three-paragraph statement. The statement said the Farley unit, West Point Acquisition Corp., had offered to give stock to junk bond holders in exchange for a delay in making interest payments. West Point Acquisition also said it had been negotiating with its lenders, a consortium of banks led by Wells Fargo & Co. and Bankers Trust Co., apparently in hopes of restructuring the $796 million loan they made last year so the Farley unit could buy Pepperell stock. Unless the loan is restructured, analysts said, Farley could be forced into bankruptcy proceedings or be obliged to sell assets, possibly including Fruit of the Loom Inc., the country's biggest underwear manufacturer. West Point Acquisition said the defaults would not affect West Point-Pepperell, which continues to trade as a public company on the New York Stock Exchange even though the Farley unit owns about 95 percent of its stock. Farley, who paid $1.56 billion for its Pepperell stock and assumed $1 billion of the company's debt, still needs about $85 million to complete his $58-a-share acquisition of Pepperell's stock. Until the deal is concluded, he cannot use Pepperell's cash to pay interest on the buyout debt. Pepperell's stock fell $1.25 to $37 a share Monday on the New York Stock Exchange. Fruit of the Loom, traded on the American Stock Exchange, fell 25 cents to $12.87{. About two weeks ago, Farley announced a renegotiated $1.2 billion loan that gave his manufacturing conglomerate more time to complete the Pepperell buyout and eliminated the danger of a cross-default by Pepperell in case of a default by West Point Acquisition. Two days later, Farley announced the sale of most of its Cluett, Peabody & Co. division to the French clothing maker Bidermann S.A. for $350 million and a $60 million note. However, the price was about $200 million less than Farley had sought. Farley has been stymied by the downturn in the takeover business that followed the collapse of the junk bond market last fall. Banks have been extremely cautious about backing acquisitions since the failure of Campeau Corp.'s $6.7 billion buyout of Federated Department Stores Inc., a deal heavily dependent on junk bonds. Federated and Allied Stores Corp., another U.S. retailer bought by Campeau, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization in January. Farley used junk bonds extensively during the 1980s to finance the growth of his holdings, which also include the Acme Boot Co.

DOC.HEAD: Breeden Says Anti-Buyout Laws Could Weaken Shareholder Rights
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission criticized proposed changes in state takeover laws like those being considered in Pennsylvania, saying they seek to ``tilt the balance'' against shareholders. ``Significant efforts are underway at the state level to shield management from shareholder oversight,'' Richard C. Breeden told the Council of Institutional Investors, a group of pension fund managers, on Monday. ``Pennsylvania, Indiana and other states recently have sought to tilt the balance of corporate power in favor of corporate management and against shareholders by insulating decisions by boards of directors from effective review either by the judiciary or shareholders,'' he added. Although most proposed legislation is not in its final form, ``the U.S. Supreme Court has indicated clearly that states do have the ability to legislate in takeover areas,'' said Randall Schumann, a spokesman for the North American Securities Administrators Association, a nationwide organization of state level securities regulators. Supporters of the pending Pennsylvania legislation have hailed it as the nation's toughest anti-takeover sanction, but critics warn it could discourage long-term investment because corporate officers would be less accountable for their actions. Breeden said federal regulators were concerned about state legislation that would ``insulate managers and boards from shareholders'' and thus, possibly cause institutional investors to shift much-needed capital from securities like stocks to those based on debt _ like junk bonds. That would make it tougher for U.S. businesses to raise large sums of money for long-range goals like plant expansion, research and development. ``Who wants to be a long-term captive investor?'' Breeden asked rhetorically. The legislation, passed by the Pennsylvania Senate and awaiting action in the House, would make it more difficult for corporate raiders to take over a Pennsylvania company or extract ``greenmail'' _ above-market prices paid by management to buy back the company's stock from would-be raiders. The bill also would give corporate boards far more discretion than they have now to consider interests other than those of the shareholders in making decisions about takeover bids. Breeden said shareholder input in running a company is guaranteed under federal law and ``while we respect'' states' rights in matters of corporate governance, ``we will not hesitate to seek to enforce federal interests.'' Breed also said the SEC was reviewing the shareholder voting and proxy process, especially changes recommended by the California Public Employees Retirement System and a shareholders' rights group, the United Shareholders Association. A proxy is a shareholder's absentee ballot for a company's annual meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Bonds Cause $836 Million Quarterly Loss at Big Insurance Company
DOC.TEXT: First Executive Corp. said the plunging value of its junk bond holdings caused it to post an $836 million loss in the fourth quarter and a $776 million loss for 1989. The insurance holding company, whose subsidiaries include Executive Life Insurance Co. of Los Angeles, announced in January that it anticipated an after tax charge of $515 million to 1989 earnings due to junk bond losses. It said Monday the losses were so bad it had added another $344 million to the charge. The huge writeoffs caused revenue to plunge 44 percent for the year and left third-quarter revenue more than a half-billion dollars in the red. Los Angeles-based First Executive became the second Southern California institution in as many days to be buried beneath an avalanche of losses from junk bonds, which pay high rates because they fund risky ventures. On Sunday, Columbia Savings & Loan Association reported losses of $575 million in a five-month period due to junk bonds. The losses rendered Columbia insolvent and in danger of seizure by federal regulators. Both First Executive and Columbia were closely allied with Michael Milken, the financier who pioneered the use of junk bonds in the 1980s while working for the Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. brokerage. First Executive invested about $6.5 billion in junk bonds. It said that as of Dec. 31, when its fourth quarter and fiscal year ended, the value of that portfolio had declined about $1.4 billion below face value. For the fourth quarter, First Executive's $836 million loss, the equivalent of $9.98 a share, compared to a profit of $48 million, or 42 cents a share, in 1988. Revenue plunged far into red ink: from $552 million in 1988 to a negative $541 million in 1989. For the year, First Executive's $776 million loss was the equivalent of $9.67 a share and came on revenue of $1.19 billion. That compared with a profit of $175 million, $1.51 per share, on revenue of $2.14 billion in 1988. First Executive said its assets at the end of the year were about $19.2 billion and shareholders' equity more than $1 billion. Life insurance in force was about $59.7 billion compared with $57.3 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: Southland Reports $1.01 Billion Loss Because Of Goodwill Writedown
DOC.TEXT: 7-Eleven owner Southland Corp. lost $1 billion in the fourth quarter of 1989 after a huge takeover-related writeoff, and the company said earnings this year wouldn't meet targets set in its bank financing agreements. The convenience store company said Monday it would have to restructure its debt or file for bankruptcy protection. Dallas-based Southland said a $947 million writeoff wiped its books clean of goodwill, or the difference between what the convenience store company was worth and the $4.9 billion the founding Thompson family paid in 1987 to take the company private. ``The market values that we established in 1987 are not the same as they (are) two years later,'' said spokeswoman Markeeta McNatt. ``It's not necessarily that we paid too much, but the events since then have impaired the value of those assets.'' Terms of the buyout was announced prior to the Oct. 19, 1987 stock market crash, but the deal was not financed until after the crash. Southland has been struggling to meet the payments on the LBO debt. Last month it announced a recapitalization plan involving the sale of $400 million of Southland stock to Ito-Yokado Ltd., which operates 7-Eleven stores in Japan. The sale would give Ito-Yokado 75 percent of the common stock, and leave about 15 percent in Thompson hands. The deal is contingent on bondholders approving the restructuring of some $1.8 billion in debt and preferred stock. Most analysts have suggested bondholders, who would forego about $1.4 billion, will not agree to the deal. Complete details have yet to be filed with the federal Securities and Exchange Commission, and Ms. McNatt said negotiations with bondholders can't begin until those details are available. Jay Lustig, an analyst at Drake Capital Corp. in Santa Monica, Calif., said bondholders will not accept the restructuring, especially if the Thompsons continue to run the company. ``Bondholders no longer want the Thompsons running the company,'' he said. ``It's not their company. There is no positive net worth. This now means the creditors own the company.'' Lustig said bondholders would prefer Southland to declare bankruptcy rather than continue under Thompson leadership. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, Southland said it lost $1.01 billion, or $4.92 a share, on revenues of $2.1 billion. That compares with a loss of $37 million, or 22 cents a share, on revenues of $1.97 billion in the same three months of 1988. For all of 1989, the company lost $1.31 billion, or $6.48 a share, on $8.35 billion in revenue, compared with a 1988 loss of $216.2 million, or $1.22 a share, on $7.99 billion in sales. Southland operates about 6,900 7-Eleven stores in addition to five distribution centers that service more than 5,900 stores in the United States and 21 foreign countries.

DOC.HEAD: Bids Entered for Bonwit Teller Stores
DOC.TEXT: Several regional retailers, a French department store and real estate tycoon Donald Trump have made offers for Bonwit Teller department stores, but efforts by a former executive of the bankrupt chain to make a bid collapsed. A group that included former chief executive William Ruben and Remington Products Inc. president Victor Kiam said it was prepared to offer $36 million for 13 of Bonwit's 16 stores if given two more days to secure financing. That would have been the biggest bid of any entered at a bankruptcy court hearing Monday. Bonwit's creditors refused to grant the two-day extension, though, saying a delay could threaten the other firm bids. A consortium including Trump bid $21.75 million for five Bonwit Teller department stores, including the chain's flagship outlet in Manhattan's glitzy Trump Tower. The other stores covered by the bid included Bonwit Teller properties in Boston, Buffalo and Manhasset, N.Y., and Short Hills, N.J. The group would forgive $269,000 in financial obligations on the stores in Trump Tower and Short Hills and match whatever the final bid is for liquidating the inventory at the Boston and Buffalo stores. The Bonwit Teller name would be retained. The terms of the proposal are similar to ones in a plan presented earlier by Pyramid Cos., a Syracuse, N.Y.-based shopping mall developer and owner. Pyramid, operating as Bontel Corp., is part of the consortium but also left its own bid intact. The earlier Pyramid plan, submitted to Bonwit Teller's parent company L.J. Hooker Corp. on March 9, called for buying the same five stores for $16.5 million plus the assumption of some liabilities. Besides Bontel and Trump Equitable Fifth Ave. Corp., which is part of the Trump Organization, the consortium includes Prutaub, a joint venture that operates the Short Hills Mall, and Pilevsky Group, headed by Philip Pilevsky a New York real estate owner. Members of the consortium also presented bids for individual stores and other potential buyers submitted plans at the hearing. Atlanta-based L.J. Hooker has been under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors since August, after its Australian parent company, Hooker Corp., entered ``provisional liquidation,'' an Australian legal proceeding similar to bankruptcy. Since then, L.J. Hooker has sold holdings and late last year liquidated the B. Altman & Co. department store chain. The hearing before Judge Tina Brozman was held to consider possible alternatives to the Pyramid offer. Bidders were obliged to put up 10 percent of their offers. Lawyers for Hooker said the company will decide which bid _ or bids _ are acceptable and make a recommendation on Wednesday to the judge, who must approve any deal. Among offers entered at Monday's hearing was one from R.H. Acquisition Corp. on behalf of Ralph Hibbard, a Canadian investor with past retailing experience. Hibbard offered more than $7 million cash for stores in Bal Harbour and Palm Beach, Fla., Troy, Mich., Philadelphia and Jenkintown, Pa. Frances Brewster Inc., an upscale Florida men's and women's apparel retailer, offered to pay $2.2 million for the lease on the Palm Beach Bonwit Teller plus the liquidation value of the store's inventory. The company, which operates a shop on tony Worth Avenue virtually across the street from the Bonwit Teller, would not retain the Bonwit Teller name. A French retailer, Galeries Lafayette, offered to buy only the Trump Tower store for $4 million. The sum essentially would be for the inventory. The retailer would keep the Bonwit Teller name for 135 days and then change it over to its own for the autumn season. McCurdy & Co., a Rochester, N.Y.-based operator of apparel retailers in upstate New York, offered $1.5 million for the lease, equipment and furnishings of the Buffalo store. It also would pay 60 percent of the wholesale cost of the retail inventory for a maximum bid of $3 million. The Limited Inc., a Columbus, Ohio-based specialty apparel retailer, offered to buy the leases on the Boston and Buffalo stores for $4 million evenly divided between the two. There was a separate $1.75 million bid for the lease on the Troy store from Somerset Mall Ltd. partnership, which operates the site of the store. A lawyer for the mall said it was unclear whether the Bonwit name would be retained. Consortium members bid individually in case their joint offer was rejected. Trump Equitable bid $5 million for the lease on the Trump Tower store, Bontel bid $5.5 million for leases on the Boston and Buffalo stores plus the inventory at liquidation prices and the rights to the name. Pilevsky bid $5.5 million just for the Manhasset property. Hooker also received two bids to liquidate the Bonwit Teller chain valuing the inventory at about 50 cents on the dollar.

DOC.HEAD: Builder Refinances 150 Properties In $456 Million Deal
DOC.TEXT: Trammell Crow Co., the nation's largest commercial and residential builder, has refinanced more than 150 properties using $456 million pumped into the company by a large institutional investor. The injection by an arm of Equitable Life Assurance Society was regarded as a positive move for the company and for the troubled real estate market in the Southwest, where most of the properties are located, analysts said. ``Our attorneys tell us that this is one of the largest real estate transactions ever done in terms of the number of properties involved,'' said Robert Whitman, Trammell Crow's chief financial officer. ``It is probably the single largest capital commitment made in the Southwest recently.'' The investment by Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Inc. comes against a backdrop of rumors of financial trouble for Dallas-based Trammell Crow. ``I hope this transaction will have a very positive effect on the Trammell Crow Co. and give the naysayers a new perspective,'' said Douglas Tibbets, president of Equitable Real Estate. ``I think the whole business is in extremely fragile condition right now,'' said Richard Kateley, chief economist at Real Estate Research Corp. in Chicago. ``And not just in Texas, but the whole marketplace could react negatively to any bad news from a major player like Trammell Crow. ``If this transaction had not closed, it would have been a real depressing signal,'' he said. The refinancing includes both performing and non-performing properties centered in Texas, Arizona and Colorado. About 70 percent are industrial buildings, the warehouses and distribution buildings on which Trammel Crow founded its business more than 40 years ago. ``The majority of it is just good old solid property,'' said Charles Klepfer, Equitable's regional senior vice president. ``These under-performing properties are some of our best projects,'' said Whitman. ``It's just that they were built at a time when the Southwest was depressed and the rental rates were down.'' ``We thought that if we could address such a significant portion (of the company's problem properties) in one transaction, we could get it all behind it,'' Whitman said. ``We wanted to remove the sword of Damocles from hanging over us.''

DOC.HEAD: Conoco Offers $23 Million to Settle Contamination Lawsuit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Conoco Inc., in one of the biggest settlements of its kind, has agreed to pay $23 million to buy 400 homes and compensate families who say its refinery is giving them cancer and other illnesses. Under the settlement announced Monday with families who had sued the company for allegedly contaminating the air and water, Conoco would buy the properties for about $18 million and establish a $5 million compensation fund. Homeowner Mike Gallagher said his family was ready to move. ``The sooner, the better. Now we can go to the other side of town. No more nosebleeds. No more headaches. We can live with good-smelling air,'' he said. Under the settlement, Conoco, a subsidiary of the Du Pont Co., admits no liability. ``I would put that as one of the largest relocation settlements in the country,'' Conoco attorney Mark Zehler said. Two comparable cases involved government money: the evacuation of homes built atop tons of chemical waste at Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y., and the virtual abandonment in 1982 of Times Beach, Mo., which was tainted by dioxin. The Love Canal buyout, in 1978, involved about $19 million to purchase 232 homes. In Times Beach, about $33 million was spent to buy 393 properties. Homeowners in the Circle Drive area of Ponca City had complained since 1987 that groundwater laced with hydrocarbons, including cancer-causing banzene, seeped into their basements and threatened their health. Some residents camped out at the state Capitol for weeks in 1988 to get the state to buy their houses. The protesters said heavy rain two years earlier had unleashed toxic, reddish-orange sludge that bubbled up from cracks in sidewalks, and black slime that oozed into their basements. Conoco said then the sludge was the result of iron ore, and the state Health Department and federal Environmental Protection Agency agreed there was no health hazard. But residents said they had suffered an inordinate rate of cancer deaths and other ailments. Gallagher said his wife miscarried twice. Another baby was born three months premature and weighed 2 pounds, 2 ounces. He lived a week, Gallagher said. ``People ask why we didn't leave,'' he said. ``We couldn't afford it.'' Refinery manager Dennis Parker said Conoco settled ``because it is the right thing to do _ for these residents, for Ponca City and for Conoco.'' ``The situation has caused dissension in our community for too long _ it's time to put it behind us,'' he said. Anna Sue Rafferty, who spoke on behalf of the plaintiffs, declined to fix blame. ``To Conoco and Du Pont we say `thank you' in coming forth with this settlement,'' Ms. Rafferty said. ``I'd just like to say none of us is happy to be leaving our home. No one intended to get rich.'' A hearing on the settlement is set for June 5 in federal court in Oklahoma City. If approved, the settlement of the lawsuit filed in March 1989 would enable many owners and renters of property to move. Residents of a larger area of the neighborhood could receive payments because of their proximity to the groundwater problems and the work needed to fix them. Conoco would pay residents the appraised value of their homes, an above market-value premium, a moving and household disruption bonus and other sums. ``I'm happy,'' Mae Morgan said while standing next to her former house, which she abandoned a year ago when she could no longer stand the fumes. ``No one will ever live in the Circle Drive area again.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined against other key currencies except the British pound in European trading today. Gold was up. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 158.95 yen, down 1.00 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar traded at 158.65 yen. Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. in Tokyo , said market players avoided major moves before the meeting among finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations scheduled for April 7, and the conclusion of the U.S.-Japan trade talks in Washington. Kanai said the dollar was likely to rise because market demand for the currency remained strong. He said there was little incentive to buy the yen. Other dollar rates at mid-morning, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.7024 West German marks, down from 1.7052; 1.5024 Swiss francs, down from 1.5068; 5.7175 French francs, down from 5.7300; 1.9145 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9193; 1,250.25 Italian lire, down from 1,254.25; and 1.1667 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1690. The British pound was quoted at $1.6295, compared with $1.6300 late Monday. London's major gold dealers fixed a recommended price of $374.80 per troy ounce this morning, up from $368.95 per ounce late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $374.25, up from $368.75 late Monday. In Hong Kong, gold rose 78 cents to close at $371.94 per troy ounce today. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $4.99 a troy ounce from Monday's $4.96.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Rise on Tokyo Exchange; Dollar Drops
DOC.TEXT: Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rose sharply today in nervous, roller-coaster trading, and the dollar dropped against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained a hefty 757.65 points, or 2.7 percent, ending the day at 28,757.65. In morning trading, the index first rose more than 500 points, then fell below the 28,000-point line. The index rose again in the afternoon as participants decided the market had bottomed out in the morning, said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. He said market players expect the index will stay above the 27,200-point level, 30 percent below where it stood at the end of last year. Inoue said another encouraging sign was the stability of government bond prices, which remained relatively steady despite Monday's heavy losses in the stock market. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 158.95 yen, down 1.00 yen from Monday's close of 159.95 yen. The U.S. currency opened at 159.10 yen and ranged between 158.80 yen and 159.35 yen. On Monday, as the dollar surged to a three-year high against the Japanese yen, the Nikkei index plunged 1,978.38 points, or 6.59 percent, to close at 28,002.07, in its second-largest single-day decline ever. The plunge followed a 1,045.71-point, or 3.37 percent, fall in the index last Friday. Analysts said both currency and stock markets were shaken Monday by a report in a leading Japanese financial newspaper that major life insurers planned to shift funds out of the stock market. Volume on the market's first section today was estimated at 650 million shares, up from 450 million shares on Monday. The price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds closed at 86.44 points, up from Monday's close at 86.02. Their yield fell to 7.260 percent from the previous day's 7.350 percent. But Inoue said uncertainty remained in the market. ``The index has only entered a range that everybody predicted would be the market's bottom, but there may be further shake-ups,'' Inoue said. Other traders said it would take time for the market to regain its energy and make a stable recovery. ``As long as the government differentiates between interest rates and the foreign exchange rate and takes two different approaches, both markets will stabilize, and will help the stock market recover,'' Inoue said. He said it would not be wise to raise interest rates in order to support the yen. On March 25, the Bank of Japan raised its official discount rate by 1 percentage point to 5.25 percent in a move widely seen as an attempt to bolster the value of the dropping yen. Dealers said the Finance Ministry on Monday bought about 1 trillion yen ($6.3 billion) in government bonds to support their price and prevent yields from rising excessively. Meanwhile, Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno said today the decline in Japanese stock prices since the beginning of this year has been excessive. The Nikkei index has lost more than 10,000 points, or 26 percent, so far this year. Traders said currency market participants focused on the stock market performance in the absence of other market-affecting news. Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co., said: ``The yen fell in the morning session as stock prices fell, but the afternoon rebound in share prices did not boost yen-buying incentives.'' Kanai said market players avoided major moves before the meeting among finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations scheduled for April 7, and the conclusion of on-going U.S.-Japan trade talks in Washington. But Kanai said the dollar was likely to continue to rise because market demand for the U.S. currency remained strong, and there was little incentive to buy the yen. He said that after the trade talks and the G-7 meeting,``the dollar will jump over the 160-yen level and rise further.'' Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said today he was concerned by recent exchange rate movements, and hoped stability would return to the market soon.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic steel production totaled 1,904,000 net tons during the week ending March 31, 1990, down 1.7 percent from the previous week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The week's production represented 85 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said Monday. American steelmakers produced 2,040,000 net tons in the same week last year, AISI said. Domestic steel production so far this year is 24,542,000 net tons, 4.1 percent below last year's production at this time, AISI said. Production by district for last week, (previous week in parentheses): North East Coast 189,000 tons (174,000 tons); Pittsburgh-Youngstown 310,000 tons (312,000 tons); Lake Erie 166,000 tons (161,000 tons); Detroit 164,000 tons (163,000 tons); Indiana-Chicago 465,000 tons (518,000 tons); Southern 298,000 tons (289,000 tons); Western 111,000 tons (112,000 tons).

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Advance Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were slightly higher Tuesday after an early rally ran out of steam. Some traders said the market might go up later in the day, particularly if the Dow Jones industrial average opens strongly in New York. ``Everyone is waiting to see what happens in New York again,'' said one trader. He said investors in the British market were apathetic after the initial opening rally. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 3 points, or 0.1 percent, at 2,224.6. The index recovered from a morning low of 2,218.0. Its high was 2,232.4. Volume was a moderate 319 million shares, compared with 308.1 million at the same time Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Indicators Drop 1 Percent in February
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The government's chief economic forecasting gauge fell 1.0 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today, but analysts said it would have changed little except for a drop in building permits. The Index of Leading Economic Indicators, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, had risen the previous three months. But because of the unusual circumstances surrounding the index's building permit component, many analysts expressed skepticism in advance of the February report. The analysts said today's index would be lowered by the February drop from the unusually large number of permits builders sought in January to take advantage of record warm weather and to beat a deadline for meeting expensive new building standards. The standards, required by 1989 fair housing legislation, are designed to make apartment buildings more accessible to the handicapped. The National Association of Home Builders said the standards would add between $3,600 and $7,200 to the cost of an apartment. According to a survey of 51 top economists published in Blue Chip Economic Indicators, the gross national product _ the nation's output of goods and services _ will grow 1.7 percent in 1990. But the survey by Eggert Economic Enterprises of Sedona, Ariz., says the economic outlook ``remains the most sluggish since the recession year of 1982.'' Seven of the 11 forward-looking statistics contributed to the decline, led by the steep fall in building permits in February after a sharp jump in the previous month _ the warmest January on record. Other negatives included faster business delivery times, lower stock prices, a decline in plant and equipment orders, a decrease in the price of raw materials, a decline in the backlog of manufacturers' unfilled orders and a drop in an index measuring consumer confidence. Three of the components were positive, including an increase in orders for consumer goods, a gain in the money supply and a drop in weekly unemploylment claims. One indicator, the length of the average workweek, was unchanged. The various changes left the index at 144.0 percent of its 1982 base of 100. The index fell 0.6 percent from September through February after declining 0.5 percent the previous six months. The January index was revised from unchanged to a 0.2 percent gain because of an increase in new orders for consumer goods. The December index was revised down from 0.6 percent to 0.4 percent because of a shorter workweek. The November index had risen 0.1 percent. The analysts said because so many building permits were issued in January, there were fewer issued in February, causing the number to decline a sharp 25 percent. Economist Michael P. Niemira of Mitsubishi Bank in New York said that drove the overall index down. If that one-time aberration were not included, the index might have exceeded its January level, Niemira said. Michael K. Evans, head of a forecasting organization here, wrote in the Evans Report shortly before the index was released that ``except for that one anomaly, the index (would) be up slightly.'' ``Excluding the housing permits component, the index is expected to stand unchanged, signifying continuation of restrained economic growth,'' Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist for Fuji Securities Inc. of Chicago, wrote in his organization's weekly Perspectives last week. David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, characterized the economy so far this year as ``a quarter of recovery.'' ``We recovered from the very cold December,'' Berson explained. ``We recovered from the Boeing strike, we recovered from the (San Francisco Bay area) earthquake and the hurricane (Hugo) _ all of which helped depress the fourth quarter.''

DOC.HEAD: Pork Prices on the Rise
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to make clear potential increase would be seasonal
DOC.TEXT: Pork ribs for backyard barbecues are costing more this spring, along with just about everything else that's part of a hog. The Agriculture Department says hog farmers may increase production seasonally later this year, but that won't do much to cool off prices before this fall. Kevin Bost of the department's Economic Research Service said last Friday's report showing further declines in the U.S. inventory of hogs and pigs ``confirmed our expectations for reduced supplies this spring and summer.'' As a result, he said, ``we should be looking at higher wholesale pork prices and higher retail prices'' in the next few months. The department's all-cut pork price _ a weighted blend of prices paid by consumers at retail stores _ rose to $1.97 per pound in February, Bost said Monday in a telephone interview. That matched the all-time high set in the late summer of 1987. Bost said wholesale pork prices have continued to edge higher, meaning that ``I wouldn't be surprised to see a new record high retail price in March'' when the Labor Department releases those consumer figures on April 17. In another report last Friday, the USDA showed the March hog-corn feed price ratio at a relatively high 22.2 bushels, up from 20.8 in February and 15.1 in March 1989. Those numbers represent the bushels of corn equal in value to 100 pounds of live hog shipped to market. Other factors are also important in the hog business, but feed costs are a major item for producers thinking about expanding or cutting back their operations. Roughly, the higher the number in the hog-corn ratio, the greater the opportunity for profit. ``In general, returns to hog producers have been pretty favorable since the middle part of last year,'' Bost said. ``If (prices) go on good enough, for long enough, eventually they expand.'' One question is the corn crop and whether livestock producers have ample feed supplies at reasonable prices. Bost said recent moisture conditions ``sure doesn't hurt those prospects'' for the 1990 harvest. Based on the situation as it looks now, pork production probably will begin to pick up at least seasonally this fall. ``We're probably looking at larger pork supplies in 1991,'' Bost said. Meanwhile, Bost and his USDA colleagues say consumers may see some easing of beef prices this summer, according to the April issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. But it won't be dramatic. ``Improved prospects for spring grazing in some areas probably will increase retention of females for (cattle) herd expansion and lower slaughter of beef cows and heifers,'' the report said. As that happens, there will be less ``non-fed'' beef for consumers, which affects hamburger prices. Prices of Choice-grade fed steers moving to slaughter ``will continue to decline as market-ready supplies increase into early summer,'' the report said. ``In some markets, prices may fall below $70 per hundredweight, perhaps not reaching the mid-$70s again until fall.'' At retail, Choice-grade beef rose to a record level in January of $2.813 per pound, on an all-cut basis and edged still higher to $2.815 in February, the report said. Broiler prices have been supported by the strength in beef and pork, with retail prices in the first quarter averaging about the same as a year ago despite a production increase of about 8 percent from year-earlier levels. Further increases are expected. In March, the estimated 12-city wholesale broiler price was about 61 cents per pound, up from 57.37 cents in February and 51.7 cents in January. In March 1989, the 12-city average was 62.1 cents. ``The wholesale broiler prices in 1990 may average 51-57 cents per pound, compared with 59 for last year,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Stempel Came Up Through Product Side
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Open to Opel in 10th graf; picks up 11th graf, GM's European ...
DOC.HEAD: With PM-GM-Smith
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. President Robert C. Stempel, who today was named to succeed Roger B. Smith as GM chairman, rose through the company's product ranks, a path decidedly different from that of his predecessor. Stempel will take over operation of the world's largest corporation Aug. 1, the day after Smith retires as GM's 10th chairman and less than three weeks after Stempel turns 57. Stempel, a big man who peers directly at whomever he's talking to, has been the company's president and chief operating officer since Sept. 1, 1987. During months of speculation about Smith's successor, Stempel was given the inside track. But that wasn't because his background mirrored Smith's. In auto industry parlance, Stempel is a ``product guy'' and Smith is a ``bean counter.'' Stempel received a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering from Worcester Polytechnic Institute in Massachusetts in 1955 and a master's degree in business administration from Michigan State University in 1970. Smith, GM's chairman since Jan. 1, 1981, received bachelor's and master's degrees in business administration from the University of Michigan. He joined GM as a senior accounting clerk in Detroit. Stempel joined GM as a senior detailer in the chassis design department of the company's Oldsmobile Division in 1958, the same year Smith became director of the general accounting section in the Detroit central office. Each man climbed through the ranks in the 1960s, with Stempel concentrating in powertrain design and Smith focusing on corporate finances. In 1972, Stempel was named assistant chief engineer at Oldsmobile and Smith was named vice president and group executive in charge of the Nonautomotive and Defense Group. Stempel joined the legion of nearly four dozen GM vice presidents when he became general manager of the company's Pontiac Division in 1978, two years before going to Europe to head the automaker's Adam Opel AG carmaking operation in West Germany. GM's European operations have produced profits that helped the giant automaker last year regain the top profit spot it lost to Ford Motor Co. in 1986. During the speculation about Smith's successor, auto analysts said among the best things GM's board could do to slow or reverse the company's slide in U.S. market share is elect someone who could apply the lessons learned in Europe to the company's worldwide operations. In 1982, Stempel returned to the United States to head the Chevrolet Division, the company's largest carmaking operation. Two years later, he was named executive in charge of the Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac Group. In February 1986, Stempel joined Smith on GM's board of directors as executive vice president in charge of the worldwide Truck & Bus Group and the Overseas Group. Nineteen months later, he became GM's 17th president.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 435.41 up 2.23 from the previous day's close.

Stock prices rose in early trading today after the Tokyo market rebounded following Monday's severe selloff there. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 11.04 to 2,711.49 in the first hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by nearly 2 to 1 in the early tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 744 up, 425 down and 554 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 45.83 million shares as of 11 a.m. on Wall Street. In Japan, prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange jumped sharply in nervous, roller-coaster trading. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 757.65 points, or 2.7 percent, ending the day's session at 28,757.65. The index rose more than 500 points in early trading, then fell below the 28,000-point line. The index rose again in the afternoon as participants decided the market had bottomed out in the morning, said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. in Tokyo. On Monday, Tokyo stock prices plummeted 6.6 percent in their second-worst fall this year. DOC.HEAD: Japan, U.S. Joint Venture To Sell Beef in Vending Machines
DOC.TEXT: A joint venture between Japanese and U.S. meat dealers will begin selling beef imported from the United States in freezer-equipped vending machines, an official representing the Japanese company said Tuesday. ``Our aim is to supply imported beef at a cheaper price to consumers by reducing the costs of distribution-related personnel required otherwise,'' said Naoki Sakai, spokesman of Jackson Co., a Japanese meat dealer based in Japan's western port city of Kobe. Sakai said it will be first time in Japan that beef is sold in vending machines. Jackson Co., which has specialized in U.S. meat since 1978, and Hamilton Meat Co., a meat packer based in San Diego, Calif., set up the joint venture in Kobe last month, Sakai said. The new firm's move followed Japan's liberalization of imports of seasoned beef into Japan on Sunday, the first day of the country's new fiscal year, he said. Under a 1988 bilateral agreement between Japan and the United States, Japan has been gradually liberalizing beef imports. Under the venture, seasoned beef for steak and sukiyaki will be processed in the United States before being imported in frozen vacuum packages for sale in vending machines in Japan, Sakai said. Vending machines will be set up at 1,000 locations, mainly near railway stations and convenience stores, Sakai said, adding that the number of beef-selling machines will be increased to a yet unspecified figure in the future. Sakai said the new joint company plans to sell a pack containing 17.5 ounces of beef for sukiyaki at about 1,800 yen, or $11.30, about half the retail price of similar but locally produced beef. ``We can sell at that price by introducting vending machines in place of the more costly workforce,'' Sakai said. Each vending machine will be connected to a computer at the venture's head office which will monitor the temperature and manage inventories within each freezer, he said. The company will install the vending machines starting next week, and it is anticipating 3 billion yen, or $18.8 million, in sales in its first year of operation, he said. Japan imported 128,000 tons of beef from the United States in the first 10 months up to January of fiscal 1989, which accounted for 41 percent of Japan's total beef imports in that period, according to Japanese government figures. Hamilton Meat Co. is a subsidiary of Omaha, Nebraska-based Beef America, a U.S. meat packer.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Gain In Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade with soybeans rebounding weakly after a steep decline in the previous session. Soybean futures fell as much as 11\ cents a bushel Monday in reaction to an Agriculture Department report that indicated U.S. farmers intend to plant more soybeans and less corn than the market had expected. Analysts said today's early rally reflected perceptions that Monday's losses were overdone. Buying interest was limited, though, by reports that the South American soybean harvest is rapidly advancing and by improved soil moisture in the Midwest, where corn and soybean planting gets underway this month. ``In the next 10 days they'll start cranking up,'' said Victor Lespinasse, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. Corn futures drew support from signs of increased export activity while wheat futures gained on forecasts for cold weather in winter wheat country. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent to 2} cents higher with May at $3.58{ a bushel; corn was { cent to 1\ cents higher with May at $2.64 a bushel; oats were { cent to } cent higher with May at $1.52 a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 2{ cents higher with May at $5.87 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange following sharp gains Monday in the hog and pork-belly markets. Live cattle futures were .08 cent to .17 cent higher with April at 78.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .23 cent higher with April at 82.85 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .40 cent higher with April at 54.50 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .60 cent to .75 cent higher with May at 56.17 cents a pound. All livestock and meat futures advanced on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Stempel Named to Succeed Smith
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after the 8th graf with Smith comments; picks up 9th graf, Most speculation ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. president and chief operating officer Robert C. Stempel, who rose through the production ranks of the world's largest automaker, was named today to succeed the retiring Roger B. Smith as chairman. Smith, who officially steps down July 31 at age 65, announced Stempel's selection at a news conference at GM headquarters. Lloyd E. Reuss, a GM executive vice president, will succeed Stempel as president, Smith said. The position of chief operating officer, also held by Stempel, was being eliminated. Stempel told reporters at the news conference his first priority is increasing GM sales. ``One of our major ones (challenges) ... is to increase our North American market share profitably,'' Stempel said. ``There is no higher priority in General Motors than increasing our market share profitably.'' GM's share of the North American car and truck market has dropped to 34.6 percent last year from 44.1 percent in 1980. GM's board of directors met Monday at the company's sprawling car- and truck-making complex in Oshawa, Ontario. A team of outside directors has been serving as a search committee for the chairman of the company that last year made $4.22 billion on revenue of $126.9 billion. Smith, who said he would remain on GM's board, praised Stempel for his domestic and international experience. ``I'm leaving General Motors on August 1 convinced we've got probably the greatest team we've ever had, because we've got some of the greatest challenges we've ever had,'' the outgoing chairman said. Most speculation in recent months has centered on the 56-year-old Stempel, although the names of two GM executive vice presidents, F. Alan Smith and John F. Smith Jr., also have been mentioned as candidates for chairman. Both Smiths, no relation to Roger Smith, had financial backgrounds. Stempel began his GM career as a senior detailer in the chassis design department of the company's Oldsmobile Division in 1958. He became general manager of the company's Pontiac Division in 1978, and two years later went to Europe to head GM's Adam Opel AG carmaking operation in West Germany. In 1982, Stempel returned to the United States to head the Chevrolet Division and in 1984 was named executive in charge of the Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac Group. In February 1986, Stempel joined GM's board of directors as executive vice president in charge of the worldwide Truck & Bus Group and the Overseas Group. The following year, he became GM's president. Reuss, 53, has been executive vice president in charge of North American Passenger Car Groups and a board member since February 1986. He was given the additional responsibility of GM's truck and bus grup in 1987. He started as a GM engineer in 1959. GM is the second of the Big Three U.S. automakers to revamp its top management for the 1990s. On March 1 Harold Poling became Ford Motor Co.'s chairman, succeeding Donald Petersen. Poling will hold the top job at Ford for three years before he is expected to give way to Allan Gilmour, executive vice president. Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca's contract with the nation's No. 3 automaker expires late next year. GM has been wrestling with excess plant capacity as the U.S. auto market softens. The huge automaker is expected to shutter its Lakewood car assembly plant in Atlanta this summer and half of its Lordstown, Ohio, plant next year. Since 1987, GM has shut down assembly plants in Framingham, Mass.; Kansas City, Mo.; and Pontiac, Mich. Balancing plant capacity with a shrinking car and truck market is one of the big challenges facing the new GM chairman. Others include managing the launch and growth of GM's Saturn Corp., which plans to begin making a small, import-fighting car this summer in Spring Hill, Tenn., and contract negotiations with the United Auto Workers union, which has tapped job security as its top bargaining priority. The Saturn project, originally proposed in 1983 as a $5-billion program to build 500,000 subcompacts a year, has been cut nearly in half. Yet with its unique labor agreement and manufacturing techniques, it is viewed as a laboratory of things to come at GM and a key step in the automaker's attempt to arrest a decline in its market share. Smith repeatedly has vowed to drive the first production car off the assembly line, now scheduled for about a month before his retirement. But overshadowing all the new product projects are GM's labor relations with the UAW. Since the last three-year contract was signed in 1987, thousands of GM's union workers have lost jobs and watched factories fall idle. There is speculation the UAW will select GM as its target company after talks start this July, meaning the union will focus its negotiating attention on that automaker. The UAW's contracts with GM, Ford and Chrysler expire Sept. 14.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Auto Sales Reach Record 5.8 Million in Fiscal 1989
DOC.TEXT: Sales of passenger cars, trucks and buses in Japan rose by 17.4 percent in fiscal 1989 to a record 5.8 million, the Japan Automobile Dealers' Association said Tuesday. It was the first time that annual sales have surpassed 5 million, and the third year in a row that new sales records have been set. An association official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, attributed the sales increase to the expansion of Japan's domestic economy, strong personal consumption spending and the introduction of new models. Sales also were boosted by the removal of higher commodity taxes on cars last April when a general 3 percent consumption tax went into effect, the official said. He said sales of passenger cars rose 22.4 percent to 4.3 million, trucks rose 5.9 percent to 1.5 million, and buses fell 7.8 percent to 22,792, all compared with fiscal 1988. Japan's fiscal year ends March 31. Sales of imported cars rose by 42.5 percent from a year earlier to 203,010, the official said. He said Toyota Motor Corp. topped the list of auto sales, with 2.4 million passenger cars, trucks and buses, up 16.2 percent from fiscal 1988. Nissan Motor Co., was second with 1.4 million vehicles, up 18.1 percent, followed by Mazda Motor Corp. with 486,636, up 29.9 percent, and Honda Motor Co., with 463,526, up 21.5 percent, the official said.

DOC.HEAD: Waste Management-Wheelabrator Merger Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Waste Management Inc. says it has reached agreement with Wheelabrator Technologies Inc. to take control of that company for about $500 million. Waste Management said Monday it would acquire an additional 33 percent of Wheelabrator common stock, bringing to 55 percent the amount of Wheelabrator shares held by Waste Management. Waste Management acquired its 22 percent interest in Wheelabrator in 1988. Wheelabrator, of Hampton, N.H., is a developer and operator of waste-to-energy facilities, water and wastewater treatment plants and air-pollution control systems. It also builds and operates small power plants. Waste Management provides solid and hazarddous waste services, city cleaning services and municipal recycling services.

DOC.HEAD: Reassurance On Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: At least one aspect of trade talks between the United States and Japan is reassuring. In some respects, that is, each nation proposes moves that conceivably could help the other. Why should there be resistance over that? Maybe there shouldn't be, but there is. Trade talks, like all inter-nation discussions, become mixed up in politics, not to mention diplomatic nuances. The Japanese would like to see Americans cut the budget deficit, save more, raise the skills and overall abilities of workers, put more effort into long-term research and, in general, improve the quality of products. Media reports suggest other, maybe more controversial, proposals have been made, including a reduction in credit cards, lower corporate bonuses and higher gasoline taxes, all ideas with support within the United States. For its part, the United States would like to see the Japanese improve their living standards, allow greater consumer access to supermarkets and department stores, pay lower prices and improve their infrastructure. There are, of course, many controversial aspects to the trade talks, but these relatively beneficent issues are among them. And all have support within the respective countries. From President Bush on down, it would seem that most Americans would be happy with a smaller budget deficit. The only major controversy appears to be the method by which it is achieved. Proposals to raise the level of U.S. education and skills are discussed every day in the United States, and a researcher would be hard pressed to find anyone with a strong negative view on the matter. Within the United States there has been repeated criticism of the tendency of some corporate managers to take the short-term view, with many of the critics maintaining that the short-term view weakens America competitively. It didn't take criticism by the Japanese to awaken Americans to an allegedly low savings rate. Almost everyone agrees that savings are good for individuals, businesses and country. On these, many Japanese and Americans see eye to eye. On the other side of the discussion, it is unlikely you would find many Japanese opposed to better living standards. Japan is rich, the world's No. 2 economic power, but many of its citizens don't know it. Many Americans are not familiar with the way the Japanese live. Roger A. Brooks, a scholar at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank, is familiar. In a position paper for the foundation's Asian Studies Center, of which he is director, Brooks urges the Japanese to say ``yes'' to opening their markets to imports. And for reasons with which many Japanese might agree. To wit: ``In the absence of imports, Japan forces its consumers to pay eight times what Americans pay for rice; to live in houses that are on average one-third the size of U.S. homes; to pay three times the world price for fiber-optic cable for Japan's telephone modernization efforts; to buy their goods at `Mom and Pop' operations with huge markups because of the law, changed only recently, outlawing discount stores.'' His portrait isn't complete. Japan, he says, has the world's largest surplus of foreign exchange, but it also has ``the greatest proportion of unpaved roads in the developed world,'' and the lowest per capita endowment of public facilities such as parks and sporting areas. Among the highly industrialized nations, he says, Japan has ``surely the least materially bountiful life.'' Reports from trade negotiations suggest a reluctance by each nation to make concessions, interspersed with occasional breakthroughs. In all, the tone has been less than highly positive. But, with these cross-table suggestions for improvements there seems to be at least a basis in good will for an agreement this month. That much is reassuring.
