DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower Overseas; Gold Advances
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was modestly weaker against major currencies in European trading Tuesday, moving in previously established trading ranges. Gold gained against the dollar. The dollar rebounded modestly from overnight losses but remained under some pressure as buyers took a more cautious approach to the U.S. currency ahead of talks this weekend among the Group of Seven industrial nations. Although dealers said the dollar is supported by worries over German unification and questions over the ability of Japan to support the sagging yen, they said that those factors did not provoke fresh dollar buying. ``Most of what we saw to day was purely intraday,'' said a senior corporate dealer at a large French bank. ``I don't think many people are taking a medium-term or long-term outlook right now.'' In late afternoon, the dollar was quoted at 1.7005 West German marks, down from 1.7052 late Monday in London. In Tokyo earlier, the dollar closed at 158.95 yen, down 1.00 yen from Monday's close. In London, the dollar traded at 159.10 yen. Other late dollar rates, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.5035 Swiss francs, down from 1.5068; 5.7140 French francs, down from 5.7300; 1.9150 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9193; 1,254.00 Italian lire, down from 1,254.25; and 1.1660 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1690. The British pound was quoted at $1.6345, up from $1.6300 late Monday. Gold traded at $375.05 bid per troy ounce late Tuesday in London, up from $368.95 late Monday. In Zurich, the late bid price was $376, up from $368.75 late Monday. In Hong Kong, gold rose 78 cents to close at $371.94. DOC.HEAD: Government Probes B-2 Flight Control System, Northrop Says
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Justice is investigating an electronic flight control system for the B-2 stealth bomber built by Northrop Corp., the military contractor disclosed in its annual report. The system, called the Actuator Remote Terminal, helps keep the B-2 stable in flight by relaying information between the plane's flight control computer and flight control surfaces. Northrop disclosed the Justice Department investigation Monday. It said its recent guilty plea to unrelated criminal charges provided for the government to drop certain investigations at the company, but not the one into the ART. The Los Angeles Times reported Tuesday that the ART has been plagued by severe technical problems. The Air Force has been upgrading it while the B-2 has been grounded for modifications since late last year. When flight tests resume later this month, the next step will be testing of the aircraft's ability to evade radar.

DOC.HEAD: US-Japanese Negotiators Resume Trade Talks
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Tops with 4 grafs showing talks resuming, picks up 4th graf pvs, The Bush administration.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Japanese negotiators resumed discussions today on one of the thorniest trade disputes between the two nations _ an effort to attack the underlying causes of America's $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. Both sides reported good progress had been made after the first day of talks Monday behind closed doors at the State Department. However, the head of a major manufacturers' lobbying group today raised questions over whether the U.S. side was demanding enough concessions from the Japanese to lower America's trade deficit by any significant degree. ``I think it is still up in the air whether these talks will yield any meaningful results,'' said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. The Bush administration launched the talks, known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, last July, seeking to force the Japanese to remove barriers that prevent the sale of American products and services in Japan. The administration is demanding a halt to cozy Japanese business practices that exclude foreign companies, as well as tougher enforcement of laws prohibiting bid-rigging and price-fixing. stration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe told reporters the Japanese initiatives were designed to ward off protectionist pressures in America and to benefit Japan. ``This is not being done for the sake of pleasing others, but to improve the quality of life for Japanese consumers,'' Watanabe said. He refused to discuss details of the Japanese package. However, published reports said Japanese negotiators proposed, among other things, making it easier for large American retailers to open stores in Japan. The Japanese negotiators also reportedly proposed increased penalties for violations of anti-monopoly laws and laid out plans for increased spending on public works projects, two demands of U.S. negotiators. Watanabe said the Japanese actions were not being taken under threat of U.S. retaliation, but he said the Japanese side felt it was important to show it had made the ``utmost effort'' to resolve the disputes. The administration is reviewing barriers against U.S. products with a congressionally imposed April 30 deadline to target countries with the most onerous barriers for intensive negotiations. Last year the Japanese were targeted for barriers against the sale of U.S. supercomputers, satellites and wood products. In recent days, negotiators have reached agreements in principle to resolve the satellite and supercomputer issues and will meet later this month in an effort to expand the Japanese market for American lumber.

DOC.HEAD: Another Shooting At Greyhound-Related Bus; No Injuries
Precede DALLAS
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with new shooting reported. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: At least five shots struck a Southeastern Trailways bus today as it traveled along a Greyhound route from Nashville to Louisville, state police said. Neither the driver nor the only passenger aboard was injured. The incident happened just two days after another Southeastern Trailways bus on a route usually traveled by strike-plagued Greyhound was hit and the driver seriously wounded. Kentucky State Police Trooper Eddie Lair said today's shooting was reported about 10:15 a.m. EDT and occurred somewhere on Interstate 65 near Sonora, about 55 miles south of Louisville. All five shots hit the bus on the driver's side, but none of them penetrated, he said. The driver, who was not identified, could not say from which direction the shots were fired, Lair said. Officials believe a .22-caliber rifle was used. On Saturday, Southeastern Trailways driver David E. Bryant was wounded in the arm by a shot fired from a pickup that pulled alongside. As in today's shooting, the Southeastern Trailways bus was following a Greyhound route under a pool arrangement. Bryant, 58, of Cincinnati was reported in fair condition today at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville. A hospital spokesman, Jim Keeley, said fears that Bryant's badly wounded arm would have to be amputated had eased. None of Bryant's 46 passengers was wounded. There have been reports of sporadic violence and other shootings since Greyhound drivers went on strike March 2. The company blames the union and says there will be no contract talks until a week goes by with no violence. On Monday, the head of Greyhound's drivers union suggested the company's refusal to negotiate is partly to blame for the violence. ``Reaching an agreement through bargaining would leave the `crazies' without any incentive to violence,'' union president Edward Strait said Monday in a letter to Greyhound Executive Vice President P. Anthony Lannie. Talks were to have resumed Monday until the company called them off in the wake of continuing violence. Lannie dismissed as ``total nonsense'' any suggestion that America's only nationwide bus system is reponsible for violence by refusing to negotiate. The walkout by 6,300 drivers and some 3,000 office and maintenance workers began over wages and job security March 2. On Monday, Greyhound said there had been 29 shootings, including 24 in which buses were the target. The union says there have been more than 60 incidents of violence against pickets. As of Monday, the company said it had 1,519 permanent replacements behind the wheel, plus 480 union members who crossed picket lines. Lannie said the company anticipates having 3,200 drivers at work by Easter, the busiest travel period of the first quarter.

DOC.HEAD: London's Options, Futures Markets Exploring Merger
DOC.TEXT: London's Traded Options Market, a subsidiary of London's Stock Exchange, and the London International Financial Futures Exchange said Tuesday they were exploring a merger. ``The aim is to combine the two markets under a single autonomous management and governance on a single trading floor,'' the two markets said in a statement. The aim is to create a more efficient market structure and enhance the London securities market, the statement said. A group made up of prominent members of London's financial community has been set up to investigate the best way to fully integrate the two markets, they said. The group should give an interim progress report by the end of April, with definitive proposals on the link-up expected by the end of June, the markets said.

DOC.HEAD: Panasonic Announces First Erasable Optical Storage for Video Use
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The recorder ...,' and 8th graf, `Panasonic's device ...,' to CORRECT that the recorder is analog, not digital.
DOC.TEXT: The first commercially available optical disc recorder that can erase stored images and record over them will give broadcasters a better tool than videotape for showing video replays, Panasonic said. The new device would allow television stations to more easily replay a sports highlight, for example, than conventional videotape technology, the Japanese company said Monday. It also can store more minutes of video and provides better picture quality than videotape. The recorder can find an individual frame of recorded video within one second, the company said. That's much quicker than videotape machines, in which the tape must be rewound to the exact spot. Panasonic also said the machine could be used for interactive training programs, to store criminal records in police departments, and for sales and marketing uses, such as recording videotapes of homes to show to prospective buyers. Eventually, similar devices could be made for home use, said Edward Rothchild, a San Francisco-based consultant on optical storage devices. He calls such recordable laser video disc players ``the next mass consumer products,'' which could supplant VCRs and videotapes much as compact discs are replacing phonograph records. The current generation of home laser video disc machines can only play prerecorded discs. They have failed to become a major market in part because they cannot record TV shows. Optical storage devices have been around for years, but most of them cannot be erased once the original recording is made. They are used primarily for long-term storage of computer data, such as invoices or bank statements. Panasonic's device works on the magneto-optical principal, in which a magnetic field is used to magnetize certain portions of the optical disc. A laser beam ``reads'' these magnetized portions and converts them into a picture. Unlike a compact disc, it stores the information in conventional analog form instead of in the computer language of digital storage. Jay Bretzmann, an analyst for International Data Corp., said the device's major advantage over videotape is its ease of locating certain portions of stored video. He also said it could be reused many more times than videotape, which tends to degrade in quality over time. ``I think it will expand the market for these devices,'' he said. He said Panasonic is leveraging the expertise of its parent, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. of Japan, in optical storage devices. Rothchild said other Japanese companies have demonstrated similar machines but that Panasonic is the first to the market. In addition to their appeal to TV stations, he said, they also should prove popular with movie studios, which already are using non-erasable optical discs to edit film. Erasable discs would be a great cost-savings, he said. Panasonic did not disclose the price of the recorder. It plans to begin shipments in the fourth quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Simmons Won't Pursue Georgia Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Investor Harold Simmons has ended his $1.1 billion tender offer for Georgia Gulf Corp., deciding instead to back the chemical company's recapitalization plan at its April 19 annual meeting. However, Simmons' NL Industries Inc., which owns almost 10 percent of Georgia Gulf's stock, left open Monday the possibility of another tender offer if shareholders reject the recapitalization plan. In January, Georgia Gulf, which is based in Atlanta, proposed the debt-financed recapitalization to boost the price of its stock and fend off an earlier offer from Simmons. Simmons countered with another tender offer in a move analysts said was designed to pressure Georgia Gulf to complete the recapitalization as proposed. Since Georgia Gulf amended its original plan two weeks ago, its stock has traded close to the $45 a share offered by Simmons. In a statement, NL Industries said it was not willing to increase its bid at this time and would instead support the Georgia Gulf plan. NL said it was also ending a planned proxy fight for control of Georgia Gulf's board. Georgia Gulf stock was trading at $43.87{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange Tuesday. Georgia Gulf has promised shareholders $30 a share in cash plus $8.50 a share in notes, and stock the company has valued at $11 a share. The original proposal promised stock and $38 a share in cash, but analysts were concerned that the company would be unable to sell the $200 million in junk bonds needed to finance the offer. ``While they are offering less cash, it is a more doable transaction,'' said Michael Snetzer, a Simmons strategist. If shareholders approve Georgia Gulf's recapitalization plan, NL could walk away from its investment with about $15 million in profits based on a $45-a-share value for the proposal. If shareholders do not approve the plan, NL said it might consider another tender offer for the company.

DOC.HEAD: Market Collapse Reflects Uncertainties Over Economy, Structural Changes
DOC.TEXT: Pessimism about the economy and outcome of trade talks with the United States have helped spur the protracted slide in Japan's stock market, analysts said Tuesday. Traders said many investors are concerned the the trade negotiations in Washington could affect the structural causes of Japan's $49 billion trade surplus with the United States and lead to wrenching changes in an export-oriented economy that is largely responsible for the nation's stunning growth. In the talks, called the Structural Impediments Initiative, the United States has pressured Japan to boost public works spending, simplify its complex distribution system, ease the way for large retailers to open stores, and tighten enforcement of its Anti-Monopoly Law. ``Japan will have to make a series of changes in the structural talks, and will have to forget about the old structures that supported our stock market boom and the strong yen in the past,'' said Kenji Maeshiro, a stock analyst with Yamaichi Securities Co. ``What we need now is to have a new approach to stock investment in order to cope with the new economic structures and policies,'' he said. So far this year, the Tokyo Stock Exchange's Nikkei Stock Average has fallen more than 10,000 points, or 26 percent, from a record 38,915.78 at the end of 1989. The market's total value also has dropped quickly _ at the close of trading on Tuesday, it stood at 456.8 trillion yen or $2.87 trillion, down from 611.15 trillion yen or $3.84 trillion at the end of last year. The recent string of stock market plunges was topped by Monday's drop of 1,978.38 points, or 6.59 percent, in the Nikkei's second-largest single-day dive ever, as the dollar surged to a three-year high against the yen. The only larger single-day loss was during the Black Monday global stock crash on Oct. 20, 1987, when the Nikkei shed 3,836.48 points, or 14.9 percent, to close at 21,910.08. As the market has continued its steep declines, securities dealers and analysts have repeatedly lowered their predictions for the Nikkei's bottom, with most estimates now near the 27,000-level. Following the 757.65-point or 2.7 percent rebound Tuesday, traders' predictions were divided. Some said the market had bottomed out, while others said market nervousness and pessimism would persist in coming weeks. Josen Takahashi, chief economist at the Mitsubishi Research Institute, said the market plunges reflected fear of higher inflation in Japan. Due partly to the yen's weakness, wholesale prices rose a relatively high 3.8 percent in the second 10 days of March from a year earlier. In another sign of the declining currency, Japan reported a $4.907 billion overall trade surplus in February, down 32.4 percent from a year earlier. Takahashi said inflationary pressures began forming last year, when market participants disregarded rising short-term interest rates and continued to push up stock prices. Ordinarily, when interest rates rise, stocks fall. The Bank of Japan plunged in by boosting its key official discount rate three times, from 2.5 percent to 4.25 percent, followed by an additional 1 percentage point hike on March 25 this year to 5.25 percent. The objective was to discourage borrowing, cool inflation and stabilize the yen. Market players had expected the most recent discount-rate increase to come shortly after parliamentary elections on Feb. 18, and blamed the extended delay with further destabilizing stock prices and the yen. Despite its recent heavy market intervention, the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, has failed to halt the yen's decline. Because of the intervention, Japan's foreign currency and gold reserves suffered the largest fall ever in March, dropping $6.947 billion to $73.496 billion, the Finance Ministry reported Monday. The tumble was the third consecutive monthly decline. Takahashi said stocks will continue to fall unless underlying problems _ a mix of higher interest rates, the weaker yen and higher consumer prices _ show signs of improvement. The yen is unlikely to strengthen under Japan's current political and economic conditions, he said. ``Japan has became more isolated and its relative importance has declined as hopes about reforms in Eastern Europe and uncertainties over the U.S.-Japan trade talks have grown,'' he said. A leading Japanese economic newspaper, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, called Tuesday on political leaders to take action to improve the economic climate. ``Unless Japan's political world can satisfy the markets in reforming the country's structural problems, there will be no chance of the yen's recovery, and no bottom for the stock market,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Mighty Japanese Banks Humbled by Markets, Regulators
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Names Takahashi and Takanashi are cq.
DOC.TEXT: Japan's leading banks, which bumped U.S. competitors from the world's top 10 list in the 1980s, are finding themselves squeezed by higher costs, reduced business and the Tokyo stock market's slide. ``The advantage Japanese banks used to enjoy has been largely eradicated. ... The whole perspective of international banking is considerably changed,'' said David Threadgold, an analyst with County NatWest Securities. Paul Heaton, senior analyst at W.I. Carr Securities, predicts that profits at the 13 leading commercial banks dropped 11 percent for the fiscal year ended March 31. In the previous year, profits rose 25 percent. Leaving out income from equities sales, earnings from banking business may be down by 50 percent from fiscal 1988, Threadgold said. In addition, the fall of the yen and Japan's stock market have imperiled the banks' plans to raise their capital levels to meet international standards set for 1993. ``Management at top banks feel we have entered a very difficult period. But we are not going to see any bankruptcies,'' said Teruyuki Takahashi, a senior manager at the Japanese Federation of Bankers' Associations. The world's 10 biggest banks in assets are Japanese. Sheer size will keep them there, but they will become weaker competitors abroad as their source of cheap funds dries up, Threadgold said. Rising interest rates have made it more expensive for banks to acquire funds for lending. Banks now are paying holders of money market certificates 5.8 percent interest, compared with the 0.75 percent paid on ordinary bank accounts. Furthermore, more customers now can buy money market certificates because the minimum purchase has been cut from $62,500 to $6,250. Meanwhile, business from income-producing loans has been chilled by higher interest rates and by government efforts to cool the feverish property market. Japan's central bank has raised its key rate for loans to commercial banks from 2.5 percent to 5.25 percent in the past 10 months. In turn, commercial banks' prime lending rates jumped from about 5.5 percent to around 7.2 percent. ``The speed of change is too fast,'' Takahashi said. At the same time, the Bank of Japan has instructed banks to keep property loan growth in line with the industry's overall loan growth, instead of their recent pace of double the overall rate. The move is aimed at helping cool property prices that have jumped 50 percent to 90 percent annually in Tokyo and other major cities since the mid-1980s. Banks have been dealt a double blow by the rapid change: they are paying higher rates on customer certificates but are earning relatively low interest on long-term past loans. Anticipating higher rates, many companies rushed to take out long-term loans over the past year, Heaton said. Furthermore, loan volume is slumping, said Yoshiaki Takanashi, chief of research at Yasuda Trust Bank. Businesses are raising more of their funds from other sources or simply putting off capital spending, he said. Heaton said loan growth, which had been expanding at 12 percent to 14 percent a year, now was less than 10 percent. Meanwhile, the rapid fall of the yen and the stock market has hurt the banks' attempt to meet international capital adequacy standards, said Takanashi, at Yasuda Trust. Major economic powers, acting through the Swiss-based Bank for International Settlements, have set a March 1993 deadline for banks to hold capital equal to at least 8 percent of their loans and other assets. Japanese banks used to maintain only about half that and have been relying heavily on the equities market to raise the needed capital through new share and covertible bond offerings. The stock market's more than 25 percent loss this year has drained the value of banks' shareholdings and made it difficult to raise new capital in the market, Takanashi said. Additionally, the yen's fall of about 10 percent against the U.S. dollar this year has raised the value of dollar-denominated loans overseas, he said. These inflated loan values, comprising roughly 40 percent of the city banks' assets, require more capital in reserve.

DOC.TEXT: The world's two most powerful economies have become inextricably wedded. But too often the relationship between the United States and Japan seems like a bad marriage characterized by frequent spats. What do the two have in common apart from money?

Never mind trade tensions. At Sam Kusumoto's company, a recent office party was enough to put a crimp in U.S.-Japan relations. There wasn't an argument or even a minor contretemps at the affair. Many of the American employees just didn't show up. It seems they didn't know about it in time, explains Kusumoto, president of Minolta USA in suburban Ramsey, N.J. ``At Japanese companies, we have very nice horizontal communication,'' he says. ``Everybody listens to what the other guy is talking about over the phone. After office hours we associate.'' So plans for just about everything spread chattily through the ranks _ in Japanese, of course. Formal notice, American-style, is almost an afterthought. ``The Americans didn't hear about the party,'' Kusumoto says. ``And when they discovered the date was decided months ago they got upset.'' A simple miscue, but behind it lay a gulf of misunderstanding that somehow has defied nearly 50 years of U.S.-Japan amity and more than a century of cultural exchange since 19th century Japan, under American prodding, cast off its feudal kosode (robes). Today more than ever, the world's two most powerful economies have become inextricably wedded. But too often the relationship seems like a bad marriage characterized by frequent squabbles and little in common apart from money. The tensions have appeared in numerous forms, despite the best efforts of both sides to avoid them: in charges of discrimination by American employees of Japanese companies, in a hardhearted new appraisal by Washington of its one-time protege, and vice versa. And not least, in an undercurrent of racism. The racism often surfaces subtly. When Japanese companies purchasedsuch American corporate icons as Columbia Pictures and New York's Rockefeller Center last year, the headlines often read ``The Japanese Buy ...,'' as if the entire nation were bent, samurai-like, on the takeover. In contrast, other major foreign purchasers _ British, Canadian, Dutch _have been described more accurately as individual companies. Part of it is the sheer cultural impact of Japan's new wealth, an economic sea change that made Japan the world's largest creditor by the end of the 1980s, and its former patron, the United States, the largest debtor. ``It's the Japanese rate of buying that's frightening,'' says Marlene Rossman, a New York-based consultant to New York companies. Japan is now second only to Great Britain in U.S. investments. From May 1987 to last May, the number of U.S. factories with at least partial Japanese ownership nearly doubled from 550 to 1,043, according to the Japan External Trade Organization. Japan's total investment in U.S. real estate, corporations and subsidiaries soared from $4.7 billion in 1980 to $53.4 billion in 1988, according to the most recent Commerce Department figures. Japanese companies now hold about 50 percent of the commercial real estate in downtown Los Angeles, more than 20 prime properties in Manhattan, including Tiffany's, and substantial holdings in Washington. It is not over the issue of Washington real estate, however, but closer to the heart of the nation's capital that U.S.-Japanese tensions have perhaps cut deepest. Particularly irksome were the 1989 trade figures released in February. The United States enjoyed a $1.5 billion surplus with the 12-nation European Community, a sharp turnaround from a $9.2 billion deficit in 1988. But with Japan, despite a sharp decline in the dollar engineered to help U.S. exports, the deficit was a stubborn $49 billion. That was no appreciable improvement from the previous year's $51.8 billion deficit with Japan, even with an 18 percent increase in U.S. export sales, says J. Michael Farren, undersecretary for international trade in the Commerce Department. The trade frictions are aggravated by what many in Congress and the Bush administration see as the Japanese government's xenophobic resistance to open markets and cultural disposition to treat trade as economic warfare. ``The fallacy in asking the Japanese to open their markets is they haven't got the foggiest idea what an open market is,'' says Clyde Prestowitz, a former Commerce Department negotiator whose influential 1988 book, ``Trading Places,'' portrayed Japan as having carefully planned its export-fueled ascendancy. In Tokyo, Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said U.S. analysts were wrong in arguing that Japan's culture was an unchangeable barrier to concepts like an open market. On March 22, U.S. and Japanese trade negotiators reported a breakthrough over the key issue of opening supercomputer exports to Japan. In addition, experts point out, Japan has been moving from an export-based to a domestic market-based economy. Japan has a long history of adapting foreign ideas, Watanabe said, ``and there is no reason why we cannot continue to do so.'' One reason, however, is that the Japanese are not as keen on foreign ideas these days, an attitude born of Japan's pride in its postwar ``miracle'' and a growing contempt for the United States' persistent problems.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: persistent problems.
DOC.TEXT: According to a Business Week poll released Dec. 7 _ Pearl Harbor Day _ more than half of the Japanese don't have much or any admiration for the United States, its economic success or its people. A recent book published in Japanese, ``A Japan That Can Say No,'' stunned Washington when word trickled back of its harsh view of the United States. But in Japan it has ruffled few feathers because much of its content ``has been expressed privately by (Japanese) journalists and businessmen who deal with America,'' Taro Kimura, a former anchorman for Japan Broadcasting Corp., commented in a newspaper column. One of the book's authors, Shintaro Ishihara, a right-wing former Cabinet minister, went beyond the usual criticisms of U.S. corporate shortsightedness and product quality. He wrote that racial prejudice is at the base of U.S.-Japan frictions. American whites, realizing their culture is declining, fear losing leadership to the ``yellow-race Japanese,'' he said. But Ishihara's outspokenness still represents an extreme. The irony of U.S.-Japan frictions is that both sides _ the Japanese in particular _ seem to try so hard to avoid misunderstanding. Many Americans _ even President Bush _ say they welcome Japanese investment here. And no one denies that many Japanese are still more mad for the West than mad at it. Japanese companies still pay out monstrous fees for endorsements by such American celebrities as Michael Jackson (who are rarely if ever seen in U.S. ads). Most Japanese cigarettes and many other products bear English names like Peace and Seven Stars, giving them the kind of cachet that French-sounding brands once had for Americans earlier in the century. In February, Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, in an apparent reference to recent polls, worried that ``some (Americans) are expressing the view that the economic threat from Japan is more serious than the military threat from the Soviet Union.'' ``The big problem underlying such a fear,'' he said, is ``that it is impossible to guess where Japan's huge economic power is headed, and under what philosophy or principles. ``What we need is to make further efforts to convey our views and way of thinking clearly to Americans.'' Accordingly, kokusaika, or ``internationalization,'' has become the official rage in Japan. The government, for example, has proposed tax breaks for companies that increase imports to Japan or make donations in the United States. Most Japanese companies have rooted themselves in America as successfully as their products _ and more successfully than their European competitors, according to a survey released last year by Columbia University's School of Business. The study found that, on average, Japanese firms in the United States have outperformed European competitors in terms of low absentee rates, low manager turnover and high product quality, among other criteria. In addition, recent polls have found that while mistrust is on the rise, a majority of Americans still have favorable feelings toward Japan. So, trade frictions aside, what's wrong? For one thing, many Japan observers contend that at the level of top management, at least, ``Americanization'' of Japanese-owned firms in the United States is just window dressing, a commercial ploy like the marketing of Christmas in Tokyo department stores, where few shoppers are Christian. While Japan's famed worker-participation techniques, such as quality circles, may work on the factory floor, American managers of Japanese subsidiaries are still under the yoke of a ``shadow system'' of command from Tokyo, some experts say. According to the first systematic survey of American managers in Japanese corporations, released last fall by the University of Michigan, most are excluded from planning and decision-making inside the companies and have little access to strategic information. Under the ``two-tiered'' Japanese employment system, Japanese managers do a three- to five-year rotation abroad. When they return to Japan, they are typically replaced by another Japanese executive from overseas rather than the Americans who have worked alongside them. This has led to resentment among many American managers. In addition, the Michigan study found that women and minorities still suffer widespread discrimination by Japanese companies. Minolta's Kusumoto, who has been in the United States more than 20 years and recently published a book on his experiences, ``My Bridge to America,'' asks that Americans be patient and recognize that Japan's tightly knit society can unravel itself only so fast. ``Many Japanese are hesitant to disclose secrets to Americans,'' he says. ``We came from companies with so-called lifetime employment. We have complete trust in an employee because we know he's going to stay. But here many people come and go, and we think maybe he'll give secrets to a competitor.'' Kusumoto says that only recently have he and other Japanese executives felt strongly enough of the loyalty of long-standing American employees to promote them to top positions. ``It's not racial,'' he says. ``It's a matter of trust.''

DOC.TEXT: Anger over the U.S. trade deficit is fed by a growing belief in Washington that Japan, once seen as a junior partner recreated in our image after World War II, has been playing by its own rules. In his much-discussed 1988 book, ``Trading Places,'' Clyde Prestowitz, a Japan expert and former Commerce Department trade negotiator, contends the Japanese have always identified national security with economic security. While America has been preoccupied fighting the Cold War _ to the benefit of allies such as Japan _ Japan has taken our trusting free-traders for a ride, Prestowitz says. Unlike U.S. policy-makers hostile to direct government support of business, Japan's powerful bureaucracy has generously subsidized its key industries in an export-at-all-costs drive for global supremacy in consumer electronics, automobiles and other important industries. Unlike U.S. policy-makers concerned mostly about keeping consumer prices low _ and thus markets open _ resource-poor Japan has subtly but effectively closed many of its markets to foreign imports. How else but through waves of unanswered exports could the Japanese pay for their raw materials? The familiar pattern, the Prestowitz school says, was to force leading U.S. companies to license their technology to Japan by refusing them initial market entry there. Then, using the technology, they built Japanese counterparts while protracting open-market negotiations in the time-honored Japanese manner. Prestowitz notes that in other countries, particularly in Europe, trade restrictions are also the norm, something that's all the more forbidding considering the consolidation of the 320 million-consumer market of the European Community planned for 1992, with the prospects of Eastern Europe joining in. ``American leaders show an amazing myopia,'' Prestowitz said in a recent interview. ``At the moment in our dealing with Japan and rest of the world our objective is to obtain some kind of utopian free trade. To achieve that we effectively insist that everyone change their societies to become like ours. When we were the big guy on the block accounting for half the world's GNP we had a big stick. ``These days we have a begging cup in our hand and people don't really need to pay attention to us.'' Prestowitz's answer, and that of a growing number of supporters, is if you can't beat 'em, join 'em. They say the government needs to ``manage'' trade in technologies critical to the sources of waning U.S. strength, such as semiconductors, and to adopt industrial policies to bolster them. As an example, Prestowitz points to the strict tabs kept on international airline service and banking. To Bush administration officials, however, Prestowitz's conclusion smacks of heresy, raising the bugaboo of protectionism. Their response is to lay on more open-market pressure. ``The administration is absolutely committed to the free-trade principles we've followed for the last 40 years,'' says J. Michael Farren, undersecretary for international trade in the Commerce Department. ``Moving toward managed trade ... will undermine the entire world trading system as we know it.'' But Farren concedes that other countries are looking to Japan's model. ``Japan is running the risk of spreading the contagion of closed markets to the rest of world,'' he says.

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rose sharply today, boosted by a rebound in the Tokyo market and firm bond prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 34.46 to 2,734.91 as of 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 2 to 1 among New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 1,037 up, 425 down and 471 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 121.38 million shares with one hour of trading remaining. In Japan, prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange jumped sharply in nervous, roller-coaster trading. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 757.65 points, or 2.7 percent, ending the day's session at 28,757.65. On Monday, Tokyo stock prices plummeted 6.6 percent in their second-worst fall this year. The selloff initially spilled over to Wall Street, where the Dow Jones average slipped as much as 30 points in early trading before firming to close 6.76 points lower at 2,700.45. Analysts say the link between the Tokyo and New York markets is not as strong as once believed. They also say most of the trouble on the Japanese exchange is due to domestic concerns, including interest-rate worries and a belief that stocks are overpriced compared to earnings. Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany Corp., said the U.S. market today was encouraged by three factors: its rebound Monday, the firming in Tokyo prices and a stable bond market. Treasury bond prices were mixed in a narrow range today. Johnson said the recovery Monday in New York suggests ``that our markets continue to manage the declines in Tokyo pretty easily.'' Among actively traded blue-chip issues today, Philip Morris rose 1[ to 40|, Eastman Kodak rose 1] to 40], American Telephone & Telegraph was up [ at 41} and Union Carbide was up \ at 22[. Among other active issues, Unocal dropped 1| to 32 after negative analyst comments. A Merrill Lynch analyst lowered his earnings forecast for the oil company and others said they were less bullish on the stock. Unocal has been the subject of takeover rumors in recent days. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 2.01 to 188.09. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 2.06 to 361.43.

DOC.HEAD: `I Need 250 Thousand!': Lawyers Deal in Open Court; Trump Involved
DOC.TEXT: If deal-making really is art, then the bidding for Bonwit Teller was the aesthetic equivalent of finger painting. A bankruptcy court hearing Monday turned into a corporate casbah as attorneys frantically arranged offers for the failed department store chain _ not over the typical Wall Street power lunch, but within earshot of a federal judge. Deals came together, fell apart and came together again. Bidders changed sides. A dramatic 11th-hour proposal by a would-be savior failed. A lawyer played auctioneer as two sides upped offers $1 million at a pop, waiting for the opposition to crumble. ``I need 250 thousand from each of you and I need it now!'' implored Donald N. David, a lawyer representing deal-master Donald Trump, to members of a group bidding on five of the 16 Bonwit department stores. David got an icy stare from one participant, who refused to raise his ante. A representative of Trump _ whose eponymous gold Tower on Fifth Avenue houses Bonwit's flagship store _ and two other groups contributed the difference. The deal lived. Bankruptcy court is becoming a home away from home for American big business in the 1990s as companies stumble under the weight of junk bonds and other takeover- and expasion-related problems in the 1980s, the decade of debt. A new era of restructuring means more unusual proceedings like the one Monday in which about 200 people _ mostly lawyers _ crammed into a steamy bankruptcy courtroom overlooking New York Harbor. Amid shouting, cajoling, the toot of the Staten Island Ferry and pounding of a jackhammer six floors below, Bonwit's was carved into pieces. Lawyers constantly pleaded for another minute as they huddled to cut a deal. Most unusual was that the nearly 10-hour ordeal took place in open court, where judges rarely tolerate more than one person speaking at a time _ always deferentially _ let alone protests and open outcry bidding. ``I've never seen anything like it before,'' David, of the New York firm Dreyer & Traub, said Tuesday. ``I think if it weren't for that informality they wouldn't have raised anywhere near the amount of money they did for the estate.'' L.J. Hooker Corp., Bonwit's Atlanta-based parent, held the auction to boost the liquidation value of the upscale store chain it bought three years ago. Hooker had received just one bid for five stores prior to the auction. On Monday, the take for Hooker creditors rose by millions. Also, some of the stores may survive. A first round of bidding included offers from a French retailer, a Florida department store, a Buffalo chain, a Canadian investor and a group that included Trump and the women's apparel store the Limited. As the second round began, the Trump group booted the Limited and embraced Pyramid Cos., a Syracuse, N.Y.-based shopping mall developer and owner that already had made the pre-auction, five-store bid. When it became apparent the group needed to raise its $20.25 million offer or lose out to a possible combination of other bids, the haggling intensified. David, an energetic bearded man with a thick New York accent, hustled about a station of about 15 lawyers and businessmen seeking more money. He got it. In 20 minutes, the bid rose by $1.5 million, collapsing once in the process. Meantime, the court looked more like Sotheby's when two bidders battled for a Bonwit store in exclusive Palm Beach, Fla. Lawyers for Frances Brewster Inc., a Florida retailer, and Ralph Hibbard, a Canadian investor, called bids from opposite sides of the courtroom, raising the price to $2.2 million from $1.6 million. ``Sounds like an auction,'' Bankruptcy Judge Tina Brozman said to laughter. After the Hibbard group conceded, Hooker lawyer Sheldon Hirshon, serving as impromptu auctioneer, said: ``Going once, going twice...'' The final drama was provided by the day's hoped-for white knight. Hooker lawyers had wanted to preserve the Bonwit's chain. In the morning they announced that a group led by Bonwit's ex-CEO William Ruben was planning a bid for 13 stores. In the mid-afternoon they said the deal was off. Around 6:30 p.m., lawyers told the judge it was on again. Ruben showed up in court and told reporters his $36 million bid could make Bonwit ``viable again.'' All he needed was one day to arrange financing. Furious, David said reopening the bidding would violate an agreement and ``make a fool out of everybody here.'' Hooker attorneys eventually acquiesced, fearing they could lose all bids if the Ruben group collapsed. Attorney Alan Hyman said Hooker decided ``to resort to the heady and cerebral theory that a bird in the hand was worth two in the bush.'' David, an hour after pacing angrily and saying, ``It's off,'' gave associates two thumbs up.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Production Steady in March, but Still Above Output Cap
DOC.TEXT: OPEC nations held oil production steady in March but remained more than a million barrels a day above their self-imposed supply cap, according to estimates released Tuesday. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries pumped a total of about 23.7 million barrels a day in March, the same as in the previous month, according to the Paris-based International Energy Agency. Sales of OPEC crude oil in March were believed to be lower than production due to apparent excess supply of heavy, sour grades and weaker than expected demand from refiners, the group stated. Private analysts predicted the cartel would increase output even more this month. ``It seems it will go up in April, maybe to as much as 24 million barrels a day,'' said Pierre Terzian, editor of the Paris-based newsletter Petrostrategies. Leading the surge in last month's production were Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Nigeria, according to the International Energy Agency's Monthly Oil Market Report. All were estimated to be above the individual quotas the cartel set for each country last year and reaffirmed at a recent meeting in Vienna. The organization imposed a cartel-wide ceiling of 22.1 million barrels a day for production in the first half of 1990, to help support a price of $18 a barrel. But members, led by Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, have been cheating on their quotas. Oil prices soared in early January but have been gradually slipping since then, falling in early March below $18. The average price of a basket of seven crudes monitored by the agency was $17.33 a barrel in the last week of March, down from $17.47 the previous week. Prices of West Texas Intermediate, the key American grade, have ranged from $20 to $22 a barrel during that time. In an effort to keep prices firm, OPEC oil ministers met last month and issued a fresh call for restraint by all nations in the normally weak April-June quarter. Analysts say that if the cartel keeps production high, prices will weaken in the coming months. Demand for crude normally slumps in the second quarter when spring weather warms the United States and other consuming nations. The International Energy Agency predicted demand for OPEC oil at 20.4 million barrels a day in the current quarter. Analysts argue that some of the producers, particularly Kuwait, want prices to stay at the $18 level so the cartel does not lose market share to other oil-producing nations. High prices will prompt other suppliers to pump more. According to the oil market report, Saudi Arabia, the world's No. 1 oil exporter, pumped 5.6 million barrels a day in March, above its quota of 5.4 million barrels. Iran and Iraq were about at their quotas of 3.1 million barrels a day. The United Arab Emirates produced some 2 million barrels a day, about double its supply cap. Kuwait's output was estimated at 1.8 million barrels a day, above its limit of 1.5 million barrels. Nigeria supplied about 1.8 million barrels a day, up from its quota of 1.6 million barrels. Other production estimates for March were: Libya, 1.3 million barrels a day; Algeria, 800,000 barrels; Gabon, 300,000 barrels; Venezuela, 1.9 million barrels; Ecuador, 300,000 barrels, and Indonesia, 1.3 million barrels. The International Energy Agency is an arm of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, made up of two dozen industrialized nations.

DOC.HEAD: Speculative Buying Boosts Crop Futures
DOC.TEXT: Futures prices of grain and soybeans closed mostly higher Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid speculative buying centered in the corn and wheat markets. The late rally in the grains spilled over into soybean trading, reversing a slide that had threatened to extend the sharp losses posted Monday, when soybean futures plunged as much as 11\ cents a bushel. Brokerage houses and independent floor traders did most of the buying while commercial grain dealers were net sellers on the day, said Victor Lespinasse, a floor trader for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. He linked the rally to rumors of new Soviet purchases of U.S. corn and to expectations for a seasonal advance in prices as the 1990 growing season begins. Grain and soybean futures typically rise early in the growing season as traders focus on weather conditions and the potential for crop damage. At the close of trading, wheat futures were 1 cent lower to 5} cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.61{ a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 2} cents higher with May at $2.66\ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1 cent higher with May at $1.52\ a bushel; soybeans were \ cent to 2\ cents higher with May at $5.85\ a bushel.
