Analysts say the link between the Tokyo and New York markets is not as strong as once believed. They also say most of the trouble on the Japanese exchange is due to domestic concerns, including interest-rate worries and a belief that stocks are overpriced compared to earnings. Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany Corp., said the U.S. market today was encouraged by three factors: its rebound Monday, the firming in Tokyo prices and a stable bond market. Treasury bond prices were mixed in a narrow range today. Johnson said the recovery Monday in New York suggests ``that our markets continue to manage the declines in Tokyo pretty easily.''
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Guarantees Future Rebates on Minivans Bought Now
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. on Tuesday guaranteed future 1990 model year rebates for anyone buying one of its minivans now. The minivans _ the Dodge Caravan, Plymouth Voyager and Chrysler Town & Country _ currently have no rebates. When the company offered cash-back deals on the vehicles last December and January, sales soared. Since then, they've tapered off. Sales of Chrysler's minivans top those of all competitors combined.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The energy futures market finished mixed in quiet trading Tuesday, with prices of crude oil and unleaded gasoline losing ground and home heating oil posting gains. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the contract for May delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 18 cents to $20.30 a 42-gallon barrel. The contract had advanced 20 cents on Monday. Among refined petroleum products, wholesale home heating oil for May delivery rose 0.23 cent to 55.50 cents a gallon, after gaining 0.93 cent Monday. May unleaded gasoline, which settled up 0.72 cent in the previous session, declined 0.20 cent to 65.8 cents a gallon. Natural gas contracts traded on the New York Merc for the first time Tuesday. The June contract settled at $1.685 per 1,000 cubic feet. Peter Beutel, an energy analyst with Elders Futures Inc., said internal market influences were largely responsible for Tuesday's price fluctuations in the absence of any fundamental factors. ``Trading was quiet today,'' he said. ``A lot of people were involved earlier in the day promoting new natural gas contracts.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Varied; Gold Gains
Precede LONDON-BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mixed against major foreign currencies in light trading Tuesday as dealers lacked incentives to buy or sell heavily. Gold gained in trading at home and abroad. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for April delivery settled at $375.30 a troy ounce, up $5.50 from Monday. Later, Republic National Bank of New York quoted a troy ounce of gold bullion at $375.25 as of 4 p.m. EDT, $5 higher than Monday's late bid. Currency dealers said the dollar traded in a narrow range for much of the day. Renewed demand to buy dollars against the Japanese yen in particular surfaced in afternoon domestic trading and pushed the dollar higher. The dollar ended in New York at 159.76 yen, up from 158.65 yen on Monday. But in Tokyo trading, which ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar declined to 158.95 yen, 1.00 yen lower than Monday's close. In London, the dollar traded at 159.10 yen. Richard Levine, a vice president at Elders Futures Inc., said trading was generally light. There were no fundamental developments that caused any shift in sentiment toward the dollar. Dealers overseas said there was a cautious approach to the U.S. currency ahead of talks this weekend among the Group of Seven industrial nations. The finance ministers of the United States, West Germany, Japan, France, Britain, Italy and Canada are scheduled to meet in Paris on April 7. Although worries about German unification and questions about Japan's ability to support the sagging yen tended to support the dollar, those factors did not provoke fresh dollar buying in Europe, dealers said. The British pound was quoted at $1.6345 late in London, up from $1.6300 late Monday. In New York, sterling fell to $1.6358 from $1.6390 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Monday, included: 1.6990 West German marks, up from 1.6985; 1.5035 Swiss francs, up from 1.5010; 5.7085 French francs, down from 5.7105; 1,247.75 Italian lire, down from 1,249.25; and 1.1656 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1678. Selected dollar rates late in Europe, compared with late Monday's levels were: 1.7005 West German marks, down from 1.7052; 1.5035 Swiss francs, down from 1.5068; 5.7140 French francs, down from 5.7300; 1.9150 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9193; 1,254.00 Italian lire, down from 1,254.25; and 1.1660 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1690. Rumors of possibly heavy gold buying by investors from the Middle East lifted prices. Gold bullion posted mostly solid gains in European and Asian trading before strengthening in the United States. In London, gold traded late in the day at $375.05 a troy ounce, up from $368.95 Monday's late bid. In Zurich, Switzerland, the late bid was $376 an ounce, up from $368.75 late Monday. Gold rose 78 cents in Hong Kong to close at $371.94. Silver also rose. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.007 a troy ounce, up from $4.946 Monday. In London the late silver bid was $5.02 a troy ounce, up from Monday's $4.96.

DOC.HEAD: ABC, CBS, NBC Heads: Need `Level Playing Field' for Free TV to Thrive
DOC.TEXT: The heads of the big three TV networks complained Tuesday that cable television had several profitable advantages over them, although the chief of third-place CBS said his company had no plans to develop cable ventures as the other two had. Chief executive officers Thomas Murphy of ABC, Laurence Tisch of CBS and Robert Wright of NBC each told the National Association of Broadcasters that one expensive factor affecting the networks was regulations enabling them to lock up shows for only four years. After the four-year period, the networks end up paying huge sums to production studios to retain shows that had become hits. NBC just bought a seventh year of ``The Cosby Show'' at a reported $50 million, the most expensive renewal in TV history. ``We're in the worst of all worlds,'' Tisch said. ``We are allowed to lose money if it doesn't work, but not allowed to make any money if it does work.'' With network costs soaring and advertising revenue sluggish _ while competing cable channels are reaping revenue from advertising and subscriber fees _ ``we have to develop other revenue streams,'' Wright said. He said ratings indicate the majority of TV viewers still are watching the big three networks, but they're nevertheless paying for cable TV. ``None of us get any of that money,'' Wright said. Broadcasters are asking Congress to make cable companies pay for carrying broadcast television programming. ABC and NBC are in the cable TV business _ ABC by ownership of ESPN and Lifetime, and NBC with its C-NBC cable channel _ but CBS has no such ventures. ``I think we missed the boat, perhaps,'' Tisch said. ``Maybe we should have been in the business 10 or 12 years ago. ``But I can't picture CBS developing a cable network that could be profitable, and I'm not in the mood to bang my head against the wall for 10 years. ... The only thing a new toy would do is assure that we stay in third place forever. If we're going to succeed, we'll succeed as free broadcasters.'' Murphy said ABC was fortunate that its cable ventures, particularly ESPN, were well established. CBS, meanwhile, has spent billions of dollars for network sports programming, including new contracts with Major League Baseball and the National Football League. ``Financially, it's not a gamble,'' Tisch said. ``We need the sports support. ...I think the advertisers will be there.'' Murphy said ABC did not give up on sports, ``We got outbid. We decided we'd rather put our money on series programming.'' In response to questioning, Tisch said there was no instability at CBS Sports, despite the sudden sacking of top sportscaster Brent Musburger on Sunday. The dumping of Musburger and his reported $2 million salary by third-place CBS ``wasn't a message,'' Tisch said. ``It was an individual negotiation which didn't work out.'' Earlier Tuesday, Federal Communications Commission Chairman Alfred Sikes told the broadcasters he supports self-regulation of radio and television, but he pledged not to permit ``regulatory neglect'' when rules and practices hamper competition. Getting agreement on standards of broadcast content will be difficult, he said, but the public will demand them and the question is ``who will act to set them.''

DOC.HEAD: Gold Futures Rise Sharply; Saudi Buying Seen
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices rose sharply Tuesday in a burst of Middle Eastern buying, possibly by some of the same investors whose sale last week of at least a million ounces of the metal triggered a collapse in prices to 4{-month lows. On other commodity markets, copper futures climbed strongly; cocoa futures surged; grains and soybeans advanced; oil futures were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $5.50 to $5.90 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in April at $375.30 a troy ounce; silver futures finished 6 cents to 6.4 cents higher with April at $5.007 a troy ounce. Analysts said heavy buying of gold bullion occurred overnight in Tokyo and London, sparking rumors that Saudi investors were buying back at a profit some of the gold they were believed to have sold on March 26 for British pounds. Observers were divided on how much gold was purchased. But they agreed that it appeared to be less than the huge amount sold last week when investors around the world jumped on the bandwagon and dumped an estimated 2 million ounces of bullion onto the market. Analyst James Steel of Refco Inc. in New York said the Saudis may have bought only 25,000 ounces and appeared to have sold no British pounds, which cast doubt on speculation that a reversal of last week's move was in the works. But George Milling-Stanley, first vice president in charge of bullion sales for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said the parties who started last week's selloff had reversed ``a good chunk'' of their sales. What had not occurred, he said, was follow-through buying Tuesday by U.S. and Far Eastern investors. Analysts agreed the market was likely to remain jittery and that a rally back above $400 an ounce was unlikely without substantial buying by the Japanese, who have been largely absent from the gold market for the past two months. ``It's going to take some volume buying by somebody or other and it could very well be the Asians,'' said Milling-Stanley. Copper futures surged late in the session on sketchy reports of a mudslide in Chile, one of the world's largest copper-producing countries. Copper settled 2.5 cents to 3.85 cents higher on the Commodity Exchange with April at $1.274 a troy ounce. Cocoa futures leaped as much as $52 a ton on New York's Coffee Sugar & Cocoa Exchange on technically inspired buying after two days of lower prices. Cocoa settled $48 to $52 higher with May at $1,215 per ton. Most grain and soybean futures rose on the Chicago Board of Trade amid speculative buying centered in the corn and wheat markets. The late rally in the grains spilled over into soybean trading, reversing a slide that had threatened to extend the sharp losses posted Monday, when soybean futures plunged as much as 11\ cents a bushel. Wheat futures settled 1 cent lower to 5} cents higher with May at $3.61{ a bushel; corn was 2\ cents to 3 cents higher with May at $2.66{ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1 cent higher with May at $1.52\ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 3} cents higher with May at $5.86 a bushel. Energy futures mostly declined on the New York Mercantile Exchange ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly inventories report. The report showed a greater-than-expected increase of 4.3 million barrels of U.S. crude-oil stocks last week, a larger-than-expected decline of 7.1 million barrels of gasoline, and a smaller-than-expected drop of 0.9 million barrels of heating oil. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 11 cents to 18 cents lower with May at $20.30 a barrel; heating oil was .05 cent lower to .23 cent higher with May at 55.50 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .20 cent to .40 cent lower with May at 65.88 cents a gallon. Natural gas futures began trading Tuesday on the New York Merc. The contract for delivery in June traded from $1.58 to $1.655, settling at $1.635 per million British thermal units. Cattle futures slipped on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on expectations of rising cattle supplies; pork futures were mixed after Monday's sharp gains. Live cattle settled unchanged to .38 cent lower with April at 78.60 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .02 cent to .30 cent lower with April at 82.60 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to .45 cent higher with April at 54.72 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .57 cent lower to .20 cent higher with May at 55 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Companies To Provide Digital Music Service Over Cable TV
DOC.TEXT: A maker of cable television equipment and a media company said Tuesday they would launch a system to send digital music programming over cable TV lines. Scientific-Atlanta Inc. said it will make the gear to send the music, while International Cablecasting Technologies Inc. said it will provide the musical programming over 27 channels initially. Up to 288 channels could be used eventually, the companies said. The system will allow the transmission of compact disc-quality sound over a satellite network that will be hooked into local cable TV systems. In the home, the system will be attached to a subscriber's stereo system. The service, called the Digital Music Network, is scheduled to be launched this fall, the companies said. Tele-Communications Inc. and Viacom International Inc., both major operators of cable TV systems, and Prime Cable, another cable operator, have signed on to offer the service to more than 5 million subscribers, said Jerold H. Rubinstein, chairman of ICT. Rubinstein is a former chairman of ABC Records and former chairman and co-owner of United Artists Records. Scientific-Atlanta is a major maker of cable TV selector boxes and satellite transmission equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Turner Blames Competitors, Not Consumers for Cable Reregulation Effort
DOC.TEXT: Cable television pioneer Ted Turner on Tuesday said cable TV's competitors and not cable subscribers are responsible for rallying efforts to impose more regulations on the cable industry. The chairman and president of Turner Broadcasting System Inc. also said he opposed the heavy investment being made in developing expensive high definition television while half the world still doesn't have television at all. ``Before the rich world pigs out on a $3,000 television set that is only slightly better maybe we ought to furnish the people in the world with black and white sets,'' Turner said. He also said his company's talks on possible ventures with CBS Inc. have run into ``blind alleys'' but are continuing. Addressing the annual conference of the Advertising Research Foundation, Turner was asked whether he thought customer complaints about price increases or service were driving recent proposals to reregulate the cable TV industry. Turner said it was neither and said surveys have shown ``the vast majority of cable subscribers are perfectly happy'' with their cable service. He said broadcasters, the motion picture industry and independent television are ``whipping Washington into a frenzy because they are really scared to death of cable now. I think that's most of it.'' Turner's Atlanta-based company produces the Cable News Network, Headline News and Turner Network Television as well as the superstation WTBS. Its owners include some of the major cable TV system operators. In his speech to the researchers, Turner said the globalization of communications has contributed to efforts to outlaw most whaling, save the African elephants and tear down the Iron Curtain in Eastern Europe. He said that in 10 years, there would not be a single dictatorship or totalitarian state in the world. In a question and answer session, he was asked about the development of HDTV, a technology that will make television pictures much sharper. Turner said he was against it because ``half the people in the world don't have a television set, half the people in the world don't have electricity.'' He said HDTV would also make the trade deficit with Japan larger because ``they will be made in Japan, you wait and see, all of them.'' Turner was asked about reports that he is trying to reach a cooperation agreement with CBS Inc., the operator of the CBS Television Network and a company he once tried to acquire. He noted CBS and his company already have reached a deal on providing coverage of the Winter Olympics. ``We may do something else one of these days, but it's not easy,'' Turner said. He said the CBS News department is ``not too enthusiastic about doing anything with us but top management I think is.'' ``We are exploring a number of things but we have run into a number of blind alleys so far. We are having fun and we are talking,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, In Japan ... to CORRECT Tuesday's closing Nikkei Stock Average.
DOC.TEXT:
Stock prices rose sharply and broadly Tuesday in moderate trading, boosted by a rebound in the Tokyo market and firm bond prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 36.26 to 2,736.71. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,071 up, 431 down and 468 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 154.31 million shares, up from 124.36 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 182.88 million shares. In Japan, prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange jumped in nervous, roller-coaster trading. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 757.65 points, or 2.7 percent, ending the day's session at 28,759.72. On Monday, while the U.S. dollar surged to a three-year high against the Japanese yen, the Nikkei index shed 1,978.38 points, or 6.59 percent, to 28,002.07. It was the index's second largest single-day decline ever.
On Monday, Tokyo stock prices plummeted 6.6 percent in their second-worst fall this year. The selloff initially spilled over to Wall Street, where the Dow Jones average slipped as much as 30 points in early trading before firming to close 6.76 points lower at 2,700.45. Analysts say the link between the Tokyo and New York markets is not as strong as once believed. They also say most of the trouble on the Japanese exchange is due to domestic concerns, including interest-rate worries and a belief that stocks are overpriced compared to earnings. Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany Corp., said the U.S. market Tuesday was encouraged by three factors: its rebound Monday, the firming in Tokyo prices and a stable bond market. Treasury bond prices rose moderately by the close after trading in a narrow range. Johnson said the recovery Monday in New York suggests ``that our markets continue to manage the declines in Tokyo pretty easily.'' Other analysts said the rally could be short-lived due to the moderate trading volume Tuesday. Philip Morris was the most-active NYSE issue, with 2.5 million shares changing hands as the stock rose 1] to 40~. Among other active blue chips, Eastman Kodak rose 1{ to 40{, General Electric gained 1 to 65, Exxon rose ~ to 47[ and IBM rose } to 106|. Unocal, the second most-active issue, dropped 1| to 32 after a Merrill Lynch analyst lowered his earnings forecast for the oil company and others said they were less bullish on the stock. Unocal has been the subject of takeover rumors in recent days. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market grew by $41.984 billion, or 1.29 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 2.47 to 188.55. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 6.10 to 398.94, and S&P's 500-stock composite index rose 4.94 to 343.64. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 4.47 to 437.65. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 2.28 to 361.65.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS sketch of departing chairman Roger Smith
DOC.HEAD: With AM-GM-Smith, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following are thumbnail sketches of the four new members of General Motors Corp.'s top management as announced Tuesday by retiring GM Chairman Roger B. Smith. New positions will be effective Aug. 1, the day after Smith steps down.

New position: Chairman and chief executive officer. Current position: President and chief operating officer since Sept. 1, 1987. Degrees held: bachelor's from Worcester Polytechnic Institute in Massachusetts and master's in business administration from Michigan State University. Age: 57 on July 15, 1990. Length of GM employment: 32 years. First GM job: Senior detailer in the Oldsmobile Division's chassis design department. Background: Was promoted through Oldsmobile product development and engineering operations before becoming director of engineering in the Chevrolet Division in 1975. Three years later he was appointed general manager of the Pontiac Division and in 1980 was appointed managing director of Adam Opel AG in West Germany. Two years later, he was named general manager of the Chevrolet Division. In 1986, as an executive vice president, he was put in charge of GM's worldwide Truck & Bus Group and the Overseas Group.

New position: President. Current position: Executive vice president in charge of North American Automotive Operations. Degrees held: Bahelor's in mechanical engineering from the University of Missouri. Age: 54 on Sept. 22, 1990. Length of GM employment: 30 years. First GM job: Experimental engineer. Background: Worked through the 1960s in engineering rising to become chief engineer of the 1970 Chevrolet Camaro and Nova. In 1973 he was named manager of Chevrolet product planning and two years later became chief engineer at Buick. In 1978, Reuss became director of engineering at Chevrolet. Two years later, he was named general manager of the Buick Motor Division and elected a GM vice president.

New position: Vice chairman. Current position: Executive vice president in charge of GM Hughes Electronics Corp., Electronic Data Systems Corp., GM technical staffs and corporate information management. Degrees held: Bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering and master's of science degree from Michigan State University. Age: 60 on May 2, 1990. Length of GM employment: 35 years. First GM job: College graduate-in-training. Background: Schultz rose through the product ranks to become chief engineer of the Emission Control Systems Project Center in 1977. A year later, Schultz became chief engineer for the Buick Motor Division. In 1981, he was named general manager for Delco Electronics Division followed three years later by being named group director of engineering for GM's Chevrolet-Pontiac-Canada Group. He was named as a vice president in 1985, a year before being appointed group executive in charge of CPC.

New position: Vice chairman. Current position: Executive vice president of GM's international operations since June 27, 1988. Degrees held: Bachelor's in business administration from the University of Massachusetts, master's of business administration from Boston University. Age: 52 on April 6, 1990. Length of GM employment: 29 years. First GM job: A variety of jobs at GM's Fisher Body facility in Framingham, Mass., while working on an advanced degree. Background: Began in the financial ranks and rose to comptroller of the corporation in 1980. He then switched to product development work and was named general manager of General Motors of Canada before moving to Europe and becoming president of General Motors Europe in 1987.

Current position: Chairman and chief executive officer since Jan. 1, 1981. Degrees held: Bachelor's and master's in business administration, both from the University of Michigan. Age: 65 on July 12, 1990. Length of GM employment: 41 years. First GM job: General accounting senior clerk, Detroit Central Office. Background: Rose through financial ranks to election as GM treasurer in March 1970. Other executive positions included vice president in charge of financial staffs and executive vice president.

DOC.HEAD: Company Says It Will Challenge Votes
DOC.TEXT: Allegheny International Inc. said it will ask a federal bankruptcy court to disallow a New York investment group's votes against the company's reorganization plan. The company said Monday it had received the necessary two-thirds majority vote from all classes of its creditors and shareholders except the senior secured bank class and the senior unsecured class. The vote fell short in those categories because of negative votes cast by Japonica Partners and its affiliates, Allegheny International said. Japonica Partners is competing with Allegheny International's management to take over the Pittsburgh-based company. The company said it will file suit in U.S. Bankruptcy Court to disallow the votes of Japonica and its affiliates, saying it questions their motives in rejecting the plan. ``AI is pressing forward to have its plan of reorganization confirmed,'' Chairman Oliver S. Travers said. Japonica responded with a statement saying, ``We believe there is no basis whatsoever for excluding the votes of any Allegheny constituent who voted against management's plan and that any attempt by management to resuscitate its failed plan ... will not be successful.'' Management reorganization plan is worth about $687 million and would pay off creditors and shareholders with stock in a reorganized company. Japonica, meanwhile, proposes paying creditors and shareholders in cash. The partnership has said it has a $120 million line of credit. Bankruptcy court is scheduled to begin confirmation hearings on the plan April 19.

DOC.HEAD: Xerox To Take First Quarter Pre-Tax Write-Off.
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. said it would take a pre-tax charge of approximately $400 million in the first quarter to write down the value of its investment in VMS Realty Partners, a Chicago-based real estate company. VMS Realty acquires, manages and develops hotels, office buildings, shopping and residential centers. The company announced in February that it had ceased all but essential payments to its creditors because of severe financial problems. A Xerox subsidiary paid $106 million for a 25 percent equity stake in the company in 1987. In addition, the subsidiary holds VMS subordinated notes and accrued interest totalling $136 million, and has extended a $125 million in credit to the company through an unsecured line of credit, Xerox said. Through its third-party financing operations, Xerox also has $200 million in collateral loans and other secured financing arrangements with VMS. Xerox said it was writing down the investments after evaluating the holdings VMS has left to resolve its financial difficulties. Xerox said it would release its first quarter results toward the end of April.

DOC.HEAD: Icahn Says Divided USX Worth 35 Percent More
DOC.TEXT: Carl Icahn said Tuesday his plan to break up USX Corp. into separate energy and steel businesses would be worth a third more than the company's current market value. In a letter to other USX investors, a shareholders committee led by the New York investor estimated the value of the plan at $48 a share, including $39 a share for USX's Marathon Oil Co. subsidiary and $9 a share for its U.S. Steel unit. USX stock closed at $37.12{ Tuesday, up $1.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Icahn claimed his plan would boost shareholder value by 35 percent based on Monday's closing stock price of $35.62{ a share. Icahn, who owns 13.29 percent of USX, or about 34 million shares, has asked the company's 144,000 shareholders to approve a plan to spin off at least 80 percent of U.S. Steel to existing shareholders, with the remaining 20 percent going to new investors. The spinoff company would assume no more than $1.5 billion of the steel division's long-term debt. USX management has opposed the plan, saying it would make Marathon and U.S. Steel more vulnerable to slumps in either the energy or steel industries. USX bought Marathon in the early 1980s as a cushion against cyclical swings in the steel business. USX has said 65 percent of its revenues come from Marathon, while 31 percent come from steel operations. Icahn said in the letter that USX could properly structure the breakup to make it essentially tax-free to the company and its stockholders. The plan would preserve net operating losses of USX, he said. USX Chairman Charles Corry recently told Wall Street analysts that Icahn's plan would cause tax difficulties because the company could lose tax credits resulting from steel losses in the early 1980s. The stockholders will cast non-binding votes on Icahn's proposal May 7 at Marathon Oil's headquarters in Findlay, Ohio. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., is joined on his stockholders committee by TWA Vice Chairman Alfred Kingsley and McDEP Associates Inc. Chairman Kurt Wulff. Icahn said he based the $48-a-share figure on analyses by the committee and by McDEP. USX officials were not immediately available for comment Tuesday night.

DOC.HEAD: Big Stock Bonuses for MCA Film Chief
DOC.TEXT: MCA Inc. film chief Thomas Pollock was given MCA stock worth $5.7 million in 1989 and stock options worth $7.8 million when issued last August, according to proxy material shareholders received this week. Pollock also was paid a base salary of $627,000 last year, bringing his total compensation to more than $14 million. His salary was raised to $850,000 this year. Sidney Sheinberg, president of the Universal City-based movie, TV, music and theme park giant, was issued stock worth $7.2 million last year, and his salary jumps to $900,000 this year from $729,000 in 1989. MCA Chairman Lew Wasserman's salary also jumps to $900,000 from $559,000. The figures were contained in proxy material sent out in advance of the company's annual meeting May 8 in Chicago. Among other things, the material asks shareholders to approve a new stock option plan under which Pollock was given his options. The plan authorizes the issuance of 5 million new shares, 600,000 of which would become available to Pollock at $55 a share over the next five years. He may exercise 20 percent of the options once a year, beginning this July. MCA's stock was trading at $68 a share when they were awarded last August. It has since fallen in value, closing at $50.50 on the New York Stock Exchange Tuesday. At that level, Pollock would lose money by exercising his options. MCA's last stock option plan was approved in 1968 but never exercised. The company said the new plan was needed to provide competitive compensation for MCA executives. That was a reference to outfits like Walt Disney Co., whose Chairman President Frank Wells made $72.4 million on the sale of stock bought through options in 1989. Also in the material, MCA urged a ``no'' vote on a shareholders proposal calling for no more MCA productions such as last year's Martin Scorsese movie, ``The Last Temptation of Christ.'' Some religious groups objected that the movie depicted Jesus as weak, confused and lustful. The supporting statement for the proposal says Jesus is shown as a ``disturbed man who frequents brothels, hallucinates seeing snakes, vows that he always tells lies and acts only as a result of fear, says that he sins a lot and asks forgiveness from a prostitute, and feels tormented by God.'' The proposal, made by Dean Shahinian of Alexandria, Va., calls for all shareholders to censure MCA for ``anti-Christian effects.'' ``We urge management to establish a corporate policy not to use corporate assets to falsely defame Jesus Christ or other major religious leaders,'' it says. In opposing the proposal, MCA said censoring a film because it contains an unconventional religious viewpoint could stifle religious and creative expression. Noting that Scorsese won a best director Oscar nomination for ``Temptation,'' MCA said the film was Scorsese's interpretation of a novel, not the company's view of Christ. ``The democratic way is to discuss, to debate,'' MCA said.

DOC.HEAD: United Pays $77.5 Million To Settle Reservations Complaints
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines agreed to pay $77.5 million to settle lawsuits filed by Continental Airlines and others accusing United of unfair competition in the computerized reservations business, according to documents made public Tuesday. United, a subsidiary of Chicago-based UAL Corp., revealed the amount of the settlement in its annual report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The settlement was reported last week by Continental but the amount wasn't disclosed. United spokeswoman Sara Dornacker said she could not comment on the settlement beyond what was contained in the SEC filing. In the filing, United said the settlement concluded three cases that were initiated from Sept. 1985 to March 1989 by Continental, New York Air Inc., Frontier Airlines and System One, a computerized reservations system operated by Continental's parent company, Texas Air Corp. The plaintiffs contended United illegally monopolized or attempted to monopolize the computer reservations business or the air transportation business in various markets. The settlement was reached last Wednesday, shortly before the beginning of jury deliberations in a 10-week trial of Continental's lawsuit in federal court. Continental had sought $336 million in damages, claiming United programmed its computer reservations system to unfairly favor United flights over its competitors. Continental also accused United of overcharging it and other carriers for the reservation service. Last year, American Airlines settled similar allegations by Continental for a reported $100 million. United prevailed last December in a similar suit filed in 1984 on behalf of 11 other airlines, including USAir. An appeal in that case is pending.

DOC.HEAD: Schering-Plough Announces Pending Sale of Maybelline Cosmetics Subsidiary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Chicogo GmbH in 4th graf cq
DOC.TEXT: Schering-Plough Corp. said it has agreed to sell its Maybelline cosmetics business for about $300 million in cash as part of its plan to concentrate on pharmaceuticals. The buyer is MBP Acquisition Corp., which consists of Playtex Family Products, members of Playtex and Maybelline management, the private investment firm of Thomas H. Lee Co. and certain of the Boston firm's affiliated investment funds, Schering-Plough said Tuesday. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets assisted Schering-Plough in the transaction, which requires government approval. The sale stems from Schering-Plough's decision to concentrate on prescription and over-the-counter drugs as well as personal care and vision care products, said Robert P. Luciano, chairman and chief executive officer of Schering-Plough. In July, Schering-Plough sold its two European cosmetics companies, Rimmel International Ltd. and Chicogo GmbH. Last December, the company announced it was seeking offers for Maybelline. In 1989, Schering-Plough recorded total cosmetics sales of about $300 million, most of which were generated by Maybelline, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: China to Build More MD-80s
DOC.TEXT: The Chinese government has approved the production of an additional 20 McDonnell Douglas MD-80 jetliners by Shanghai Aviation Industrial Corp., Douglas Aircraft Co. announced Tuesday. The agreement brings China's total orders for the MD-80 to 50 and continues co-production of the aircraft in China into 1994. The aircraft are built from subassemblies and components shipped from Long Beach by Douglas Aircraft. The orginal contract, signed by the two parties in 1985, covered production of 25 MD-80s through 1991. Twelve of those have been delivered to China's airlines.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Share Prices Higher in Tokyo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: Share prices rose on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday morning while the dollar was firm against the yen and interest rates rose. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average gained 212.05 points, or 0.74 percent, ending the morning session at 28,971.77. The dollar was changing hands at 159.32 yen late in the morning, off from 159.62 yen at the opening but up from Tuesday's close of 158.95 yen. The U.S. currency ranged between 159.28 yen and 159.70 yen during the morning. The price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds slipped to 86.21 points late in the morning from Tuesday's close of 86.51. That boosted its yield to 7.311 percent from 7.245 percent. Currency trading was calm in Tokyo, where the dollar's higher opening followed overnight gains in New York, dealers said. A dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, who requested anonymity, said the dollar gained in New York because of renewed speculation the U.S. Federal Reserve has been halting its support for the yen in an attempt to pressure Japan to make trade concessions in talks being held in Washington. ``The rumor has been in the market for some time, and it was brought up again in New York. Such speculation has been already factored into the market here,'' the dealer said. Another Bank of Tokyo dealer said the Group of Seven (G-7) industrialized nations may take some measures to defend the yen against the dollar when monetary authorities meet in Paris on Saturday. Other dealers said bullish sentiment toward the dollar remained unchanged with no new market-affecting news. Stability in the currency market contributed to the increase in the Nikkei index, said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a stock trader with Daiwa Securities Co. ``Reassured by the yen's stability in the last couple of days, stock investors continued to buy today following yesterday's gains,'' he added. On Tuesday, the index rose 757.65 points, following Monday's crash of 1,978.38 points, or 6.59 percent, its second-largest single-day decline. The plunge followed a 1,045.71-point fall in the index last Friday. As of Tuesday's closing, the Nikkei index had lost more than 10,000 points, or 26 percent, since the beginning of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors to Decide Fair Competition in Dallas Newspaper War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with opening statements; picks up 3rd graf, `At issue ...' SUBS 6th graf, `The trial ...' to UPDATE with testimony to begin Wednesday. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Dallas' two newspapers went to court Tuesday in a fight over syndicated comic strips and columns, the latest twist in a bitter competition between the two dailies that cover the nation's eighth largest city. The Dallas Times Herald is seeking at least $33 million in actual damages for what it considers a grab for monopoly by The Dallas Morning News and its parent, A.H. Belo Corp. The purchase of the syndicated features ``is not something done in an open competitive way,'' Times Herald attorney Frank Jones told jurors during opening statements. ``We think it was done in a way to destroy newspaper competition in Dallas, Texas. We think this is a case of preserving competition of newspapers in Dallas County. ``We think the evidence will show total arrogance and disregard by The Dallas Morning News,'' Jones said. Lawyers for The Morning News countered that the paper was just competing and was willing to pay more for the contested features. ``The only thing is, we went out and competed with them for these features and paid a better price,'' said Harry Reasoner, an attorney for Belo. ``Did we go out and pay a better price? You betcha. Did we tortiously interfere and violate the law? No.'' At issue is a joint venture Belo formed last year with Universal Press Syndicate Inc. to develop syndicate features for television use. Part of their agreement was that Universal Press invoke a clause in its contract with the Times Herald allowing it to break off service. The Times Herald lost 26 features distributed by Universal Press, including Dear Abby, Erma Bombeck and Doonesbury. The Times Herald contends the deal violates anti-trust laws. The Morning News maintains it's just fair competition. Testimony was scheduled to begin Wednesday and the trial is expected to last more than a month. In addition to actual damages, the Times Herald is seeking unspecified punitive damages from its larger rival. Times Herald attorney Wayne Fisher told prospective jurors that anti-competitive practices in the Dallas media market threatened to drive the Times Herald out of business and could inflate the value of The Morning News by as much as $500 million. The Morning News attracts about 60 percent of newspaper advertising and circulation in Dallas, court documents show. ``It's important to see if The Dallas Morning News can get away with the conduct they've been getting away with over the past year,'' Fisher said. ``If they do, the dangerous possibility is the Dallas Times Herald will not survive or The Dallas Morning News may get what the law calls monopoly power.'' ``What the Times Herald is telling you is they would not like The Morning News to compete for these features,'' countered William Sims, an attorney for The Morning News. ``They don't want to up the ante, and that's not what competition is all about. We have the right to compete for these features.'' The lawsuit is the latest legal salvo in the papers' prolonged battle, which in the past focused on challenging circulation features. As a result of the Universal Belo joint venture, the Times Herald also is asking the Federal Communications Commission to revoke the license of Belo's WFAA-TV, the top-rated television station in Dallas.
